HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Declines Against Yen On Harder U.S. Trade Stand

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar tumbled against the Japanese yen in late trading yesterday after a senior American official warned that Washington would use its own trade laws to force Japan to open its markets if negotiations with Tokyo failed to produce results.
The remarks by the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, contrasted with his softer comments on Monday and with the progress to reopen the long-stalled American-Japanese trade talks. 
 Both nations agreed yesterday to widen trans-Pacific trade talks to include the financial-services sector and reopened the negotiations later in the day.
In an interview published yesterday in The New York Times, Mr. Kantor said the Clinton Administration would not wait for all trade issues with Japan to be settled in a so-called framework or package deal.
"When you are ready to reach agreement on a particular sector," Mr. Kantor said in the interview, "you should go ahead and finalize that and continue to move forward on the other areas."
 
Isn't 'Going Soft'
 But yesterday afternoon, Mr. Kantor, speaking in Paris, said: "Our goals and strategies have not changed. We will open the Japanese markets either through the framework or through U.S. trade laws."
He added, "One thing I have never been accused of is going soft."
 The remarks spurred fears that the Administration might eventually pursue a stronger yen as a means of curbing the United States' $60 billion trade deficit with Japan if trade talks fail again.
"With the tone of these comments being more aggressive than recent statements, this provided the perfect excuse to sell the dollar," said Bill Arnold, chief dealer and vice president at the Chemical Bank in New York.
After trading in a narrow range most of the day, the dollar fell to 104.17 yen in late New York trading, from 105.29 yen on Monday.
The dollar had fallen sharply against the yen after trade talks collapsed in February. But this week Mr. Kantor signaled a softening of the American stance that had encouraged dollar buyers -- until yesterday, that is.
"If Kantor is resorting to these terror tactics against Japan, it probably means things aren't getting done and the market should not be too long dollars right now," said Randolph Donney at Pegasus Econometrics in New York.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Dell Computer Closes Out Bad Investments

BYLINE: By KATHRYN JONES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DALLAS, June 7

 BODY:
Continuing to shore up its financial position, the Dell Computer Corporation said today that it had closed out some bad financial investments that had forced the company to take a charge in the first fiscal quarter and would require a charge in the second quarter.
The personal computer company, based in Austin, Tex., had announced its strategy to get out of the investments last month when it released its first-quarter earnings, which were surprisingly strong despite a charge of $26.3 million for losses related to the investments. 
 Dell, like some other companies, had invested in interest-rate derivatives, betting that interest rates would hold steady or fall. When interest rates rose, Dell lost money and took a charge of $15.6 million in the quarter on the derivatives. The value of derivatives is derived from underlying securities like stocks, bonds or currency.
Dell also took a charge of $10.7 million for losses on other investments in the first quarter that ended on May 1.
Thomas J. Meredith, the chief financial officer of Dell, said the company had gotten out of the remainder of its derivative investments and short-term investments with exposure to the principal. The company has said that closing such investments is expected to result in an after-tax charge of about $6.9 million in the second quarter, which ends on July 31.
 
Credit Changes Planned
 Shares of Dell rose 62.5 cents, to $28.25, in Nasdaq trading today.
Mr. Meredith, speaking at a technology investors' conference in New York, also said Dell expected to restructure and expand a revolving credit arrangement with a group of banks led by Citibank to $90 million, from $75 million. The company also said it was renewing an asset securitization program -- a financial instrument that allows assets to be used as collateral against borrowings -- with Barclays Bank P.L.C.
Dell had cash and lines of credit of about $487 million at the end of its first quarter.
The latest actions, coming on the heels of a good first quarter during which Dell's gross profit margins rose, showed that the company had made substantial progress in improving its operations, said Antoine Tristani, an analyst with the Southcoast Capital Corporation in Austin.
"Everything is finally coming together for them," Mr. Tristani said. He said Dell had a strong balance sheet for a company of its size and expected the company to introduce its redesigned notebook computers during the second quarter.
"The key issue for the company is revenue growth," he said, noting that revenues had been stalled for the last three quarters. "They're in the best position now to get revenues going than they have been in a long time."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "A History of Hedging"
 
1992: In November, an analyst suggested that Dell had accounted improperly for speculative foreign-currency trades. The Securities and Exchange Commission began an investigation.

1994: In April, Dell said it expected losses from derivatives. In May, Dell took a $15.6 million charge for losses onderivatives and a $10.7 million charge on other investment losses but still reported higher-than-expected earnings. Yesterday, Dell announced plans for a $6.9 million charge in the current quarter to close out its position in derivatives.

HEADLINE: U.S. Backs Bid To Press Peace On Bosnia Foes

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 8

 BODY:
The United States has decided to support a European strategy for ending the war in Bosnia that envisions possible punitive steps against either warring party that does not accept an emerging peace plan, senior American and French officials said today.
President Clinton told the French Prime Minister, Edouard Balladur, in a meeting on Tuesday that it was important for American, Western European and Russian negotiators to work as one to complete a map dividing the country, present it to the Bosnian Serbs and the Muslim-Croatian federation based in Sarajevo, and make clear that there would be consequences if either side rejected it, the officials said. 
 In particular, Mr. Clinton said the Americans and the Europeans would have to consider suspending the stringent economic sanctions against Yugoslavia, which supports the Bosnian Serbs, if the Sarajevo Government rejected the plan and the Serbs accepted it.
Until recent months, the Clinton Administration insisted that it had no intention of producing a map for Bosnia. But Clinton aides said that in meetings with French officials on Tuesday, the President said the United States would work to refine a map that gives the Muslim-Croatian federation 51 percent and the Bosnian Serbs 49 percent of the country's territory.
Both factions reject the 51-49 split. The Bosnian Serbs, who would have to give up nearly a third of their captured territory under the plan, say it is too much. The Government in Sarajevo, strengthened militarily by the recent federation with the Bosnian Croats, is insisting on 58 percent.
The American embrace of the European position, which was hinted at publicly both in Mr. Clinton's speech to the French National Assembly on Tuesday and in subsequent news briefings by senior Administration officials, reflects a subtle shift by the Administration.
Publicly, the Administration has vowed not to impose a peace settlement on the Sarajevo Government, which American officials at times have called the "aggrieved party." That is still the formal American position, as a senior Administration official briefing reporters on Tuesday said more than once.
But in the last few weeks, as the United States has become directly involved in hammering out a detailed peace settlement in a "contact group" with Western European and Russian representatives, it has had to face the issue of what to do if the parties do not agree and if the French and other nations with troops in the Balkans carry out their threats to withdraw them.
In his speech on Tuesday, Mr. Clinton pointed out that the group "is working on a map, which can be the basis of a full and final cessation of hostilities," adding, "We must do all we can to get both sides to embrace it."
 
Clinton Presents Strategy
 Although Charles Redman, the Administration's special envoy on Bosnia, has offered proposals for a map and has discussed various scenarios in the contact group, what was significant for the French was that Mr. Clinton himself came to Paris and presented them with what they described as a pragmatic, workable strategy for resolving the Bosnia crisis.
"Clinton presented us with a much, much clearer picture, much more realistic, than we have ever received from the Administration," said a senior French official, who only months before had excoriated the Americans as unhelpful. "He really seemed to fully comprehend our concerns."
Mr. Clinton's meeting with Mr. Balladur, and a subsequent meeting with President Francois Mitterrand, offered a clear sign that Washington is now willing to put more pressure on the Serbs and the Bosnian Government to make peace.
What particularly struck Mr. Balladur and his aides, French officials said, was that it was Mr. Clinton who brought up the issue of a possible lifting of the sanctions, a idea that had been repeatedly broached by the Europeans and steadfastly refused by the United States.
"The President did discuss what type of consequences would arise under different scenarios," a senior Administration official said. "There would be particular consequences if either the Serbs or the Muslims refused or delayed an agreement."
 
Issue of Ending Sanctions
 The official cautioned, however, that the Administration did not believe that the Serbs would accept the plan and the Bosnians reject it. Even if that were to happen, he said, "lifting the sanctions is still an issue that is not settled."
Since last November, the Europeans have promoted a plan that includes rewarding the Serbs with a progressive lifting of the sanctions if they moved toward peace, a position the Americans have never endorsed.
The emerging American position coincides with an agreement by Bosnia's warring factions in Geneva today to end the fighting for a month so the United Nations can work out a more durable truce. The length of the cease-fire was a concession to the Bosnian Government, which has argued that the four-month cease-fire favored by the Serbs would allow them to solidify their territorial gains.
But a senior Administration official traveling with Secretary of State Warren Christopher from Paris to Istanbul, where he will be attending NATO meetings, played down the importance of the cease-fire. "Cessation of hostilities is not the answer to war," he said. "The answer to war is a negotiated settlement."
The official characterized the United Nations cease-fire in Geneva as "yet to really take off." By contrast, he described the negotiations under a joint American, Western European and Russian initiative as a more substantial effort that has been "moving right along."
Mr. Clinton assured the French that he had no intention of violating a United Nations-mandated arms embargo and unilaterally arming the Bosnian Muslims. But he described the pressure from Congress to lift the embargo, saying that if there were no peace agreement by the fall, he expected that the House of Representatives would follow the lead of the Senate and pass a resolution endorsing such a move.

HEADLINE: O.E.C.D., Seeking Wider Membership, Signs Russian Pact

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PARIS, June 8

 BODY:
Signaling that it is no longer an exclusive club of rich nations, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development signed its first cooperation agreement with Russia today and declared itself ready to welcome new members from Eastern Europe and Asia.
The 25-nation organization, which monitors and analyzes the economic performance of industrialized countries, said it would talk with Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic and Slovakia about membership and expected an application from South Korea. 
 In a further break with its past, the O.E.C.D. said it would also seek a dialogue with China, which, it noted, "has become in many respects a leading player in the world economy." Only free market democracies are allowed to join, but experts believe the organization could sign a cooperation agreement with China.
 
Advocating Broader Role
 Opening the Paris-based organization to broader membership has the strong backing of the United States, which argues that the O.E.C.D. can not only stabilize Europe following the end of the cold war but also bridge the industrialized world and the fast-growing economies of Asia.
"The United States sees a broader role for the O.E.C.D. and also encourages its reform," Secretary of State Warren Christopher said today. "The community of market democracies is not a closed club. It is open to open societies. It is open to open markets. It is open to freedom everywhere."
In addressing the group's annual ministerial meeting, Mr. Christopher gave priority to completing "the unfinished business of postwar reconstruction" in Eastern Europe. "Europe must not be split into zones of prosperity and poverty, stability and insecurity," he said.
Mr. Christopher called Russia's integration with the West "the best investment we can make in our security." He hailed today's cooperation agreement, which will let the O.E.C.D. provide Moscow with Western expertise on legal, structural and statistical reforms.
Russia's Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, who signed the accord, welcomed it as "a real step forward in the future integration of our country into the world economy." He said Russia could profit from advice on economic laws, foreign investment rules, banking and privatization of state enterprises.
 
Revising Its Mission
 The decision to become more international is a turning point for the O.E.C.D., which emerged from an organization created in 1948 to help enact the Marshall Plan. Until now, it has functioned as a low-profile "think tank" that devoted much time to economic studies for its member states.
In a statement today, ministers agreed to start negotiating membership status for Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic and Slovakia. "I think we're talking in terms of 15 to 18 months," said Canada's External Affairs Minister, Andre Ouellet.
Japan, which is the only Asian O.E.C.D. member, also favored negotiations to admit South Korea to the group in 1996. Japan's envoy, Nomuo Matsunaga, told today's meeting that "the O.E.C.D. should also commence a dialogue with China."
But Ireland's Foreign Minister, Dick Spring, said China's human rights record would influence the extent of the organization's contacts with Beijing.
Sir Leon Brittan, the European Union's trade commissioner, warned against expanding too quickly. "We must not so widen our membership that our work becomes shallow," he said.
The O.E.C.D. is also under pressure to diversify its work. On Tuesday, it offered policy recommendations to reduce unemployment in the industrialized world. It has now been asked to study the impact of trade on labor, investment and the environment.

HEADLINE: Legacy of '93 Flood: Sand, Sand and More Sand

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTSBURG, Mo., June 3

 BODY:
First came the flood, which tore nearly 500 holes in the farm levees along the Missouri River last year and drowned $150 million in crops.
Now the water is gone, but the rampaging river left even greater trouble: millions of tons of sand that have transformed miles of fertile bottom land into a desert landscape of blowing grit and shifting dunes, in some places five feet deep. 
 Nowhere in the Midwest was the agricultural damage from the 1993 flood as extensive as it was here in Hartsburg and the other farm villages that hug the Missouri River. The Soil Conservation Service, a unit of the Federal Department of Agriculture, estimates that of the 945,000 acres on the Missouri River flood plain, 455,000 were damaged by sand scoured from the bottom of the river and erosion.
Reclaiming the flood plain, for generations Missouri's most productive farmland, could cost $500 million, the Soil Conservation Service said. Perhaps 200,000 acres have been permanently ruined by sand.
"It's an awful mess," said Orion Beckmeyer, who before the flood last summer grew corn and soybeans with his brother, Glen, on their 900-acre farm here on the Hartsburg bottom along the Missouri River.
The brothers estimate that perhaps 100 acres are beyond help, and as Orion Beckmeyer climbs into the cab of his four-wheel-drive tractor, he scowls at a landscape of water, sky and sand so foreign it could pass for the New Jersey shore.
"The good thing is that the flood brought this community together," he said. "The bad thing is that we got years of work putting this place back together. No matter what we do, the land will never be as good as it was."
While luckier neighbors nurse along the corn and soybeans they planted on undamaged land, this will be the second successive year that the Beckmeyers will not harvest a crop. Nor are they alone. Along the 498 miles of the Missouri River that runs through this state, hundreds of farmers are trying to reclaim sand-covered land by turning over their fields with immense plows. They hope to mix the sand on top with more fertile dirt that lies beneath it, giving their ground enough organic matter to support a crop next year.
But when the sand is more than two feet deep, plowing is useless, said Russell C. Mills, the director of the Soil Conservation Service in Missouri. "In a lot of places out there we have sand five feet deep," Mr. Mills said. "The river turned the best farmland in the world into a giant sandbox."
The extent of the damage surprised farmers in the flood plain. But the possibility of such devastation had been anticipated for decades by Government hydrologists and engineers, Mr. Mills said.
The Missouri River, called "The Big Muddy" by people around here, naturally carries five times the amount of sediment as the Mississippi River above Cairo, Ill. The Missouri River also falls swiftly, twice as fast as the Mississippi.
Hemming in such a river with dikes and levees, as most hydrologists are quick to point out, invites trouble during flooding. The high walls increase the depth of the water, concentrate the river's energy, and accelerate the current. In a river like the Missouri, fast water scours the bottom, digging beneath the rich layer of dirt that usually lies there and churning up sand instead. Anywhere along the way that is flat will cause the river to slow down and the sand will drop out.
In 1944, as the United States began to invest heavily in flood-control structures on the Missouri, Congress anticipated problems. In the plan that they approved that year, the lawmakers proposed to build Federal levees 1,500 to 2,500 feet back from both banks of the Missouri.
The idea was to give the river up to a mile of open space in high water, thereby dispersing the energy of floods across a larger area, particularly around river bends where the damage is generally most severe. By designing a system of farm levees that gave the river room, Congress sought to reduce the velocity of the water and limit the amount of sand that would be scoured from the bottom and deposited on farm fields.
But the proposal was rejected by farmers, many of whom had already built their own levees right on the Missouri's banks, and were loath to move them. Over the years, those levees were built higher and stronger by farmers and the United States Army Corps of Engineers. By 1993, the Missouri River was essentially a huge, man-made channel.
Last summer during the flood, the Missouri ripped the levee system apart with a vengeance that still leaves farmers and agricultural officials awestruck.
 
Wrath of the River
 What occurred here on the Hartsburg bottom was typical. The river blasted several openings in the levee and at each one poured through with the same violence as if a dam had collapsed. At the biggest break, the gushing water scoured a gaping hole in Mr. Beckmeyer's field that was 70 feet deep across 40 acres. Vietnam veterans here say bombs from B-52's did not cause such large craters.
As the water poured onto the bottomland, it swirled around three of Mr. Beckmeyer's metal grain bins, causing a whirlpool that dug a 12-foot hole into which the bins fell. They lie now in a toppled heap, as though they were pins hit by a giant bowling ball.
It wasn't until the flood waters had spread well onto the Hartsburg bottom that the current slowed, depositing sand from the holes and the river on Mr. Beckmeyer's fields.
In all, the flood punched 465 holes in the Missouri River's levees, according to an estimate by the University of Missouri's Food and Agriculture Policy Research Institute. The research institute said that 546 million cubic yards of sand ended up on farmers' fields -- enough to create a pile in Central Park 406 feet high, as high as some 30-story buildings.
Last month, in a draft report, a committee of Federal experts convened by the White House discussed at length the damage along the Missouri River. The committee recommended that the Government seriously consider reviving the 50-year-old Congressional plan for giving the Missouri River more space. "The flood of 1993 demonstrated the need for some form of floodway to provide greater capacity to convey flood flows," the committee said.
Environmentalists in Missouri and in Washington support such a change in policy because it would reduce economic losses in floods and restore some of the river's natural systems.
But the recommendation has produced nothing but catcalls from farmers and has all but been ignored by the Clinton Administration. Last year, the White House and Congress approved legislation that provided over $300 million to repair levees across the Upper Mississippi River basin. Although work along the Missouri has proceeded at a slower pace than along the Mississippi River, the Army Corps of Engineers and other Federal agencies overseeing the repairs say they have no plans to halt contracts or move levees back.
The reason is the same in 1994 as it was in 1944. Farmers, who hold considerable political power in Missouri, want to protect their land from any flooding, and levees built directly on the banks, they say, are the best way to do it. Never before, they added, had the river done as much damage as it did in 1993 and they are willing to take the chance that a comparable flood will not occur for decades.
This week, after months of delay, the Army Corps of Engineers approved the final contract to repair the Hartsburg levee surrounding the Beckmeyers' farm. "I'd heard that because of this new report, maybe the Government was having second thoughts about fixing the levee," Orion Beckmeyer said. "It's taken a long time to get the work finished. But when they let that contract, we all felt a little better."

HEADLINE: U.S. Shifts Stress to Haiti Sanctions

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 8

 BODY:
Encountering more opposition than it expected on military intervention in Haiti, the Clinton Administration sought today to signal a shift in its policy by voicing a new confidence that economic sanctions would succeed in ousting the Haitian military leaders.
In separate appearances, both Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott and William H. Gray 3d, President Clinton's special adviser on Haiti, played down the prospects of military intervention while trying to bolster the notion that sanctions would work, even though they have failed to budge Haiti's military for more than a year. 
 Both officials said a surge in cooperation from other countries had finally created an effective embargo that they said should be given some time to squeeze the Haitian military and their wealthy supporters.
And Mr. Gray suggested that the United States and several other countries planned to tighten the sanctions even further this month, to ban all commercial air traffic and financial transactions between Haiti and other countries.
 
'Higher Degree of Confidence'
 "Not only are we committed to exhausting all political, diplomatic and economic instruments available to us to achieve a peaceful multilateral solution to this problem, but as a result of what's happened in recent days we have an even higher degree of confidence that that is indeed possible and it certainly is our hope," Mr. Talbott said at a news briefing, referring to recent talks in which Latin American and Caribbean allies have backed tougher sanctions.
One Administration official said the increased emphasis on sanctions and the decreased emphasis on intervention was "a tactical shift."
Part of that shift results from the Administration's encountering far more opposition to its talk of military intervention than it had expected -- in Congress, among the American public and among other countries.
And part of the shift results from the Administration's new-found belief that tougher sanctions just might work, especially now that the Dominican Republic, the only country that borders Haiti, has pledged to crack down on smuggling.
Testifying before the House Foreign Affairs Committee, Mr. Gray said the new, tougher sanctions would increase the Administration's chances of pressing Haiti's military to cede power.
To turn up the pressure on the Haitian military's rich supporters further, he said, the United States and other countries are looking into denying visas to wealthy Haitians who support the military as well as freezing their assets.
"I have confidence that the sanctions can create an environment where people come to their senses," Mr. Gray said, noting that business supporters of Haiti's military are rethinking their allegiance. "We have a responsibility to try every arrow in the diplomatic quiver to make sure the coup leaders step down."
Mr. Gray and Mr. Talbott in no way ruled out the use of military force, saying repeatedly that the United States had important national interests at stake in restoring democracy to Haiti. But Mr. Gray said no United States invasion was imminent.
Mr. Talbott indicated that the Administration would not wait forever for the sanctions to work. "We do feel a sense of some urgency here, for the very simple reason that people are dying," he said.
Administration officials acknowledge that with all their talk about the urgent need to oust Haiti's military leaders quickly and about perhaps using force to do so, the Administration runs the risk of being criticized for backing off if it does not invade Haiti within weeks.
Sanctions, mainly on oil and weapons, have been in effect on and off for more than a year, but the Haitian military seems no closer to stepping down. Although Administration officials boasted early this year that the embargo represented the toughest sanctions ever enforced in the Western Hemisphere, Mr. Gray dismissed those sanctions as porous and piecemeal.
On May 21, new United Nations sanctions took effect that ban all trade with Haiti except for food and medicine.

Haitians Confront U.N.
 PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, June 8 (AP) -- Police and armed civilians stopped two cars carrying United Nations observers Tuesday night, smashed their radios and seized a handgun, United Nations officials said today. It was one of the worst confrontations since the observers arrived in 1991.
The chief of the United Nations human rights observer mission in Haiti protested to the commander of the Haitian armed forces, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras.
Hours before the incident, the army-installed government threatened to arrest Prime Minister Robert Malval, who was appointed last year by Haiti's exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
Mr. Malval had said that Haitians would be more likely to support American troops than their own military if the United States invaded.
Shouting epithets against international observers, about 20 armed Haitians stopped a United Nations vehicle carrying two security officers on the road from Petionville to Port-au-Prince, said Eric Falt, a United Nations spokesman.
Another vehicle carrying Haitian employees of the United Nations was stopped minutes later. The armed men seized one weapon and three portable walkie-talkies and destroyed two radio phones, Mr. Falt said, adding that United Nations personnel were not harmed.

HEADLINE: After Humdrum Primary, California Candidates Gird for Tough, Costly Races

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 8

 BODY:
The 1994 California races for Governor and the United States Senate got officially under way today after a round of lackluster primary voting on Tuesday that routinely produced the expected nominees.
The fall contests shape up as anything but routine. 
 In the primaries for governor, Republicans renominated Gov. Pete Wilson and Democrats chose Treasurer Kathleen Brown, setting up what promises to be a hard-fought contest.
Ms. Brown, a 48-year-old moderate liberal, is the third member of the Brown political dynasty to seek the California governorship. Her father, Edmund G. (Pat) Brown, served from 1959 to 1967, and her brother, Edmund G. Brown Jr., served from 1975 to 1983.
Mr. Wilson, a 60-year-old moderate conservative, is an experienced, resourceful campaigner who, like Ms. Brown, is sometimes mentioned as having national ticket potential.
The race, Mr. Wilson vowed this morning at a Republican breakfast, will fought over real issues, "not what your family was."
He is also expected to press the crime issue, betting that Ms. Brown may be vulnerable. California voters now say that crime, not the flagging economy that the Democrats have focused on, is their biggest worry, and Ms. Brown, though she has promised strong measures to fight crime, opposes capital punishment.
In the Senate race, the Democratic nominee is the incumbent, Dianne Feinstein, a 60-year-old moderate liberal, and the Republican candidate is Representative Michael Huffington of Santa Barbara, a 46-year-old moderate conservative.
That contest also shapes up as a close one.
Senator Feinstein is expected to dwell on Mr. Huffington's limited political record and his limited residency in California. He has been active in politics for under three years and has been a resident of California only slightly longer.
"He's a legislative cypher," she said today in the opening shot of her campaign.
Mr. Huffington will probably try to paint Ms. Feinstein as a big-government, big-spending, high-tax liberal. "She's a career politician who never had a private sector job," he scoffed today.
And each has raised questions about whether the other has paid enough income tax over the years.
But ultimately, another kind of money -- campaign money -- may decide the Huffington-Feinstein contest: the race could turn out to be the most expensive Congressional election in history.
Mr. Huffington, whose wealth from family oil investments in Texas has been put at $75 million, spent $6 million to win nomination on Tuesay and vows to spend an additional $10 million, if necessary, to win in November.
Ms. Feinstein, who also has considerable family wealth and, further, is regarded as one of the best political fund-raisers in the country, promises to come up with at least $10 million.
The spending record for a Congressional race is $25.9 million, set in the 1984 Senate race in North Carolina.
From a national perspective, both the Senate race and the governor's race will be watched closely.
 
Presidential Hints
 California is the most populous and politically powerful state, so what happens here in November will hint at Presidential prospects in 1996. Further, the outcome of the Huffington-Feinstein race will help determine whether Democrats retain control of the Senate and whether the small contingent of women in that body shrinks. Republicans would need to wrest seven seats from Democrats to take over the Senate.
Political analysts and polltakers say the crucial accomplishment this fall for the nominees in both the races for governor and the Senate will be to win back party members who favored some other candidate on Tuesday.
While none of the four nominees were seriously challenged in the primaries -- the results seemed so preordained that only about 40 percent of registered voters turned out -- the balloting did produce evidence of soft support for some candidates. So for the fall contest, the timeless political work of protecting and strengthening support will be crucial.
 
Halfhearted Unity
 Those efforts got under way first thing this morning, though hardly smoothly for Mr. Wilson.
At a Republican unity breakfast here, the Governor called for "a very unified party." But the Governor's primary opponent, Ron Unz, a right-leaning computer millionaire, avoided a direct endorsement of the man who beat him with 62 percent of the vote, offering instead general support for Republican candidates who espouse "party principles and policies."
The unity pitch went better for Ms. Brown during a press conference at which she was joined by other Democrats who won nomination on Tuesday. One after another they rose to offer their support to her effort to unseat what she called "the Rip Van Wilson Administration, which wakes up once ever four years, just in time for an election."
Ms. Brown came out of the Tuesday primary with comfortable double-digit leads over two opponents, Insurance Commissioner John Garamendi and State Senator Tom Hayden.
Still, Mr. Wilson could take more comfort from the results of a Los Angeles Times survey in which voters were questioned as they left the polls on Tuesday. Almost 50 percent of the Republicans who chose Mr. Unz said they would be back with Mr. Wilson come November. Less that 20 percent said they would vote for Ms. Brown.
Of Democratic voters, roughly a third of those who voted either for Mr. Garamendi or Mr. Hayden said they would go with Ms. Brown in the fall. But another third said they would vote for Mr. Wilson.
In the Senate primaries, surveys of voters leaving the polls found support for Ms. Feinstein and for Mr. Huffington to be about equally solid, with both assured of getting the votes of two of every three members of their respective parties in the fall.
Ms. Feinstein faced no serious opposition in the Democratic primary.
Mr. Huffington handily defeated his one major opponent, former Representative William E. Dannemeyer of Orange County.
There were several other notable political developments in the Tuesday balloting.
In the Democratic contest for the nomination to run for secretary of state, the Acting Secretary, Tony Miller, defeated Assemblywoman Gwen Moore of Los Angeles and Michael Woo, a former Los Angeles councilman and mayoral candidate. Should Mr. Miller win in November, when his Republican opponent will be Assemblyman Bill Jones of Fresno, he would be the first openly gay candidate elected to statewide office in California.
In the race for the Democratic nomination for treasurer, a former state Democratic party chairman, Phil Angelides, defeated the former president pro tem of the State Senate, David Roberti, who had earlier fended off a recall effort led by members of the National Rifle Association.
Mr. Roberti, author of several gun control bills, ran out of money in the treasurer's race, having used up much of his financing in the earlier fight against the recall.
And in Palm Springs, the former mayor, the entertainer Sonny Bono, won the Republican nomination for Congress. His Democratic opponent will be Assemblyman Steve Clute.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
HOTEL IS SEIZED IN DRUG-LAW TAKEOVER
Federal authorities seized the Kenmore Hotel, a filthy, dilapidated residential hotel near Gramercy Park, saying that drug dealers used it to operate "a virtual supermarket for crack cocaine." The owner, prosecutors said, did nothing about it. A1.
If ghosts roam the Kenmore, they bear names like Dashiell Hammett and Stephen Crane. B3.
 

MAYOR FACES QUANDARY IN AID WINDFALL
New York City has received an unexpected windfall of at least $85 million in new aid from Albany and Washington. But rather than soothing the city's budget fight, the money has created a political quandary for Mayor Giuliani, who has pledged all along to spend less money, not more. A1.

HEADLINE: MTV Worker Dismissed Over Cuba Concert

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, June 8

 BODY:
After complaints by the leading Cuban exile group, the fledgling Spanish-language network of MTV has dismissed an employee here who was helping to organize a private tour to Havana for a concert by a Cuban singer.
The employee, Maria Romeu, an assistant to the managing director of MTV Latino, was dismissed on Monday, five days after an official of the Cuban American National Foundation called the network. The network said the group had complained that material promoting the Havana trip, in which MTV Latino is not involved, had been faxed from the network's corporate offices here. 
 The exile group contends that travel to Cuba is immoral and violates the economic embargo against Cuba that has been American policy for three decades.
A spokesman for MTV Latino, Nelson Benedico, said Ms. Romeu "was terminated for one very simple reason, which was that she used the company name and resources for a personal matter."
A letter of dismissal sent to Ms. Romeu this week also accused her of "jeopardizing the company's image" by creating the impression that MTV Latino, which began playing music videos in Spanish and English in October, was involved in "highly sensitive and political activities."
 
Questions of 'Public Image'
 "Clearly, this has called into question the company's reputation and public image in the community of Miami," said the letter, dated June 6 by the network's personnel director. "In addition, there are potential ramifications and consequences that have placed the company at risk at our corporate level."
Mr. Benedico said he was not sure what the letter meant by a "risk" to MTV Latino, and the personnel director referred all inquiries to Mr. Benedico. But Mr. Benedico said it would be "absolutely ludicrous to suggest that we were worried about bomb threats" or advertisers' boycotting the network, two tactics that have often been employed against those who run afoul of exile groups here.
Ms. Romeu said, however, that MTV Latino officials had been unhappy that the network was carried on only one cable television system in the Miami area, which has the most affluent Hispanic population in the United States.
The network recently began playing music by the Cuban singer Carlos Varela, whose concert in August in Havanna was the focal point of the tour Ms. Romeu was organizing. She said that MTV Latino "deliberated for six weeks" over whether to use the video because of concern about possibly violating the Trading With the Enemy Act or alienating powerful Cuban exiles here.
 
Coup Becomes Morass
 The network, which cultivates the same hip image as its English-language counterpart, appeared to have achieved a coup by playing the video shot in Havanna and featuring a performer who is regarded as the voice of Cuba's disgruntled youth. But, as often happens in Miami on all matters Cuban, politics has intruded.
The focal point of the dispute is Mr. Varela, a 31-year-old singer and songwriter who lives in Havana but is admired by some young Cuban-Americans here. In recent years, Mr. Varela has developed a large underground following among Cuba's young people, and has irritated the Communist Party elite that has ruled Cuba for the last 35 years, by writing songs about the country's problems.
MTV Latino, which has an estimated 3.5 million subscribers in Latin America and the United States, has been broadcasting a video of Mr. Varela, "Robinson," since May 23. The song was taken from the compact disk "Coins in the Air," which was released in the United States last year but is still unavailable in Cuba because of its political content. It is a rock parable that includes references to the collapse of the Soviet bloc and suggests parallels between the isolation of Robinson Crusoe and the Cuban nation.
Mr. Benedico said MTV Latino would continue to play the video despite the dispute over Ms. Romeu's involvement in a rare officially sanctioned performance by Mr. Varela that is scheduled for August. But Ninoska Perez, a spokeswoman for the foundation, said her group objected to any effort to portray Mr. Varela as a courageous dissident.
"He is part of the system," she said. "The Cuban government is using Varela to make people think there are changes taking place in Cuba and that you can have internal dissent."

HEADLINE: TOKYO RELUCTANT TO LEVY SANCTIONS ON NORTH KOREANS

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, June 8

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration's plan to impose new global sanctions against North Korea for its defiance of nuclear inspectors has run into strong resistance from Japan, throwing into question the effort to impose strict financial sanctions against the Communist Government.
The Japanese, concerned about North Korea's reaction, are balking at a quick cutoff of the hundreds of millions of dollars that Koreans living in Japan send back to relatives in the North. Combined with China's reluctance to exert greater pressure on North Korea, the sharp debate threatens to greatly reduce the pain inflicted on the North. 
 Japan has said it would abide by any sanctions imposed. But in private, officials say, Tokyo has been arguing against Washington's plan, which would set a deadline for North Korea to open its nuclear complex to United Nations inspectors, and halt financial transfers if the North refused to comply. Instead, Japan wants to issue another warning and another vague threat of sanctions.
"We are in agreement on the overall goal of bringing the North Koreans back to the negotiating table," a senior Japanese official said tonight. "But stopping the remittances of funds is a very heavy sanction. Our differences are over the weight of the sanctions and the timing."
The Japanese are worried about North Korea's threat to launch a war against South Korea if sanctions are imposed, as well as possible uprisings or terrorism by the 250,000 Koreans in Japan who have links to the North -- mostly the descendants of Koreans brought to Japan as slave labor during its occupation of the Korean Peninsula from 1910 to 1945.
Japanese officials also fear that a halt in the North's biggest supply of hard currency could trigger widespread suffering among the people.
"We look at the funds differently than the United States does," a senior Japanese official said last week. "They see this money as something that props up the North Korean Government. We see it as largely something from Koreans in Japan who want to help their families."
Though estimates vary greatly, intelligence agencies believe that Koreans in Japan send $600 million to $1.8 billion to North Korea every year, a huge figure in a country whose gross domestic product is only about $20 billion a year.
Intelligence officials say almost all of the money winds up in the Government Treasury or in the pockets of Government officials.
Ever since North Korea began unloading spent fuel rods from its 25-megawatt nuclear reactor last month, yielding a supply of plutonium that could produce four or five nuclear weapons, Washington's coordinator of North Korean policy, Robert L. Gallucci, has sought a United Nations Security Council resolution that would get Pyongyang's attention. Cutting off the financial transfers has been crucial to that strategy.
Japanese officials have said that even if the Security Council votes to block the transfers, they doubt it is possible to stop all of them.
Much of the money is reportedly cash carried by hand by Korean-Japanese with North Korean passports. They visit North Korea via a ship that runs between Niigata, Japan, and North Korea, or by plane through Beijing. A good deal of it originates in the pachinko industry, a game similar to pinball that is a multi-billion-dollar industry.
Japanese authorities say they could impose limits on the cash that individuals could carry abroad. But they argue that it would be virtually impossible to stop money transfers through banks in Hong Kong, Switzerland and elsewhere.
Japan has also argued that lesser sanctions would help bring China aboard. China's Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, was quoted recently in the official China Daily as saying, "Sanctions are not a sensible choice, as they would only aggravate the crisis."
While officials on all sides say the differences are over tactics rather than strategy, the impact on Washington's relations with Japan could be considerable. The United States has supported Japan's bid to become a permanent member of the Security Council, and Tokyo's handling of the crisis is widely regarded as the greatest test of its ability to take a leading role in regional security.
Mishandling the standoff could also bring down the fragile minority Government of Prime Minister Tsutomu Hata. Mr. Hata has reportedly been arguing for a more aggressive stance by Japan, but the opposition Socialist Party, with long and strong links to North Korea, holds the deciding votes when a no-confidence resolution is presented in Parliament, perhaps as soon as this month.
South Korea's President, Kim Young Sam, is now taking a far harder line against the North than at any point in his 16 months in office. Today, at the first meeting of the country's National Security Council since 1991, Mr. Kim made it clear that he would not settle for anything less than a full accounting of what the North has done with its plutonium.
"North Korea's development of nuclear weapons is intended for use not against other countries but against South Korea, and thus their program should be stopped at any cost," the President said. But Government officials here say that "at any cost" does not include a military strike on the North's nuclear facilities.
 
North Seeks Talks With U.S.
 KIEV, Ukraine, June 8 (Special to The New York Times) -- The Foreign Minister of North Korea said today that international inspectors would be allowed to visit its nuclear sites again if the United States resumes negotiations to resolve their differences.
The official, Kim Young Nam, said at a news conference during a three-day visit to Ukraine that if talks were resumed, North Korea would "provide full technical support for the preservation and measurement" of fuel rods removed from a North Korean nuclear reactor.
[The State Department quickly rebuffed the offer, saying the withdrawal of fuel rods had made further inspections moot.]
Last year, the United States and North Korea held two rounds of talks on the nuclear issue. "The problem can only be decided between them," Mr. Kim said.

HEADLINE: Mutual Fund Bailout;
Paine Spends $33 Million to Cover Losses, But the Gesture Proves Troubling to Some

BYLINE: By SUSAN ANTILLA 

 BODY:
Some Wall Street executives were likening it to the arrival of Santa Claus to the securities markets: For the second time this spring, a brokerage firm said it would inject millions of its own money into a mutual fund to rebuild investors' confidence.
Paine Webber Group Inc. said yesterday that it would put $33 million into its popular Short-Term U.S. Government Income Fund, which has attracted $1.7 billion from investors since it was started in 1990. The fund has suffered as a result of losses in the fixed-income market this spring. 
 Now, in part as a reaction to a class-action lawsuit, the brokerage firm will partly cover the losses in its mutual fund and pay the lawyers who represented the investors who sued. [Page D7.]
The question in the financial community yesterday was: Has a socialistic principle invaded the free markets of Wall Street? But that may miss the point. It may be that in the wake of the sharp decline in the bond and stock markets this year, there is a fear among money managers of a loss of investor confidence, especially because a lot of small investors were not aware of the risks that they were taking or were misled about the risks by money managers.
Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said yesterday that he was generally pleased by Paine Webber's action, noting that investors had been shocked to learn that some funds with the soothing word "government" in their titles were not as secure as they sounded.
But he conceded that the movement to repair the damage of markets that had gone bad could backfire. "I don't think it's gone too far yet," he said. "But if the notion were to prevail that it is in the interest of fund managers to subsidize the performance of all funds, that would be very distorting to the market."
Paine Webber's generosity is troubling to believers in a free-market economy in which investors should enjoy the gains and tolerate the pain of a market's ups and downs.
"The danger is that people will expect that if you lose a little money, some Santa Claus is going to step up and make you whole," said William Fitzpatrick, general counsel of the Securities Industry Association. "I think the better thing to do is to educate people that there is risk in the market."
But consumer advocates generally applauded the recent moves in which investors were assisted after having been given the wrong impression about the potential risks of an investment.
"Brokerage firms are seeing that they have commitments to live up to," said Barbara Roper of the Consumer Federation of America.
Earlier this spring, the Piper Jaffray Companies, based in Minneapolis, made the first move to shore up investors' confidence in a mutual fund. It said it would invest at least $10 million in its Institutional Government Income Portfolio Fund, which had dropped by more than $3 a share from a peak of $11.62 in January. Piper also said it would waive the management fees in several other "closed-end" funds that traded on the New York Stock Exchange -- an attempt to offer a small compensation for the losses from this year's volatile fixed-income market.
Mutual funds will feel increasing pressure to put up some extra cash when losses occur, said Arthur Abbey, a New York lawyer who represented a group of investors against Paine Webber. "I think it would be very hard now for a firm that experiences the same thing to take a position different to Paine Webber -- and every firm has one of these things," he said, referring to the short-term government-bond category of mutual funds.
Mr. Levitt said he had heard of "a number of instances in recent weeks and months" in which fund managements had decided to inject money to keep money market mutual funds from falling below $1 a share -- a level at which consumers expect money market funds to consistently trade. Mr. Levitt said fund managements were padding money market funds in this way "more so today than in any time in recent memory."
 
Good Performance, at First
 Indeed, the very securities that had caused Paine Webber's problem appear to have helped the same mutual funds' performance until the crisis in the fixed-income markets in the spring, Wall Street experts pointed out yesterday.
To be sure, Paine Webber's was not a simple case of investors taking a hit because a market had gone haywire. The fund's prospectus said it retained the right to trade in mortgage-backed securities, which are backed by pools or groups of home-mortagage loans, and which hurt the Paine Webber fund and scores of other mutual funds. But the prospectus also said the fund had no immediate plans to exercise that right.
A spokesman for Paine Webber said that while its portfolio manager probably had not broken the letter of the law, the firm had decided to bail investors out because, "We chose to take the high road and say, 'Look, we're not hanging our hats on any legalese.' "
The firm felt that the risks in the fund had not been communicated fairly to investors, who saw it as very safe, the spokesman said.
Mr. Abbey, the class-action lawyer, said the key issue was that the prospectus had not disclosed "the illiquidity of these assets," meaning that investors had not been warned that the mortgage-backed securities market could end up with no buyers.
"It's a liquidity issue more than a disclosure issue," he said, acknowledging that Paine Webber could have pursued a legal battle in which it contended that it had left open the option of buying the mortgage-related securities that ultimately caused such trouble.
Those who worry about the trend to make up investor losses point to many markets that are deemed highly liquid one day only to turn out to have no buyers the next. In October 1987, even the New York Stock Exchange was such a market, as the Dow Jones industrial average plunged more than 500 points.
If precendents are increasingly set by mutual fund complexes to make investors whole when markets turn sour, or when brokers misrepresent products, it could also create an uneven playing field. Large firms like Paine Webber can choose to take multimillion-dollar losses to increase investors' confidence, while less well-heeled funds may not.

HEADLINE: Rifkin Gets Maximum Sentence for Murder

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., June 8

 BODY:
Joel Rifkin, the unemployed landscaper who confessed to killing 17 women, was sentenced today to 25 years to life in prison for murder by a Nassau County Court judge who described Mr. Rifkin's crimes as "brutal and horrific."
Mr. Rifkin, 34, showed no emotion as he stood before Judge Ira H. Wexner, who, in response to a request from the defense, said he would recommend that Mr. Rifkin be given psychiatric care and counseling in prison. 
 Mr. Rifkin was convicted last month of killing Tiffany Bresciani, 22, whose body was found in the back of his pickup truck after he was stopped by the state police for a traffic violation. During questioning, he admitted killing 16 other women, who he said were prostitutes he picked up in Manhattan.
Jurors quickly rejected his claim that he was temporarily insane when he killed Ms. Bresciani.
 
More Charges Await
 Unshaven and wearing a rumpled white shirt, baggy gray pants and brown loafers, Mr. Rifkin shuffled from the courtroom in leg chains and handcuffs. Law-enforcement officials said he would be transferred to the care of state prison officials in Brooklyn until his next court appearance, perhaps Thursday, when a pretrial conference is to be held in Suffolk County Court, where he faces charges in two more killings.
Judge Wexner, in giving Mr. Rifkin the maximum allowable sentence of 25 years to life, told him, "During the entire course of this trial, you never once exhibited any feelings of remorse."
He also sentenced Mr. Rifkin to an additional 2 1/3 years in prison for endangering the lives of the state troopers in the chase before his arrest almost a year ago, on June 28.
Before sentencing, the prosecutor, Fred Klein, said: "Joel Rifkin is, in my opinion, best described as a killing machine. What he did to Tiffany Bresciani was not impulsive. It was very deliberate, premeditated and methodical."
Mr. Klein read a letter in court from Cheryl Bresciani, the victim's mother. Of her daughter's death, Ms. Bresciani wrote: "I live one day at a time. Nothing seems to relieve the agonizing pain."
Cheryl Bresciani was not in the courtroom today, but relatives of three other victims sat quietly, tears welling in their eyes, during the sentencing.
Margarita Gonzalez, the sister of Jenny Soto, 22, who the authorities say was strangled by Mr. Rifkin, said she wanted to thank Tiffany Bresciani.
"Although she was not my sister, I feel for what she went through," Ms. Gonzalez said. "And if it wasn't for her, Joel Rifkin would still be out there."
 
'His Tortured Existence'
 Mr. Rifkin's lawyer, John Lawrence, said he was "not surprised by the verdict and sentence, considering the circumstances."
Mr. Lawrence had argued that Mr. Rifkin was a paranoid schizophrenic who suffered from delusions and was therefore unable to know that he was killing his victims or that it was wrong.
"It's only through proper psychiatric care and treatment that Mr. Rifkin will find peace from his tortured existence," Mr. Lawrence said.
Mr. Rifkin will try a new insanity defense in the Suffolk murder trial, said his lawyer in that case, Martin Efman. Mr. Efman said he hoped to show that as an adopted child, Mr. Rifkin suffered from a wide range of emotional problems, including hypersensitivity to rejection that caused him to kill his victims in a murderous rage.
Mr. Efman said he would call as his chief defense witness Dr. David Kirschner, an expert on adopted killers, who has developed a psychopathology he calls adopted-child syndrome.
Mr. Rifkin told psychiatrists who testified in his first trial that he believed his mother, like his 17 victims, was a prostitute. He will seek court release of his adoption papers to determine if any genetic clues in his background can explain his behavior, Mr. Efman said.
Mr. Rifkin also faces murder charges in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx.
In the Suffolk case, Mr. Rifkin is accused of murdering Leah Evens of Brooklyn and Lauren Marquez of Sunnyside, Queens, both 28. In his confession, Mr. Rifkin told when and where he picked up both women in lower Manhattan, how he strangled them and where he buried them in the resort areas of Southampton and Westhampton Beach.
If convicted, Mr. Rifkin faces an additional 25 years to life for each killing. If found not guilty by reason of insanity, his attorney expects that Mr. Rifkin would spend the rest of his life in a state prison for the criminally insane.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Margarita Gonzalez, the sister of Jenny Soto, 22, who authorities say was strangled by Joel Rifkin, wept as she left court yesterday in Mineola, L.I., after his sentencing in the murder of Tiffany Bresciani. (Steve Berman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New Fuel for the Fed's Rate Fire

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 8

 BODY:
The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, has found another argument to justify its attempts to shove inflation ever lower with repeated increases in short-term interest rates.
Buttressing his argument with a new Federal Reserve study, he is contending that the central bank can increase the productivity of the nation's people and factories by at some point pushing consumer price inflation even lower than the 2.4 percent for the year that ended in April. The reasoning goes that lower inflation forces businesses to become more efficient because they cannot raise prices, and that when businesses are more efficient, the nation's economic output and standard of living rise. 
 Mr. Greenspan's fascination with the link is important not only as a defense of past interest rate increases but also as one of many signals about future policy. The research may help to explain why Mr. Greenspan has gradually become more willing than most Federal Reserve officials to raise interest rates this spring, after some initial reluctance.
 
Findings, and Skepticism
 A preliminary draft of the study contends that with a reduction of one percentage point in the inflation rate, the nation's productivity and economic growth rates both rise by two- or three-tenths of a percentage point.
But the argument does not impress Administration officials or some private economists, who are skeptical of the Federal Reserve's new claims and worry that in using higher interest rates to slow the economy and therefore push down an already low inflation rate, the Federal Reserve will excessively restrict the economy and needlessly cost the country hundreds of thousands of jobs.
Mr. Greenspan first cited the research in Congresssional testimony at the end of last month to argue that further reductions in inflation may be needed. "We don't have enough observations to know that it's conclusively the case," he told the Senate Banking Committee, "but I think it's becoming persuasively the case that not only is it -- which everyone agrees to -- important to bring the inflation rate down from 10 percent to 5 percent, but it's increasingly becoming evident that the lower we get under 5 percent, the more stable and growing the economy is."
Mr. Greenspan has previously indicated a desire to reduce inflation to 1 or 2 percent, as measured by the Consumer Price Index. The productivity research is the latest of many justifications that the central bank has offered over the years for raising interest rates. In effect, the central bank is arguing that short-term economic pain may be necessary for long-term economic gain.
The new Federal Reserve study found that low inflation has gone hand in hand with high productivity, and high inflation with low productivity, during the last 40 years in the United States. The same correlation was found in similar periods in Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy and, to a lesser extent, Japan.
The study also used a much-debated statistical device to make the case that it was low inflation that raised productivity, rather than high productivity causing low inflation. Finally, the study's authors, two Federal Reserve economists, attempted to adjust for the booms and busts in the business cycle, although they acknowledged that their success could be questioned.
Instead of using consumer prices, the new Federal Reserve study uses a different inflation measure -- prices charged by businesses for all goods -- that produces slightly lower numbers and offers a broader comparison to business productivity. The study excluded prices and productivity on farms and in government agencies.
Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the head of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers, disagrees with Mr. Greenspan's argument. She said in an interview that while extremely high levels of inflation might have hurt productivity in foreign countries, inflation in the United States had never been high enough to have a demonstrable effect on productivity, even in the late 1970's.
"I don't think it has been well documented at lower levels," she said.
 
Link or No Link?
 Barry P. Bosworth, an economist at the Brookings Institution, said earlier academic research had failed to document any clear link to productivity for inflation rates below 20 percent. He suggested that in arguing for the existence of a link at much lower levels, Mr. Greenspan might be looking for a politically palatable explanation for the central bank's interest-rate increases this spring.
"I think it's a bit of throwing everything at the fan and seeing what sticks," Mr. Bosworth said. "He wants to make the argument for the benefits of low rates of inflation."
But Stanley Fischer, an economics professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who will soon become the deputy managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said that his own research in the last two years suggested that Mr. Greenspan might be right, at least for inflation rates of 3 percent or more.
The new Federal Reserve research will be discussed at length on Thursday during a Bank of England conference on monetary and financial policy, he said.
Federal Reserve officials initially expressed reluctance to share the new study even after Mr. Greenspan had mentioned it in his testimony, but they relented last weekend.
Economists at the Federal Reserve said Mr. Greenspan had taken a strong personal interest in the research. Other central bank officials were largely unaware of the work until Mr. Greenspan mentioned a link between inflation and productivity.
"I was taken by that comment myself -- it has some intuitive appeal but I have not seen any of the data," said Robert P. Forrestal, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta.
 
Computer Modeling
 The study consists of highly esoteric statistical calculations and computer modeling, rather than any field research involving interviews with companies or workers. The study also does not address why low inflation may cause higher productivity.
It suggested that temporary shrinkages in the economy might be needed to curb inflation and increase productivity. "Even if a one-percentage-point reduction in inflation boosts the trend growth of productivity (and hence output) only 0.2 percentage point, then an initial sacrifice of, say, two and a half percentage points of G.D.P. is more than recovered within five years," the draft says. The arithmetic is true because of a compounding effect.
Two Federal Reserve economists, Glenn D. Rudebusch and David W. Wilcox, wrote the paper.
Susan M. Phillips, one of the five sitting governors of the Federal Reserve Board, said on Tuesday that when inflation was low, businesses were more willing to judge long-term investments on their own merits and tended to make more efficient decisions, adding to productivity. When inflation is high, she said, businesses tend to time investments to minimize the erosion of returns by inflation.
But other research has suggested that high productivity may produce low inflation, rather than the other way around, Ms. Tyson said. Mr. Rudebusch and Mr. Wilcox tried to show this was not the case by using a statistical technique known as a Granger test. In using the test, the two economists compared each year's productivity with inflation in four previous periods and found a strong correlation. They found no correlation when they compared inflation with productivity in four previous periods.
Some economists have criticized the Granger test over the years as unreliable for examining indicators like productivity that tend to rise and fall with the health of the overall economy.

HEADLINE: In Budget, Albany Preserves Some Hometown Goodies

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 8

 BODY:
Since 1986, when the State Legislature was ridiculed for appropriating $175,000 to help build the Museum of Cheese in Rome, N.Y., legislative aides say they have been trying to clean up the process that produces the budget items referred to here by euphemisms like "legislative initiatives" and "member items." Elsewhere the spending is more commonly known as pork.
But that did not prevent this election-year budget from including grants like $2,500 for the Farmingdale Midget Football league, $5,000 for the Firefighters Monuments for the Massapequas, $100,000 for Carnegie Hall, and $250,000 for the Boonville Fair. 
 The money was on a list released by legislative aides shortly after midnight Tuesday that disclosed, for the first time in a six-month budget process, about $102 million worth of proposed grants to local youth, cultural and social-service organizations.
 
Minor-League Stadiums
 Four hours later, before the sun brought daylight to the Capitol, the Legislature approved the spending as part of the state's $34 billion budget. It also approved a lump-sum appropriation of $48 million -- $24 million for each house -- that legislative leaders will distribute later this year to members for pet projects in their districts.
And earlier this week the Legislature allocated $127 million to pay for the construction and renovation of 10 minor-league baseball stadiums and for a swimming center on Long Island that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has compared to the Taj Mahal.
Critics of the grants say they understand that each appropriation has a constituency. They say many -- although not all -- deserve taxpayer support. But they argue that the selection process mocks the concept of equity.
In choosing projects, the relative merit of any given proposal, compared to that of thousands of others made by the 211 lawmakers, usually takes a back seat to considerations like seniority, party affiliation and political vulnerability.
 
'Sense of Competition'
 "There is no sense of competition among needs," said Brian D. Backstrom, vice president for research of Change-NY, an anti-tax group.
"The problem with them is they become a tool of incumbency when legislators, particularly during election years, don't think about the best use of this money but the use that will get the most votes," said Andrew Greenblatt, executive director of New York State Common Cause. "So the money usually goes to organized, high-profile groups or causes."
Mr. Backstrom and Mr. Greenblatt said this year's grant process was particularly opaque, even by the standards of a budget that was negotiated almost entirely behind closed doors.
Legislative leaders said they were negotiating the grant list until the final hours Tuesday night and did not want to release it in parts. With the budget already more than two months late, they said they wanted to pass it as soon as negotiations closed.
The grants requested by the Democratic leaders of the Assembly tend to be for social-service organizations, like senior-citizen centers and AIDS education groups. Many of the grants requested by the Republicans who control the State Senate are for local civic, youth and economic-development projects. Senate aides say that is because Mr. Cuomo includes many similar initiatives in Democratic districts when he proposes his own budget in January. Minority parties control very little of the money.
 
A Soaring Museum
 The appropriateness of the grants is always open to interpretation.
The National Soaring Museum, at Harris Hill between Elmira and Corning, received a $5,000 one-time grant this year to advertise new directions to the museum while the state replaces a bridge on its main access road. James W. Swinnich, executive director of the museum, which is dedicated to the history and science of gliders and sailplanes, said the museum has lost 50 percent of its visitors since the bridge construction began.
He said Senator John R. Kuhl Jr., a Republican from Hammondsport, helped secure the grant for billboards and new brochures showing an alternate route. But he said he lost the use of two prime billboards because the budget was so late.
Senator Kemp Hannon, a Republican from Garden City, procured $30,000 this year, as he has in past years, for the Long Island Coalition for Fair Broadcasting, a nonprofit research group that encourages New York City television stations to carry more news about Long Island.
 
Too Much Buttafuoco
 "Our function is to complain when they only cover Joey Buttafuoco, and if they do a good job, we let them know that too," said Abby B. Kenigsberg, the group's executive director. She defended the use of state funds for her organization, which has a total budget of $130,000, by saying it "encourages a free press."
Senator Hannon said the grant provides "regional promotion of 2.5 million people who heretofore had been ignored by a city-centric electronic media."
In nearby Bellmore, the Bellmore-Merrick Roller Hockey Association will be able to repair the fence around its blacktop rink because of a $2,500 grant secured by Senator Norman J. Levy, a Republican from Merrick, according to Ted R. Manara, an association board member.
And in Massena, the work of Senator William R. Sears, also a Republican, will provide $250,000 for architectural planning for the $14 million St. Lawrence Aquarium and Ecological Center, which is expected to bring $5 million in economic activity to the region each year.
"These grants are only egregious in the eyes of the beholder," said John E. McArdle, a Senate spokesman. "People in districts back home, where these funds go to senior-citizen centers, rape crisis centers, day-care centers, find them very worthwhile."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Decline After Early Rally

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Bond prices declined yesterday, pushing interest rates higher, as rising commodity prices and a falling dollar helped erase a morning rally. 
 The Treasury's 30-year bond lost 6/32 of a point, or $1.875 for each $1,000 bond. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 7.27 percent from 7.26 percent on Tuesday.
The bond market's retreat came late in the day and followed a morning rally that had been set off when Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, told bankers in London that inflation was "clearly restrained." Mr. Greenspan's comments reduced speculation the Fed will raise interest rates soon.
 
Lack of Investor Interest

 
 Wall Street's largest securities firms were among the biggest buyers of Treasuries, betting early in the day that they could sell bonds at even higher prices to investors. When investors failed to show much enthusiasm, bond firms "dumped what they bought," said Peter Hirsch, the top Government bond trader at Salomon Brothers.
Contributing to the bond market's late slump was the drop in the dollar that followed remarks by Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, who said trade sanctions against Japan could not be ruled out in an effort to force Tokyo to accept more American goods.
"Once again, the Administration is refusing to pay heed to the old wartime adage that loose lips sink ships," John Ryding, an economist at Bear, Stearns & Company, said. "Bonds have benefited from overseas buying, and the benefits for foreigners holding U.S. assets decline as the U.S. currency declines."
Bonds also came under pressure from a rise in the Commodity Research Bureau's index, which some traders consider a leading indicator of inflation.
Adding to the bond market's worries were comments by Thomas Hoenig, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, Mo., who said that while inflation was stable, the economy was nearing full employment.
Some economists believe the threat of rising inflation increases dangerously as the unemployment rate drops. More inflation erodes the value of fixed-income securities such as bonds.
 
10-Year Note's Yield at 6.95%

 
 Among other Treasury issues, the yield on the 10-year note rose to 6.95 percent, from 6.94 percent on Tuesday. The yields on some intermediate and short-term issues were also marginally higher.
Mr. Greenspan's comments indicate the Fed is "likely to pretty much sit on its hands for the next three months, and maybe beyond," said Anders Ekernas, president and chief investment officer of the ABB Investment Management Corporation, in Stamford, Conn.
The Bundesbank's president, Hans Tietmeyer, echoed Mr. Greenspan's sentiments at the London conference of bankers, saying that he "hopes and expects" a lower inflation rate.
Central banks around the world are trying to calm inflation fears, Mr. Ekernas said.
"The Fed has gone out of its way to reassure the market it's not going to raise rates in July," when Fed officials next meet, Robert Bluestone, a managing director and head of fixed-income investments at Oppenheimer Capital, said. "They're going out of their way to gain the bond market's confidence."
Bond yields have fallen about 40 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, since topping out at 7.66 percent on May 11, "and we've got more to go," Mr. Bluestone said.
Bond yields were 6.30 percent before the Fed began raising rates in February. The long bond ended at a record low yield of 5.78 percent on Oct. 15, 1993.
The Fed has raised the rate on overnight bank loans four times this year for a total of 1.25 points.
 
Belief in a Rally

 
 "I'm feeling a lot better," said James Casselberry, head of almost $1 billion in fixed-income investments at the MacArthur Foundation in Chicago. So long as the Fed doesn't raise rates, bonds can keep rallying, he said.
"I definitely don't think we'll run through 7.30 percent," Mr. Casselberry said. "I feel like I can come out of my foxhole."
Thomas J. Steffanci, director of fixed-income investments at Fidelity Investments in Boston, has not changed his opinion that bonds will rally this year. "Our view remains the same -- that is, the economy is on a moderate growth track, with inflation that's acceptable to the Fed and the bond market, and that the inflation premium in the bond market is too much," Mr. Steffanci said. "I would not be surprised to see 7 percent or slightly through that in the next three months."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Weaker Against Yen After Tough U.S. Trade Talk

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar continued to weaken against the Japanese yen yesterday after Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown said the United States would not rule out the use of trade sanctions to open Japan's markets to American goods. 
 Mr. Brown's comments, coupled with tough talk on Tuesday by Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, convinced many traders that the United States was willing to resume calls for a strong yen to curb Japan's trade surplus if current negotiations fail.
"The Clinton Administration says it isn't using the dollar as a tool, but no one believes them," said Dave Glowacki, senior trader at NBD Bank in Detroit. "People are going to be nervous until the trade talks are over."
 
 
Sanctions Still Possible
 The dollar fell to a three-week low of 103.65 yen just after Mr. Brown said in Paris that the use of sanctions against Japan "should not be ruled out."
A White House economic aide, W. Bowman Cutter, said later that the United States had no intention of driving the dollar lower against the yen, a strategy it pursued last year. In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 104 yen, down from 104.17 yen on Tuesday.
But the dollar rose against the German mark as traders sold marks for yen, a strategy that often requires them to sell marks for dollars and then sell dollars for yen. The dollar rose to 1.6695 marks from 1.6659 marks.
Mr. Kantor fired the first salvo on trade on Tuesday, when he said that the United States might use trade law to pry open Japan's markets if the two countries did not reach an agreement. Those remarks sent the dollar plunging 1.12 yen on Tuesday.
 
 
Traders Rattled
 The remarks by Mr. Brown and Mr. Kantor rattled traders because the Treasury went to great lengths last month to rescue the dollar from a free fall. It called on the Federal Reserve and 18 other central banks to stage a dollar-buying spree on May 4. Five days before, the Fed alone bought $700 million with marks and yen.
The Clinton Administration has "done a brilliant job of confusing the market about the U.S.-Japanese trade situation," said Chris Furness, a currency market analyst in London.
The dollar rose to a two-month high of 105.55 yen on Friday, a few days after the United States and Japan resumed formal trade talks.
