HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Oil Prices Rally as Supplies Grow Tighter in Midwest

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Oil prices rallied late in the day, bouncing back from Tuesday's selloff amid growing concerns about dwindling supplies in the Midwest. 
 On other commodity markets, copper rose to a 21-month high as demand from factories and other industrial users continued to deplete inventories. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities rose 2.25 points, to 231.21.
Midwestern oil stockpiles are at a 15-month low, and they fell 2.3 percent last week, to 68.4 million barrels from 70.1 million barrels a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Inventories are 10.9 percent below those of a year earlier.
"The bottom line on crude is that the Midwest market is still tight," said John Saucer, an analyst at Smith Barney Inc. in Houston. "It's like magic. When they drop below 70 million, people start taking notice."
Crude oil for July delivery rose as high as $18.40 a barrel before settling at $18.34 a barrel, up 59 cents on the New York Mercantile Exchange. That was the biggest one-day rise in two months. July unleaded gasoline rose 0.46 cent, to 51.81 cents a gallon, while July heating oil rose 0.15 cent, to 46.62 cents a gallon.
 
Shortage in Oklahoma
 While supplies elsewhere are plentiful, Mr. Saucer said, traders are concerned that not enough crude will be available for delivery in Oklahoma against the futures contract.
Elsewhere, copper rose to a 21-month high as rebounding economies worldwide continued to push up industrial demand and reduce inventories.
"Heavy manufacturing in Europe and the U.S. is causing this to happen," said Richard Hirsch, vice president with Deutsche Bank's Sharps Pixley brokerage in New York. "Old-fashioned industrial commodities are booming. Smokestack America is really booming, and that's what's helping copper."
Copper for July delivery rose as high as $1.095 a pound before settling 1.75 cent higher at $1.0855 a pound on the Commodity Exchange.
Copper stockpiles held in London Metal Exchange warehouses have fallen by 40 percent so far this year at a time when stocks are low and demand is growing and have reached a 14-month low. Inventories in American exchange warehouses are 58 percent lower.
Separately, coffee prices rose on fears that cold weather could arrive next month in Brazil, harming the world's largest crop at a time when stocks are low and demand is growing. July coffee rose 5 cents, to $1.2795 a pound at the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Closed-end country funds are not always what they seem to be.

BYLINE: By Leslie Eaton 

 BODY:
IF you want to know how excited investors are about various foreign stock markets, there's no easier place to look than the quirky world of closed-end country funds.
These country funds generally raise a fixed amount of money that they invest in stock markets abroad. Americans can buy shares in the fund here that trade for more or less than the value of the underlying foreign stock portfolio. When the price of shares has been bid up to well over the price of the underlying assets -- that is, a premium, -- that's usually a sign that investors are enthusiastic about a given country's prospects. 
 But not always. As the fate of the Turkish Investment Fund shows, sometimes fund shares trade at huge premiums not because investors think a foreign market is about to take off, but because they can't believe how far it has dropped.
How fallen are the mighty: in 1993, the Turkish stock market was the hottest in the world, more than doubling in value in the space of just a few months. But in mid-January the Turkish market hit its peak and has fallen so sharply since then that investors' fortunes have been turned upside down. In January, the price of the shares in the fund were cheap at a 9 percent discount to the value of the Turkish stocks. But last week the shares of the fund were trading at a 72 percent premium to its collapsed net asset value, or N.A.V. Investors would now have to pay $1.72 for every $1 of the fund's assets.
While that premium is by no means a record -- funds specializing in Korea and in Spain traded at more than 130 percent at various times in the late 1980's -- the Turkey fund's premium is by far the largest today, according to Michael Porter, the closed-end fund analyst for Smith Barney.
The reason that the fund's premium has soared from 23 percent to as high as 80 percent this year is that the value of its portfolio plunged more than 64 percent this year, much of which was caused by a collapse in the Turkish lira. But, at the same time, the fund's shares sank just 48 percent, leaving them selling at a much higher price than the value of the stocks in the Turkish Investment Fund. "It's sort of like you've fallen from the 100th story of a building, and now you're down to the 20th floor -- you still have a long way to go," Mr. Porter said, adding, "I've never seen that kind of N.A.V. meltdown."
Antoine van Agtmael has. An old hand at overseas investing and now the president of Emerging Markets Management, Mr. van Agtmael points out that often the best-performing market in one year is the worst performer the next year. "If the economy policy is not sustainable, the bottom falls out," he said. "We've seen that in Brazil, Turkey, Eastern Europe, and numerous other countries."
In the case of Turkey, "the combination of still-high inflation, slower economic growth and political challenges add up" to a less-than-optimistic outlook, he said. Still, he added, because most of that is already reflected in stock prices, "Turkey actually offers some interesting opportunities."
But Morgan Stanley Asset Management, which runs the fund, remains cautious, at least for the next year. "The expectation is still that this will be a V-shaped recession, with a very rapid recovery" in Turkey, Marianne Hay, the fund's portfolio manager, said. "But we think it may take longer than that."
Bottom fishers beware: as long as the fund trades at such a whopping premium, it will be almost impossible to make money, fund mavens warn. "If you are right, and the N.A.V. rallies sharply and the currency is in your favor, the danger is that the premium will contract," said Thomas J. Herzfeld, whose Miami firm specializes in closed-end funds. For example, he noted that earlier this year, Italy Fund was trading at a 24 percent premium. The net asset value rose 20 percent, but the premium contracted as demand for the fund seemed to slacken a bit and the share price fell from $12.50 to $11.
"The pitfall in buying the Turkey fund," Mr. Herzfeld said, "is you can be right about the market and still lose money."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
South Africa's huge challenge: bringing the good life to blacks.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
IT seems a miracle: South Africa has become a multiracial democracy. But democracies can't live by virtue alone, and the economic challenge facing the new Government is far greater than generally understood. 
 Indeed, by the reckoning of many of South Africa's well-wishers, it will take a comparable miracle to transform an economy twisted by apartheid into an engine of growth capable of satisfying the expectations of the majority anytime soon. "The South African economy is unique," said Jeffrey Herbst, a political scientist at the Woodrow Wilson School at Princeton and contributor to "South Africa: The Political Economy of Transformation" (edited by Stephen Stedman). "No country has ever been saddled with this set of problems."
South Africa is obviously not just another third-world economy with little to show from top-down rule other than a big foreign debt. Along with most of Africa's industrial capacity, it can boast of excellent transportation, communications, hospitals, schools -- in short, all the accouterments of a modern consumer culture.
Probably more important, said Stephen Lewis, an economist who is president of Carleton College, the governing African National Congress has demonstrated remarkable flexibility, jettisoning the rhetoric of revolutionary socialism almost overnight. And it has gone out of its way to reassure the world that South Africa's fiscal and monetary policies will be prudent to the point of austerity, retaining key technocrats from the Nationalist administration as a symbol of its sincerity.
What's more, the Government's commitment to the rule of law is backed by an independent judiciary and a professional civil service. "Investors aren't going to be ripped off by the legal system," said Robert Klitgaard, an American economist teaching at the University of Natal.
However, for all the grace displayed by black South Africans in their hour of triumph, Mr. Herbst expects that their patience is a rapidly depleting asset. He predicts that the pressures to deliver the good life to the great majority will grow rapidly as time passes and the A.N.C. coalition fractures along the ideological spectrum.
Such redistribution is more easily imagined than accomplished, though, by a government that honors property rights and is reluctant to raise taxes very much, lest it undermine incentives for savings and production.
By the estimate of one South African economist, Servaas van den Berg, bringing social spending on blacks to the standard enjoyed by whites would increase Government outlays from one-quarter of national output to almost half. And that figure does not include the cost of remedial programs for the most impoverished Africans, the bottomless pit of need in a country in which rural inhabitants generally lack electricity, clean water, nutritious food and basic skills.
Almost everyone's preferred way out of the bind is rapid economic expansion, with the added output spent on the poor. And on first glance, the prospects seem favorable.
Plagued by boycotts from abroad and wasteful bureaucratic efforts to sustain apartheid from within, average living standards fell by 15 percent in the 1980's. If South Africa could simply go back to the growth experience of the 1946-73 period, output per person would rise by one-quarter over the next decade.
But Mr. Herbst notes that South Africa's "normal" growth in the past was achieved only through abnormally high rates of investment. And while the hoped-for end of white flight and assured access to world capital markets should make a difference, he is skeptical that the "apartheid dividend" will be sufficient to push growth much above the 2 to 3 percent rate needed to cover population growth.
It is still tempting to compare South Africa to the latest crop of Asian tiger cubs -- Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia -- which started in seemingly more difficult economic circumstances and have managed 7 percent-plus growth for a decade. But they do not suffer from severe shortages of skilled labor, a legacy of apartheid. Nor do they have powerful labor movements, committed to protecting wage gains that raced ahead of productivity in the 1970's and 1980's. Nor do they have huge entrenched bureaucracies hostile to free enterprise. Nor are they dependent on foreign savings, a dependence that pushes South Africa's foreign currency accounts into deficit whenever the economy shows signs of vitality.
To Mr. Herbst, South Africa's best hope is to rely on the maturity of the electorate to sustain civility through a long economic transition. South Africa will have succeeded, he argues, "if the next election is about who gets what" rather than the viability of democracy itself.
While no Pollyanna, Mr. Lewis thinks economic miracles can be made to happen. In the end, he believes that South Africa's economic prospects "turn on the capacity to change institutions." And where else on earth, he asks, have so many shown the strength to set aside both grievances and prejudices in order to move on?

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Low Shock Threshold In White House Expose

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:

The Agenda
Inside the Clinton White House
By Bob Woodward
Illustrated. 352 pages. Simon & Schuster.
$24. 
 Ever since Bob Woodward's first book, "All the President's Men," the expose of the Watergate scandal he wrote with Carl Bernstein, we have come to expect startling revelations from him, an expectation that was hardly dampened by his succeeding works: "The Final Days," "The Brethren," "Wired," "Veil" and "The Commanders."
After the announcement of Mr. Woodward's latest book, "The Agenda: Inside the Clinton White House," anticipation of high-level gossip was further excited by reports that it revealed the power wielded by Hillary Rodham Clinton, and the influence exerted on Presidential policy by Alan Greenspan, the presumably apolitical chairman of the Federal Reserve system.
So it comes as somewhat of a surprise that while "The Agenda" is built of unsourced inside scenes that resemble in pace and point of view the shocking narrative of Richard M. Nixon's resignation, "The Final Days," the tone and attitude of the new book are not only far from sensational but also neutral almost to the point of ambiguity.
True, Mrs. Clinton does put in regular appearances to tell her husband and his advisers in caustic words to shape up and stop dithering. And true, Mr. Greenspan delivers messages to the President fervently approving anything that might cut the deficit and lower long-term interest rates.
Moreover, the President keeps having tantrums, so often and so violently that you come think of them as his way of keeping himself going. And his anguished indecisiveness can make Hamlet look like Fortinbras.
Mr. Woodward reports an incident in which Thomas F. McLarty, the White House chief of staff, makes a promise to Representative Dave McCurdy in exchange for the Congressman's support of the President's economic plan and then promptly seems to forget his obligation. There are several other scenes of back-corridor treachery. And in one confrontation, Vice President Al Gore tells off the President in tones that witnesses felt breached protocol.
But are we supposed to be shocked by such reports? Haven't these sorts of incidents always occurred behind the scenes as White House staffs have tried to define Presidential policy and put it into effect? Is it remarkable that a President would start out with a visionary agenda only to see it whittled down by compromise from a mighty oak to a toothpick, as President Clinton seems to have done in promising an economic plan that would tax energy consumption, stimulate the economy, invest in development and cut spending, and in the end settling for merely lowering the deficit?
Has it never happened before that in pressing legislators for votes a President pulls out every emotional stop from self-pity to profane abuse, as the President seems to have done with Senator Bob Kerrey in seeking his support? If a Lyndon B. Johnson leaned on a senator in a forest, would there have been no expletives to delete?
The lack of a firmer point of view in "The Agenda" can be traced in part to the author's rush to get the book out while its news is still fresh. As he points out in his introduction: "Much of this book was reported while events were developing, before the outcomes and consequences were known or imagined. As a result, I believe, it contains some events that otherwise might have been lost to the record."
Also, Mr. Woodward is searching for a unique point of view, one that "falls between newspaper journalism and history." As he explains: "I believe there is a place for reporting that aspires to combine the thoroughness of history with the contemporaneity of journalism. This book aims to find that ground."
If one detects the faintest note of defensiveness about the author's heavy reliance on interviews conducted on "deep background," it seems to be echoed in his announcement that all material connected with his interviews will be deposited in the Yale University Library, with the files to be "opened to the public and researchers in 40 years to provide the exact source or sources for each portion of this book." If this holds true, it will be 2034 until we finally get to cross-examine Mr. Woodward's methods of reporting.
Without ambiguity, the main point of "The Agenda" is that in the first year of his Administration, President Clinton fell absurdly short of the promise he made when, in accepting the Democratic Presidential nomination on July 16, 1992, he said, "George Bush, if you won't use your power to help people, step aside, I will." The next April the President was telling his staff with bitter sarcasm: "We're Eisenhower Republicans here, and we are fighting the Reagan Republicans. We stand for lower deficits and free trade and the bond market. Isn't that great?"
But many of Mr. Woodward's finer points are not so obvious in what they reveal. Scenes shift and conversations are reported without distinct guidelines to the author's point. The lack of a sturdy framework can be disquieting. Readers with a solid background in Presidential politics will probably find Mr. Woodward's raw material invaluable. But those without an ideological or historical foundation may find themselves perplexed by much of what Mr. Woodward reports.
In the end, one finds it hard to tell whether "The Agenda" is meant to be an indictment of an ineffectually struggling Presidency or an objective revelation of how most Washington Administrations have to work these days.

HEADLINE: The Harm in Family Welfare Caps

 BODY:
A destructive provision in President Clinton's forthcoming welfare-reform bill would allow states to put a cap on family welfare benefits. Under the cap, mothers who give birth while on welfare would receive no additional money for the care of the additional child. That will do little good and much harm. According to nearly every careful study, family caps do nothing to discourage childbirth but they do victimize innocent children.
Family caps, which are also included in several bills already before Congress, are based on the false notion that larger benefit checks encourage welfare mothers to have more babies and thereby stay longer on welfare. But a welfare mother would have to be crazy to think of babies as an economic advantage. The average extra stipend to welfare mothers who give birth is less than $75 a month -- which does not even cover the cost of diapers and other expenses for the new baby. 
 Studies -- including research by Mary Jo Bane and David Ellwood, who head the Administration's task force on welfare reform -- do not show that raising welfare benefits leads to more illegitimate births. Indeed, welfare mothers typically have fewer than two children -- which is fewer than women in the non-welfare population.
Thus the family cap will not significantly reduce illegitimate children or welfare costs. But it will take $75 a month from mothers desperately trying to feed, clothe and educate their children. There are also legal questions, not yet settled, whether states have a right to discriminate against additional children.
New Jersey, Georgia and Arkansas have already received permission from Washington to impose family caps under current law. This page embraced New Jersey's application because, in the absence of national reform, states deserved wide latitude in figuring out how to discourage welfare dependency. But that rationale will no longer apply once Congress passes national reform.
Mr. Clinton's two-years-and-out plan -- whereby welfare recipients would, after two years of collecting benefits, be required to find a job or accept a government-subsidized job -- would make long-term dependency by the able-bodied impossible. A state cap on family benefits would then serve no purpose other than to punish poor children.
As a former Governor, Mr. Clinton leans to giving states room to experiment. But welfare policy is the wrong place for state options. States have all the wrong financial incentives -- by stinting on benefits, they encourage out-migration and discourage in-migration of poor families. The place to set welfare rules is in Washington, so that the poor do not have to shop around for humane treatment. Under the discipline of national welfare reform, there is no justification for family caps.

HEADLINE: A Budget: Delayed and Deficient

 BODY:
Without a trace of embarrassment, Gov. Mario Cuomo and the Legislature have finally agreed on a state budget they should have adopted 10 weeks ago. Heaping praise on themselves for cutting taxes and adding money for all sorts of popular causes in an election year -- like school aid and baseball stadiums -- they neglect to mention that, once again, they failed to remove the Medicaid burden on New York City and county governments statewide.
Over all, New York City fares well. It will get more state aid than Mayor Rudolph Giuliani sought, including token Medicaid relief and a significant increase in aid for schools. Moreover, the increase in school aid is more generous than the basic aid formula that has shortchanged the city for years. 
 It may seem odd when a state government dominated by Democrats gives a Republican Mayor more help than he asks for, but that is not how it plays in politics. Facing elections in November, the Democratic Governor and the Democrats who control the Assembly wish to be seen as helping New York City's preponderantly Democratic voters.
The Mayor sought $275 million of state aid in various forms -- school aid, Medicaid, etc. Depending on who in Albany is spinning out the numbers, he will get a little more than that or a lot more, perhaps as much as $425 million altogether.
Even so, the Mayor complains that the Legislature, in a separate bill, would require that the school aid be used to aid schools -- not diverted, as the Mayor wants, to reduce the budget gap or finance other programs. The Mayor is on weak ground here. When Albany earmarks aid, it ought to go to the intended beneficiaries. Mr. Cuomo should sign the bill sending school aid to the schools.
The tax cuts in the new budget are more than twice as large as Governor Cuomo proposed, thanks to unexpected surplus funds and insistent pressure from the Republican-controlled Senate. The state's 5 percent tax on high-priced hotel rooms is repealed as of Sept. 1 -- a welcome relief for New York City. But the biggest tax reduction, phasing out the 15 percent corporate surcharge, is not really a cut at all. The entire surcharge was scheduled to expire this year; now it is only phased down.
The big disappointment was failure to start shifting anything more than a modest share of Medicaid costs out of local budgets. New York State shoulders a smaller portion of Medicaid costs than any other state. Governor Cuomo proposed this year that the state assume the whole burden. Mayor Giuliani and county executives statewide pressed the Legislature to approve. The urban-Democratic Assembly did, but the suburban-Republican Senate did not, apparently because New York City would get 70 percent of the benefit.
All through the recession, shrinking revenues forced Albany to agonize over budget cuts. With renewed expansion, budgeting should be easier now. So why did it take until June 8 -- the next-to-latest budget in the past decade -- for Governor Cuomo and the Legislature to come to terms? Their tardiness put an enormous strain on local budgets that will only now be mitigated by the belated largesse.

HEADLINE: Turning a Profit On Dirty Reactors

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You report (Business Day, May 31) a plan to "shift responsibility from private companies to the Federal Government for millions of dollars in damages from certain types of nuclear accidents outside the United States." The idea is promoted by the Energy Department. The cited beneficiaries will be Bechtel, Combustion Engineering, Nuclear Fuel Services and Raytheon. Westinghouse, General Electric or both should gain too. 
 The cited companies argue they cannot work on Russian nuclear projects because local laws impose great liability on the nuclear contractors. Private insurer premiums are prohibitive, because the risks are so great. Uncle Sam is thus likely to pay on any guarantees, so it amounts to a huge subsidy of nuclear power.
There are alternatives to nuclear power -- fossil fuels (including natural gas), solar and wind power, energy efficiency. They can have high-technology components without nuclear power's dangers -- nuclear proliferation, cost overruns, meltdowns.
Special interests always win if those with a general interest keep silent. If the Federal Government guarantees Russian reactors, American tax dollars will fly out Washington windows into the pockets of United States nuclear-reactor manufacturers.
 
JOHN TEPPER MARLIN
 DIETRICH FISCHER
New York, June 2, 1994
 
The writers are on the board of Economists Allied for Arms Reduction.

HEADLINE: U.S. FINDS IT HARD TO WIN CONSENSUS OVER NORTH KOREA

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
One week after Washington said it would push for economic sanctions against North Korea, the Administration is still struggling to complete its plan and says it may be weeks before the United Nations Security Council will be ready to vote on the matter.
With China voicing objections and Japan expressing reservations about imposing tough sanctions, and with differences within Administration ranks, the White House has yet to draft a sanctions resolution. 
 Robert L. Gallucci, the Assistant Secretary of State for Politico-Military Affairs and the Administration's point man on North Korea, told a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee today that Washington hoped to agree on a position in the next several days.
But even after the Administration's position is set, officials said, consultations at the United Nations could be difficult and prolonged. "We expect the process to continue over the next few weeks," Mr. Gallucci said, referring to consultations with allies.
Although Washington has repeatedly said it would push for a gradual tightening of global sanctions if North Korea continued to thwart inspections of its nuclear sites, the Administration has moved slowly to develop a response since the North called Washington's bluff.
In part, the delay reflects the Administration's difficulty in agreeing on a plan that would punish North Korea for blocking inspections while keeping some threats in reserve to dissuade the North from withdrawing completely from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty and developing nuclear weapons.
It also reflects the Administration's difficulties in securing the support of other Security Council members. Mr. Gallucci pointedly declined to predict that Washington's diplomatic efforts would result in tough sanctions that would get the North Koreans' attention.
He told the panel, for example, that it was unclear whether a resolution by the Security Council would include a ban on the hundreds of millions of dollars in private funds that flow to North Korea from Japan.
"The question is whether the sanctions resolution will initially or eventually take account or limit such remittances," he said, "and at this point I can't predict whether the resolution or resolutions would so limit remittances."
The difficulty in devising and winning support for sanctions has undercut the message of resolve that Washington has sought to convey. As Representative Gary L. Ackerman, a New York Democrat, observed at the hearing today, "It just seems there are no stated punishments for those stated crimes and violations."
 
Twin Goals
 The crisis was set off by North Korea's decision to destroy evidence of its past plutonium production by rapidly withdrawing spent fuel rods from its Yongbyon nuclear reactor. In devising its sanctions, the Administration wants to punish North Korea for defying the International Atomic Energy Agency, while dissuading the North from using the fuel to make bombs.
The Administration's emerging plan would specify initial sanctions to be imposed by the Security Council if North Korea continued to defy the atomic energy agency. Tougher sanctions would be imposed if the North pressed ahead on the nuclear front.
The key questions include which sanctions to seek now and which to put off. And if sanctions are imposed, what would North Korea have to do to get them lifted?
Mr. Gallucci, the Assistant Secretary of State, has recommended two steps: a cut-off of the funds that are sent by Koreans living in Japan, and a voluntary embargo on arms purchases and deliveries.
 
The Pentagon's Concerns
 Pentagon officials, in contrast, have been more concerned with limiting the growth of the North Korean nuclear program than with solving the mystery of whether the North diverted a bomb's worth of plutonium in 1989. When the issue of sanctions was debated in past weeks, an official said, the Pentagon's approach was to "go low and slow."
Officials said today that there were broad areas of convergence but that important issues needed to be resolved.
China, for its part, appears to be as concerned about possible instability on the Korean peninsula as it is of a nuclear North Korea.
Japan would prefer that the Security Council begin by issuing a warning and undertaking some modest sanctions. Japanese officials have said Tokyo would prefer that any ban on remittances from Koreans in Japan be part of a broader trade ban that would be put off for now.
 
Agreement in Principle
 But all sides have sought publicly to maintain a united front.
"Japan believes it is time to show an appropriate response to North Korean actions, including sanctions, at the U.N. Security Council," Mr. Gallucci said in an unusual statement to the panel that he said had been approved by the Japanese Government.
Some Administration officials say North Korea's recent decision to shut down its reactor is a sign that it will soon rush to build nuclear weapons regardless of what actions the United Nations takes.
North Korea may be getting some comfort from the possibility that China will wield its Security Council veto. "I'm not prepared to try and predict how China will vote on a specific sanctions resolution," Mr. Gallucci said today, "certainly not knowing in advance what that resolution will look like."

Carter to Visit Koreas

 ATLANTA, June 9 (AP) -- Former President Carter said today that he and his wife will visit North and South Korea next week as private citizens, and he hopes to discuss "important issues of the day with leaders."
"The initiative for this trip has been from Korea, not Washington, and I will have no official status relating to the U.S. Government," Mr. Carter said in a statement.
A State Department spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Mr. Carter was "traveling in a private capacity."
"He has been in touch with the White House and has been briefed," the spokesman said.
Mr. Carter said: "My hope is to discuss some of the important issues of the day with leaders in the area."

HEADLINE: Health Legislation Advances in Senate

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
National health insurance took two major strides forward in the Senate today as one committee approved a bill, guaranteeing a Senate vote on the issue, and another, perhaps more crucial, committee shifted from general discussion to serious work on new legislation.
By a comfortable 11-to-6 margin, Senator Edward M. Kennedy's Labor and Human Resources Committee adopted the Senator's more generous version of President Clinton's health care proposal. It is the first Congressional committee to act, and its vote insures that the full Senate will confront the issue this summer. 
 At the Finance Committee, whose close partisan and ideological divisions parallel those in the full Senate, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the chairman, sought support for a detailed new proposal that he showed his colleagues today. It is a less generous plan than Mr. Clinton's.
Mr. Moynihan's proposal eliminated several politically popular benefits in the Clinton bill, like prescription drugs and long-term care for the elderly and government insurance for early retirees. Mr. Moynihan's willingness to eliminate those provisions, in a year when he is running for re-election, made it clear that he was seriously pushing for health care legislation and not just acting for show. He is also making known his worry that if the cost cannot be controlled, the bill cannot be passed.
The Clinton, Kennedy and Moynihan plans all rely on employers to buy health insurance for their workers and to pay most of the premiums. Mr. Kennedy's bill would exempt employers with 10 or fewer workers; Mr. Moynihan's would exempt employers with 20 or fewer workers but only for several years.
Mr. Moynihan, who has been skeptical of the Administration's financing estimates, proposed much higher taxes than the other bills did. He would raise the tobacco tax from 24 cents a pack to $2 and impose a 1 percent payroll tax on companies of 500 or more employees. Mr. Clinton proposed a tobacco tax of 99 cents, and Mr. Kennedy suggested a tax of $1.74.
All three measures would seek economies by enabling individuals to buy health insurance through purchasing cooperatives called health alliances. Mr. Clinton would make participation compulsory for almost all Americans, while Mr. Moynihan and Mr. Kennedy would make it voluntary while also giving the alliances much less authority than Mr. Clinton would. The provision to make participation voluntary should make the proposal more palatable to opponents of the Clinton plan in both parties.
The Labor Committee move was steeped in history, for Mr. Kennedy has campaigned for national health insurance for a quarter-century. But the bill moved out of his committee today was the first that was more than a political statement and that could perhaps become law.
President Clinton hailed the Labor Committee vote, saying it "gives me great confidence that Congress will pass legislation this year that meets the expectation of the American people: guaranteed private insurance for every American that can never be taken away." Referring to other measures in Congress, the President said, "For the first time in our history, committees in both the Senate and the House are seriously moving forward on health care reform."
Just before the vote, Mr. Kennedy told his committee, "Comprehensive health reform is a defining issue for this Congress."
He went on: "Comprehensive health reform has never been easy, or it would have been enacted long ago. The time for action is now. This committee is the first in the Senate or House to vote out comprehensive reform, but others will not be far behind."
There was drama of a different sort at the Finance Committee, as Mr. Moynihan ended the months of suspense about where he stood. He has fueled the uncertainty by speaking kindly about Republican ideas and by his occasional outbursts about parts of the Clinton plan that he thought were badly conceived.
 
'This Is Where You Begin'
 Mr. Moynihan was far more cautious in discussing his bill. Talking to reporters after his committee met, he said: "This is where you begin. You have to begin."
By proposing tax increases and an employer mandate, Mr. Moynihan was not reaching out to Republicans, who offered a range of comments, from negative to noncommittal.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, said, "It doesn't look very good to me." Senator John C. Danforth of Missouri said, "I think it's a piece of paper, and we all need a piece of paper." But he added, "It's an awful lot of taxes."
More hopeful, Senator Dave Durenberger of Minnesota said, "This is more realistic" because it requires less Federal regulation than Mr. Clinton's plan. But he also said, "This is not yet a middle-of-the-road bill."
Two Democrats whose votes Mr. Moynihan will need if the committee's nine Republicans oppose his efforts were also cautiously negative. The committee has 11 Democrats.
One of these pivotal Democrats, Senator David L. Boren of Oklahoma, said, "I think the worst thing we could do for the country is press forward with a bill that's not on a bipartisan basis." The other, Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, said the bill had too much government and too many mandates.
In the House today, the Ways and Means Committee began going over the proposal of its new acting chairman, Representative Sam M. Gibbons of Florida. His plan would provide more benefits than the Clinton plan with fewer taxes. But he said his proposal was not final because he did not yet have a cost analysis by the Congressional Budget Office. He said he did not know when he would get that analysis but would not hold any votes until he did.
In addition, a subcommittee of the House Committee on Education and Labor voted in favor of a single-payer health plan, like the Canadian system. Under this plan, payroll taxes and others would replace insurance payments, and the Government would then pay all medical and hospital bills.
A subcommittee can send as many bills as it wants to a full committee, and this subcommittee has already approved a bill patterned on Mr. Clinton's but with more generous benefits. The full Education and Labor Committee will begin discussing that bill on Friday morning.
In approving the Kennedy bill, one Republican on the Senate Labor panel, James M. Jeffords of Vermont, joined the committee's 10 Democrats. The other six Republicans on the panel voted no.
The Kennedy bill would broaden the ability of individuals to choose health insurance beyond President Clinton's plan by allowing them to enroll in the Federal Health Benefits Program, which offers a variety of options to Federal employees, including members of Congress.
It also sought to meet widespread complaints about the potential effect on small business of requiring employers to pay for insurance. It would allow employers of 10 or fewer workers not to pay for insurance, though those who employed one to five workers would have to pay a 1 percent payroll tax and those with 6 to 10 workers would pay a 2 percent tax.
Mr. Clinton's plan had no such exemptions, though it offered subsidies, as Mr. Kennedy's does, to small employers.
The Moynihan bill is initially more generous to small business and eventually tougher on them. His plan would allow employers of up to 10 workers to pay a 1 percent tax and employers of 11 to 20 workers to pay a 2 percent tax.
But it would eliminate those exemptions and require all employers to insure their workers if by 1998 this system had not resulted in the insurance of 97 percent of employees and their dependents. Mr. Moynihan would raise the standard even higher by the year 2000, requiring all employers to insure all workers if 98.5 percent of workers and dependents were not insured.
The taxes in the Moynihan proposal drew some sharp attacks. Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, the senior Republican on the Finance Committee, said, "It's a Burger King bill, a Whopper, $190 billion in taxes." He said that was "the Democrats' way out: tax and tax and spend and spend."
 
Concern About Deficit
 Mr. Moynihan expects final revenue and spending estimates from the Congressional Budget Office by late next week. But his proposal leans away from some expensive benefits and calls for more in taxes because of his fear about increasing the deficit.
All three measures are intended to reduce the soaring rate of health care costs by instituting more competition among providers. And all declare that their formulas will guarantee that all Americans have health insurance that cannot be canceled and that cannot be denied because of pre-existing medical conditions.
All three would insure people primarily through employers but would require individuals not covered either directly or as dependents to buy their own insurance. Each would offer much larger tax benefits than are now provided for such insurance and provide large subsidies for those with low incomes.
All three bills would leave the Medicare system of health care for the elderly as it is, while providing insurance under the new systems to those now covered by Medicaid, which serves the poor.
All three bills would enable states that preferred a single-payer system to adopt one for themselves.

The Clinton Plan:
 Universal health insurance coverage.
 Mandatory enrollment in regional insurance purchasing alliances.
 Employers required to pay at least 80 percent of premiums.
 Would raise cigarette tax to 99 from 25 a pack.
 
Kennedy Plan:
 Universal health insurance coverage.
 Participation in alliances is voluntary.
 Employers required to pay premiums or a payroll tax in the case of small businesses.
 Would raise cigarette tax to $1.74 a pack.
 Adds benefits to those in Clinton plan.
 
Moynihan Plan:
 Aims at universal health insurance coverage.
 Participation in alliances is voluntary.
 Employers required to pay premiums or a payroll tax in the case of small businesses.
 Would raise cigarette tax to $2 a pack.
 Overall, offers fewer benefits than Clinton plan. (pg. A1)
 
"POINT BY POINT: Comparing the Clinton, Kennedy and Moynihan Visions of Health Care"
 
BENEFITS:
 
Clinton: Basic benefit package includes doctor, hospital and emergency services; some coverage for mental health and substance abuse; prescription drugs; rehabilitation services; hospice, home health and extended nursing care services; preventive care; lab and diagnostic services.
 
Kennedy: Follows outlines of Clinton package but provides additional benefits for women, children, the disabled, low-income individuals and for mental health and substance abuse. Provides increased coverage for preventive exams and additional benefits for long term care.
 
Moynihan: Follows outlines of Clinton package with more generous mental health benefits but no coverage for long term care or prescription drugs for the elderly.
 
ALLIANCES:
 
Clinton: Most Americans would be required to get their coverage through regional insurance purchasing alliances. All firms with 5,000 or fewer employees would have to purchase coverage through an alliance.
 
Kennedy: Individuals could purchasing insurance from private insurers, participating in consumer health purchasing cooperatives established by the states or participate in the Federal Employees Health Benefits Plan, the existing plan forFederal workers.

Moynihan: Participation in alliances would be voluntary. People working for companies with fewer than 500 employees, self-employed people and those not connected to the work force could buy insurance through a cooperative. Companies with 2 to 10 workers could enroll employees in the Federal Employees Health Benefits Plan.
 
EMPLOYER MANDATE:
 
Clinton: Employers would be required to pay about 80 percent of the costs of the average health insurance plan in their area for a single person or about 55 percent of the cost of the average family plan, but no more than 7.9 percent of payroll. Companies with 75 or fewer employees and average annual wages under $24,000 a year would be eligible for subsidies. Individuals would pay up to 20 percent of the premiums.
 
Kennedy: Would exempt small businesses with 10 or fewer employees and average annual wages under $24,000 per worker. Employers of one to five workers would be required to pay a 1 percent payroll tax instead. Employers of 6 to 10 workers would pay a 2 percent tax. Employees of exempted small businesses would be required to buy their own insurance, but with very substantial subsidies. Some companies would be elibigle for subsidies based on, depending on the wages of individual workers.
 
Moynihan: All employers with more than 20 employees would have to pay at least 80 percent of the average premium for the standard health plan. Employers of 20 or fewer workers could, as an alternative, pay a payroll tax: 1 percent for companies with 1 to 10 employees and 2 percent for those with 11 to 20 employees. As in the Kennedy plan, employees of exempted small businesses would be required to buy their own insurance, but with subsidies. "Trigger" mechanism would require small employers to pay premiums if specified percentages of workers nationwide did not have coverage from employers by certain dates.
 
TAXES:
 
Clinton: Requires a 1 percent payroll tax on companies with 5,000 or more workers. Raises the current 24 cents a pack cigarette tax an additional 75 cents for a total of 99 cents.
 
Kennedy: Requires companies with 1,000 or more employees to pay a 1 percent payroll tax. Increases the cigarette tax 75 cents above the President's plan to $1.74 per pack.
 
Moynihan: Requires companies with 500 or more employees to pay a 1 percent payroll tax. Increases the cigarette tax to $2.00 a pack. Raises the current 11 percent tax on handgun ammunition to 50 percent. Imposes a new tax on health insurance premiums. (pg. A18)

HEADLINE: New York's Council Votes Plan to Build 42d St. Trolley Line

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Reviving images of urban travel from another era, the City Council approved a plan yesterday to build a trolley line along 42d Street from one side of Manhattan to the other.
Officials said the project would cut traffic, pollution and noise, encourage development on the West Side of Manhattan and add a spectacular tourist attraction to one of New York City's most congested thoroughfares. 
 The vote by the Council, the final step in the approval process, allows the Government to seek bidders for the $135 million project. Officials said that they have selected four consortiums of companies to bid on the project. The companies would lay the track, provide the cars and operate the system on a franchise basis.
The cost of the project includes $60 million in street refurbishing and replacement of water and sewer lines, which would be paid by the city. The rest of the cost would be borne by the successful bidder, whose expenses would be recouped through fares and possibly advertising revenues.
There would be no operating subsidy from the city. City officials said that if engineering studies that the Council authorized yesterday validated their cost estimates and if the expected bids materialized the rail system would open by the end of 1996.
Despite yesterday's vote, the project is still far from becoming a certainty. Engineering studies could determine that the city's cost estimates are too conservative and that the project would not be economical.
Also, prospective bidders might shy away from the project if they concluded that the city's ridership estimates -- 9 million passengers a year -- were too optimistic. And the Giuliani administration has not set aside money for the project and would need to revise its capital plan to finance the street rehabilitation.
Officials said Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was committed to the project and would seek state and Federal money to help pay the city's share.
Despite the hurdles, the vote was hailed by proponents of the rail system, primarily because it represented the last approval needed by a government body to get the project under way. The vote also authorized spending $750,000 for the engineering study to verify the cost estimates.
"It means that the West End of 42d Street will become accessible and developable," said Frederic S. Papert, president of the 42d Street Development Corporation, a private nonprofit group. "It means that New York will have the tourism attraction that the cable car has in San Francisco. It means that there will be cleaner air in midtown Manhattan. It means new life for 42d Street."
Under the plan, developed by the city's Transportation Department, a fleet of trains would travel between a terminal near the United Nations headquarters on East 42d Street and First Avenue and end at a pier at the Hudson River at West 34th Street.
 
Four Stops Planned
 The route would include four stops along 42d Street -- at Grand Central Terminal, the New York Public Library, Times Square and the Port Authority bus terminal -- and one at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center at 39th Street and 12th Avenue. Each train would accommodate up to 250 passengers -- with two cars per train in rush hours -- compared with the 75-passenger capacity of buses.
Although the rail system has come to be known as the "42d Street trolley," the fleet of 17 rail cars would more resemble sleek, futuristic subway cars with large windows. They are intended to make inaccurate the perennial complaint of crosstown travelers in midtown: that it seems to take longer to travel the 13 blocks from east to west than to travel the length of Manhattan.
Transportation Department officials say that when the project is completed, it would take 20 minutes to travel from one side of Manhattan to the other, with the trip from Grand Central to the bus terminal lasting little more than 8 minutes. Some trains would travel only between Grand Central and the bus terminal, while others would travel from one side of the island to the other.
The department said that the cost of ridership would not exceed a bus or subway ride's cost, now $1.25, and that passengers could transfer between buses to the rail system for one fare. They said they expected the system to be used by more than 9 million passengers a year, about a third of the ridership of the subway system's shuttle train linking Times Square and Grand Central Terminal.
But the construction of the rail system would permanently alter midtown traffic patterns. For example, 42d Street would become a one-way, three-lane street for westbound traffic only, with the eastbound lanes reserved for the rail system.
Transportation officials acknowledged that the adjustment of traffic would create far more severe congestion on the adjacent eastbound streets, primarily 40th Street. Officials said they were looking into increasing towing and ticketing for double-parked cars and adjusting traffic lights for greater speed.
While businesses, particularly those along 42d Street, have applauded the project, the prospect of the construction of a rail system in midtown Manhattan has been criticized by some neighborhood organizations and some public officials who fear the project could result in lengthy disruption and unnecessary costs.
While city officials conceded that there were still many hurdles before construction begins, they said they had been encouraged by the level of interest by prospective bidders.
Transportation Commissioner Elliott G. Sander said more than a dozen consortiums indicated interest in the franchise. The field was narrowed to four that the city considered most qualified to handle the project. "This administration viewed the project upon coming into office and feels very strongly about it," Mr. Sander said.

HEADLINE: Kenmore Hotel: The Place at the End of the Line

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG 

 BODY:
One old woman walks through the Kenmore Hotel and spells her name over and over, as if she is afraid of losing it somewhere down the long, dark hall. Another woman, her cheeks rouged a candy-apple red, goes from person to person in the lobby, asking people she has never seen before what they would like for dinner.
On the eighth floor, a man sits amid jumping fleas, crusted dirt and six-month-old newspapers, screaming that he should not have to live like this because he is an American. 
 Down the hall, a transvestite whose only possessions are a purple party dress and a fake fox fur with a hole in it talks about how the Kenmore is really not as bad as it looks, as the water backs up in the sink for the fifth straight day and a rat runs past a pile of garbage in the hall.
And on every floor, single mothers and families and other hard-working people are just trying to survive amid the craziness.
It is a blessing to be a little mad in the Kenmore, say some of the people who live there, held prisoner by their poverty and victimized by criminals who prosecutors say controlled whole floors of the building.
The 621-room Kenmore, a red-brick residential hotel at 145 East 23d Street, was seized by United States marshals on Wednesday under a little-used 1984 law that allows the authorities to take over a building being used in the sale of drugs. It had become a bizarre warehouse for crack dealers, prostitutes, robbers and extortionists, said both Federal investigators and people who live there. The criminals did not go outside. They worked the halls, said the residents.
"You know what I'd like to do? I'd like to live in the suburbs," said Phillip Yee, standing in one hall, his bare feet dirt encrusted. "I like the suburbs. In the suburbs, your neighbors don't light fires in the hall."
Residents said the hotel owner, Tran Din Truong, a Vietnamese immigrant who prosecutors say used the Kenmore as a "cash cow," allowed the building to fall apart, the filth to collect and the toilets to overflow, even as he allowed it to become a haven for criminals.
Rent that is considerably less than the usual Manhattan rate -- $ 200 a month for a room the size of a closet, with the bathroom down the hall, or $ 400 for a slightly bigger room -- has filled it over the years with elderly residents; poor people with physical, mental and emotional problems; welfare mothers, and others who cannot afford anything better.
"This is what I have to live in," said John Grant, 38, who sat on a bare narrow mattress in a filthy hole, five feet wide and about eight feet long. His voice became higher, shriller, as he talked. "Look at me. I'm dying in here. I'm dying."
He said he was unemployed, disabled and had lived in the Kenmore for 14 years. He does not own any pictures or keepsakes. The walls of his room are covered with yellowed newspaper photos that he likes to look at.
"It's not fair," he said, almost screaming. "It's not fair."
The Kenmore has been a rundown apartment house for as long as anyone can remember, but when the predators moved into the building and sold their drugs and stole from people who had almost nothing to give, when the prostitutes started having sex with clients in the stairwells and halls, the quality of life dipped even lower. The old people suffer most, said Kirk Mickels, 39, who lives on the 19th floor.
"Some are afraid to come out of their rooms," he said. "Some shouldn't be here. Some have mental problems. Some have health problems, and these people prey on them."
Dennis Brady, 43, studied music at Lehman College in the Bronx and once dreamed of being a concert pianist, but eviction from a building that went co-op, loss of a hotel job and injuries he suffered from being run over by a soda-delivery truck landed him in the Kenmore. He said he has neck, head and back pain, but he worries more about the old people there who may never get to live anywhere else.
His tiny room is crowded with books like "The Tibetan Book of the Dead" and "Celtic Heritage." One of his favorites is "Purity of Heart," by Kierkegaard. Kierkegaard, he said, would find hope in the lives of the people there, but he would want society to help them.
Others have lived worse than this already.
 
A Way Station
 For Mr. Mickels, 39, his little room is just a place to catch his breath.
"I've been told this is the last stop, but I don't believe that," said Mr. Mickels, bouncing his visiting 2-year-old grandson, Eric, on his knee.
Mr. Mickels moved into the $120-a-week room in March, shortly after being released from prison after serving six years for a crime he would rather not discuss.
"A lot of us make mistakes, and a lot of us recover," said Mr. Mickels, who grew up on Wyona Street in East New York.
Each morning he sweeps his room and then sweeps the hallway, he said, explaining that there has not been any janitorial service for a long time.
On the wall of his room, just to the left of an immaculate porcelain wall sink, are button-photos of Malcolm X and Marvin Gaye, and a photograph of Mr. Mickels, as an inmate, coordinating an entertainment event at Sing Sing Correctional Facility in Ossining, N.Y.
"I want to do prison counseling," said Mr. Mickels, who is in a training program run by the Fortune Society, a nonprofit organization that helps former convicts.
He said that when he leaves the Kenmore, he doesn't want to travel far from needy people, explaining that "I want to live in the ghetto. A little place. A little car. And some food in the house would be nice."
On the hotel's eighth floor, two dark rooms are joined a by a small bathroom, and for four years this suite has been home to Lonie Houng, 40, her four young children and her husband, Steven Kaplovich, 59, who makes $24,000 a year as a handyman in a Sutton Place apartment building.
The children -- Max, 5; Joey, 6; Jonathan, 9, and Juliana, 8 -- sleep on mattresses on the floor of a main room with cracked and peeling walls. The toilet does not work; water has to be poured from a bucket into the tank to flush it.
There are vermin, "lots of mice," Ms. Houng said. The family's cat, Con Mel, lies purring in a dresser drawer, asleep. He is the first line of defense, when he is awake.
"I don't mind this that much, but I feel bad for the babies. They sleep on the floor and they have asthma," Ms. Houng said. "We can survive with no problem, but they need space and they can't eat good food here. I cook on a hot plate."
Conditions at the hotel are better, in some ways, than those she left when she was brought to the United States at 14 by an American airman who became her first husband.
"There was shooting," she said of her childhood in Pleiku, where she was raised by her father, Vu Quang Trong, whom she described as "the second most famous painter in my country."
A year ago, Ms. Houng was robbed by a man in the hallway who tried to stab her. He missed when she sank to the floor, she said. "We would move," she said. "But it is hard to find people to take us with four children."
Mr. Yee said people who live in the hotel should expect life to be hard. He said people get what they pay for.
Down the hall from him, residents point to a metal exit door that has been dented several times. One resident explained that it happened when one man repeatedly clubbed another man in the head with a baseball bat but missed several times and hit the door.

HEADLINE: President to Campaign Against Teen-Age Pregnancy

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration has settled on a campaign against teen-age pregnancy that includes new restrictions on welfare payments, $400 million in grants to schools and neighborhoods over five years, and the use of the President's bully pulpit to promote responsible behavior.
Officials who outlined the plan said three-quarters of the grant money would go to a thousand needy schools, to be used for education and counseling programs. While there will be much local flexibility, the programs may be loosely patterned after an Atlanta model that promotes both abstinence and contraception and uses older students as mentors. 
 The remainder of the money would be used to create about a half-dozen larger, experimental programs to improve opportunities in distressed neighborhoods. Those programs could provide teen-agers with services as diverse as family-planning clinics and recreational activities, like midnight basketball leagues.
The strategy was developed as part of President Clinton's plan to overhaul the welfare system, which he is expected to announce as early as next week. The entire package must go before Congress, where an unbridled debate is expected and passage seems unlikely this year.
 
First Welfare, Then Work
 Mr. Clinton wants to expand training opportunities for welfare recipients, but those who are still unemployed after two years will be required to enroll in a work program. The thinking is that the time limit will make welfare less attractive and so discourage teen-agers from having children they cannot support.
The number of children being born to unwed teen-agers is a source of increasing national concern. But while Mr. Clinton is putting more oratory and money into the issue than previous Presidents, it is unclear whether his Administration has the answer.
Mr. Clinton would also require unwed mothers younger than 18 to continue to live at home, and he would raise the financial penalties on those who did not seek education and training. He would also try to discourage irresponsible sexual behavior by young men by increasing efforts to collect child-support payments.
Officials said the legislative changes would be accompanied by a public campaign to urge teen-agers to avoid pregnancy and stay in school. It would include speeches by Mr. Clinton and members of his Cabinet, and, possibly, a new, nonprofit foundation to supplement the work.
Officials from many agencies spent more than a year putting the plan together, often disagreeing about whether two decades of previous experiments could offer more than vague clues about how to proceed. The decision to spend $400 million over five years is a middle position, between calling for further experiments and proclaiming a nationwide solution.
The Secretary of Health and Human Services, Donna E. Shalala, gave an optimistic reading of the research on past programs. "We have had some successful demonstrations in this country," she said. "What they've told us is that you have to do a lot of things, not a single thing."
But an economist at the University of Pennsylvania, Rebecca Maynard, took a dimmer view, noting that some previous programs had led to higher, not lower, pregnancy rates.
"We really don't know what to do," said Ms. Maynard, who served as a consultant to the officials drafting the Clinton plan. "We've got some promising new ideas, but they're still ideas. They haven't been tested."
Teen-age pregnancy is the most troubling end of a larger national problem: the rising incidence of out-of-wedlock births at all ages. Single-parent families are much more likely than those headed by two parents to experience poverty and associated traumas like crime or drug abuse.
The problem is acute for the children of unwed parents who are themselves teen-agers. Administration officials express it as a tale of two poverty rates. About 80 percent of the children born to unwed, teen-age dropouts will live in poverty. But the figure is only 8 percent for parents who finish high school, marry and defer having children until age 20.
The number of children born to unwed teen-agers has sharply risen in recent years -- from about 250,000 in 1980 to about 357,000 a decade later. The reasons are complex and not entirely understood, but they seem to include increased sexual activity among most teen-agers and diminishing economic prospects for those in the poorest neighborhoods.
Administration officials conducted several reviews of the academic literature on teen-age pregnancy, including one review led by William Galston, a staff member of the White House Domestic Policy Council.
 
'Abstinence-Plus'
 "I came to the conclusion that we had, in fact, learned something from the previous decade," he said. "You might describe the emerging consensus as 'abstinence-plus.' "
Mr. Galston said that for teen-agers 15 or younger "the principal message has to be: don't, you're too young." For older teen-agers, he said, "the principal message is still, 'don't, but if you do, act responsibly and make sure you don't do something that harms your future.' "
Mr. Galston and other officials are impressed by the Postponing Sexual Involvement Program, which serves eighth graders in 16 Atlanta schools. The program supplements a curriculum on human sexuality with talks by high school students that encourage the postponement of sexual activity.
Marion Howard, the program's director, said the older students sometimes conduct role-playing exercises to help girls ward off unwanted sexual advances. Among the social skills that she said were being imparted was, "How to say 'no' without hurting the other person's feelings."
The program also refers sexually active teen-agers to a clinic, where they can get contraceptives.
 
Uncertain Research
 Ms. Howard said an evaluation had found that the program was delaying the onset of sexual activity by a year and was reducing pregnancies by about one-third, but she cautioned that the last finding was based on a small research sample.
But Ms. Maynard, the former Administration consultant, says such success stories are often based on imprecise research techniques and can be impossible to duplicate on a larger scale.
She helped evaluate a program called the Teen-age Parent Demonstration, which provided intensive counseling and education to 6,000 teen-age mothers in New Jersey and Illinois. She found the services had done nothing to keep the mothers from having a second child. And in Chicago, she said, the program had an effect opposite than what was intended: unwed mothers were more likely to have an additional child.
 
Opposite Effect
 Ms. Maynard speculated that in making young mothers feel more competent the program might have made them feel competent enough to raise a second child.
Under the Clinton program, the Government would choose 200 schools a year for the next five years to receive grants of about $60,000 a year. The schools would have latitude in designing their programs, but they would also have to specify the underlying scientific research.
Officials supplemented their talk of legislative details by stressing the importance of a cultural campaign to encourage responsible sexuality. A White House aide, Gene Sperling, foresaw "a wide-ranging mobilization effort, including not only Cabinet members but also outside people."
Mr. Sperling was vague about the extent of Mr. Clinton's direct involvement, but he predicted that the President would continue to make remarks like those he offered in February at Kramer Junior High School in Washington, D.C. Mr. Clinton told the students to "make up your mind you're not going to have a baby until you are old enough to take care of it, until you're married."

HEADLINE: P.L.O. Pleads for Faster Disbursement of Foreign Aid Money

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, June 9

 BODY:
The Palestine Liberation Organization is pressing for a speedier disbursement of millions of dollars pledged by foreign governments and international agencies for projects in Gaza and Jericho, asserting that it urgently needs $177 million from a Paris meeting of aid donors that will conclude on Friday.
But P.L.O. officials are resisting some donors' insistence on stringent measures to supervise the spending of the money, complaining that some of these requirements for accountability are humiliating and cumbersome. 
In a reversal of old roles, Israeli officials are joining the P.L.O. in arguing for less stringent controls. Israel has sent a high-level delegation headed by Yossi Sarid, the Environment Minister, to assist the Palestinians in the Paris talks.
The Israelis are becoming worried that lack of funds may seriously impair Palestinian efforts to begin self-government. Israel plans to complete handing over responsibility for the upkeep of public services in Jericho and Gaza in three months. This means that hospitals will no longer be supplied with medication and that electric power will be cut off if the nascent Palestinian National Authority fails to make payments for power to the Israeli Government.
 
A Growing Police Force
 P.L.O. officials here said the immediate infusion of at least $100 million this month is necessary to pay the salaries of a steadily growing police force whose numbers are approaching 7,000, and to fix sewers, supply hospitals with medication and pay teachers.
Foreign donors had pledged some $2.4 billion in financial aid to the Palestinians, but the mechanisms for disbursing these sums have yet to be clarified. So far, only $7 million, from the United States and Norway, has reached Palestinian hands.
Much of this money has already gone to pay overdue salaries of the Palestinian police staff, most of whose members had not been paid for more than seven months before arriving in Gaza and Jericho last month.
"The money is the carrot for signing the peace agreement with Israel," said Hassan Abu Libdah, deputy chairman of the Palestinian Economic Council for Development and Reconstruction, which is the agency in charge of receiving and spending financial aid in the autonomous regions. "We have signed. Yet all we hear now is demands for accounting before we even get more funds. It's like being considered guilty before the trial. Let us have the funds and we will account for them."
 
Palestinians' Cash Needs
 According to agency figures, the P.L.O. estimates that it will need $381 million this year to launch the self-rule process. Palestinian officials said they expect to raise $204 million of this sum from taxes and various fees collected in Jericho and Gaza.
In an effort to show that they are serious about tax and bill collection, P.L.O. officials began to distribute leaflets in Gaza on Wednesday warning that electricity will be cut off to Palestinians who fail to pay their bills. But even if they meet their target in tax collection, Palestinian officials say they will face a steep deficit.
"We will have a deficit of $177 million, and without securing it we can't build new administrations or pay the police force or employees," said Ahmed Qurei, the P.L.O.'s newly appointed finance minister. Mr. Qurei is responsible for negotiating most of the economic agreements with Israel related to the peace treaty signed in Cairo on May 4.
 
Donors Meet in Paris
 Representatives of foreign donors, which include the United States, the European Union, Japan, Saudi Arabia, Norway, the World Bank and other parties, began meeting in Paris today to discuss the difficulties blocking the flow of money.
Most donors seem to favor well-planned projects and some accountability -- procedures which the P.L.O. describes both as delaying tactics and an unwarranted intrusion.
"I can understand that donors are concerned about how their funds will be spent, but their conditions are humiliating because no Palestinian official will go begging to donors each month and tell them, 'Please pay my employees' salaries,' " Mr. Qurei said recently.

HEADLINE: NATO Rebuffs the Russians On Role in Decision-Making

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 9

 BODY:
NATO decided today to pay special attention to Russia because of its history and military strength, but it rejected Moscow's demand for a voice in NATO decision-making.
In agreeing to join the American-inspired Partnership for Peace program, which offers a sort of junior partnership to members of the former Warsaw Pact, Russia had hoped that it could have a special formal relationship with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization that was on a higher level from that of smaller countries. 
 At a meeting with NATO defense ministers in Brussels last month, Defense Minister Pavel S. Grachev of Russia called for a "full-blooded strategic relationship" with NATO that would go beyond the "partnership" framework to enhance military cooperation with its former enemies, and a separate document formalizing that special relationship.
He said at the time that Russia's status as Europe's largest nuclear power required a broader "consultative mechanism" with NATO that would involve nuclear disarmament, peacekeeping missions, conversion of military industries and dealing with global threats like terrorism and environmental pollution.
But the NATO communique today and statements by NATO officials and foreign ministers made clear that that would not be the case. They also assured the rest of Eastern and Central Europe that NATO's enhanced cooperation with Moscow would not signal a 1990's version of the 1945 Yalta accord, which led to the division of the Continent.
 
No 'New Dividing Lines'
 "We will not draw new dividing lines across Europe nor engage in a NATO-Russian condominium," the Deputy Secretary General of NATO, Sergio Balanzino, told reporters after today's meetings. "No country can hold a droit de regard over NATO," he added, meaning that no outsider could veto a NATO policy or decision.
A number of ministers went out of their way to speak of cooperation, not confrontation, with Moscow. "No vetoes, no surprises, substantial cooperation," Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd of Britain told reporters in explaining the relationship that NATO envisions with Moscow. By that, he said, he meant that Russia would not be allowed to veto NATO decisions, that NATO would not spring surprises on Moscow and that both sides would work to increase cooperation.
But Mr. Hurd also made clear that NATO did not believe that there was a need for "an extra document accorded to Russia and not to others."
In a speech to NATO and in remarks to reporters, Secretary of State Warren Christopher also stressed the positive, welcoming Russia's new role in NATO and laying out specific areas in which Russia would cooperate in a unique way with the Western alliance.
"Russia's size, broad interests, resources and military capabilities provide the basis for a productive relationship with NATO in addition to the Partnership for Peace," Mr. Christopher said. He added that the safe dismantlement of nuclear weapons and nonproliferation strategies would be natural areas for cooperation.
Mr. Grachev pledged in Brussels last month that Russia would join the partnership plan, and NATO members are eager for Russian leaders to sign onto it as soon as possible. Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev of Russia is certain to be asked his country's intentions in meetings between NATO and the former Warsaw Pact members on Friday.
 
A Face-Saving Way Out
 But Mr. Christopher offered his Russian counterpart a face-saving way out of committing his country to a date certain on Friday, telling reporters that it would be natural for Mr. Kozyrev to want to consult with the leadership back home first.
On the war in Bosnia, Mr. Christopher told reporters that the United States could support the lifting of economic sanctions against the Serbs if they were to accept a peace settlement in Bosnia and the Bosnian Muslim Government was to reject it. From the very beginning, he said, it was understood under a current plan that "if the Serbian government agrees on a settlement and acts upon it, then there could be a contemplation of the lifting of sanctions." He added, "There's nothing new about that at all."
Mr. Christopher would not be drawn into a discussion of whether the United States would resuscitate its plan to arm the Bosnian Muslims if they agreed to a peace plan but the Serbs rejected it.
In a meeting with French leaders in Paris on Tuesday, President Clinton said that there would be negative consequences for the party that did not embrace the emerging plan, adding that consideration would have to be given to lifting economic sanctions against the Serbs if they accepted peace, but the Bosnian Muslims rejected it.

HEADLINE: North Korea Threatens Japan Over Backing U.S.-Led Sanctions

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 9

 BODY:
North Korea threatened today to mete out a "deserving punishment" to Japan if it cuts off the North's chief source of hard currency or joins in other economic sanctions, apparently in an effort to intimidate its wealthy neighbor from participating in an American-led effort to force the North to accept nuclear inspections.
North Korean officials have denounced Japan before and have accused it of harboring plans to build nuclear weapons of its own. But this appeared to be the first time that the North threatened to target Japan if it joined the movement for sanctions in the United Nations. 
 Japanese officials have said in the past that North Korea does not have the military ability to pose a direct threat to the country, apart from its experimental Rodong-1 missile, which may be able to strike Osaka and Western Japan. But they fear that North Korean agents living in the large Korean community here could easily disrupt cities or perform acts of terrorism.
If Japan should "join force in any sanctions against us," the North said in a statement monitored in Tokyo, "we would regard it as a declaration of war and Japan would be unable to avoid a deserving punishment for it."
While such language is common from the North these days, the Japanese Government has done little to prepare the public for the possibility that a confrontation could develop, and officials clearly fear that the North's attempt to rattle the country could work.
 
Monitoring Troop Movements
 In Seoul today the South Korean Defense Minister, Rhee Byong Tae, told the Parliament that the United States and the South Korean military had stepped up its reconnaissance efforts to monitor troop movements in the North. He said that while there had been no unusual activity, the North has stockpiled extensive supplies and deployed a number of new weapons systems just north of the Demilitarized Zone.
In recent days Japan has been arguing to slow the sanctions efforts somewhat, and to give North Korea another warning about opening its nuclear installations.
Officials here are wary of a quick cut-off of the $600 million to $1.8 billion that intelligence agencies say is funneled to the North's Government every year by Korean residents in Japan. That sanction, they argue, should come later because it would have a devastating effect on ordinary citizens in the North.
The Japanese Foreign Minister, Koji Kakizawa, warned the Parliament today that "we must avoid remarks that might incite North Korea." His aides said Mr. Kakizawa was growing increasingly concerned that the allies could talk themselves into a conflict with the North.
 
China Opposes Sanctions
 The North Korean warning came as China told the South Korean Foreign Minister, Han Sung Joo, that it was not ready to join a sanctions resolution at the United Nations.
"We are not in favor of the involvement of the United Nations Security Council in this issue," the spokesman for the Chinese Foreign Ministry, Shen Guofang, said today. "We do not agree on sanctions, because sanctions will only serve to push the parties concerned into confrontation with one another and result in a situation no one wants to see."
It was unclear, however, whether China would veto any sanctions effort in the Security Council or simply abstain. Mr. Han said little as he emerged from the meeting.
Administration officials have said in recent weeks that if they could not get a sanctions resolution through the Security Council, they would attempt to organize informal sanctions with Japan and South Korea. However, that would do little to cut off oil and other vital supplies that the North imports across the Chinese border.
