HEADLINE: Tokyo Journal;
How Do Japan's Rulers Approach U.S.? Carefully

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 9

 BODY:
There is nothing simple about sending the Emperor of Japan on a two-week tour, especially when the destination is America.
So much can go wrong -- just ask the bureaucrats who thought it would be a nice touch to send the royal couple to Pearl Harbor until someone thought better of it -- and there are so many uncomfortable issues to be neatly sidestepped, like a $60 billion trade surplus. 
 So it is no wonder that after five decades of intensive training and five years on the job as symbol of the state, Emperor Akihito, 60, is the master of innocuous conversation. But that makes it all the more remarkable that the middle-aged couple who arrive in the United States on Friday have managed to breathe a bit of new life into a 1,600-year-old monarchy that, as Emperor Hirohito might have put it, was not necessarily developing to Japan's advantage.
Japan's leaders have never failed to mold the Emperor to fit the current needs of the state -- Hirohito was transformed from a uniformed military leader on a white horse to a quiet biologist -- and the 11-city tour gives them a chance to do it anew.
And while the Government protests that everything the Emperor does is apolitical, no one denies that the mission to America is part of a grander scheme to portray Japan as something more than a source of Walkmans and economic heartache.
It doesn't hurt that this is the first royal couple in two millenniums who might actually enjoy a tour of Monticello, a weekend in the Rocky Mountains or a few innings at the Cardinals-Pirates game in St. Louis. All three are on the whirlwind schedule.
The image-makers have been so busy that suddenly imperial candor and a public sharing of pain -- within carefully defined limits, of course -- are suddenly permissible. To the astonishment of the Japanese press, Empress Michiko, who is 59, did the unthinkable last week: she talked about the mysterious illness, presumed to be some kind of nervous breakdown, that left her unable to speak last fall.
"The worry and sadness of having lost my speech grew bigger and bigger each day," she said at a news conference, speaking in a weak but clearly audible voice. Though she made no direct reference to a spate of critical magazine articles about her that many believe triggered her illness, she offered this tidbit of introspection, "My heart, weary and sad at the time I was taken ill, had become hard and fragile, for which I now blame myself."
By British tabloid standards, this may hardly seem like hot stuff, but it has its appeal in Japan. Michiko is the subject of considerable sympathy, and her critics have been stunned into silence. Instead, the weekly gossip magazines are filled with speculation over when Crown Princess Masako, a graduate of Harvard and then a diplomat, will provide the country with a future Emperor. (Twice the press has declared her pregnant, so far incorrectly.)
But new and youthful as the imagery may be, Akihito is still dogged by the war that was launched in his father's name. He has spent much of the last five years on an "apology tour" of the region, including the first visit of a Japanese monarch to China. He has swung down through Southeast Asia, and even went to mend fences with the residents of Okinawa, the only Japanese territory invaded in World War II.
"These were training missions," a Japanese diplomat joked the other day. "America's the big leagues."
Since nothing is done lightly in the palace, the Emperor has spent weeks boning up on contemporary America. There have been briefings on social issues, delving into everything from health care to gun control. There was lunch with former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, now the American Ambassador here. Japanese business executives were called in to talk trade -- within limits. One of Japan's most prominent executives confessed the other night that if the discussion ever ventured into something mildly controversial "His Majesty skillfully moved on to another topic."
A small group of American reporters was even invited for a no-quotations-please audience over coffee at which the Emperor and Empress chatted about their lives and inquired about the United States while legions of nervous aides circled.
It is within the bounds of the ground rules to say that the Emperor expressed his understanding that two countries as big as America and Japan will go through a lot of ups and downs; he is looking forward to seeing if squirrels still populate the parks of Washington, and he was amazed, during a trip through the Rocky Mountains years ago, that his limousine drove for hours without passing more than a handful of people. Try that in Japan, he said.
Anything beyond such chitchat, though, is left to the hands of the professionals in the Foreign Ministry, who script every word and calibrate every expression of regret. They were the ones, it turned out, who created a miniature crisis here before the Emperor was even packed.
It arose when someone decided to send the Emperor to Honolulu to meet Japanese-Americans. How could he go to Honolulu without stopping off at the memorial over the sunken U.S.S. Arizona?
There was anguish and hand-wringing and consultations and finally a decision that the visit would simply raise anew all the old questions about war responsibility. After fumbling for official explanations, a few officials explained that if the Emperor visited Pearl Harbor this year, the Japanese right wing would bring enormous pressure on the Government to send him next year, the 50th anniversary of the end of the war, to Yaskuni Shrine, where the Japanese heroes of the war are enshrined. And that would not do.
If the Emperor himself has thoughts on this he is, as always, keeping his own counsel. "In World War II, many lives were lost, many people were wounded and many people suffered," he wrote recently, neatly ducking a written question about whether Japan should keep apologizing for events that happened half a century ago. "My heart grieves deeply because of this."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Imperial candor, within limits, has suddenly become permissible in Japan. At a news conference with her husband, Empress Michiko even talked about the mysterious illness that left her unable to speak last fall. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Everything's Coming Up Vanilla

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
Vanilla is no longer plain vanilla.
Suddenly this age-old, ho-hum flavoring is a hot marketing concept. Women are spraying it on as perfume, bathing in it and using it as a lip gloss. Men will soon be sampling vanilla cologne. Makers of cake frosting, flavored coffee and ice cream say every new vanilla offering these days becomes an instant best seller. Food companies are using vanilla to put some zest in low-fat dairy desserts. And a recent study of patients undergoing tests at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York praised vanilla's scent as soothing -- especially while undergoing magnetic resonance imaging. 
 "Vanilla is the scent of the moment," said Annette Green, president of the Fragrance Foundation, a nonprofit group in New York that sniffs out scent trends.
"It's the new musk," she said, referring to the fragrance blockbuster of two decades ago. In the scent world, she added, "vanilla is the first dominant element to come out of the kitchen, and that makes it almost revolutionary." As cosmetics executives put it, vanilla makes the big "smell impression."
Vanilla, which some food historians believe was first brought to the United States by Thomas Jefferson, has long been an important ingredient in food and fragrance. So how can a flavoring so old be perceived as new?
Vanilla "evokes memories of home and hearth, warmth and cuddling," said Susan Rosenthal, director of marketing at International Flavors and Fragrances, the world's largest scent and taste purveyor.
In September, Coty Inc. introduced Vanilla Fields cologne spray mist for women and rang up $25 million in retail sales in four months. Kmart discount stores started marketing it last fall and it has become the retailer's most popular fragrance. "Manufacturers see vanilla as a trend, and a lot of them are coming to us with vanilla scents," said Lorraine Boyle, co-buyer for the Kmart Corporation in Troy, Mich.
In August, Coty plans to introduce yet another vanilla fragrance. "We thought, why not put vanilla and musk together?" said Mary Manning, vice president of market development. Thus, Vanilla Musk was born.
At the Bonne Bell Company, vanilla has been added to its line of Smacker and Lip Smacker glosses and the company has introduced a new scent, Vanilla Blossom Fragrance, as well as Vanilla Vibes shower and bath gels. "We're going to see tons of activity with vanilla in the next six months," said Jess Bell Jr., vice president for marketing.
And next fall, a big competitor will be a scent called French Vanilla from Parfums Parquet, a division of Houbigant Inc. of Ridgefield, N.J. "We've used vanilla before now, to give fragrances warmth, sensuousness and buttery softness," said Gene Folkers, the division's vice president of marketing. "But this is the first time we're giving vanilla star status." French Vanilla will debut in October with a $5 million ad campaign.
 Vanilla scents are even doing well at the pricey peak of the fragrance market. Thierry Mugler, a French designer, reports brisk sales of "Angel," a vanilla-scented perfume priced at $150 for a 75-milliliter star-shaped blue bottle.
 
 
Hold the Flowers
 Although some shoppers reject vanilla is too sweet and cloying, others prefer vanilla scents "because they're not too flowery," said Jeaneane Judelson, an event coordinator for the Pediatric AIDS Foundation in New York. For three months she has been wearing Chopard Casmir, a vanilla-based scent sold at Saks Fifth Avenue stores. "I've never been a person who liked floral fragrances," she said, "and now we have these alternatives."
Vanilla is also an important constituent of three new fragrances for men: the just-released Samba Nova Homme from Perfumer's Workshop in New York; the soon-to-be marketed Nicole Miller for Men, made by Riviera Concepts of Toronto, and Cassini for Men, scheduled for introduction in the fall by Cassini Parfums.
The vanilla boom is not entirely natural. Different products may use real beans, pure vanilla extract and vanillin -- often a less expensive, artificial version used in scents and some baking confections -- or some combination of ingredients. Frequently, Government food labeling standards dictate which can be used. Also, "all natural" marketing considerations or lower-cost generic brands may prompt food companies to choose different forms of vanilla.
David Gilman, a spokesman for Haagen-Dazs, the ice cream company, said that depending on cost and labeling strategies, the tendency was "to use the real beans, because customers can taste the difference."
Imports of beans, principally from Indonesia and Madagascar, have not shown noticeable growth, but Mark Mitchell, a product manager for vanilla extract at McCormick & Company, the big spice producer, said McCormick's extract sales were running ahead of overall food industry growth this year, mostly because of the growing use of vanilla in reduced-fat foods.
"We're using vanilla to mask 'off-notes' in food when you pull fat out," he said. "That is a big area of work for us, creating customized vanilla flavors and extracts for reduced-fat food products."
 
 
A 'Less Frenzied' Flavor
 Andrew Shore, an analyst who follows the cosmetics and food industries for Paine Webber Inc., said: "It's making a surge in coffee and other foods. Vanilla is clean, it's pure, and perhaps it reflects America's yearning for a return to a less frenzied past."
Social science provides some evidence that vanilla has calming qualities. A research study of 85 patients at Memorial Sloan-Kettering who were undergoing magnetic-resonance-imaging testing found that a sweet vanilla scent reduced their anxiety and lowered their stress. Sixty-five percent of the patients described the scent as relaxing, pleasant and soothing.
In the scent world, at least, the very notion that vanilla could be newly popular is something of an import. "We knew vanilla scents were selling well in Europe, and we thought they could work here," said Mr. Bell of Bonne Bell. Houbigant also enjoyed success in Europe with a vanilla fragrance, and on the strength of that introduced the fragrance in the United States, said Mr. Folkers of Parfums Parquet.
But in the world of coffee, ice cream and cake frosting, the vanilla boom seems to be a function of strong demand, as well as vanilla's status as the substitute of choice for makers of low-fat desserts seeking a tasty fat replacement that also masks the taste of diet-food ingredients.
 
 
Scoop of the Decade
 At Haagen-Dazs, which is owned by Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. of Britain, sales of vanilla ice creams soared to $37 million last year, from $27 million in 1990, a company spokesman said, and in April, sales of its vanilla flavors were up 6.7 percent from a year earlier. In August, Haagen-Dazs plans to introduce Brownies a la Mode, a vanilla flavor mixed with chunks of brownies.
Vanilla, already a leading ingredient of cola, cream soda and other beverages, is enjoying new success as a flavoring in coffee. "Vanilla has never been more in demand, and its popularity is growing," said Ted R. Lingle, executive director of the Specialty Coffee Association of America in Long Beach, Calif., a trade group of 1,600 premium coffee companies.
In its first comprehensive survey of retailers in March, hazelnut, a blend of vanilla and a nutlike flavor, accounted for 44.7 percent of flavored-coffee sales, far ahead of any other flavor category.
Six months ago, Maxwell House Instant Cappuccino added a vanilla flavor to its product line, and it has already become the best-selling flavor, said a spokeswoman for General Foods U.S.A., a unit of Philip Morris. Three years ago General Foods International Coffees introduced French Vanilla Cafe to its line of 12 other flavored coffees, and it has become the line's best seller.
 The popularity of vanilla has extended to cake mixes and frostings as well. "Recently we've seen a growth and segmentation of the lighter-colored flavors, where vanilla is a major constituent," said Matthew Smith, marketing manager of Pillsbury dessert mixes for Grand Metropolitan.
Eighteen months ago, Pillsbury introduced a number of vanilla flavors (including French Vanilla, Golden Vanilla and Vanilla With Fudge) in its Pillsbury Plus line of frostings and cake mixes, "and all of them shot into the top third of the cake-mix market," he said.
But beyond the new vanilla worship, why has the flavoring had such enduring popularity?
"As a species we are naturally sweet-loving, probably harking back to memories of mother's milk," said Sarah Friend, vice president and director of fragrance evaluation for International Flavors and Fragrances. "Right now consumers are confused and frightened, thanks to these economic times, and they're returning to flavors and fragrances that are comforting and familiar.
"The trend is, 'Hey, let's get back to basics here.' You can even see it in the movies, with the return of 'The Flintstones,' and on Broadway, with all those revivals."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Helping to satisfy the public's new craving for all things vanilla, workers in the research and development labs of Benckiser Cosmetics, in Morris Plains, N.J., prepared samples of Coty's Vanilla Fields fragrance. (Norman Y. Lono for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: F.C.C. Opens Airwaves To Fierce Competition

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
In opening up a big portion of the airwaves for new wireless telephone and data services, the Federal Communications Commission set the stage today for a fierce technological competition to serve people on the go.
While the conventional wisdom holds that wireless communications will be increasingly popular for some time, that hardly means that every market participant will succeed. 
 Each of three competing approaches for delivering wireless telephone and data services has different strengths and weaknesses.
One approach is the traditional cellular systems. With about 16 million customers, these companies have a huge head start on their rivals and are growing rapidly and installing new technology to compete with newer entrants. In this camp is the AT&T Corporation, which has agreed to buy the nation's biggest cellular company, McCaw Cellular Communications, for $12.6 billion.
 
Digital Technology Used
 The second technology, not far behind cellular, is "specialized mobile radio" carriers, which use new digital technology to transform frequencies reserved for taxi and truck dispatch services into cellular telephone and data networks. Nextel Communications, a small New Jersey company, has won licenses covering areas with 180 million people and teamed up with MCI Communications to develop a nationwide network.
The third technology, to be adopted by the newest group of contenders, will use the radio frequencies now being opened by the F.C.C. The new frequencies offer more than twice as much capacity as today's cellular telephone systems, and the new entrants will be able to start with the newest digital technology.
AT&T executives have said they are still interested in the new frequencies that the F.C.C. is opening up, but they are gambling that being in the market early is the most important criterion for success.
In its action today, the F.C.C. decided to auction off three big new licenses in every market; each will cover radio frequencies totaling 30 megahertz, or slightly more than a standard cellular telephone license. It will also auction off three smaller licenses for 10 megahertz, which can be used individually or in combination with other licenses.
The commission also decided to let cellular companies acquire up to 10 megahertz inside their current operation territories, and an additional 5 megahertz in the year 2000.
 
Success Not Assured
 Success is hardly assured. The new systems will cost billions of dollars to build, will not be operational in less than two years and will have to compete against the well established cellular industry.
Reed E. Hundt, the F.C.C.'s chairman, emphasized that the commission was setting few guidelines about how the frequencies can be used and was primarily interested in creating a "level playing field."
"This is the first time that any country has committed itself to vigorous competition in a communications industry from Day One," Mr. Hundt said. "This means there will very likely be winners and losers, and lots of mixed results. But the guarantee I would give is that the economy will be the winner, and the consumers will be the winner."
Industry analysts predict that the biggest bidders for the new frequencies will AT&T and the regional Bell companies, which will seek to expand the reach of their cellular services.
Through McCaw, for example, AT&T will have licenses that reach only about 65 million people, or 35 percent of the United States population. Likewise, Baby Bell companies like Bell Atlantic and U S West have made it clear that they want to expand outside their territories.
The trick will be picking markets that can sustain as many as six competing services, and figuring out what to bid for the licenses.
"I'm not convinced that every market will support three or four or five players," said Lawrence T. Babbio, chief operating officer of the Bell Atlantic Corporation. "We have to look at those markets where we think the demographics lend thesmelves to three or four players."
Mark Lowenstein, director of wireless research at the Yankee Group, predicted that consumers would be confused at first by the cacophony of services, but that the contenders would ultimately target certain segments, such as budget-conscious consumers or business customers.
"I don't think any one of them will predominate," he said. "Over time, it will become clear to the user which one will be most appropriate."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A fierce technological competition is expected in wireless communications. Reed E. Hundt, the F.C.C.'s chairman, wore a prototype of AT&T's wristwatch telephone in Washington yesterday. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New York Officials Welcome Immigrants, Legal or Illegal

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG 

 BODY:
While political leaders across the country talk loudly about illegal immigrants as a costly burden, the two most prominent politicians in New York go so far as to describe them as a boon.
This week, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo quietly decided against suing the Federal Government to recover the costs of social services to illegal immigrants, rejecting for now a tactic chosen by Florida, California and Texas. He opted instead to negotiate with the Clinton Administration for reimbursement. He thus avoided a public debate that would put Mr. Cuomo, long a champion of immigrants, in the awkward position of portraying some as a drain on society. 
 "I want to negotiate with the Government instead for a lot of reasons," Mr. Cuomo said yesterday in an interview. "And one of them is, frankly, that when you bring a lawsuit on this issue, it sends out the wrong message. I love immigrants. Legal, illegal -- they're not to be despised."
Last week, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuiliani gave an even more spirited defense of illegal immigrants, virtually urging them to settle in New York City. Standing before television cameras, he criticized the growing hostility toward illegal immigrants across the country as simplistic and unsophisticated.
"Some of the hardest-working and most productive people in this city are undocumented aliens," Mr. Giuliani said. "If you come here and you work hard and you happen to be in an undocumented status, you're one of the people who we want in this city. You're somebody that we want to protect, and we want you to get out from under what is often a life of being like a fugitive, which is really unfair."
The politics of immigration is different in New York. Immigration and burden are two words that do not appear often -- or without raising a furor -- in the same sentence. Whatever their legal status, immigrants are considered a fact of life, a point of pride and an integral part of New York City's identity. Many New Yorkers know well that their own forebears arrived without papers.
"So many of the Irish, so many of the Italians who came when my parents came, were technically illegal," Mr. Cuomo said.
Because of New York City's size, new immigrants are absorbed without as much fuss as elsewhere. Often, they are responsible for revitalizing dying neighborhoods -- like Crown Heights in Brooklyn and Flushing, Queens -- and New Yorkers know it.
Illegal immigrants in New York City confound the national stereotype of a young Mexican man sneaking across the border. Italians are the largest group, followed by Ecuadoreans, Poles, Dominicans and Trinidadians. European, Caribbean, Latin American and Asian, they blend into the city without radically altering its racial and ethnic makeup. So the racism that often compounds anti-immigrant sentiment is not as stark in New York.
And against the backdrop of such tolerance, it does not jibe with the image of a New York politician, Democrat or Republican, to speak too long or too loudly about immigrants as a drag -- unless the immigrants are convicted felons.
Florida's lawsuit, announced by Gov. Lawton Chiles in a March news conference on the sand in Key Biscayne, describes a "virtual 'invasion' of the state of Florida by aliens." Such loaded language is anathema in New York.
 
No Lament on the Beach
 "You won't see Mario Cuomo standing on the beach in Far Rockaway and evoking images of how vulnerable New York is," said Frank Sharry, director of the National Immigration Forum, a national advocacy group in Washington. "That just doesn't play."
Governor Chiles, a Democrat, filed suit on April 11 to recoup $1 billion that Florida calculates it spends on social services for illegal immigrants. Gov. Pete Wilson of California, a Republican, sued the Federal Government on April 30 for $2 billion to cover the cost of jailing illegal immigrants, and promised further suits on other costs.
Both Governors are running for re-election, and evidently believe that voters want them to stand tough on illegal immigration. For Mr. Wilson, the denial of all services and rights to illegal immigrants is central to his campaign.
Mr. Cuomo, who is also up for re-election, first weighed joining Florida's suit, which is so broad as to combine the costs of legal and illegal immigrants. He also considered a separate suit by New York State, estimating the cost to New York at $1 billion, largely for the education of immigrant children. But at the same time, he began pressuring the Clinton Administration to help the states.
 
'Anti-Immigrant Rhetoric'
 In April, the Administration asked Congress to appropriate $350 million to compensate states for the cost of incarcerating illegal-immigrant felons. After that, Mr. Cuomo postponed his plans for a lawsuit.
"I'm sure Governor Cuomo is reluctant to use a tactic made famous by the inflammatory anti-immigrant rhetoric of Pete Wilson -- even if he agrees with the objective of having the Federal Government assist the high-immigrant states," said Lucas Guttentag, director of the Immigrants' Rights Project for the American Civil Liberties Union.
There are 3.85 million illegal immigrants in the country, according to Robert Warren, chief of statistics for the Immigration and Naturalization Service. California has the greatest number, with about 1.6 million. New York is a distant second, with 510,000, followed by Texas, with 405,000, and Florida, with 373,000.
No one knows just what illegal immigrants cost states. Immigration experts criticize the states' estimates as one-sided fiscal calculations that ignore illegal immigrants' economic contributions. Many are taxpayers; most are customers; some are even entrepreneurs.
 
All Americans Cost More
 The states' estimates also focus on immigrants who have just arrived in this country, which gives a misleading picture of their lifetime contribution. Over time, many illegal immigrants become legal, earn more money and pay more taxes. The average household income of legal immigrants surpasses that of natives after 10 years in this country, according to a recent study by the Urban Institute.
Still, illegal immigrants do cost the states money, as do native-born Americans. Americans happen to cost more than they pay in taxes. Most of the illegal immigrants' cost lies in education for their children, followed by emergency medical care and prison costs. Texas, which plans to sue the Federal Government soon, is the only state that subtracted estimated tax payments from its cost calculations. Texas estimates that illegal immigrants contribute $290 million to the state and cost $456 million.
Even in New York, a state that frowns on portraying immigrants negatively, it is more than acceptable to talk about illegal-immigrant felons as a burden.
But even on this issue, New York, for the moment, does not go as far as California and Florida. It wants the Federal Government to pay the cost of illegal immigrants who have served their sentences but linger in state prisons awaiting deportation.
 
U.S. Speeds Deportations
 New York State sued the Federal Government in 1992 to force it to take custody of those ex-convicts, and a Federal judge ordered New York to keep housing them.
But the Justice Department, in a pilot program with New York, has recently started expediting deportations. In the program's first eight weeks, 180 orders of deportation have been issued to illegal-immigrant prisoners compared with 270 in all 1992. It is a sign that the Administration is prepared to work with the states, Mr. Cuomo said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Steady as Traders Await Report on Prices

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Bond prices ended with little change yesterday as traders awaited today's Government report on producer prices in May.
The Treasury's 30-year bond rose 1/32 of a point, or 31 cents per $1,000 bond, while the yield remained unchanged at 7.27 percent. 
 The 10-year Treasury note was also unchanged, at 6.95 percent, and intermediate- and short-term Treasury issues showed little change.
Some bond traders are nervous that the Labor Department's report on its Producer Price Index may show signs of accelerating inflation. In a survey, economists expect the May producer prices report to show an overall increase of one-tenth of 1 percent. They expect an increase of three-tenths of 1 percent when volatile food and energy sectors are excluded.
 
Looking at the Fed
 A higher-than-expected rise in the Producer Price Index would probably revive the bond market's concerns that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates once more to restrain inflation.
The Fed has pushed up short-term interest rates four times this year to restrain the inflationary pressures on the economy.
Adding to the concerns was a comment by Lawrence B. Lindsey, a governor of the Federal Reserve Board, who was quoted in news reports as saying that the difference between the inflation rate and the Federal funds rate on overnight bank loans was at a historic low.
Consumer prices in the 12 months ended in April rose 2.4 percent, down from 2.7 percent a year earlier. The Federal funds rate is about 4.25 percent. The difference between the two is 1.85 percentage points, compared with an average spread of 2.65 points since January 1985.
Mr. Lindsey's statement suggests the Fed is not done raising rates, said Neil DeSarno, the head United States bond trader at S. G. Warburg & Company. "It doesn't sound bullish," he said. "There's a possibility we could return to the bear market we've been accustomed to the last four months."
Michael Krauss, chief fixed-income technical analyst at Lehman Brothers, said a drop in the open interest in bond futures contracts, even as prices rose during the last week, suggested that the bond market was prone to fall. Open interest measures the total number of contracts outstanding.
Declining open interest "means money is flowing out of the marketplace on up moves," Mr. Krauss said.
In the corporate market, Ontario sold $1 billion of global bonds amid demand for a growing number of new issues.
Demand for Ontario's bonds was greater than expected, money managers said. The 10-year issue was priced to yield 7.625 percent, or 67 basis points more than the Treasury's 10-year bond.
The Ontario bonds were expected to yield as much as 70 basis points more than the Treasury bond. "There was more interest than expected" in the offering, which was sold simultaneously in the United States and overseas, said Bruce Masters, who helps manage about $7 billion at the Great Western Life Insurance Company.

HEADLINE: Europe, Not Japan, Is Called America's Frontier for Trade

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
Since taking office, the Clinton Administration's message to American business has been unambiguous: "Follow the Sun." At every opportunity the Clinton team has described the Asia-Pacific region as the nation's most lucrative economic frontier. But a new study published today challenges that thesis, by amassing trade data that suggest that Europe remains America's most important economic partner and will be for years to come.
The Economic Strategy Institute, a private research group financed by American corporations, compared Asia and Western Europe in categories like trade, foreign direct investment in the United States, American direct investment abroad and technology transfers. The study concluded that the links between the United States and Europe benefited the American economy far more than those between the United States and Asia. 
 The study argues that America has much more balanced trade with Europe, and more mutually beneficial commerce, because the two markets have basically similar models of capitalism. By contrast, Japan and the other Asian nations have capitalist systems that differ greatly from that of the United States in terms of corporate structure, antitrust rules and government-business relations. This produces "highly skewed flows of goods, capital and technology," the study said.
Such conclusions will fuel the already heated debate on this subject between traditional economists and revisionists. The revisionists argue that while the Asians practice capitalism, they practice a distinctly Asian brand that makes their markets more difficult to penetrate. The conventional wisdom within the economics profession is that "capitalism is capitalism is capitalism," and therefore discrepancies in trade and investment flows between regions have more to do with basic economics -- such as the relative saving and investment rates -- and not culturally based variations in market systems.
A communality of interest has been lost during the recent, often rancorous negotiations between the United States and Europe over the new global trading rules for the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The relatively minor disputes over agriculture subsidies, airplane subsidies and movies soured both sides.
"Critics might say, 'Well, even if Europe has been important to us in the past, it won't be in the future, given the dynamism in Asia,' " said Clyde Prestowitz Jr., the institute's president and co-author of the study. "To which I would say two things: One, that may be true but the future isn't here yet. Two, in order to best take advantage of the opportunities in Asia we should be cooperating with the Europeans instead of fighting with them."
The numbers cited by the study seem to justify that conclusion:
*Although the United States exports more to Asia than to Europe, it imports even more from Asia, even though the dollar since 1985 has steadily fallen in value against the major Asian currencies. As a result, Asia accounts for nearly 75 percent of America's $1.25 trillion in cumulative trade deficits since 1980. Over this period, American-European trade has been roughly in balance and highly sensitive to exchange-rate fluctuations. In many of these years the United States has run a surplus with Europe.
*In terms of quality of trade, since the mid-1980's the United States has maintained a modest trade surplus with the European Union in the area of manufactured goods. However, the United States has consistently run a large deficit in the trade of manufactured goods with Asia. There is a pronounced tendency for America to export raw materials to Asia and import manufactured products from it.
*In 1990, the latest year for which comparative statistics are available, European-owned companies employed 2.9 million workers in the United States -- 62 percent of the total for all foreign countries in this country. American employees of Asian-owned companies represented only about 20 percent of this total. The report said monthly wages for American workers at European-owned companies were 18.8 percent above the national average, largely because 70 percent of European direct investment in the United States is in manufacturing.
*In 1991, European companies spent $7.7 billion on research and development in their American operations -- 65 percent of the total research and development spending for foreign companies in the United States. Asian companies spent $1.5 billion.
*In 1990, European companies accounted for $7 billion in American corporate income taxes, as against $100 million from Asian companies. American corporate affiliates in Europe also generated more than $32 billion in American exports, while American companies operating in Asia generated trade deficits of $7.5 billion by producing goods in Asia and exporting them to the United States.
Mr. Prestowitz said the conclusion that he hoped would be drawn from these data was not that the United States should forget about Asia. Rather, it should cooperate more with Europe, its natural partner, to help break down the barriers to trade in Asia.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Retreats After U.S. Denies Rumors About Korea

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar ended mostly lower yesterday, after retreating from an early surge set off by rumors that a dispute was heating up between North Korea and the United States.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 103.95 Japanese yen, down from 104 yen on Wednesday. It also slipped to 1.6681 German marks from 1.6692 marks. 
 Yesterday morning, the dollar jumped 1.50 yen after rumors circulated that the State Department was advising all nonessential American citizens in South Korea to leave the country. Tensions have been mounting in the Korean peninsula in recent days, as the United States, with Japanese support, pushes for sanctions against North Korea over its refusal to allow nuclear inspections.
Japan's geographic proximity to Korea, and its status as a chief trading partner in the region, renders the yen vulnerable to news of potential hostilities. Traders sold the currency to the benefit of the dollar. The mark also fell.
But after the State Department issued a statement around noon denying that Americans had been advised to leave Korea, the dollar slipped back.
"The rumor got the market all in an uproar, but when the State Department denied the rumor, it sold the dollar off," said Kevin Lawrie, vice president and manager of foreign exchange at Mellon Bank. "The net result was nil."
Mr. Lawrie and other traders said the dollar's early rally might have also been fueled by rumors that Roger C. Altman, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, planned to say the White House wanted to establish an exchange rate range of 105 to 115 yen to the dollar.
There was no confirmation from the White House, however, and the market discounted the rumors.
Traders expect today's Government report on producer prices in May to have an impact on the dollar. Currency trading has been lackluster this week, with many market participants waiting to see what the data suggest about inflation.
"For lack of anything else, the dollar will look to that," said Tom O'Malley, a foreign exchange analyst at Technical Data, a company in Boston that supplies market data to institutional investors.
Meanwhile, the British pound weakened in New York to $1.5095, from $1.5105 on Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those on Wednesday, included: 1.4112 Swiss francs, down from 1.4135; 5.6780 French francs, down from 5.6840; 1,617 Italian lire, up from 1,616, and 1.3750 Canadian dollars, down from 1.3753.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Copper Prices Rise on Signs Of Large Demand in Europe

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Copper prices rose again yesterday, reaching their highest levels since September 1992 amid continuing signs that a resurgent European economy was depleting already low inventories.
On other commodity markets, lumber rose its daily trading limit, and crude oil posted further gains. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities rose 0.46 point, to 231.67. 
 Copper for July delivery gained 0.90 cent, to $1.0945 a pound, at the Commodity Exchange of New York. Copper has jumped more than 6 cents a pound this week.
The copper-consuming manufacturing and construction industries are bolstering the economies of Germany and Britain. Germany's economy grew by 2.1 percent in the first three months, compared with a year earlier, pushed up by a surge in construction. Manufacturing output rose 3 percent in Britain, its strongest growth this decade.
Copper supplies in London Metal Exchange warehouses are at a 14-month low, and traders expect a report today to show further declines.
 
 
'Bullishness in Metals'
 "Strong economic growth in Europe and the U.S., as well as recovery in Japan, has fueled bullishness in metals," said Fred Demler, an analyst at E.D.& F. Man International in New York.
Elsewhere, lumber prices surged amid concerns that mill workers in British Columbia would strike.
"The labor situation is a potential problem," said Curt Cunningham, president of the Pacific Futures Trading Company in Seattle. "Inventory is needed to cushion against the possibility of a strike."
Contracts for many union workers in British Columbia expire at midnight on Tuesday.
The July contract for lumber gained $10 yesterday, to $390.50 for 1,000 board feet at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, after climbing $7.20 on Wednesday.
Prices could rise to their recent high of $440 for 1,000 board feet in the next three to four weeks if there was a lengthy strike, Mr. Cunningham said.
Separately, oil prices rose amid persistent concerns about limited supplies in the Midwest, where futures contracts are filled. The July contract for crude oil rose 33 cents, to $18.67 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
"They're really concerned about the supply situation right now," said Peter Madias, a trader at Brody, White & Company in New York. "People are buying more aggressively."

HEADLINE: Companies Again Raise Plans for Spending in '94

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
Corporate America intends to raise investment in new equipment and buildings by 8.3 percent in 1994, somewhat more than when last polled in the early months of the year, the Commerce Department reported today.
"We're going after market" by adding new products, said Tim Omstead, vice president of Ductmate Industries in Monongahela, Pa., a metal products company that plans to invest as much as $200,000 after spending nothing on capital improvements last year. 
 The Commerce Department survey of more than 5,000 companies discovered plans to invest a total of $634 billion, a jump of 8.3 percent from 1993 and higher than the 8 percent surge reported by companies in the January-March survey. The rise reported today is well above the 5.4 percent advance shown by the first tally in October and November, when most companies assemble annual budgets.
 
 
Biggest Increase Since 1989
 If realized, this year's increase would be the biggest since 1989, when spending for plant modernization and expansion climbed 11.4 percent.
So far, higher interest rates have put no discernible dent in such plans, analysts said.
"The rise in interest rates we've had thus far would not be expected to have an impact," said Darwin L. Beck, an economist at CS First Boston, noting the typical lags between monetary moves by the Federal Reserve and their effects on business. If rates are to hinder capital spending, he added, "that is probably an event for '95."
Modest as the shift was in the latest survey conducted in April and early May, the Clinton Administration did not forgo the chance to trumpet it.
Ronald H. Brown, the Commerce Secretary, said in a statement from Dusseldorf, Germany, "These strong and sustained expansion plans in a wide range of industries argue well for the sustainability of the recovery, for future productivity growth and cost control and for our international competitiveness."
 
 
Holding Down Inflation
 This would be the third consecutive increase in capital spending, which climbed 7.1 percent in 1993 and 3.4 percent in 1992. Such investment is considered important to holding down inflation because it enlarges the nation's productive capacity and, by incorporating the latest technology, makes it more efficient.
Today's report showed manufacturing industries planning a 6.9 percent rise in spending this year, compared with 7.5 percent in April. Durable goods industries were up a hefty 10.8 percent, and nondurables were up 3.7 percent. Large increases were registered for blast furnaces, motor vehicles, electrical machinery and stone, clay and glass. Big declines are planned for the aircraft and nonferrous metals industries.
In the first quarter, investment spending rose 2.4 percent, four-tenths of a 1 percent less than previously predicted, the Commerce Department said. The second quarter is now projected to show a 2.9 percent rise, with the third showing a gain of four-tenths of 1 percent and the fourth quarter, a gain of one-tenth of 1 percent.
 
 
Real Spending to Rise 8.9%
 When adjusted for inflation, however, today's figures showed lower planned capital spending than was previously reported. Real spending is projected to rise 8.9 percent for the year instead of the 9.8 percent before inflation in April.
After the release of the next spending report, on Sept. 8, the Commerce Department said it would replace the quarterly survey with a semiannual one. The new survey will have a different scope and details and will be published in February and September.

HEADLINE: New Jobless Claims Static

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing first-time applications for state unemployment benefits was unchanged last week, the Labor Department said today.
There were 358,000 new jobless claims in the week that ended last Saturday. That was the same as the previous week's total, which was revised downward from 362,000. The latest figure was in line with the expectations of Wall Street economists. 
 The department's closely watched four-week moving average number of claims, considered a more reliable barometer than the more volatile weekly number, declined to 362,250 last week, from 368,250 a week earlier.
New York was the only state that reported an increase of more than 1,000 claims for the week that ended on May 28, the latest period for which the data were available. New York had 2,829 new claims.
Three states reported decreases in claims, on an unadjusted basis, of more than 1,000 in the week that ended on May 28. They were California, with a drop of 3,471 claims; North Carolina, with a decline of 2,311 claims, and Washington, with a drop of 1,046 claims.

LENGTH: 2745 words

HEADLINE: A New York Tourist In His Own Hometown

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

 BODY:
A MAN and a woman walk into the River Cafe, the elegant waterside restaurant in the Brooklyn-side shadow of the Brooklyn Bridge. It's about 1:30 P.M., the tail end of lunch hour on a Tuesday. They give the maitre d'hotel their name, tell him they have a reservation and hand him a voucher, with the River Cafe typed explicitly on it, for their meal. They're on a tour package, they explain, to which he responds that he is sorry, but the restaurant is not participating in the package. Furthermore, looking down his list of reservations, he finds the couple's name nowhere.
The couple, a casually but not inappropriately dressed pair who might be from Des Moines or Boston or Painted Post, look at each other, disappointed if not aghast. 
 What do you think happens next?
You'll find out shortly, but the scene, which occurred on May 31, the second day of the much-ballyhooed tour package that is part of the NY '94 public relations campaign, was typical of the mix-ups I encountered in four days of sampling what the program is offering through the summer. (It expires on Labor Day, Sept. 5.)
Announced with a flourish in mid-May, the program is a cooperative attempt on the part of the city, the state and a variety of cultural institutions and private businesses that depend on tourism to alleviate the intimidation factor that inhibits many people from visiting New York City. The idea is simple enough: economy and convenience. With one phone call to a travel agent, you can arrange for two nights in a hotel, a ticket to a Broadway or Off Broadway show, lunch in a snazzy restaurant, a city tour by bus or boat, admissions to several of the city's museums, and a personal shopping assistant at a store of your choice. An expensive meal, a smidgen of culture, some high-rent shopping and a smattering of glitz, all for one price. A tourist's dream of New York City, yes?
As with most good ideas, however, the difficulty is execution, and, by my lights anyway, there are plenty of bugs to be worked out. I booked two tours, at the expensive and bargain-price extremes, and spent last week experiencing the city as a visitor would. Granted, I was trying out the program in its first week, with a holiday weekend thrown in to boot. And this is, after all, a complicated venture involving dozens, if not hundreds, of commercial establishments and public institutions, and it was put together only in the last six months. Even its organizers admit it got off the ground prematurely, and that the planning for next year's package, as part of NY '95, is already under way.
"This thing got fast-tracked so quickly," said Alan Rose, a vice president of marketing for the Loews Hotel chain, who served on the project's organizing committee, "that after the press conference last month, a lot of the hotels contacted us and said, 'I know we signed up for this, but what is it?' "
This confusion shows in the marketing of the packages. The tours are sold by price, but the prices in the advertisements can be misleading. There are four packages offered, with prices from $199.40 to $459.40, depending on the choice of hotel. But these are, of course, per-person double-occupancy rates (information subtly disclosed in the fine print). So the range is really $398.80 to $918.80. And for those who want to travel alone, the price range is $329 to $795.
 
A Gloss on the Big Apple
 Still, my week as a tourist was no hardship. The weather was glorious, with the kind of crystalline air that shows off the New York City skyline as a spectacular testament to mankind's industriousness. And several times I found myself thinking: Boy, what a place!
There was the boat tour, for instance: an hour's meander, via Seaport Liberty Cruises, around the the southern tip of Manhattan, departing from the South Street Seaport. On a sunny morning, with the wind spilling your hair in your eyes and the air as balmy as bath water, you look at the vertical spires of lower Manhattan, as tightly packed as porcupine quills, not to mention the Statue of Liberty, Ellis Island and the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge in the distance, and you understand why people want to come here and maybe even remember why you moved here yourself.
The boat, which makes five trips daily and normally costs $16, was nearly empty last week; as the summer proceeds, the crowds become huge, the captain said. After we got off the boat, my romantic partner (for what was, after all, a pretty romantic enterprise) and I walked through the Seaport, past City Hall and over the Brooklyn Bridge. It was a terrific way to end the morning, and it was appetite-raising, a great segue into lunch.
That was when we encountered John McFadden, the manager of the River Cafe, who was serving that day as maitre d'hotel.
Mr. McFadden showed us the reservation list: the name we used was not on it. He examined my voucher, good, it claimed, for a prix fixe lunch for two at the River Cafe, whereupon he sighed. He explained that he had tried to tell the NY '94 organizers that the restaurant didn't wish to be included; mainly, he said, because there are always mixups when reservations and payments are taken out of the restaurant's hands.
He even showed us a copy of the form sent by the tour sponsors, which he had filled out. To the question "Do You Wish to Participate in the NY '94 Tour Package?," Mr. McFadden had answered in emphatic capitals: "NO."
Besides, he added, the River Cafe doesn't have a prix fixe menu.
And then Mr. McFadden did an unexpected thing. He accepted our voucher, sat us at a window table and insisted that we order whatever we wished from the full-price lunch menu. The food was delectable, the service amiable and skilled. The bill came to $113.12, to which we were asked to contribute $5.36 in tax.
We tipped the waiter $25. Mr. McFadden declined the $10 I offered. It was a superb, gracious performance by the entire place, and I felt welcomed to New York, even though I live here.
 
Pride in Disdainfulness?
 Indeed, this is the good news. As New Yorkers, we often feel it's O.K. to be disdainful of one another, and so we brook disdain in others. It's a local quality, something outsiders can sample, like, say, crab cakes in Baltimore. And we New Yorkers seem to take pride in it, perverse as that may be.
Particularly egregious in this regard are the service professions, or so we believe. Who among us, after all, is surprised when a cabbie is rude or a waiter perfunctory? But this is to report that it appears we're lying to ourselves. Posing as a tourist, I found a remarkable willingness among hotel and restaurant personnel, car-service drivers (one actually believed us when we reported, accurately, that we were quoted a lower price over the phone, and gave us that price without argument), theater box-office people and tour guides to be friendly, helpful -- of service! -- even when their competence was at issue.
Or ours. My girlfriend and I showed up at the Frick Collection on Fifth Avenue mistakenly believing that our museum-admission vouchers were good there. The woman at the box office expressed puzzlement, even skepticism, but then opted for friendly cooperation.
"What do we give you for this?" she asked, accepting the voucher.
"Admission," I said.
"O.K.," she said, and waved us in.
Now, this attitude didn't always obtain. Identifying herself as a voucher-wielder, my friend tried to make a reservation at Lutece, for instance, and was told there were no available tables; it was only when she had someone else call back and conveniently forget to say we would be coming as part of the NY '94 package that we got a table, though, irked, we went to the River Cafe instead. Le Cirque, on the other hand, which has more of a reputation for favoring its regular customers, couldn't have been more amiable. We booked our other tour-package lunch there and as far as I could tell our treatment was no different from Kirk Douglas's, though he had a better table.
 
A Guide's Skewed Outlook
 And then there was the guide for our bus tour of upper Manhattan, a shrill-voiced woman with an intermittently squawking microphone and a French accent so thick she was difficult to understand even when she wasn't speaking French, which she did most of the time, for the benefit of one passenger, apparently the only other person from France on the bus.
The tour itself, provided by a private concern called New York Apple Tours, is pretty nifty. It uses a double-decker bus, and sitting up top in the open air, looking down on the cabs of trucks and able to reach up and touch traffic signals, gives passengers a new perspective, a second-floor view of the city.
But with this particular guide, though I couldn't understand much, what I did understand sent messages of rather dubious value: "So many people in America are sick that doctors will see them just to get insurance money," she said as the bus passed Mount Sinai Hospital. "That's why they have malpractice lawyers in America." On Lenox Avenue, she explained, "Landlords pay people to burn their buildings to get the insurance." And later, in front of the Jewish Museum on Fifth Avenue: "As I said before, Jewish people in New York are very numerous and very powerful."
There were other annoyances. Both the low-end and high-end programs promise a free Continental breakfast each morning of your stay, but there were no vouchers provided for it on either tour ("I'll have to look into that," Mr. Rose said), and we were billed for each one we ordered at the Westbury Hotel, on East 69th Street. Parking was supposed to be included, too, but the Westbury charged us for that, at $33 a night, though the hotel credited my account when I called to question my bill a few days later.
On the low-end package we stayed at the Best Western President, on West 48th Street, which shares the Days Hotel parking lot across the street. Parking (at $11 per entry) was extra, said the reservations clerk I spoke with, and breakfast in the coffee shop (there is no room service) might have been extra as well, but she wasn't sure. I didn't attempt either one, though. I put my car in the lot where I usually park it, and mornings we went out to eat.
 
Better Seats Than Expected
 As for the theater tickets, there was no problem on either package, and even though the seats are supposed to be better for the higher end than for the lower -- I was told the $199.40 package includes mezzanine seats -- we had the same choice of shows for each and we ended up with orchestra seats on the aisle for both "Crazy for You" and "She Loves Me." There was a limited list of available shows, however. I had asked specifically for "Angels in America" and "Twilight: Los Angeles, 1992" and was told they were sold out, which is true only in the producers' dreams.
Susan Lee, the director of marketing for the League of American Theaters and Producers, who organized the theater community's participation in the program, said this week that there had been some early problems with ticket availability -- partly because tickets were being provided to 687 Tony voters -- but that now virtually every show offering discount tickets is available on the tour package. Even those few shows that aren't discounting -- "The Phantom of the Opera" and "Beauty and the Beast" at the moment -- are offering tickets on the high-end package, she said.
And the personal shopping assistant? The stores that offer such a service generally do so for anyone who wants one, at no charge. And some stores don't do it at all, including Ralph Lauren/Polo Sport, for which I had a voucher but whose customer service department had never heard of NY '94. My girlfriend spoke to a staff member, who was agreeable: if we came in, he said, a regular sales clerk would help us in any way we wished.
 
Heavy Phone Time
 For the most part, though, the troubles we encountered involved making arrangements, ultimately forgivable but with the potential for getting a vacation off to an agitated start. The official travel agent for the package is Domenico Tours of Bayonne, N.J. To judge from conversations with at least a dozen of its representatives, it is an organized company full of individuals of great patience and good will (except for one woman, who hung up on me after she gave me confusing information and I asked to speak with a supervisor). But at least with the NY '94 package, they are in awe of a system they've yet to master.
In booking a tour, I spent a great deal of time on hold, listening to exhortatory, movie-theater music (I almost expected to hear "And now, enjoy the show!"). It was not, I came to understand, because there were not enough people to handle calls, but because there was a lot of information to check on. At one point I had to change some arrangements -- the Lutece-River Cafe switch -- and I kept being put on hold, only to be transferred to somebody else. There were Florence, Veronica, Harriet, Brenda and Carmine.
"What happened to Brenda?" I asked Carmine.
"Long story," he said.
It was finally Alan who got on the line and told me he had made the new reservations himself, while I'd been waiting and listening to the movie-theater music. Though we know how that turned out.
"Travel agencies don't handle restaurants ordinarily, because they don't get a commission," said Tim Zagat, publisher of the Zagat restaurant surveys and one of the organizers of the NY '94 tour package. "So this may be the first time you have a travel agency doing restaurant reservations, and frankly they don't know much about it. A lot of them don't know the difference between the Second Avenue Deli and Caravelle. Hopefully, they'll get better."
 
Pleasant Digs
 Of course none of that entirely explains why my reservation at the Westbury was mistakenly booked for June 30 instead of May 30, but no matter. The hotel, a quiet and elegant place with exquisitely attentive employees, managed to feel both homey and special, the kind of hotel that doesn't provide much to do (there's a pretty good exercise room, and the Polo Lounge) but that makes you want to hang out there, anyway. (Or to take a walk in Central Park, half a block away.)
Our room was a good place to sit in an armchair and read and munch on something from room service. I'd be remiss if I didn't mention the shower: some of the best water pressure I've ever experienced, and great steam. So great, in fact, that it set off the smoke alarm (the loudest I've ever heard).
The problem with such a hotel, of course, is the expense, even after the room rate is covered. I love room service, but sandwiches and salads for two at midnight cost $75.
This was not the problem at the Best Western President, which was clean and not unfriendly, with competent front-desk clerks and bellhops. But the room was the size of a hatbox, and the bed the size of a hat; even the hallways had a claustrophobic feel. I was a little surprised, actually. I've stayed in Best Westerns elsewhere, and they're usually more commodious. There were a bar and a coffee shop off the lobby, but I never saw anyone in either one, save for a moaning woman in the bar one night.
We ate breakfast across the street, at the Metro Deli ("Home of the Delicatessen Hall of Fame") in the Days Hotel Midtown (which is also on the $199.40 package). The waitress explained, as we scrutinized the menu: "The Nova is really popular. That's the pink stuff."
Mr. Rose acknowledged that it behooves tour customers to research the hotels carefully, particularly on the lowest-priced package. "Because we didn't want to have 25 or 30 different rates," he said, "within each price range, there's a lot of difference among the hotels."
According to figures provided by the tour sponsors, more than 4,000 phone inquiries have been made thus far, and about 200 tours have been booked. One can only wish the subscribers a smooth journey, because to judge from my experience trying to see New York through an outsider's eyes, they should have an exciting one. As it turns out, when you're not immersed in city living, the city itself has a way of reminding you that it's a cool place. Indeed, since I moved back to my apartment, I've been keeping an eye out for tourists, and I find it pleases me when it looks as though they're enjoying themselves. It occurs to me that the quicker this tour package irons out its wrinkles, the better it will be for everyone.

HEADLINE: Review/Art;
End of an Era: The Rockefellers And the Modern

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN 

 BODY:
AS much as the Guggenheims and the Whitneys are synonymous with their museums, the Rockefellers are synonymous with the Museum of Modern Art. The Modern was founded in 1929 by Abby Aldrich Rockefeller, along with Lillie Bliss and Mary Sullivan, and for most of its history either Mrs. Rockefeller or one of her children has headed its board.
So when David Rockefeller, her youngest son, recently relinquished his post as chairman to Agnes Gund and became chairman emeritus, it signaled a kind of sea change. Mr. Rockefeller still has his hand in affairs like the search for a new director, and his son David Jr. and Nelson A. Rockefeller's son Rodman are trustees. But an era of Rockefeller management at the Modern, stretching back to its beginning, has come to a close. 
 "Masterpieces From the David and Peggy Rockefeller Collection," which has just opened, is a thank-you note to Mr. and Mrs. Rockefeller in the form of a small and beautiful exhibition. The thanks are especially for works in it that they have promised to the museum (and in some cases lent long ago). These include great things: a landmark Cezanne still life, and one of the finest of his watercolors of Mont Ste.-Victoire; Signac's famous Pointillist portrait of Felix Feneon against a dizzying abstract pinwheel backdrop; Gauguin's portrait of Jacob Meyer de Haan; Andre Derain's flaming Fauvist cityscape of Charing Cross Bridge in London; Matisse's Fauvist "Girl Reading," and Picasso's Cubist view of the reservoir and houses stacked atop the hill at Horta de Ebro, Spain, the indigenous architecture of the houses a nearly ready-made Cubist design.
Most of the 21 works in the exhibition, organized by Kirk Varnedoe, are very fine. There are paintings in it outside the Modern's chronological scope, like Manet's still life called "The Brioche" (1870), which is going to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and Pissarro's "Landscape at Les Patis, Pontoise" (1868), which is going to the National Gallery in Washington. Moreover, because the Rockefellers' taste, while refined, takes in Manet and also Cubist Picasso, the show is virtually a pocket-size overview of late 19th- and early 20th-century art in France (despite a Bonnard from the 1940's that nonetheless extends in its style his work from the turn-of-the-century).
The show begins with the Cezanne and Manet still lifes. In some ways, the two are similar, borrowing the standard devices of fruit arranged on a table and in a bowl or basket, a cloth hanging over the front of the table, a knife angled diagonally inward toward the center of the canvas to underscore the recession of space. But Manet's work is somber, elegant and balanced, and it pays homage to masters like Chardin. The image is anchored at its center by the round form of the brioche, all the objects clearly delineated in relation to one another and in depth. Even though the handling of paint is astonishingly fluid, it is also exact, down to the fuzzy sheen on the peaches, the dull matte of the plums and the glints of light on the table's gilded edges and handles. The painting is a tour de force of evocative description and fancy brushwork.
The Cezanne operates according to a completely different logic. Its surface is a dense wall of short, parallel strokes that has the effect of pushing the background forward, and flattening and equalizing the image. Objects are arranged asymmetrically so the composition tilts; the ellipses of the bowl and a glass next to it are compressed; the shapes of the fruit are described not by changes in shadow and light, but by sudden shifts in hue, and the lines of the table hitch and bend. The work is vibrant and elastic.
Precisely because of its break with a picture like Manet's "Brioche," and because of its radical and independent formal harmony, it became, as Mr. Varnedoe writes, "the talisman of a new vision" for a generation that included Gauguin. (He even owned it.) The two Gauguins here, "The Wave" and the portrait of de Haan, each with its vertiginous perspective, are partly products of Cezanne's influence.
In "The Wave," Gauguin takes a bird's-eye view from a spur of rock onto a specific curving stretch of Brittany beach where waves break against giant boulders rising like a line of towers along the shore. The starting point, as with Cezanne, is observation of nature. But Gauguin also looked at Japanese prints, and Degas and Monet. His palette turns the black lichens that cling to the boulders purple, and the sandy beach blood-red. He makes arabesques out of the eddies and breakers, and an almost abstract pattern out of the pink-and-green sea.
The Gauguin portrait is abstracted in a different way, with de Haan's weird pear-shaped head and the implicit but indecipherable symbolism of the books and fruit and lamp on the table before him. Brilliant color is its subject no less than it is in Derain's "Charing Cross Bridge," or Matisse's "Girl Reading." In the Derain, the defining element is a fissure of yellow light that slices the Thames in two and rises behind Big Ben like a stack of fire. In the Matisse, a mix of colors and techniques -- daubs, scumbles, tidy outlines, wristy dashes of the brush -- transforms an image of repose into one of rapturous energy.
Six works in the exhibition have not been promised to the Modern or another museum. (The Modern is obviously hoping to be given them.) They include "The Wave" and Picasso's disturbing and remarkable "Girl With a Basket of Flowers," with her shopworn and carefully depicted face and simplified body.
Modern French painting is only part of what Mr. and Mrs. Rockefeller collect; they own 18th-century European decorative art and Asian art, too, which obviously isn't in this show because it doesn't dovetail with what the museum owns. The exhibition does not include works bought by the museum with the Rockefellers' money, either, like Martin Puryear's "Greed's Trophy" (1984), although that sculpture is on view in the contemporary galleries.
In 1968, David Rockefeller put together a syndicate (with William S. Paley, Nelson Rockefeller and others) that bought Gertrude Stein's collection. In it was Picasso's "Reservoir, Horta de Ebro" and "Girl With a Basket of Flowers." The interesting story behind that deal, along with a list of all of Mr. and Mrs. Rockefeller's gifts to the museum, is in the catalogue. It has a general introduction and concise descriptions, by Mr. Varnedoe, of each of the 21 works on view and more extensive scholarly entries by Margaret Potter and Jodi Hauptman. They are excellent. Altogether, the show turns out to be one of the most pleasurable exhibitions in New York City in some time.
"Masterpieces From the David and Peggy Rockefeller Collection: Manet to Picasso" remains at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, Manhattan, through Sept. 6.

HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By Bruce Weber 

 BODY:
A year ago, the Tony Award winners were all but obvious long before they were announced. Everyone figured "Millennium Approaches," Part 1 of Tony Kushner's "Angels in America" would walk off with most of the drama awards, and it did, winning four. And although it wasn't a grand season for musicals, two, "Kiss of the Spider Woman" and "Tommy," won a total of 12. There wasn't much left for anyone else.
This year things are different. Although complaints about the season are rife, the Tony competition is actually quite lively, with the outcomes of the races in many of the 20 categories hidden in haze, a condition that an unofficial poll of two dozen voters this week failed to clarify. (Those interviewed disclosed their votes and comments on condition of anonymity.) The winners will be announced at the Gershwin Theater on Sunday night -- the telecast, on CBS, begins at 9 -- but as of now, many prognosticators (including this one) are hedging their bets. 
 To dispense with the easy ones first, only two awards seem sure, with those questioned expressing unanimity. They are best actress in a musical, which ought to go to Donna Murphy for "Passion," and best featured actress in a musical, which should go to Audra Ann MacDonald for "Carousel."
Beyond those, however, the debate was on. Certainly the loudest laments of the year involved the dearth of solid new musicals and the inability of plays to attract audiences and stay alive, and the same whininess was reflected in the comments of voters this week. In the best-musical category, neither of the leading contenders, "Passion," the Stephen Sondheim-James Lapine collaboration, or Disney's "Beauty and the Beast," stirred much loyalty, the one being seen largely as an artfully ambitious failure, the other an advertisement for merchandise and theme parks that aims low and hits the mark. ("It's an ice show," one voter said.) Whichever wins best musical is also likely to win for book and score, although the embarrassing possibility exists that one could win for the parts and the other for the whole.
"I voted for 'Passion,' but I have to tell you I hated it," one person said. "If it wins, and it probably will, it'll be bad for the theater because people will go to see it and be disappointed. But I don't think anyone wants to vote for 'Beauty and the Beast' because it's not what theater is about. It's a cartoon."
It does seem to be true that Disney's high-visibility, very expensive entry onto Broadway has stirred some resentment among theater lifers. Another factor that may swing some votes to "Passion" is that it needs the economic boost the Tony can provide in order to stay open. "Beauty" needs no such boost; it is currently outselling even "The Phantom of the Opera."
On the other hand, several devotees of the man who wrote "Company" and "Sweeney Todd" said they could not bring themselves to vote for what they viewed as second-tier Sondheim. As one person put it, "I was going to vote for 'Passion,' but I went back to see it again, and it wasn't good enough." Then, too, road presenters make up a significant bloc of voters, and as one person interviewed put it, "they frequently vote with their future wallet in mind." It's unlikely that "Passion" will ever be a road favorite.
The question about best play is whether voters will accept "Perestroika," Part 2 of "Angels," as a new play, and whether Anna Deavere Smith's one-woman show, "Twilight: Los Angeles, 1992," will be accepted by Tony voters as a play at all. The Pulitzer Prize committee rejected both in favor of Edward Albee's "Three Tall Women," ineligible for a Tony because it is playing Off Broadway. No one gave the other nominees, "The Kentucky Cycle" and "Broken Glass," any chance.
Ms. Smith was also nominated for best actress. Among her supporters were several people who did not vote for "Twilight" as best play. Her chief competition is Diana Rigg in "Medea." The debate in this category was about expectations; the word came up a lot. Did people go to the theater expecting too much from Ms. Rigg? Did "Twilight" suffer in comparison with Ms. Smith's previous show, "Fires in the Mirror"? One voter saw this as a reason that a third nominee, Joan Rivers, in "Sally Marr . . . and Her Escorts," might sneak in:
"Even if people didn't like 'Sally Marr,' what they came out of it saying was: 'I didn't know Joan Rivers could do this.' I'm telling you, expectations are everything."
Stephen Spinella, who, as Prior Walter, the anti-angel in "Angels in America," won the Tony for featured actor last year in Part 1 of the play, stepped up to the lead-actor category this year for Part 2, and he has a strong chance again -- one voter called it "the performance of a lifetime" -- even though, as another voter put it, "for the same actor to win for the same character two years in a row is silly." His advantage, in a strong category, is that his performance is still viewable, whereas the other nominees, Christopher Plummer ("No Man's Land"), Sam Waterston ("Abe Lincoln in Illinois") and Brian Bedford ("Timon of Athens") were in limited-run shows, all long gone. Memories among voters don't tend to last.
Among the other performers' categories, the most interesting is best featured actor in a musical, which pits Jarrod Emick of "Damn Yankees" against Jonathan Freeman of "She Loves Me." As Joe Hardy, Mr. Emick has a star-size role. Mr. Freeman, on the other hand, as a maitre d'hotel, has only one scene, the musical number "A Romantic Atmosphere," but it is probably the funniest, most entertaining one of the season.
One show whose fortunes on Sunday will be particularly interesting is "An Inspector Calls," the creaky mystery by J. B. Priestley that was flamboyantly resurrected by the director Stephen Daldry and the designer Ian MacNeil. They have been given all the credit for the success of the show, a favorite for best play revival, which is why Mr. Daldry seems the favorite for best director.
But if Mr. Daldry wins, will voters feel the production has been sufficiently acknowledged and bypass Mr. MacNeil in favor of Bob Crowley, whose set for "Carousel" was equally acclaimed? "I voted for Ian MacNeil because without him there's no 'Inspector Calls,' and without Bob Crowley, there's still 'Carousel,' " one person said. But another offered the opposite view: "I voted for 'Carousel' over 'Inspector' because it was great to see a well-known show done so differently, whereas with 'Inspector' it was the designer, you have to think, carrying out the director's vision."
Meanwhile, the director of "Carousel," Nicholas Hytner, faces off against Scott Ellis, the director of "She Loves Me," for best musical director, the winner probably to depend on the winner of best revival. "Carousel" was critically and popularly lauded when it opened in March, but members of the Tony nominating committee said in interviews that they preferred "She Loves Me," and they proved it with nine nominations overall, to five for "Carousel." In discussions this week, the consensus was no real consensus. And of course, there's a third possibility: "Damn Yankees," which has 14 individuals and a corporation listed above the title as producers. As one person said: "That's a lot of votes right there."
Here, then, are one writer's predictions. As they say in television editorials, the following do not necessarily represent the opinions of management.
MUSICAL: "Passion."
PLAY: "Perestroika."
MUSICAL REVIVAL: "Carousel."
PLAY REVIVAL: "An Inspector Calls."
DIRECTOR (PLAY): Stephen Daldry, "An Inspector Calls."
DIRECTOR (MUSICAL): Nicholas Hytner, "Carousel."
ORIGINAL SCORE: Stephen Sondheim, "Passion."
BOOK FOR A MUSICAL: James Lapine "Passion."
LEADING ACTRESS (MUSICAL): Donna Murphy, "Passion."
LEADING ACTRESS (PLAY): Diana Rigg, "Medea."
LEADING ACTOR (MUSICAL): Boyd Gaines, "She Loves Me."
LEADING ACTOR (PLAY): Stephen Spinella, "Perestroika."
FEATURED ACTRESS (MUSICAL): Audra Ann McDonald, "Carousel."
FEATURED ACTRESS (PLAY): Jane Adams, "An Inspector Calls."
FEATURED ACTOR (MUSICAL): Jarrod Emick, "Damn Yankees."
FEATURED ACTOR (PLAY): Jeffrey Wright, "Perestroika."
SCENIC DESIGN: Bob Crowley, "Carousel."
COSTUME DESIGN: Ann Hould-Ward, "Beauty and the Beast."
LIGHTING DESIGN: Rick Fisher, "An Inspector Calls."
CHOREOGRAPHY: Kenneth MacMillan, "Carousel."
