SECTION: Section C; Page 24; Column 3; Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 1190 words

HEADLINE: Inside Art

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:

Questions at the Whitney
With all the turmoil during the tenures of Leonard A. Lauder as president of the Whitney Museum of American Art and David A. Ross as its director, there has been no end of speculation about what will happen when their terms expire. Mr. Lauder is known as Mr. Ross's staunchest supporter on a divided board. So when the museum announced after the board met on Wednesday that Mr. Lauder had resigned as president a year before his term expired, and would become its chairman, and that Gilbert C. Maurer, an 11-year board member, would assume the presidency, the question was inevitable: What does this mean for Mr. Ross, whose contract runs out in February 1996?
Mr. Lauder denied that the board was divided on Mr. Ross. "They're solidly behind David," he said. "Are there one or two naysayers? Sure." 
 "Gil's an experienced leader," said Mr. Lauder, who is said to have handpicked the committee that elected Mr. Maurer. "He's served the Whitney in many functions."
Mr. Lauder, who has served as president for four years, said he was stepping down early because the museum was set to embark on a major capital and endowment program in the fall. "If I started the campaign, the museum would have to change horses in midstream," he said. "It works out neatly this way."
Mr. Maurer, who is C.E.O. of the Hearst Corporation and who describes himself as a strong David Ross supporter, said the museum had not yet decided the size of its capital campaign goal. But he confirmed that the money would go toward an expansion of the museum. As to whether the architect will be Michael Graves, whose unbuilt design for an expanded Whitney caused an uproar in the art and architecture world, not to mention the Upper East Side, in the late 1980's, Mr. Maurer said, "Probably not."
 
In Memory of a Friend
 Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis has not been forgotten at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, thanks to Jayne Wrightsman, a trustee and one of the museum's biggest donors. This week the museum announced that Mrs. Wrightsman had purchased an 1817 life-size portrait of the French statesman Talleyrand by Pierre-Paul Prud'hon in memory of her friend Mrs. Onassis. The painting is on view in the museum's new 19th-century galleries for European paintings and sculpture.
"As Jacqueline Onassis was deeply devoted to the Metropolitan Museum, I wanted to give a work of art that might remind all of us of her unforgettable impact on our lives," Mrs. Wrightsman said. "The portrait of Talleyrand recalls her deep love of France and of French history, and her own triumphs there as everywhere throughout the world."
The portrait, which is more than seven feet high and valued at around $3 million, was purchased three years ago in France from a descendant of Talleyrand by Alan Salz, the New York director of the Didier Aaron gallery in Manhattan. "It seemed like a perfect painting for the Met," Mr. Salz said. "But these things take time."
The painting is one of three full-length Prud'hon portraits of Talleyrand. It shows him in civilian clothes in his house, Valencay, just south of Paris. The other two portraits show Talleyrand in court costume and were commissioned by Napoleon; this one was commissioned by Talleyrand himself.
"We have been trying to beef up our collection of Neo-Classical and Romantic paintings," said Gary Tinterow, the Engelhard curator of European paintings at the Met. "And this is an important addition."
 
Power Merger
 When the two superpower galleries Pace and Wildenstein merged in October, part of the master plan included extending the newly formed Pace Wildenstein's reach to cultural capitals other than New York City. So this week's announcement that Pace Wildenstein would open a major gallery in London took few art-world insiders by surprise. Nor did the news that the gallery would be at 147 New Bond Street, the building that has housed Wildenstein & Company since 1936.
David Grob, a private London dealer, will be the gallery's director. And the 1752 building will undergo extensive renovations, to create an unusual upstairs-downstairs relationship. The basement and ground floor of the building will become Pace Wildenstein's galleries for 20th-century paintings and sculpture, works on paper and photography; Wildenstein & Company, meanwhile, will continue dealing primarily in Old Masters from the building's upper floors, under the direction of David Ellis-Jones.
"This is all part of a bigger picture," said Marc Glimcher, director of Pace Wildenstein. "It's not the last part of the story." Mr. Glimcher said that the gallery would soon announce other locations, including one in Los Angeles.
Mr. Grob said he had had an "evolving relationship" with Pace Wildenstein. Until the renovations are complete (in 12 to 18 months), he intends to operate from temporary quarters on the building's second floor with a viewing room and computer link-up to New York.
"London will be our base for Europe," Mr. Glimcher said. "We have a large number of Italian, French and German clients. The gallery will definitely be different from our gallery in New York. It's a big mistake to give a big multi-international corporation a party line. Each gallery will have its own flavor."
 
A New Art Market
 Photography is one segment of the art market that has been faring reasonably well even in these difficult economic times. But its success is not limited to galleries and auction houses. Last week, when "Gallery Direct," a new program aimed at "serious art collectors," made its debut on the QVC televison channel, it offered photographs of Marilyn Monroe by the photographer Bert Stern. And television viewers shopped with a vengeance.
"Customers see the value in art," said Mary Forte, QVC's senior vice president for merchandising. "There's a real market for it. Art is our future."
The idea for "Gallery Direct" came from Bruce Goldstein, an electronic-marketing consultant who approached Susan Harder, the New York-based photography dealer who represents Mr. Stern. In March, before creating the new show, they tested the idea on Joan Rivers's program on QVC, "Can We Shop?" In 10 minutes, Ms. Rivers sold two of Mr. Stern's Marilyn Monroe images, one for $2,700 and the other for $5,000.
That gave QVC the confidence to proceed. On June 1 (the anniversary of Marilyn Monroe's birth), it introduced "Gallery Direct," and sold more of Mr. Stern's Monroe photographs. These came from his book "The Last Sitting," images of Monroe commissioned by Vogue magazine in 1962, six weeks before her death.
"Gallery Direct" featured photographs ranging in price from $280 for "The Last Sitting Shot," a 22-by-28-inch, black-and-white head shot of Monroe, to $7,900 for "Marilyn With Roses," a 30-by-40-inch work of the actress with colored chiffon roses covering her breasts. (Six of these were sold, and Ms. Forte said they were the most expensive items ever sold on QVC.) The top seller, however, was "Marilyn in Vogue," an image of the star in a black dress that cost $350. More than 175 prints were sold in a two-minute spot, Mr. Goldstein said.

HEADLINE: TV Weekend;
Serious Entertainment From a Rare Resource

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
Wim Kayzer, a Dutch television producer, had a simple idea: bring together several eminent American and British intellectuals for open-ended conversation. The result, more than a dozen hours of talk that broke viewing records in his country last year, arrives Sunday and dominates Channel 13's prime-time schedule through the week.
Starting with the neurologist and psychiatrist Oliver Sacks, "A Glorious Accident" continues with Rupert Sheldrake, cell biologist and biochemist; Daniel C. Dennett, philosopher; Stephen Toulmin, philosopher of science; Freeman Dyson, physicist, and Stephen Jay Gould, paleontologist. On Saturday they all join Mr. Kayzer for a three-and-a-half-hour chat. And on Sunday, June 19, viewers can fill in anything they missed, or if they missed it all, can make up the entire series, from 7 A.M. to 12:45 A.M. 
 This sort of crash-course approach, with interruptions for fund-raising, scarcely does justice to the material. The speculations floated here about mankind and nature take a little absorbing; a week between programs might have given a hooked viewer a chance to do some catch-up or preparatory reading.
But the opportunity to listen in on such heady talk by such talking heads is not so common on television that one can afford to quibble. Except for a needless gesture at visual scene-setting (the opening pictures make New York City seem like a ward in a hospital for the deranged), the project soon gets down to business. Mr. Kayzer, unseen until the final get together, takes the role of an informed auditor, tossing in a remark now and then to keep the evening's performer rolling along without pressing him to stay on any particular track.
Oliver Sacks, who leads off Sunday, tends to muse over personal experiences, especially with patients troubled by neurological ailments, like those he wrote of in "Awakenings." In the disordered workings of their minds, he finds glimpses of the order of things in the universe. The definition of "order" is a theme of the week. Dr. Sacks says he is looking for "an order which was created autonomously and spontaneously in the universe, not one which has any sort of external, divine or Platonic archetype." Take that, God.
Dr. Sacks is fascinated by memory (which he believes is closer to imagination than to replication), by smells (which he suggests are among the earliest memories), by the amorality of nature and of man. For him, life is not programmed but a matter of choices and responsibilities. ("We're not very elegantly designed. We've been improvised.") He extols the brain's powers of spontaneous creation, and he can become lyrical: "I think we dream nonstop, until we come to the sleep at the end."
But these discussions should not be reduced to print bites. Mr. Sheldrake, who holds that organisms pass on information across generations, takes exception to Mr. Dennett's more mechanistic concept of evolution. Mr. Toulmin speaks of humans as the inheritors and transmitters of tradition. Mr. Dyson tells of wartime calculations on how to murder people most economically. And Mr. Gould manages to get in a comment or two about baseball.
Although Mr. Kayzer does not go out of his way to help viewers catch the allusions tossed around casually, the drift is not hard to follow. At one point in their final get-together, the men give way to expressions of mutual admiration as though they were trapped at a testimonial dinner, but mostly the conversation stays serious without being ponderous. These estimable thinkers flounder in the face of enormities like the Holocaust, just the way the rest of us do.
Toward the end, Mr. Dyson confesses that theories don't help much in understanding why things work the way they do: "The world is much stranger than we imagined." A case in point: Who could have predicted a week's worth of such talk on national television?
 
A Glorious Accident
Oliver Sacks: Migraine

HEADLINE: Before Talks With North Korea

 BODY:
To pressure North Korea into compliance with the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, the Clinton Administration is trying to mount a credible threat of U.N. sanctions. Now Japanese misgivings and flat-out Chinese opposition have temporarily set back that effort.
This is discouraging news. Without China's acquiescence in the Security Council, there can be no U.N. sanctions. Without full Japanese participation, there can be no meaningful economic pressure on Pyongyang. 
 The Administration, which has differences in its own ranks over how tough a stand to take, is still struggling to develop an international consensus. The latest signs of diplomatic gridlock provide new arguments for reckless Washington hawks who already clamor impatiently for a more belligerent unilateral American stand. Fortunately, however, North Korea, along with its daily array of fiery threats against Japan and South Korea, has provided an opening of sorts toward moving the crisis back to a negotiating track.
On Wednesday, North Korea's Foreign Minister proposed elements of a diplomatic deal. Pyongyang now offers to guarantee "inspection" of nuclear fuel at its facilities, provided the U.S. renews the diplomatic dialogue it broke off when North Korea refused to set aside the fuel rods that International Atomic Energy Agency inspectors wanted to analyze during the unloading of its reactor last month.
Given the North's history of wriggling through verbal loopholes, the State Department understandably characterized the offer as insufficient. By failing to set aside the fuel rods the I.A.E.A. wanted to analyze, North Korea immensely complicated the inspection issue. That straightforward method of establishing precisely how much plutonium Pyongyang may have removed in the past is no longer available.
There may be alternative, albeit less satisfying ways to reconstruct at least some of this history. But the North needs to agree unambiguously to these procedures before high-level talks with the U.S. can resume.
While the effort to clarify past plutonium management continues, North Korea also needs to demonstrate good faith in safeguarding the larger quantities of plutonium it has just unloaded.
Most urgently, that means letting the I.A.E.A. verify that the unloaded fuel is not removed for reprocessing, potentially into nuclear bomb material. And it means not abandoning the framework of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. These are points former President Carter could usefully reinforce when he visits Pyongyang on a private visit next week.
What the United States needs to do now is spell out, though not necessarily in public, its own conditions for resuming talks. North Korean bad faith has increased the temperature of the crisis and narrowed the scope for a negotiated solution. Yet even as Washington seeks to build a consensus on sanctions, continued diplomacy is in everybody's interest.
In the best case, it could still produce a breakthrough on the key proliferation issues. In the worst, further diplomatic efforts could help convince China and Japan that every reasonable alternative has been explored.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Budget Reflects a Strategy to Make Poverty a Crime

 BODY:
To the Editor:
While the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies joins in the effort to restore funds for youth, educational, social, health and housing services in Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's first executive budget for New York City, we wish to focus on the philosophical direction the budget reflects. 
 By exempting the police and fire departments from cutbacks while slashing the supports on which the poor depend, the Mayor has expressed his view that the poor are expected to solve the social problems of the city. When the cuts to youth services throughout city agencies are added up, it is difficult to conclude otherwise than that this budget is a strategy to give our young people over to the criminal justice system.
In "Cause for Alarm: The Condition of Black and Latino Males in New York City," a study we published in 1991, we found that at the center of the problems for black and Latino men is their exclusion from jobs and disproportionate inclusion in the prison system. One of the most alarming statistics was that in 1990 for every 100,000 black males 16 and older in New York City, 3,123 were in prison; for every 100,000 Latino males, 2,270 were in prison. Between 1980 and 1990, the number of Latino men arrested increased by 146 percent; black men, by 95 percent.
Young people in trouble could once turn to truant officers and community agencies. Using police officers to round up truants may prove more expensive, as well as labeling troubled youngsters as criminals before they have committed a crime.
The administration has also proposed that recipients of home relief, aid to families with dependent children and Medicaid be fingerprinted. The city is willing to invest millions in this program when there is no evidence or data to demonstrate that fingerprinting will reduce fraud or alleged abuse of the welfare system. If fingerprinting saves money, it will not be because of fraud indictments or convictions, but because it will deter eligible people -- our poorest and most vulnerable citizens -- from applying for assistance they so desperately need.
Stigmatization of the poor is also contemplated in the administration's proposal to arrest and imprison unemployed homeless people -- squeegee people. Further, the chairman of the City Planning Commission is contemplating a plan to remove homeless people from residential communities and put them instead in manufacturing zones. Does this imply that the homeless are not worthy of living in communities? Why are they being treated like social pariahs, to be cut off from shops, trees, neighborhoods, parks and services?
Rather than education and training, the Mayor has proposed eliminating or reducing youth services, including summer employment, after-school and drug prevention programs, job training and intergenerational programs, with devastating cuts to community colleges and parks. These cuts are doubly damaging because the young people who provide services lose their jobs.
The future for our youth and our city depends on a vision that seeks to expand opportunities, not to criminalize or shame those who are less fortunate.
 
MEGAN MCLAUGHLIN
 Executive Director, Federation
 of Protestant Welfare Agencies
 New York, June 1, 1994

HEADLINE: Wilson? Quayle? Dole? Anyone?

BYLINE: By David Frum; David Frum is author of the forthcoming book "Dead Right."

 BODY:
The Republicans have to nominate somebody for President in 1996. But who? Pete Wilson looks less promising since he lost 34.2 percent of the vote to a relative unknown in California's gubernatorial primary Tuesday. Dan Quayle's candidacy has hardly been advanced by his book "Standing Firm."
Bob Dole is likely to fizzle early -- if he runs. It is Republicans in the provinces who pick nominees, not Washington's press corps, and only once in this century have they nominated a sitting senator (Barry Goldwater, 1964). 
 The frustration that has gripped Republicans since they lost control of the Senate and the national agenda in 1986 has not only aggravated internal quarrels, it has rendered the Reagan-era categories for understanding the party nearly obsolete. What do "conservative" and "moderate" mean when the supposedly super-conservative Newt Gingrich, the House Republican whip, interrupts a journalist's remark -- "As a conservative, you basically want to minimize the role of government" -- with a brutal "no"?
Reagan conservatism -- tax cuts, controls on spending, broad deregulation -- still figures large in Republican rhetoric. But except for a few loyalists like Senator Phil Gramm, Reaganism does not really describe what G.O.P. politicians believe, and does not predict very accurately what they will do.
Nor is it accurate to describe the party as teetering on the verge of a coup by fundamentalists. The conventional wisdom that they control perhaps six state organizations is nonsense. It's true that in low-turnout off-season local contests and in party conventions governed by complex rules (like Virginia's, at which Oliver North won the senatorial nomination) Christian conservatives can win a few dramatic victories. But when large numbers of Republicans vote, the fundamentalists' clout dissipates, as Pat Robertson's humiliating performance in the 1988 primaries showed.
With rare exceptions, G.O.P. politicians become vulnerable to challenges from religious conservatives only if, like the Governor of Minnesota, Arne H. Carlson, they have also alienated economic conservatives. Republicans who have gained the loyalty of economic conservatives -- like Senators Paul Coverdell of Georgia and Kay Bailey Hutchinson of Texas -- can win despite moderate stances on abortion.
To understand G.O.P. politics, discard "moderate" or "conservative" and forget the religious right. Think instead of three big categories.
Dull and worthy. The most popular Republican on the banquet circuit -- after Jack Kemp -- is Dick Cheney, the former Defense Secretary. He formed an exploratory committee last year and has given only one on-the-record speech in 18 months. It made two points -- foreign policy is important and our health system is not in terrible condition. His popularity testifies to the institutional Republican Party's yearning for solid, unexciting small "c" conservatism.
Like Mr. Cheney, the governors most frequently mentioned as Presidential candidates -- "moderates" like Mr. Wilson and "conservatives" like Tommy Thompson of Wisconsin and John Engler of Michigan -- show scant enthusiasm for a Reaganesque economic agenda. They favor cautious domestic reforms that would be tougher than the Democratic alternatives, but only incrementally.
Mr. Wilson has made illegal immigration his issue. Mr. Thompson and Mr. Engler have devoted their attention to welfare and education. None has shown the radical discontent with the cost and intrusiveness of the Government that conservatives felt in the 70's, when Washington spent less than two-thirds what it does today. If former Secretary of State James Baker runs, he will be the dullest and worthiest of all.
Spacemen. In a 1984 speech, Mr. Gingrich posed the question "Why do liberals oppose a strong American presence in space?" His answer -- they hate America -- was less striking than his question. Robert Taft, Mr. Republican of the 40's, would have derided any Republican who would spend hundreds of billions to land men on Mars. Today, Washington is full of conservatives who would use the Government for transforming purposes like star-trekking and uplifting the underclass. Mr. Kemp is the most prominent of these dreamy Republicans.
Unlike the dull and worthy, the spacemen possess political vision. Their problem is that their visionary policies, like school vouchers and tenant ownership of public housing, threaten the interests and values of core G.O.P. voters. Tenant ownership would transfer assets worth tens of thousands of dollars each to the most dependent welfare recipients. School vouchers would fill fancy suburban schools with inner-city children.
The anxious. The conservatism of the 70's attacked high taxes and depreciating currency; the conservatism of the 90's focuses on race and sex. Anxious conservatives like William Bennett, Patrick Buchanan, Mr. Quayle -- even Ross Perot -- worry more about the character of society.
The "need for families," Mr. Quayle wrote, "is what the Republican Party should embrace as its cause" -- not, apparently, tax cuts. Mr. Buchanan has bitterly observed, "We are two countries, and many Americans in the first country are getting tired of subsidizing and explaining away the deepening failure of the second."
While 70's Republicans brimmed with ideas for conquering inflation and reducing taxes, anxious Republicans offer few practical suggestions. Some, like Mr. Buchanan, would preserve America's ethnic balance by capping immigration. But about the only proposal offered for achieving Mr. Quayle's hopes of promoting the traditional family is a drastic reduction in welfare payments. That might discourage single parenthood among the five million families on welfare, but it would have little impact on the 95 million households who are not.
The 90's have proved a fallow intellectual period for the right. Republicanism fades into vacuity when Republicans stray from their role as opponents of Big Government. This is why the party seems headed for disappointment, in November and in '96.

HEADLINE: HOW THEY DO IT;
A Credit Card With a Little Bonus for Retirement

 BODY:
David DuBois, 37, of Norwalk, Conn., is the chief operating officer of a drug rehabilitation center based in Minneapolis, and trevels around teh country on business. Last year, he got a credit card called the Start card, which funnels a small portion of his total purchases into a tax-deferred annuity.
 He said he checked into other rebate cards but found most useless. "I don't need frequent flier miles because I travel so much anyway," he said. "And I found that the others were so confusing, I couldn't figure out how to make them work for me." 
 Mr. DuBois charges less than $2,000 a month on the card, and generally pays his bill in full each month. If he continues spending at his current rate, his annuity account will have at least $10,000 when he is 65. Of course, the value of the money will have been eroded somewhat by inflation. "I'm not under the illusion that this is the best instrument for saving for retirement," Mr. DuBois said, "but I need a credit card anyway." This is money "I wouldn't have had otherwise."

HEADLINE: U.S. BARS FLIGHTS AND MONEY DEALS WITH THE HAITIANS

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 10

 BODY:
President Clinton announced two measures today to increase pressure on Haitian military leaders and their wealthy supporters: a halt to commercial flights between Haiti and the United States and a ban on financial transactions between the two countries.
Administration officials said the ban should hit rich Haitians hard because many of them have bank accounts or investments in the United States. The ban, which takes effect immediately, will prevent Haitians from wiring money from their American accounts to Haiti or from making deposits in American accounts. 
 William H. Gray 3d, the President's special adviser on Haiti, said the measure would affect hundreds of millions of dollars in transactions, including letters of credit that Haitian companies use to import goods.
The ban on commercial flights, which begins on June 25, affects American Airlines, the only United States carrier with flights to Haiti. Canada joined the ban today, and American officials said that together, the two countries account for more than 75 percent of the flights in and out of Haiti.
The new measures are part of the President's revised strategy of putting the threat of military intervention on the back burner while increasing economic pressure to topple Haiti's military rulers, who ousted the elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, in September 1991.
"These steps represent an important new stage in our efforts to restore democracy and return President Aristide to Haiti," Mr. Clinton said at a White House news conference. "The message is simple: Democracy must be restored; the coup must not endure."
After months of an embargo that has mainly hurt Haiti's poor, the new sanctions represent a mid-course revision. The Administration now is directing its economic fire more at Haiti's elite in the hope that they will be squeezed so hard that they will join the international call to oust Haiti's military rulers.
"What we're trying to do," said a senior Administration official, "is say to the ruling class who support the military, that if you think you can sit out these sanctions for six months or a year and by that overturn the election because President Aristide's term ends at the end of next year, well, we're not going to let that happen. We're not going to say, 'Let the masses and the middle class suffer, but the very wealthy don't have to pay a price.' "
Mr. Gray said other countries with close economic ties to Haiti, like France, have indicated that they, too, would soon announce bans on commercial flights and financial transactions.
The State Department announced today that it was withdrawing embassy dependents and 120 of about 200 employees because the tension in Haiti has increased and because the flight ban would make it hard for Americans in Haiti to return to the United States.
At the State Department's daily briefing, Christine Shelly, a spokeswoman, urged the 8,000 Americans in Haiti to leave as soon as possible.
 
To Hurt Supporters of Coup
 Mr. Gray said the new sanctions would "hurt those people who are the supporters of the coup, who presently can now go and get on an Air France plane, go to Paris, shop and come back, or get on an American Airlines plane and come to New York."
"I assure you that not too many of the poor children or the poor people of Haiti are flying American Airlines, either economy or business or first class, coming to Miami or New York," he said.
After repeatedly saying in recent weeks that military intervention was an option for ousting Haiti's military rulers, Mr. Clinton did not even mention the idea at today's news conference. With new sanctions, it appeared as if his Administration has stared the prospect of military action in the face and, sobered by the gravity of such a move, taken a step back, redoubling efforts to exhaust all economic sanctions and diplomatic means to oust Haiti's military.
Mr. Gray said today that military intervention has not been ruled out, but refused to say how long the United States would wait for the sanctions to succeed before it took stronger action.
 
Easing Burden on Poor
 To ease the burden on Haiti's poor, Mr. Gray said there would be one exception to the ban on financial transactions: Haitians living in the United States would be permitted to send up to $50 a month to relatives in Haiti so long as they do not belong to the military.
Although Mr. Gray said that sum may sound small, he explained that it should be of significant help in the hemisphere's poorest country, where per capita income is only about $350 a year.
American Airlines operates a 266-seat A-300 Airbus from New York and Miami to Port-au-Prince.
Timothy Smith, an American Airlines spokesman, said that between June 16 and June 24, the airline planned to increase its service to accommodate the flow of people it expects out of Haiti.
Administration officials said the new measures aim to show Washington's resolve after a series of moves that have sent mixed signals to Haiti's rulers over the last two years. The Administration is looking at further measures to turn up the heat on the elite, including denying all visas for travel to the United States.
 
Little Haitian Reaction
 There was little official reaction to Mr. Clinton's announcement, with both the military and the country's army-backed civilian Government keeping quiet.
The ban on financial transactions will not apply to the activities of the United States Government, the United Nations, foreign embassies and nongovernmental agencies providing food and other relief.
The ban on financial transactions differs from a freeze on personal assets. The Administration has frozen the assets of more than 630 Haitians, most of them military officers or members of the Haitian Government. Under the freeze, these Haitians may not touch their money in the United States. Under the ban on financial transactions, a family with a child attending college in the United States would be allowed to withdraw money from a bank account in the United States to pay for the child's tuition.
Administration officials acknowledged that Haitians might be able to transfer money from their American accounts to banks in Switzerland or France.
 
Canadian Is Freed
 The Coast Guard today returned 396 fleeting Haitians, bringing to 1,855 the number sent back over the last five weeks, a spokesman at the American Embassy in Haiti said. The Administration has repeatedly said it would send back all Haitian refugees until it opened a shipboard processing center off the Jamaica coast, a center that a senior official said would begin operating on Monday.
This morning in Haiti, a Canadian citizen missing for two days was released from a military prison. He bore obvious signs of mistreatment, international officials said.
Victor Edmonds, 38, was set free from a military jail known for its brutal treatment of inmates. His face was swollen, two teeth were broken, and parts of his clothing were covered in blood, said a human rights official from the joint observer mission of the United Nations and the Organization of American States who saw him.
While many Haitians, particularly those supporting Father Aristide, have been regular targets for the military, foreigners had always been considered off limits, because of the potential backlash harming them could provoke. This incident is believed to be the first time a foreign resident has been beaten or mistreated by the Haitian military or their allies.

Gray 3d, at the White House yesterday. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times) (pg. 6)

COMING OF AGE, WITHOUT WALLS
Berlin Journal: In the old East Germany, the Jugendweihe symbolized not only the passage from childhood into maturity, but a commitment to Marxism. HEADLINE: Palestinians Given Pledges For More Aid

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PARIS, June 10

 BODY:
Facing a severe cash flow problem just as they begin administering Gaza and Jericho, Palestinian authorities obtained some relief today as international donors pledged an additional $42 million worth of aid to cover start-up costs.
Nabil Shaath, who headed the Palestinian delegation to a two-day meeting with donors here, said the outcome was "much better than expected" and would help set up a Palestinian national authority "that can survive on its own." 
 Mr. Shaath said he was hopeful that another $35 million worth of emergency aid would be pledged at another donors' meeting scheduled to be held here on July 10 and 11. "I think they understand the timing of the aid is as important as the amount," he added.
 
Several Donors
 A detailed breakdown of the new aid was not made available, but Mr. Shaath said the United States, Norway, Saudi Arabia, Canada and Japan had all contributed additional resources. He added that the 12-nation European Union, which has already pledged $600 million through 1999, was still the largest donor.
The chairman of the meeting this week was Jan Egeland, Norway's Deputy Foreign Minister, whose Government helped broker the peace accord between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization. Israel also sent Uri Savir, a senior Foreign Ministry official, to support the Palestinian case.
"We believe the Palestinian side has created the necessary conditions for progress," Mr. Savir said at a news conference. "We need the economic ingredient to make the Palestinian authority a success. This is a boost for the Palestinian economy and for continuing the peace process."
Last October, donors led by the European Union, the United States, Japan, Norway and Saudi Arabia pledged $2.4 billion in aid over five years, with some $700 million due to be disbursed in 1994 to set in motion programs to improve hospitals, schools and local infrastructure.
 
Short-Term Needs Slighted
 But the P.L.O. was slow in establishing mechanisms that reassured donors of accountability in the use of their funds, and the donors themselves minimized the short-term costs involved in setting up the new governing authority in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank town of Jericho.
"In hindsight, we might have been better at seeing the need for recurrent costs," Mr. Egeland said. "We went in with long-term projects. Few donors made allocations for the Palestinian police. Maybe we should have done so, but we did not. So we're having to shift some long-term aid toward start-up expenses."
The Norwegian official said that donors had been asked to assign 25 percent of their 1994 pledges to cover these immediate needs. "We hope not to have to convert development resources into current expenditure in the years ahead," he said.
Mr. Shaath, the chief negotiator of the Palestinian self-rule agreement with Israel last month, said the Palestinian police, now numbering close to 7,000, had received their salaries for April and May. After the $42 million is disbursed, he added, the police budget should be covered through the end of August.
"We're not interested in recurrent expenses that need recurrent aid," the Palestinian delegate said. "But it was this critical gap that scared us. We were going into a venture for which we lacked the start-up money."
Caio Koch-Weser, a World Bank representative, said he was confident the crisis had passed. "This is a partnership between the Palestinian authority and the donors that now works," he said, adding that the Palestinians' budget for 1994 is fully financed and the new Palestinian Economic Council for Development and Reconstruction is "up and running."

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Pressing Sanctions for North Korea

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 10

 BODY:
As North Korea threatened to sever all ties with international nuclear inspectors, the Clinton Administration sought today to signal its determination to win approval of tough economic sanctions against the North, a message intended in part to overcome news reports of internal and international divisions.
In an unusually explicit speech, a senior Defense Department official also announced that the United States had intensified its intelligence operations in the region to analyze how and when North Korea might use nuclear or other weapons if fighting began on the Korean Peninsula. 
 At the White House, President Clinton spoke for more than an hour by telephone Thursday night with President Kim Young Sam of South Korea, then joined top foreign policy advisers this morning for part of a four-hour meeting about the tensions on the Korean Peninsula. Secretary of State Warren Christopher said separately that the United States hoped "within a few days" to present the United Nations with a proposal to punish North Korea for refusing to allow inspectors access to critical evidence about its nuclear weapons capability.
 
Trip Was Cut Short
 "I think I would not want to tie myself down to a particular time, but it's time to move forward with a resolution," Mr. Christopher said in Turkey as he cut short a foreign trip to return to Washington and join in the Administration's attention to the issue.
The new show of intransigence by North Korea came today after the International Atomic Energy Agency suspended technical aid to the Government as a penalty for its refusal to grant access to agency inspectors seeking evidence of a secret nuclear bomb. North Korea countered by saying it would no longer guarantee the continuity of measures intended to safeguard the security of its nuclear plants and would ask the only two United Nations inspectors still in North Korea to leave.
That would leave the world without any way to monitor whether North Korea begins to reprocess the spent fuel rods it has been withdrawing rapidly from its Yongbyon nuclear reactor into nuclear weapons-grade plutonium.
With Republicans voicing increasing criticism of Mr. Clinton for failing to prepare Americans for a possible war, and China, Japan and even the Pentagon clearly reluctant to embrace certain sanctions, much of today's public display by the Administration appeared part of an effort to respond with an image of seriousness and resolve.
 
No Precise Proposal
 But Mr. Clinton, who left the meeting of his principal advisers to announce a toughening of policy toward Haiti, left the White House briefing room abruptly rather than answer questions about North Korea. Even after the marathon gathering, White House aides acknowledged that they have yet to settle on a precise sanctions proposal to present to the United Nations.
And in Istanbul, Mr. Christopher announced the Administration's support for an international conference on North Korea, a step intended to reiterate to its Government that there are rewards if it changes its behavior and lives up to its treaty obligations by reopening its nuclear installations to international inspection.
The White House also made clear its support for a planned private trip by former President Jimmy Carter to North Korea next week, and officials described him as a potentially important emissary who could carry Washington's views to the Government and report back to Mr. Clinton on what he had learned.
Mr. Carter was briefed at a Washington airport this afternoon by Anthony Lake, the national security adviser, and White House officials said the former President would meet this weekend with State Department specialists assigned to fill him in on American policy.
With Mr. Carter scheduled to visit Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, at a time when the United States, China and Japan are likely still to be wrangling over the terms of proposed United Nations sanctions, a senior White House official expressed hope that North Korea might see Mr. Carter's visit as an opportunity to seek "a face-saving resolution" to the standoff.
 
Identifying Steps to Take
 While today's White House meeting was intended mostly to identify the punitive steps against North Korea that might win approval by the Security Council, Administration officials said it also included extensive discussion of "prudent" military steps the United States might take if tensions on the Korean peninsula increase.
They said the comments made in the speech today by Ashton B. Carter, an Assistant Secretary of Defense, reflected some of that concern. In an address that outlined problems posed by the spread of nuclear weapons and other weapons of mass destruction, Mr. Carter said the United States was "significantly increasing our intelligence assets" in the Korean Peninsula and was analyzing "scenarios" in which North Korea might use such weapons if the diplomatic standoff turns to war.
In separately holding out the prospect of an international conference on North Korea, the Administration appeared to have intended to send two simultaneous messages. First, it signaled American willingness to embrace a proposal that originated in Moscow, which has not yet publicly embraced the idea of sanctions against North Korea.
It could also serve to lower the volume of war talk in Washington by showing North Korea that there are rewards for better behavior. But the decision may also have the unintended consequence of signaling to North Korea that the United States does not have a clear plan for stopping the world's most isolated and authoritarian Government from developing nuclear weapons.

HEADLINE: Dow Posts Gain of 20.31; Volume Is Uninspiring

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market rose moderately yesterday, aided by a modest rise in blue-chip stocks like Aluminum Company of America and Bethlehem Steel and a strong rise in computer-related stocks like Microsoft and Intel after the release of an unexpectedly favorable computer-industry index.
But despite the price rise, traders continued to hold back. In the 14th consecutive session of below-average trading, volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 222.6 million shares, compared with the average this year of 296 million shares. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 20.31 points, to 3,773.45, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 rose 0.81 point, to 458.67. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 5.37 points, to 734.25.
The week's listlessness was reflected in the industrial average's track record. The Dow ended just 1.23 points above its close a week ago.
 
Few Trends in Trading
 There seemed to be few trends in yesterday's stock activity. The Dow, for example, rose mainly because of five stocks: Alcoa, up 1 3/4, to 73; Caterpillar, up 1 5/8, to 105 1/8; Bethlehem Steel, up 1 3/8, to 21 1/8; Chevron, up 1 1/8, to 90 3/4, and Texaco, up 1, to 64 3/4. But none of the five stocks seemed to be affected by any immediate news.
If there was a trend, it was the strong lift given to the Nasdaq index by four computer-related stocks: Oracle Systems, a developer of computer networking software, which rose 23/16 , to 36 3/4; Intel, the leading semiconductor maker, which rose 63/64 , to 5963/64 ; Novell, another developer of computer networking software, which rose 5/8, to 17 1/8, and Microsoft, the developer of personal-computer software, which rose 5/16 , to 529/16 .
All these stocks benefited, if only indirectly, from the Semiconductor Industry Association's report late Thursday of the book-to-bill ratio, an indicator of future demand for semiconductors. The ratio was expected by Wall Street to drop sharply to 1.12 in May from 1.14 in April.
 
Strong Demand for Chips
 Instead, the ratio dropped only modestly to 1.14 from a revised 1.15, indicating continued strong demand as the industry heads into its slower-selling summer season. The number means that for every $1 of semiconductors shipped, the industry received $1.14 worth of new orders.
The lift from the semiconductor report overcame negative news for Microsoft, the subject of an unfavorable court ruling regarding versions of its mainstay MS-DOS software. The ruling, which Microsoft is appealing, concerned a patent infringement allegation involving data-compression technology.
Stocks rallied despite a rise in long-term interest rates. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond rose 4 basis points, to 7.31 percent. Rates shot up after a mixed report on producer prices showed that overall prices fell a tenth of a percent while the core rate, which excludes food and energy prices, rose four-tenths of a percent.
Bond traders may have paid even more attention to the Commodity Research Bureau index, which rose 1.21 points, to 232.88, the fourth rise in a row. The index is a proxy for commodities traders' inflation outlook.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose five-tenths of a point, to 253.59, with advancing stocks outnumbering declining stocks by 1,189 to 878. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 0.66 point, to 441.84.
Of the 30 components of the Dow industrials, 18 rose, led by Alcoa, which helped to lift the average by 4.3 index points. Of the 500 component stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, 217 rose.
In Tokyo, stocks finished slightly lower yesterday, failing to maintain an early rally after the Bank of Japan released its quarterly "tankan" corporate survey showing some signs of improvement in the economy. The Nikkei index of 225 issues ended down 7.60 points, or four-hundredths of a percent, at 21,395.18. It had risen as high as 21,559.81 earlier in the day.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
 California has been operating the first state-sponsored insurance-purchasing alliance for small companies that allows their employees to choose health coverage at relatively lower rates. Congress is considering proposals to provide Federal money to help states set up alliances like California's year-old program. [Page 1.]
The Government issued a mixed report on inflation, showing that producer prices edged down one-tenth of 1 percent in May but only because of big declines in food and energy prices. Excluding those components, the Producer Price Index's core rate rose four-tenths of 1 percent. [37.]
 
Companies
 A Federal judge ordered Microsoft to stop selling and to recall two versions of its MS-DOS operating system, which is by far the most commonly used personal computer software. [37.]
The Ziff family's surprising decision to sell its computer magazine empire can be traced back four years, when three younger members began to show signs that they did not want to follow in their father's and grandfather's footsteps. [37.]
The Fidelity mutual fund group has sharply cut its stake in United Airlines' parent company, signaling its distaste for the proposed buyout of the carrier. [37.]
A Federal appeals court overturned new regulations intended to force local phone companies to accept more competition. [37.]
Perot Systems is said to be considering a partnership or possibly a merger with SHL Systemhouse, Canada's largest independent computer services company. [39.]
Jamesway's chief executive departed to become the head of its bigger rival, Ames Department Stores, in a move that may have sounded the death knell for the ailing Jamesway. [39.]
Directors of Curtice-Burns Foods accepted a takeover offer from Dean Foods with an effective value of $453 million. [39.]
 
International
 In the third big scandal to hit Germany's financial community this year, bankruptcy papers were filed by Balsam A.G., an international sports flooring company that is the focus of a huge fraud investigation. [39.]
 
Markets
 The stock market rose moderately, aided by gains in blue-chip stocks and a surge in some technology-related stocks. The Dow Jones industrials rose 20.31 points, to 3,773.45. But the trading volume remained slow. [38.]
Treasury prices fell and interest rates rose as investors became increasingly concerned whether inflation would remain subdued, especially in light of the Government's mixed report on May producer prices. [46.]
The dollar slipped against other currencies, pulled down by falling bond prices. [48.]
Volatile grain prices climbed following forecasts of a few more days of rain-free weather in the Corn Belt. [48.]
 
Your Money
 Corporate retirement plans are subject to regulations and backstops of varying degrees, but sometimes there are no guarantees -- merely good faith and financial strength. [35.]
 Government bond funds are often less conservative than investors may think, with some consisting of leveraged pools of highly complex securities. [35.]
BankAmerica pumped $17.4 million in capital into its Pacific Horizon Prime money market fund in May to make up for losses from investments in exotic securities. [35.]
State insurance regulators are looking more closely at companies that provide terminally ill people with early payouts on their life insurance policies. [36.]

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Send Mixed Signal

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 10

 BODY:
In a mixed report on inflation, prices received by American producers edged down one-tenth of 1 percent for the second consecutive month in May, but only because of big declines in food and energy prices, Labor Department figures showed today.
Without those components, which often swing erratically in response to the weather or political developments, the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods climbed four-tenths of 1 percent, a pace a little faster than expected. 
 "This economy is tightening up and we are getting a little bit of inflation at the producer level, but it's not very serious," said L. Douglas Lee, chief economist for NatWest Markets in Washington.
 
Selling in Bond Market
 The Labor Department's report prompted some selling in the bond market, pushing interest rates modestly higher, as traders and other operators seemed to be unnerved more by the rise in so-called core, or underlying, inflation than reassured by another slight easing in the overall index. [Page 46.]
Separately, a panel of 52 forecasters surveyed by Blue Chip Economic Indicators trimmed its estimate of inflation at the consumer level this year by one-tenth of a point, to 2.7 percent, the same as last year, while maintaining its prediction of 3.3 percent for 1995. Blue Chip, based in Sedona, Ariz., reports its findings on the 10th day of each month.
Analysts said the producer price figures did not seem likely to hasten any additional tightening of monetary policy by the Federal Reserve.
The increase of four-tenths of 1 percent in the core rate -- exceeded only in January and matched only in November during the last year -- was concentrated mainly in tobacco and motor vehicles, the department found.
But tobacco prices were unchanged before the department adjusted them statistically to account for seasonal factors.
"I don't think volatile tobacco prices are enough to fire up the Fed to raise rates again," said Jay Goldinger, investment strategist at Capital Insight in Los Angeles.
The higher prices for light trucks and passenger cars -- up 2 percent and eight-tenths of 1 percent, respectively -- reflected the recent weakness of the dollar against the Japanese yen that has made Japanese cars relatively more expensive and thereby has given American producers an umbrella under which to raise prices.
The Producer Price Index, unlike the Consumer Price Index, which is scheduled to be issued on Tuesday, excludes imported goods and most services.
Without the inclusion of tobacco and motor vehicles, Merrill Lynch calculated, the core Producer Price Index would have moved up just one-tenth of 1 percent, and the overall index would have fallen three-tenths of 1 percent.
A main source of unease today seemed to involve prices at the intermediate stage of production, just before finished goods. The overall intermediate index rose two-tenths of 1 percent, but a rise of three-tenths of 1 percent for the intermediate core was slightly faster than the January-April period that was itself slightly faster than the average in 1993.
"There are signs of incipient inflation pressure," said Carl J. Palash, economist at MCM MoneyWatch, a New York advisory firm.
Crude materials, on the other hand, dropped 1.4 percent over all last month, and 1.1 percent without food and energy, the report also showed.
The finished-goods index, in which energy was down 1 percent, reflected a drop of 2.8 percent in gasoline prices and declines for residential gas and electricity that were larger than in April. But home heating oil turned up.
Food prices fell nine-tenths of 1 percent as declines accelerated for red meats, fresh and dry vegetables, eggs and processed chickens while dairy products and processed turkeys turned down. Fresh fruits and melons jumped 5.6 percent, reversing a decline in April.
Capital equipment rose four-tenths of 1 percent for the second consecutive month, with increases for motor vehicles and commercial furniture more than offsetting a decline for civilian aircraft.
In intermediate goods, like a bolt of cloth, the main upward pressure was from materials used in manufacturing.
Durable materials jumped nine-tenths of 1 percent as prices for copper and brass mill shapes surged 6.9 percent, after falling about 1 percent in April, while indexes also turned up last month for hot and cold rolled steel sheet and strip, plywood, copper cathode, flat glass and aluminum mill shapes. Partly offsetting those were declines for building paper and building board and smaller increases for aluminum ingots and cement.
Nondurable manufacturing materials rose seven-tenths of 1 percent, a bit less than in April, as primary and intermediate basic organic chemicals, fertilizer materials, woodpulp, paperboard, paper and plastic resins and materials all advanced. Basic organic chemicals declined.
Construction materials rose two-tenths of 1 percent after falling twice that much in April, the Labor Department also found in its survey, which is conducted by mail questionnaire to cover prices for the Tuesday of the week containing the 13th of the month.
Consumer prices, by contrast, are surveyed throughout the month.
Crude prices in today's report showed energy up 1 percent -- in contrast to declines at later stages.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Producer Prices" Indexc of finished goods prices. 1982-100. Seasonally adjusted. Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics

HEADLINE: Even Wealthy Haitians Starting to Feel Pinched

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, June 8

 BODY:
The BMW's and bougainvillea of the hilltop neighborhood of Juvenat sometimes make it difficult to remember that Haiti is the hemisphere's poorest country, or that for more than two years it has been subjected to a series of ever tighter international embargoes.
This enclave of mostly newly made fortunes is shaken only by the rumble of earth-moving equipment rushing to complete private roads whose access will be monitored by the latest in electronic security devices. Despite a worldwide ban on trade with Haiti, great cement and marble mansions are still going up here that would make denizens of Beverly Hills blush. 
 But if the holders of Haiti's unexplained fortunes seem anything but eager to release their grip and allow the restoration of the exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, for many others, increasingly including many well-to-do Haitians, the pressures of the outside world are beginning to tell.
Haiti's national bank has been the scene this week of angry confrontations as holders of Government checks have been told they will have to return to collect their funds because of a run on cash reserves.
 
Scramble for Cash
 In times of unrest, people here have long been used to paying a premium to buy American dollars. Lately, however, even the local currency, the gourde, has become scarce, as nervous Haitians stow away whatever savings they have to wait out the crisis.
Many say the scramble for cash is likely to get worse. A tightening of the international embargo announced this week will suspend all financial transactions with Haiti. This measure will end an estimated flow of $200 million to $300 million sent by Haitians living abroad to their families here each year.
Since sanctions were first imposed shortly after the coup in September 1991 against Father Aristide, economists here say those funds, along with large profits from cocaine trafficking, are the only things that have kept Haiti's economy afloat.
At the Port-au-Prince airport, the mood is also growing more and more frenzied as wealthy Haitians send their smartly dressed children off to the United States before a total ban on commercial air traffic takes effect later this month.
 
Rising Efforts to Leave
 Counterfeit American visas and fake immigration cards have been turning up in record numbers as those wanting to leave seem willing to try any ruse to board the last remaining flights.
Airline officials in Haiti say that in an incident that was hushed up last week, an airport worker was shot in the leg by a desperate traveler whose papers were rejected as invalid.
"This country has always been chaotic, we are used to that," said a Haitian airline official who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "But lately, with all the uncertainty over the future, it is taking on the feel of the Wild West."
For Haiti's elite and professional classes, for the first time in months there has been a suspension of disbelief over the determination of other countries and especially the United States to restore Father Aristide.
 
Much Nervous Waiting
 Each day has become a ritualized wait for news from the outside world on the latest measures to force the surrender of the Haitian military leaders, with no question more nervously debated than if and when a foreign military intervention might be undertaken.
With speculation running high, pure rumor and Byzantine interpretations of events have overtaken the news in a society that was already given to the mysterious.
Lately, as has regularly happened during the more tense moments of the long-running crisis, the reading of tea leaves has turned to supposed divisions between top army leaders.
The latest ruminations along these lines had for their unlikely inspiration a short news item broadcast by local radios about the violent eviction of a prominent lawyer from his downtown offices.
 
'Arm Wrestling by Proxy'
 One explanation was that the lawyer, Osner Fevry, simply owed 16 months of back rent. But for much of the country's elite, the circumstances, from the trashing of the office by shadowy police auxiliaries to the mysterious disappearance of a judge who had been involved in the matter, hinted at what one diplomat called "arm wrestling by proxy" between the powerful police chief, Col. Michel Francois, and the army Chief of Staff, Phillipe Biamby.
Diplomats with direct recent experience with the military confirm that tensions in that institution are rising too, but caution against drawing wishful conclusions.
Army irregulars stopped members of the United Nations human rights observer mission at a roadblock here this week, seizing their walkie-talkies and destroying radios mounted in their vehicles.
Making clear that the mood of the army had not changed from confrontation to surrender, the observers' verbal protest was met with the response, "You should feel lucky you are alive."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Decline On Inflation Concerns

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices fell yesterday and interest rates rose as investors became increasingly concerned about whether inflation would remain subdued.
The bond market found mixed signals in the Labor Department's report on producer prices in May, which posted a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent -- but only because of big declines in food and energy prices. 
 Moreover, rising commodity prices -- another closely watched gauge of inflation -- also rattled bond investors. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodity prices rose for a fourth day, gaining 1.21 points, to 232.88.
Investors are still worried about the re-emergence of inflation, which diminishes the value of fixed-income securities. "It's going to take more signs of slowing in the economy" for bond yields to fall, said Monty Cleworth, who handles $300 million in fixed-income investments at Denver's Founders Asset Management.
 
Yield Rises to 7.31%
 In trading yesterday, the Treasury's 30-year bond fell 12/32 point, or $3.75 per $1,000 of bonds. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 7.31 percent, from 7.27 percent on Thursday.
Yields on intermediate- and short-term Treasury issues also rose, with the yield on the 10-year note climbing to 7.01 percent, from 6.95 percent.
Many bond traders focused on the Labor Department's report showing that excluding food and energy costs, the core rate for its Producer Price Index jumped a larger-than-expected four-tenths of 1 percent.
"The message from the rise in the core rate is that it's not all quiet on the inflation front," said Brian Hilliard, economist at Societe Generale Strauss Turnbull in London.
Yesterday's trading marked the first time this year that the bond market had failed to rally after the release of the Producer Price Index. On the other hand, it was also the first time in 1994 that bond yields were lower, not higher, than in the previous month.
Some traders noted that with Treasury yields at their lowest in weeks, investors would need more than a report on inflation for bonds to rally.
Inflation indicators reflect what prices were, not where they are going, said Craig Coats, who oversees $16 million in capital at Coats Asset Management, a leveraged Treasury bond firm in Palm Beach, Fla.
The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, supported the notion that inflation measures were not perfect forecasting tools. Mr. Greenspan said this week in London that measures of inflation, while "clearly restrained," were "history."
"If the best news on the inflation front is over, I'm not sure the Fed won't have to raise rates again," said Michael Marzano, head of bond futures trading at Yamaichi International (America).
 
Costs Seen Rising
 Thomas Rooke, director of futures research at Paine Webber, said the chief executives of United States companies were telling the securities firm that their costs were starting to rise.
The next guidepost for the bond market will come on July 8, when the Labor Department releases the June employment report, Mr. Coats said. The economy added 191,000 nonfarm jobs in May, fewer than economists had expected.
Treasury bond yields were about 6.30 percent before the Fed began pushing up interest rates in February. The 30-year bond ended at a record low yield of 5.78 percent on Oct. 15, 1993.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Grain Prices Up on Forecast Of Continued Dry Weather

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Volatile grain prices turned higher yesterday following forecasts of at least a few more days of rain-free weather in the already parched Corn Belt.
Because of higher prices for grain, coffee, cocoa and lumber, the Commodity Research Bureau index rose 1.21 points, to 232.88. The index is a key guide of commodity inflation. 
 The dry spring has worried farmers in a swath from Iowa through northern Illinois and to Ohio and southern Michigan. A high pressure ridge that moved over the Great Plains was likely to keep the region dry, weather experts said.
"Everybody wants to be bullish on the ridge coming in to keep the West dry," said Paul Haugens, trading specialist for Rodman & Renshaw.
"There wasn't very much volume today because they were afraid of what's going to happen Monday," Mr. Haugens said, noting several forecasts calling for a breakup of the ridge next week that could usher in needed rains.
 
Violent Price Swings
 July soybeans jumped 9.25 cents, to $6.82 a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade, while July corn added 2 cents, to $2.73 1/4.
The grain markets have experienced violent price swings recently on the changing weather outlooks, with trading on Mondays particularly sensitive to weekend weather.
The market is sensitive because of relatively low stocks of grain after last year's flood-damaged harvest.
Wheat prices also strengthened, with July wheat gaining 3 cents, to $3.38 3/4 a bushel.
Equally volatile coffee prices rose slightly in New York ahead of important crop estimates from the United States Department of Agriculture. July coffee rose 0.35 cent, to 125.20 cents a pound on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, while July cocoa gained $24, to $1,325 a metric ton.
After the close of trading, the Government estimated the global green coffee crop at 90.6 million 132-pound bags, down by 4 percent from last year's production.
 
Income Crippled
 Brazil, the world's largest coffee grower, was expected to produce 23.5 million bags, down 5 million bags from last year. Colombia, the second-largest producer, was expected to produce a crop of 12.5 million bags, the lowest since 1988-89.
The report said low world coffee prices were crippling growers' income and causing a downturn in production.
Elsewhere, oil prices finished lower after spending most of the session focused on the expiration of options contracts. When the July strike price of $19 a barrel was seen as unattainable, the market dropped off and finished lower. July crude oil fell 19 cents, to $18.48 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
"Once it became clear it wasn't going to make it, people decided to take profits ahead of the weekend," said Morris Greenberg of Lehman Brothers.

HEADLINE: ROWING;
Oarsman From Croatia Helps Brown Dominate

BYLINE: By WILLIAM N. WALLACE 

 BODY:
An enduring feature of college rowing is losing your shirt. Tradition dictates that after the races those who have lost come around and hand over their shirts, each with its distinctive school color and design, to the victors.
Igor Boraska, a world-class oarsman from Croatia, says he has collected "about 80 shirts," and no wonder. Boraska rows in the seven seat for Brown, the No. 1 crew in the nation, which has won its last 16 races over two seasons and goes for No. 17 on Saturday at the national championship regatta on Harsha Lake, Ohio, near Cincinnati. 
 Boraska and the other Bears in the boat can each expect to collect six more shirts, including the highly sought crimson one from Harvard. It will take a miracle, or an accident, for the Bears to lose because, said the Dartmouth coach, Scott Armstrong, "They are so powerful, it's ridiculous."
Crews from California-Berkeley, Cornell, Dartmouth, Harvard, Princeton and Washington will chase Brown, which has beaten all of these eights except Washington at least once this season (Dartmouth and Princeton thrice). Brown has thus ended Harvard's long reign as the titan of intercollegiate rowing.
Steve Gladstone, the Brown coach, has been the subject of criticism from other coaches for his worldwide recruiting, but he has an easy defense. He points to Boraska as an ideal athlete, devoted, hard-working, an excellent student and so grateful for the opportunities that were given him in his two and a half years at Brown.
Boraska, who just graduated with a degree in mechanical engineering and economics, is from Split, a city on the Adriatic physically untouched by war. Before Yugoslavia broke up in 1991, Boraska was a member of the national team along with Dennis Zvegelj, the No. 2 oarsman in this Brown varsity. Zvegelj is from Bled in Slovenia.
Between the Eastern Sprints at Worcester, Mass., on May 15 and last week's Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta at Syracuse, Boraska first went home to Split and then won a gold medal at an international regatta in Duisberg, Germany.

HEADLINE: A Stronger Case for Police Cuts

 BODY:
Rudolph Giuliani was elected Mayor of New York as a relentless crime-fighter. The police union gave him strong support, and he is now engaged in difficult negotiations over the next police contract. So his ritual rejection of critics who tell him to cut the police budget is understandable. But a little mayoral flexibility would serve the city better.
New analyses by State Comptroller Carl McCall and City Comptroller Alan Hevesi expose the weakness of his position. Also, the City Council is pressing for a small cutback that would let it restore some of the brutal cuts he proposes for other agencies, cuts made deeper by exempting police, firefighters and teachers. 
 Granted, both Comptrollers and the Council majority are Democrats. The critics could thus be dismissed as politically motivated. But this is a budgetary issue in which economies can be achieved without sacrificing public safety. No one proposes weakening the city's police force. Indeed, everyone wants to strengthen it. The critics are rightly alarmed by the awful waste of expensively trained police on office work.
The debate centers on a "memorandum of understanding" between former Mayor David Dinkins, Gov. Mario Cuomo and the leaders of the Legislature, under which the city was authorized to raise taxes and earmark lottery revenues to build its uniformed police forces to a total of 38,310. There is a growing consensus that, rather than counting the number of bodies in uniform, the proper target is "patrol strength" -- the number of officers actively involved in enforcement work, as distinct from desk duty. Mayor Giuliani and Police Commissioner William Bratton remain fixed nonetheless on total numbers, insisting it is the only measure that leaves the department free to deploy the force in the ways it feels are most effective.
State Comptroller McCall, in an audit of the police buildup, said the department had failed its "promise to New Yorkers" to move police out of desk jobs that do not need uniformed personnel and put them in the street. The city could save $11 million in just one year, and more in the years following, by substituting civilians for police in those slots.
In a separate report, City Comptroller Hevesi said nearly 1,500 police officers could be replaced with civilians who are paid less and get substantially less generous pension benefits. Mr. Hevesi's report also offered dramatic examples of what will happen to other services if the police remain sacrosanct. Too often, money saved now in shortsighted ways would cost the city lots more down the road -- like the cut in rat control that can only worsen public health problems.
The budget deadline is still three weeks away -- time enough for more jockeying and a rational compromise that strengthens the patrol strength of the New York City Police Department while reducing its cost.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Why Does U.S. Let Beijing Tell Us What to Do?;
Our Best Leverage

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Trade, the Real Engine of Democracy" (Op-Ed, May 25), Senator Bill Bradley has sought the stillbirth of linking trade privileges to human rights before the concept gets a chance to experience life. In dealing with China, he ignore our nation's proud heritage of principles over crass commercialism.
For example, there has been overwhelming support in Congress and the Presidency for economic sanctions as a tool to end apartheid in South Africa and restore democracy in Haiti. China's harsh repression of political dissidents, students and trade unionists is no less deserving of available nonmilitary actions to influence that government's behavior. 
 Trade sanctions are not always successful but are the best leverage we have. Senator Bradley talks about our growing exports to China, but is silent about the huge and growing part of our market China is taking. We have close to a $25 billion trade deficit with China, counting legal and illegally transshipped exports from there. Why should American consumers support a regime that doesn't respect many of the principles our country was founded on?
Since unions or any other collective action by workers are illegal in China, the country is in effect subsidizing its huge exports on the backs of its own people. Working conditions -- wages, required hours, health and safety -- are appalling, with no opportunity for the workers to change them. We should not put our stamp of approval on this type of trade.
Equally disturbing is the huge commercial operations of the People's Liberation Army. That China's military has an enormous source of revenue in the billions of dollars not subject to government oversight or control is, I believe, unique in the world. If the army wants to use the money to make secret chemical or biological weapons, who can tell it no? How can we negotiate a nuclear disarmament treaty with China when the military doesn't need the Government as its source of revenue? This independence is very dangerous, mainly to China's Asian neighbors.
China's trade surge has come mainly at the expense of other third world countries that export to us. It is these countries, most of which treat their citizens with dignity and legal protections, whose development we should aid by our consumer dollars.
I concur in cutting off trade with tiny Haiti, but it's hypocritical not to do the same with China just because it's big and we can earn more profits there.
 
JACK SHEINKMAN
President, Amalgamated Clothing
and Textile Workers Union
New York, June 2, 1994

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

And Bear in Mind
(Editor's Choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
THE BEAK OF THE FINCH: A Story of Evolution in Our Time, by Jonathan Weiner. (Knopf, $25.) A fascinating look over the shoulders of biologists who watched natural selection in motion over some 20 years in finch populations.
 
BLACK BETTY, by Walter Mosley. (Norton, $19.95.) In Mr. Mosley's fourth novel about the black Los Angeles private detective Easy Rawlins, Easy agrees to track down Black Betty, "a great shark of a woman" who figured conspicuously in his own earlier life.
 
BONE BY BONE: Stories, by Gary Krist. (Harcourt Brace, $19.95.) Fictions that carry their own weight by drawing, with engaging observation, the daily activities of ordinary people learning to swim in hot water.
 
THE CONFIRMATION MESS: Cleaning Up the Federal Appointments Process, by Stephen L. Carter. (Basic Books, $21.) A law professor argues cogently that the Federal confirmation process has become a monster, grotesquely unfair to nominees of both right and left, and destructive to the political life of the nation.
 
EDITH WHARTON: An Extraordinary Life, by Eleanor Dwight. (Abrams, $39.95.) This life of the novelist in whose work architecture serves virtually as a language lays special emphasis on the houses and gardens Wharton inhabited and carefully made her own; copious illustrations.
 
LEAN AND MEAN: The Changing Landscape of Corporate Power in the Age of Flexibility, by Bennett Harrison. (Basic Books, $25.) An economist's polemic against analysts who see small, efficient businesses as the models for social organization in a world of rapid change.
 
MASTERS OF AMERICAN SCULPTURE: The Figurative Tradition From the American Renaissance to the Millennium, by Donald Martin Reynolds. (Abbeville, $67.50.) A clear, readable art historian's guide, handsomely illustrated, to modern American figurative sculpture.
 
SCHOOL FOR THE BLIND, by Dennis McFarland. (Houghton Mifflin, $21.95.) A deft, affecting novel whose aging protagonist retires in the vain hope that he can plan the outcome of life and decline slowly, affably toward its end.
 
SHOT IN THE HEART, by Mikal Gilmore. (Doubleday, $24.95.) Fifteen years after Norman Mailer's "Executioner's Song," Gary Gilmore's youngest brother reclaims his own life in this highly personal account of his family.
 
THANK YOU FOR SMOKING, by Christopher Buckley. (Random House, $22.) A comic novel that succeeds in enlisting the reader on the side of the devils, represented by an implausible hero: Nick Naylor, an energetic, unscrupulous lobbyist for the cigarette industry.
 
A WAY IN THE WORLD, by V.S. Naipaul. (Knopf, $23.) A brilliant, probing autobiographical meditation on empire and inheritance by a mind at the peak of its powers, made of complementary narratives about characters from the author to Sir Walter Raleigh.
