SECTION: Section 4A; Page 11; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 990 words

HEADLINE: Players And Payers

BYLINE: By Michael Graetz and James Tobin; Michael Graetz, professor of law at Yale, was Assistant to the Secretary of the Treasury from 1990 to 1992. James Tobin, emeritus professor of economics at Yale, won the Nobel Prize in Economic Science in 1981.

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN

 BODY:
The President and First Lady have achieved remarkable consensus on a truly revolutionary principle: All Americans must be entitled to adequate medical services without regard to ability to pay or risk of ill health. Now it's up to Congress to embody that principle in law, a historic opportunity comparable to the enactments of Social Security in 1935 and Medicare in 1965.
Unfortunately, excessive solicitude for existing institutions and interests, and the difficulties of reconciling them with the Clintons' fundamental principles, have made their proposal a bureaucratic and legalistic morass. 
 The biggest flaw in the Administration proposal is the requirement that employers pay the premiums -- a mandate whose awkwardness and unfairness stand out starkly in a system dedicated to universal coverage.
Employer-based medical insurance is a historical accident -- one that no one would choose now if given a clean slate. During World War II, trade unions and employers circumvented Federal wage ceilings by offering medical fringe benefits. Their popularity and generosity boomed after the war, as Congress sheltered them without limit from income and Social Security taxes.
The fact that employers write the checks for medical care does not mean that they bear the full costs. They can generally shift some costs to workers in reduced take-home pay and some to customers in higher prices. The sure losers are taxpayers who have to make up the revenue lost to the tax shelter.
Much of the Administration's 1,300-page proposal is devoted to expedients intended to mitigate the difficulties and anomalies of employer mandates. It's a hopeless task. Some families have no employed members. Some have two or more. Many employees work part time. Some have more than one job. Americans frequently change jobs, employers, work locations, places -- even states -- of residence.
Under an employer mandate, responsibilities for paying a family's premiums would frequently be divided among several sources -- various employers, governments and the family itself -- in proportions varying month to month. Keeping track of these liabilities would surely involve extensive paperwork and administrative hassle, contrary to Mrs. Clinton's claim that an employer mandate eliminates the need to track individuals.
Nor would the new system be equitable. Equity demands that public subsidies, direct or via employers, be a larger share of premiums and of income the poorer the family. Equity also requires that families' subsidies be the same if their incomes are the same.
But in the Clinton plan, subsidies depend more on the size of employers' payrolls than on families' ability to pay. The system is also full of bad incentives -- for example, not to hire workers with dependents.
It's individuals who get sick and need medical services. It's individuals and families whose ability to pay is the natural criterion of equity. It's individuals who must be guaranteed coverage. So it's individuals who must be required to have insurance. Let employers help pay the premiums if they wish, but count those payments as taxable income. Treat the self-employed exactly the same as employees.
Let people choose where they will buy insurance. One option should be a version of Medicare or a selection of the health plans made available to Federal employees. Let's call this option Fedmed.
Fedmed would offer the basic universal medical insurance package at premiums that in total would cover the costs. Let private health plans offer the same package, provided they do not pick and choose members or charge higher premiums for risky cases. As in the Clinton plan, it would probably be necessary to collect money from plans that happen to have low-risk clienteles and distribute them to plans with high-risk members.
With these provisions, Fedmed would be protected against becoming the last-resort insurer of bad risks. As in Medicare itself (which would continue as at present), people could choose their own physicians and other providers.
Fedmed would have low administrative costs and would wield enough clout to limit payments to providers. It would also let people change employment status, residence or family situation without losing coverage. But it need not be a monopoly.
Federal subsidies to individuals would take the form of refundable tax credits, "vouchers" or a credit card payable to Fedmed or other insurers. For low-income families the subsidies would cover the whole premium of the basic package; most other families would receive vouchers at least as valuable to them as the current tax exemption for employer-provided insurance.
A family of four in the 28 percent tax bracket with a $4,300 insurance package would receive vouchers of $1,204 -- 28 percent of the premium. No family would face an out-of-pocket cost of more than 10 percent of income for the basic package.
This plan would not require new broad-based taxes or new burdens on employers. One source of financing would be redirecting the Clintons' proposed subsidies to employers and low-income people, about $100 billion in 1999. Eliminating the tax shelter for employer-paid premiums would contribute $125 billion, and our plan would replace Medicaid acute care for those under 65 (about $75 billion more).
Robert Reischauer of the C.B.O. destroyed a semantic attraction of employer mandates when he testified recently that federally required purchases of insurance should be included in the budget. Their popularity is waning among businesses and in Congress, where support appears to be growing for the plans of Representative Jim Cooper and Senator John Chafee; unfortunately, these plans do not assure universal coverage in this century.
Our proposal is not a radical reconstruction. It builds on the best of existing institutions. A victory for it would be a victory for the basic principles that the Clintons have so eloquently set forth.

GRAPHIC: Drawing

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

SECTION: Section 6; Page 41; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 3108 words

HEADLINE: A Bridge Too Far?;
Benjamin Chavis

BYLINE: Alex Kotlowitz writes about race and urban issues.

 BODY:
AS THE Rev. Benjamin F. Chavis Jr. finishes his fiery address at William Paterson College in Wayne, N.J., he readies himself for the inevitable Farrakhan question. A middle-aged white man leans into a microphone set up for the audience. Does he, Chavis, refute the anti-Semitism of the Nation of Islam minister? Doesn't Chavis think it unusual that he, the leader of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, the nation's oldest and largest civil rights organization, would invite Farrakhan to a conference of national black leaders?
Chavis (pronounced CHAY-vis) moves stiffly away from the podium, his arms folded across his chest. He reminds the questioner that in a speech at the Smithsonian Institution in January -- just weeks after a senior Farrakhan aide had delivered a hate-filled speech at Kean College in Union, N.J. -- he had denounced anti-Semitism as a "hideous form of racial hatred and bigotry." The N.A.A.C.P., Chavis continues, does not condone bigotry of any kind. Then, with his right arm slashing the air, he asserts, "The N.A.A.C.P. will not be dictated to." The blacks in the auditorium, most of whom are middle-aged and middle-class, pepper their applause with shouts of "Amen." 
 Earlier that evening, as we drove from Newark Airport to the college, Chavis had predicted just such a response. Civil rights leaders in recent years "had punked out" (street lingo for having backed down), he said, and that if he and the N.A.A.C.P. are to win the hearts and minds of blacks, he must not "punk out early."
In April, Chavis, who is 46, completed his first year as executive director of the Baltimore-based N.A.A.C.P., and it is fair to say that in that short time Chavis has not punked out. He has placed himself at the epicenter of a vigorous, heated debate over what direction the once-vital civil rights movement should take. In the simplest of terms, the debate has pitted longtime integrationists against a growing black nationalist sentiment. It is what one historian calls "a timeless conundrum" that ripens with each new generation of black leaders. W. E .B. Du Bois debated Booker T. Washington on just that subject; the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. tangled with Malcolm X.
In entering the fray, Chavis has pushed the N.A.A.C.P. back into the spotlight, sharpening the edges of what one member describes as "a genteel, lace-curtain organization." This is, after all, an organization that in recent years has been widely known for its televised Image Awards.
While Chavis insists he has not abandoned the N.A.A.C.P.'s long march toward integration, he sees its future as a champion for self-help and economic empowerment. By placing an emphasis on building and strengthening black institutions, including small businesses and black colleges, Chavis hopes to revive, if not redefine, the N.A.A.C.P. -- and by extension the civil rights movement, which has been languishing since the extraordinary victories of the 1950's and 60's. Indeed, the 85-year-old N.A.A.C.P. saw its membership plummet from one million in the early 1960's to under 500,000 in the early 1990's.
The N.A.A.C.P. has, in its recent past, represented largely middle-class, politically moderate blacks and has historically been reluctant to form coalitions. But Chavis hopes to broaden the organization's base, which means engaging the disparate and sometimes oppositional forces within the black community, including Farrakhan's Nation of Islam. Chavis is awed by Farrakhan's ability to turn out blacks -- more than 20,000 at a recent speech in Houston; Chavis himself barely filled half the 961-seat auditorium at William Paterson.
Although Chavis has begun a much-needed crusade to involve young blacks in discussions about their future, some of his efforts have been controversial. He has supported and attended gang conferences in cities like Chicago and Kansas City. He has proposed opening N.A.A.C.P. chapters for Hispanic- and Asian-Americans. And two months ago in Detroit he met with leading black nationalists and pan-Africanists, including Leonard Jeffries and Lenora Fulani, taking considerable heat from his own board. In fact, Chavis has so riled some N.A.A.C.P. members that there is an effort underfoot to remove him as executive director.
Chavis's most ambitious undertaking to assemble the varied elements of the African-American community begins today in Baltimore. He has convened a three-day conference of black leaders to thrash out differences over, among other things, economic, educational and criminal-justice concerns. Those invited include Farrakhan; the Rev. Jesse Jackson; Coretta Scott King; the members of the Congressional Black Caucus; business leaders like John Johnson and scholars like Cornel West.
"I'm a child of the N.A.A.C.P.," Chavis says, "but I'm also a child of the broader movement." As he steers the N.A.A.C.P. on a course of black self-help, Chavis views integration as more of a byproduct than a goal in the struggle for racial equality. Building stronger black institutions and communities, he argues, will create economic and social parity -- and common ground -- between whites and blacks.
"Empowerment and integration are not mutually exclusive," he says. "They are in fact inextricably linked."
CHAVIS SEES HIMSELF FOLLOWING in the footsteps of W. E. B. Du Bois, the activist and intellectual who helped found the N.A.A.C.P. in 1909. Du Bois wrestled hard with whether black Americans should assimilate or separate. In effect, Du Bois "invented the idea of racial and ethnic hyphenization," wrote the historian Eric Foner in The Nation. According to Foner, Du Bois concluded that "blacks did not have to choose. . . . Their destiny was to be African-Americans."
Chavis would agree. But despite this common ground, his political journey seems the mirror image of Du Bois's. Where Du Bois ultimately moved to the left, joining the Communist Party and eventually becoming a citizen of Ghana, Chavis went from wearing black power tams to muted-color business suits.
Along with three sisters, Chavis was raised in Oxford, N.C., a small town nestled among the rolling hills near the Virginia border. Chavis's father was a bricklayer, his mother a teacher, and like many blacks of the time, they passed down family history, in part to prepare their children for the inequities they would face in their own lives.
When he was 4, Chavis sat on his father's knee and listened to the story about his great-great-great-grandfather, John Chavis, one of the first blacks to attend the precursor to Princeton University, some 150 years earlier. He then returned to North Carolina to teach the sons and daughters of slave owners. He also surreptitiously tutored slave children and free blacks, and for that, the family lore goes, he was murdered.
"My father told the story in a way that didn't make you afraid," Chavis recalls. "It made you curious. Why did that happen? What was wrong with teaching black children to read and write?"
Much of Chavis's childhood memories revolve around his and his family's resistance to the Jim Crow laws of the South. He remembers mischievously drinking out of a whites-only water fountain; of receiving his first N.A.A.C.P. card, from his father, at age 12, and of angrily turning the Boy Scouts' three-fingered salute into a half-raised fist at a statewide jamboree where blacks were shunted to one end of the arena. Chavis became so defiant by age 12 that his parents sent him to live with his oldest sister, June, in Lenoir, N.C., a larger town where his antics might be less noticed.
Chavis went to college, first to St. Augustine's, his father's alma mater in Raleigh, N.C., and then to the University of North Carolina at Charlotte, where he majored in chemistry. Planning to become a doctor, he became active instead in the Southern Christian Leadership Conference. After King's assassination, he became more militant. In 1969, he ran for the Charlotte City Council, posing for his campaign photo in a leopard-skin dashiki. He was also ordained in the Black Christian Nationalist Church, based in Detroit.
His life then took another turn when he was recruited as a full-time organizer by the United Church of Christ, a predominately white, Protestant congregation active in liberal causes. "I was looking for someone with his boldness," says the Rev. Leon White, who hired Chavis.
White soon sent the young black activist to Wilmington, a coastal North Carolina city where black high-school students were protesting racial discrimination in the school system. The town was subjected to small acts of vandalism. Then, on Feb. 6, 1971, a white-owned grocery store was firebombed. Chavis and nine others were found guilty of arson and sentenced to long terms in prison. The Wilmington 10, as they came to be known, insisted that they had been framed. Amnesty International considered them political prisoners. Liberals rallied to their defense. After four and a half years in prison, during which time he received his divinity degree from Duke University, Chavis was paroled in late 1979. A Federal Appeals Court later overturned the convictions because, among other things, the defense had been denied access to a key prosecution witness.
In 1980, Chavis was ordained as a minister in the United Church of Christ. He continued his work for the church's Commission for Racial Justice, becoming its director in 1986. During his tenure there, he coined and popularized the term "environmental racism," commissioning a study that showed the propensity for industrial polluters and waste sites to be placed in or near minority neighborhoods. His work became so respected that he joined the Clinton-Gore transition team as an authority on environmental justice issues.
By his own measure, Chavis has become "more mainstream," although his prison experience and his flirtation with black nationalism have given him a certain cachet among young people, whom he is trying to recruit into the N.A.A.C.P. In his travels, he has made a point of visiting and talking with inner-city youth. "I know the lingo," says Chavis, who peppers his conversation with such street terms as "hood" and "homeboy." In his first year, Chavis has brought 160,000 new, mostly young members into the N.A.A.C.P., lowering the median age from 52 to 38 and increasing the membership by an astounding one-third. It is his most tangible and significant achievement as the N.A.A.C.P.'s new head.
"How does the weather look?" Chavis asks.
It is 1:30 A.M., hours after Chavis's New Jersey speech, and he is sprawled on his hotel bed, on the phone to his staff in Jackson, Miss. He is scheduled to catch a 7 A.M. flight to the state capital, where he plans to lead a march protesting the planned closing or reduction of three black colleges. He is so tired that he falls asleep while completing the next day's details.
Chavis keeps such a frenetic schedule he occasionally has his family join him on the road so that he can spend more time with them. He lives with his wife, Martha, and their two young children in a suburb of Baltimore. He also has three grown children from a first marriage (a fourth child recently died of liver failure). This usually guarded man is fiercely intense, his freckles the only, albeit unintentional, bow to playfulness. His detractors describe him as humorless, and he is uncomfortable with small talk or the idea of leisure. Avocations? He thinks for a minute. "I read chemistry books," he offers.
Chavis may indeed not have the luxury of taking a respite given the critical issues facing African-Americans. Black-on-black violence and the ever-growing drug plague are destroying families and unraveling communities. A Harvard University study shows the number of black students in schools with predominately minority enrollment is rising. And even the burgeoning black middle class -- in the words of Ellis Cose, author of "The Rage of a Privileged Class" -- "is in excruciating pain," because of the pricks and slights that have accumulated over the years.
Given such frustration and anger among both poor and middle-class blacks, integration as a goal is not a priority for Chavis. That reflects a growing sentiment in the black community that integration, as it has been practiced, has fallen far short of expectations. In a study financed by the Russell Sage Foundation, 47 percent of the blacks polled support the idea of an independent black political party.
So divided are blacks on the subject of integration that in St. Louis the black leadership is split over a plan that buses 14,500 mostly black children to suburban schools. In Mississippi, black leaders who want increased funds for state-financed black colleges find themselves somewhat defensively explaining that no, that doesn't mean they endorse separate-but-equal facilities. And tune into black talk-radio shows across the nation and you will hear about "nation building" or "opting out."
"We in the N.A.A.C.P. are engaging that sentiment, to get it to evolve from an isolationist stance," says Chavis. This is why he extends his hand to separatists like Farrakhan and Kwame Ture (the former Stokely Carmichael).
As Chavis mines such alienation among blacks, he risks being criticized for trying to be everything to everybody. And his message at times can seem jumbled. In his efforts to reach out to black youth, he has participated in highly publicized deliberations with street gangs, seemingly helping to perpetuate the very myth he denounces in speeches: that the majority of young blacks belong to such gangs. He says he backs the kind of community-based schools supported by Mayor Freeman Bosley Jr. of St. Louis, but he also endorses the vigorous defense of voluntary school busing by the local N.A.A.C.P. chapter. And he praises Farrakhan's self-help efforts while denouncing anti-Semitism, a seeming keystone to the Nation of Islam minister's world view.
Chavis's invitation to Farrakhan has met with stinging rebuke from critics and allies alike, particularly since Jews played such a prominent role in the N.A.A.C.P.'s early years. But Chavis appears unwilling to bend on this issue -- Farrakhan's strong following among young blacks can't be ignored. "There comes a time when even enemies must sit at the table to talk about the future," he tells the William Paterson crowd, even as he says later in his speech that the N.A.A.C.P. "doesn't retreat from its position" on anti-Semitism "because we sit down with Farrakhan."
Chavis has an ingenuous confidence in his ability to sway people, and one suspects that that extends to his relationship with Farrakhan -- or at least to his followers. There are few organizations besides the N.A.A.C.P., he says, "that pose an alternative to Louis Farrakhan." Nonetheless, his relationship with the Nation of Islam minister has drawn attention and energy away from his efforts to redirect the N.A.A.C.P. toward his philosophy of self-determination.
With nearly one out of every two black children living in poverty, Chavis knows that he can't afford such diversions. "We have millions of people because of economic inequality who are consigned to deprivation and degradation," he says. "And if you want to know what is the new beachhead, the new mandate of the civil rights movement as we move into the 21st century, it is the question of economic empowerment."
On the plane ride from Newark to Jackson, Chavis checks off what the N.A.A.C.P. has undertaken to bring capital into the black community. Agreements with more than 60 companies to hire and promote more blacks, as well as to buy supplies from black-owned vendors. Agreements with two banks to finance N.A.A.C.P.-staffed, neighborhood-based lending offices. An entrepreneurial training program for high-school and college students. The theme of next month's annual N.A.A.C.P. convention is "Accepting the Torch: New Initiatives for Community and Economic Empowerment."
"I'm a composite," he says, wanting to assure the old guard while appealing to the young. "Empowerment isn't about choosing between separatism and integration.
Not everyone agrees. One outraged N.A.A.C.P. member, Michael Meyers, executive director of the New York Civil Rights Coalition, is mounting a campaign to oust Chavis. "Our strategy should not be one of gilding the ghettos but opening up the suburbs to blacks," he argues. "The N.A.A.C.P. should help students integrate white colleges. Instead they're screaming and yelling about saving black colleges."
Chavis's most difficult challenge, however, may come from within the N.A.A.C.P., as some of the 64 board members have protested his efforts to build alliances with more radical blacks. "We are a mainstream, integrationist civil rights organization," says Joe Madison, a board member and radio talk-show host. "We never have pitched a broad tent."
Moreover, William F. Gibson, the chairman and a South Carolina dentist, has long viewed himself as the N.A.A.C.P.'s true chief, according to some people close to the organization. When Chavis was appointed executive director, the N.A.A.C.P. officially referred to the appointment as a "partnership" between Chavis, Gibson and the board.
"Clearly there's a struggle for control," says one insider, speaking on the condition of anonymity. Gibson says that is "a myth." He adds, "We talk two or three times a week; our philosophies of running this organization are parallel." Nonetheless, differences between the board and Chavis have become public enough that a recent N.A.A.C.P. news release made a point of affirming the board's support for Chavis.
"I'm going to steady the course of the ship and keep going forward; I'm not going to do battle." says Chavis, who refuses to discuss publicly his relations with Gibson and the board.
ON A SATURDAY AFTERNOON in late April in Jackson, Miss., Chavis leads 15,000 blacks, most of them college students, on a three-mile protest march from Jackson State University to the Capitol. It begins to rain, first a slight drizzle and then an unrelenting downpour. A sea of umbrellas unfolds. But not for Chavis, who, despite the casual dress of his brethren -- T-shirts, jeans and sneakers -- is in a gray suit and wing tips.
Unprotected and clutching a blue N.A.A.C.P. cap in his hand, Chavis marches, his body erect as a young marine's, his gaze fixed straight ahead. He seems invigorated by the warm rain. It is as if he sees this small act of nature as a test of his commitment, of his perseverance, of his capacity not to punk out. It is as if he is girding himself for further downpours.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 68; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 1154 words

HEADLINE: 72 Hours of Iceland (On New York Time)

BYLINE: By Peter Passell; Peter Passell writes on economics and other subjects for The Times.

 BODY:
Hmm. . . . Where to go this weekend? The Robertsons invited us to the Berkshires. But their furniture is covered with cat hair, and all they ever want to do is ransack the flea markets for Fiestaware.
Some guy in accounting was talking up a new bed-and-breakfast near Brattleboro. But the last time we tried one of those, the towels smelled of mildew and the syrup on the pancakes was strictly Log Cabin. 
 Well, then, how about a weekend in Iceland?
Yes, Iceland.
It costs a bit more -- well, a lot more -- but the flight doesn't take much longer than driving to the Hamptons on a Friday afternoon. And even three days in this pristine Scandinavian outpost perched amid glaciers, volcanoes, hot springs and waterfalls beats any number of the same-old, same-old getaways. And if you do it the way I did, you won't even have any jet lag to endure.
Here's the strategy: Take Icelandair's red-eye, which leaves J.F.K. every night of the week at 8:50 P.M. Formalities are a breeze at Keflavik, surely the most hassle-free international airport in the world. Then taxi straight to Reykjavik (glancing only occasionally at the lava-blasted moonscape along the road) and take a long nap.
The idea is not to fight the four-hour time change in summer but to ignore it, eating and sleeping by the New York clock. That turns out to be a cinch in the land of the midnight sun, since many restaurants in Reykjavik stay open till 11 P.M. or midnight to accommodate revelers.
Where to sleep? Icelandair's own hotels are pleasantly anonymous -- and cheap if booked as part of a package. But the freshly restored Hotel Borg is a treat: a prewar Art Deco building with a good restaurant and a sushi chef from Tokyo. (Even if you don't stay there, check out the racy decor in the restrooms.) Or consider the Hotel Odinsve, a calm and airy little place that, like much of Iceland, looks as if it were decorated by Ikea.
O.K., now it's noon, local time, and you are rested and ready to roll. Where to? You might head for any of a dozen farms outside Reykjavik for a leisurely ride on a pint-sized Icelandic horse. Trekking with these gentle creatures is said to be a fine way to get into the mood of the brooding valleys near the capital. I prefer pedals or motors, so I headed to the closest big glacier, the Myrdalsjokull, some 600 square miles of ice that covers a dormant volcano two hours southeast of Reykjavik.
In the winter, Benedykt Bragason organizes cross-country odysseys for snowmobilers frustrated by the lack of roaming room back home. In summer, he offers novices a chance to skim the glacier's hills and dales at warp speed.
The first hour of glacier-mobiling took pure concentration, learning to control the howling machine with a combination of throttle and body English as I followed Bragason's track through the snow. Once I was into the rhythm, it was like downhill skiing turbocharged: 95 percent thrill, 5 percent terror plus glorious vistas of the snowfields. Bragason commands $140 for two hours in the saddle. You can phone Snowmobile Expeditions at 011-354-1-682-310.
Back in Reykjavik, it's dinner at 10. The sushi-sashimi combo at the Hotel Borg is good, and -- unlike other restaurant food in Iceland -- a bargain. Afterward, there's time for a walk through the twilight, buttoning up against the chill of the island's springlike summer.
First impressions of this city of 100,000 aren't favorable: too much concrete, too little history. It's not that Reykjavik has bulldozed its past. There just wasn't much of it until Iceland struck it rich on fish exports after World War II. But the town, blissfully free of street crime, litter, pollution and psychotic drivers, does grow on you.
Don't miss the waterfront, where trim little fishing boats prepare for sea and larger whaling vessels wait in mothballs for the green light to kill Willy. Window-shopping turns up overpriced European clothes and ultrawarm Icelandic woolens. Puzzle over the surprising architectural consequences of substituting corrugated steel for more expensive wood siding. Painted, it is Lego-like charming; unpainted, it catches the light at sunset to produce an unearthly glow. The swans on the Tjnorin, the springfed pond in the center of town, are ravenous. Bring bread.
And if it's birds you want to see, along with the detritus of an active volcano, the place to go is the Westman Islands, an easy day tour from Reykjavik by commuter plane. Heimaey, the largest of the islands, was nearly buried by lava during an eruption in 1973. A third of the houses and a handful of farms are now buried under a pile of steaming stones and cinders that towers some 700 feet above the town of 5,000 hardy souls.
It was fun to climb the lava mountain on foot, pausing at the top for a candy bar and great view of the local daredevil motorcyclists, who bounce off the walls of the crater like skateboarders at a Santa Monica playground. Cruising the islands later, our local tour boat cozies up to seafront cliffs and inches into black lava caves lined crevice-to-crevice with nests.
Cutesy-poo puffins, which the unsentimental Icelanders net as game, are the prize attraction. But I was equally charmed by guillemots, diving birds all suited up in black and white, like ushers at a wedding. And a pod of killer whales hunting herring left me awestruck.
So that's two days which leaves part of a third before taking the late-afternoon plane back to New York.
White-water enthusiasts might want to get up a little early to make the trip to Gullfoss, a major waterfall not far from the 1,000-year-old ruins of Iceland's first republican assembly. I chose a more leisurely drive in the direction of the airport, through the windswept lava fields of the Reykjanes Peninsula.
Stop first at Krisuvik, where sulfurous gases bubble up from the gray mud and a vent in the rock has been blowing boiling water into the sky for as long as anyone can remember. But save the best -- or at least the weirdest -- for last.
At first glance, the Blue Lagoon seems to be the chemical waste-water pond for the smoke-belching industrial plant beside it. That's just what it is, but the smoke coming from the stacks is harmless steam, and the waste is a benign mixture of hot water and powder-blue mud from a geothermal electricity plant. Take a dip (towels and suits are for rent) and watch Icelandic teen-agers cavort in what might have been the set for an Antonioni movie. If you're as lucky as I was, you'll see one of the periodic gatherings of the Miss Iceland contestants practicing their smiles.
Is a lightning visit to Iceland worth the $1,000-plus price, not to mention the 10-hour round trip in a Boeing 757?
As a soul-cleanser, it sure beats the ritual luxuries of the pleasure palaces closer to New York. And besides, when was the last time you visited a place so strange that the phone book is alphabetized by first names?

GRAPHIC: Photo: Miss Iceland contestants in the Blue Lagoon last month. The geothermal electricity plant in the background gives the water warmth and its distinctive color. (PHOTOGRAPH BY RAGNAR AXELSSON/GAMMA LIAISON FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES)

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2381 words

HEADLINE: STAGE VIEW;
On Stage, Survival Of the Fizziest

BYLINE: By DAVID RICHARDS 

 BODY:
IT'S LONG BEEN KNOWN AS THE fabulous invalid and the Great White Way, but we may have to start calling it Six Flags Over Broadway.
While there has always been a raffish, thrill-seeking side to theatergoing, the distinction between Broadway and a theme park grew decidedly narrower during the 1993-94 season. 
 It wasn't just because the Walt Disney Company came to town, commandeered the Palace Theater with the stage version of one of its biggest animated features, "Beauty and the Beast," turned the lobby into a mammoth souvenir boutique and proclaimed its intentions of renovating a theater of its very own on 42d Street. Nor was it just because the producers of "Grease!" painted the Eugene O'Neill Theater shocking pink, scrawled some of the show's mindless lyrics on the facade and then, to complete a dubious effect, piped 1950's rock-and-roll hits out onto the sidewalk.
Still, as signs go, those were clear and unequivocal. You bought your ticket, took your seat and went on a ride. The seats just didn't move.
The season was woefully short on quality, although the 48th annual Tony Awards, broadcast from the Gershwin Theater tonight (on CBS at 9), will try to convince viewers otherwise. It was, however, long on glitz, special effects, flashing lights and scenery outperforming the performers -- all in the service of the enduring American fallacy that bigger is, if not better, at least better for box office.
To a degree, that has always been so. Ziegfeld didn't forge a name by shaving corners, after all, and it has been more than a decade since "Cats" launched the vogue for the megamusical (which costs megabucks and, presumably, weighs a megaton). Still, it used to be that spectacle was only a part of what Broadway offered its customers. Now it is very nearly everything, and the pressure to go for broke can be felt in the dramas and one-person shows too.
That "Wonderful Tennessee," Brian Friel's imperfect but questing play about three Irish couples experiencing a collective middle-aged crisis, was the first dramatic flop of the Broadway season was sadly prophetic. Ireland's greatest living playwright was writing about the unslaked thirst we all have for the spiritual or, as one character defined it fumblingly: "What is beyond language. The inexpressible. The ineffable." Broadway is no longer particularly receptive to the ineffable. The effable has become its specialty in the mid-90's.
In lieu of the ever more elusive theatrical magic, we get magic tricks, which are far easier to engineer. At the end of "Beauty and the Beast," the lifeless body of the beast (Terrence Mann) rises off the castle floor, spins in midair like a propeller and emerges from the ordeal as a suitably handsome prince. Understandably, everybody gasps, although it's merely the latest development in stage machinery that has already brought us helicopters lifting off and chandeliers crashing down.
Leave it to Ricky Jay, the charming sleight-of-hand artist whose one-man show "Ricky Jay and His 52 Assistants" was a runaway Off Broadway hit, to demonstrate that magic is not a trick. It's the irresistibly beguiling patter surrounding the trick. The mind has to be seduced before the eye can be amazed. Broadway seemed to get it backward this season. As if to underscore the point, Mr. Jay's 52 assistants were a deck of playing cards.
Size and money do not necessarily preclude quality, of course. The opening montage of "Carousel," the season's most artful musical revival, gives you the impression you're 10 years old again and standing inside a kaleidoscope. With each turn of the revolving stage, the director, Nicholas Hytner, alters the picture, until the gloom of a 19th-century New England mill has been supplanted by the giddy, come-hither colors of a traveling carnival.
Ian MacNeil's surrealistic set for "An Inspector Calls," which depicts the mansion of the wealthy Birling family as a glittery doll house isolated in a cobblestone moor, puts J. B. Priestley's socialist thriller on dazzlingly fresh footing. And Diana Rigg's rigorously intelligent performance in the title role of "Medea" certainly justifies the final coup de theatre, in which the rusted metal walls of the palace crash to the ground, leaving her triumphantly profiled against the racing clouds.
Writing down to the wire, Tony Kushner successfully delivered "Perestroika," the brilliant concluding installment of "Angels in America," his epic examination of AIDS and an ailing land and the front-runner to win tonight's Tony for best play. Everything about this two-part work has proved large -- its emotions, its themes, its running time (seven hours). Largest of all, though, is the compassion the playwright extends to each of his characters -- Roy Cohn, the drama's archfiend, included. The production is not without its own plethora of special effects (including an angel who somersaults in mid-flight), but the drama would probably be equally gripping on a bare stage. To prosper in today's climate, however, "Angels in America," lauded to the skies, has to be an eye-popping event as well.
Why else would "Twilight: Los Angeles, 1992," Anna Deavere Smith's compelling investigation of the rioting triggered by the police beating of Rodney King, come with sophisticated videotape, glide-on-glide-off scenery and space-age lighting? The real fascination is how Ms. Smith, playing nearly 40 real-life characters, changes -- no, mutates -- from one character to the next. No scenery needed.
Unfortunately, to envision (and promote) theatergoing as an event is to acknowledge that it is no longer a habit. While there will always be people to shell out $75 for a ticket (next season's top price for "Show Boat"), chances are they'll do so only once or twice a year. Under the circumstances, they expect to be bowled over. The clear loser in all this, as it has been for years, is the straight play, which, far more than the musical, lures audiences with intangibles -- the lies of the mind, the shifts of the heart, silence and suggestion. With the exception of "Perestroika," none of the Tony-nominated dramas -- "Twilight: Los Angeles, 1992," Arthur Miller's "Broken Glass" and Robert Schenkkan's two-part epic "The Kentucky Cycle" -- acquired must-see status, for all their respective virtues. And without it, survival is impossible.
The underlying danger here is that while producers desperately want to give spectators their money's worth, no one seems to know what that means any longer. Some of the indecision is reflected in the fact that more than half of Broadway's 13 musicals this season were revivals, and there were almost as many old plays (10) as new (12). When you're unsure of the future, the tendency is to fall back on the past and refurbish it.
To my mind, Christopher Plummer's wickedly mischievous performance in the Roundabout Theater Company's "No Man's Land" (four characters, one set) was worth anyone's money. Increasingly, the strategy is simply to give audiences more to gape at. Theatergoing becomes an adjunct of tourism, indoor sightseeing, if you will. To say that the revival of "Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat," once a humble school oratorio, looked like a Las Vegas stage show this time around vastly understated the case. It looked like a Las Vegas hotel.
Every square inch of "Beauty and the Beast" has been profligately illustrated, and you could no doubt mount an Off Broadway show for the price of one of Ann Hould-Ward's extravagant costumes. The musical is doing brisk business, however, and after an especially snowy winter that turned the theater district into an arctic wasteland some weeks, the business is highly appreciated. Since Disney is also a major player in the long-awaited redevelopment of 42d Street (the New Amsterdam Theater will be its Broadway base), "Beauty and the Beast" is officially held to be a good thing and its Tony nomination for best musical is applauded.
At the same time, the show is a scary harbinger. Broadway still likes to think that it is receptive to individual artistic initiative, and the corporate hubris of Team Disney -- determined to have a hit, and hang the costs -- was troublesome. In the Palace lobby, $25 will buy you a black sweatshirt with the "Beauty and the Beast" logo and the inscription "My first Broadway show." The unmistakable implication is that Disney will attract a whole new category of spectators, young and old, who have evinced no interest in theater as it has been practiced up to now.
If "Passion," Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine's study of obsessive love, wins the Tony tonight (my bet), it will be as much an anti-Hollywood vote as an endorsement of the downbeat musical itself, which is flawed. Better to reward flawed Sondheim, the feeling goes, than to throw open the town to "The Little Mermaid" live in an onstage tank. "Passion" is, at least, an adult musical that allows Donna Murphy to give a spellbinding performance, as a sickly 19th-century Italian woman, consumed by her love for a dashing soldier. You can discuss it afterward. "Beauty and the Beast," whatever its visual appeal, is very nearly content-free.
Under duress, the Tony nominating committee coughed up two additional candidates for best new musical. One, "A Grand Night for Singing," was no musical at all but an expanded nightclub revue of Rodgers and Hammerstein songs. The other, "Cyrano," would have been a huge hit, if breathtakingly opulent costumes made for high drama. But they don't, so it wasn't, and $8 million went up in battle smoke. The producers of "The Red Shoes" managed to lose another $8 million, by massacring a beloved movie, while the wizards behind "The Best Little Whorehouse Goes Public" spent $7 million for neon and the privilege of financing Broadway's most vulgar flop in years. The "Whorehouse" debacle was all the more disheartening because its co-director and co-choreographer was Tommy Tune, long thought to be one of the few remaining Broadway showmen capable of combining splash and class.
CHEERING NEWS OF ANY SORT was in short supply this season. Off Broadway generated what little there was. None proved more satisfying than the rehabilitation of Edward Albee, heralded as Broadway's savior in the 1960's, which now seem light-years away, as does the Broadway he was supposed to save. Mr. Albee began the season as a critical pariah and ended it, at age 66, with his third Pulitzer Prize for drama. "Three Tall Women," the playwright's acerbic profile of his autocratic mother on her deathbed, staged by the Vineyard Theater, was responsible for the turnaround. But an industrious Off Off Broadway troupe, the Signature Theater Company, helped by devoting its entire season to Albee plays, most of which had never been seen before in New York.
The most provocative works -- "Pterodactyls," Nicky Silver's loopy family drama; "All in the Timing," David Ives's antic one-acts; "Lonely Planet," Steven Dietz's lovely play about AIDS and friendship; "The America Play," Suzan-Lori Park's cryptic but hypnotic meditation on black history, and "Suburbia," Eric Bogosian's scorching study of lost youth -- turned up Off Broadway or in not-for-profit theaters. But even some usually dependable not-for-profit institutions (Playwrights Horizons and the financially strapped Circle Repertory Company) drifted artistically.
And the much anticipated renaissance of the Joseph Papp Public Theater that was to take place under its new producer, George C. Wolfe, had yet to happen, partly because Broadway continued to exercise a strong claim on Mr. Wolfe's time and energy. Both "Perestroika" and "Twilight: Los Angeles, 1992," which he directed, had protracted birthing pains.
Lincoln Center Theater alone appeared capable of combining innovation and tradition, Broadway's proclivity for spectacle and an Off Broadway spirit of adventure without losing its soul or developing a split personality. Its revival of Robert Sherwood's 1938 drama "Abe Lincoln in Illinois" featured Sam Waterston in a stovepipe hat, and 48 -- count 'em, 48 -- supporting actors, unthinkable for a straight play by today's commercial economics.
It's hard to imagine that "Carousel" will ever look as darkly beautiful as it does right now at the Vivian Beaumont Theater. What's more, under the umbrella of the Festival of New American Plays, Lincoln Center produced some stunning fare downstairs in the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater: Mr. Bogosian's "Suburbia"; "The Lights," Howard Korder's ferocious canvas of urban rot, and "Hello Again," Michael John LaChiusa's chronicle of seduction.
Mr. LaChiusa's smart, beguilingly world-weary work was the best original musical of the season, although ineligible for Tony honors, since it wasn't staged in a Broadway house. Stay tuned, however. A lot of healthy nurturing was going on at Lincoln Center Theater. The organization's sense of purpose and its eagerness to get on with the future merely underscored the wavering and confusion of Broadway.
Because escalating the stakes is Broadway's habitual way of dealing with a crisis, it's pretty much a foregone conclusion that the forthcoming season will see the big grow bigger, the stagecraft more amazing and the hype shriller, just as the thin patch of ground between the blockbuster hit and the instant flop will continue to shrink. Already a contest is shaping up between two super-musicals -- the revival of "Show Boat" directed by Harold Prince and Andrew Lloyd Webber's "Sunset Boulevard." "Show Boat" has one of the all-time classic scores. "Sunset Boulevard" has one of the all-time spectacular sets. "Show Boat" has a cast of 71. "Sunset Boulevard" has Glenn Close in the role of a lifetime. Each, we're being told in ad campaigns, will be unlike anything we've ever seen before.
Yet, this quest for the experience to end all experiences is suicidal, a death wish in disguise. A taste for sensationalism may be built into the American temperament. But catering to it will not save Broadway. One of Mr. Friel's characters inadvertently offered another solution. Replenishment, she speculated, as she gazed wistfully out to sea, may have something to do with recapturing "the wonderful, the sacred, the mysterious."
It's just possible.

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL VIEW;
Her Mission: To Stir Up More Fun

BYLINE: By Edward Rothstein 

 BODY:
IN 1964, RUDOLF BING, THE GENERAL MANAGER of the Metropolitan Opera, said of the newly formed Lincoln Center that it was "deteriorating into a free-for-all jungle." The next five years saw almost constant conflicts among the Met, the New York City Opera, the New York Philharmonic and the New York City Ballet, organizations that had at great risk and expense made the experimental arts center their new home. In 1967, John D. Rockefeller 3d, the chairman of the center's board, noted "feelings of mistrust, fear, competition and even bitterness" among the center's constituents. With recurring budgetary crises, it often looked doubtful that the institution that had created the phrase "performing arts" would survive.
Tomorrow, Beverly Sills -- retired soprano, virtuoso fund-raiser, ebullient former director of the New York City Opera and member of the board of the Metropolitan Opera -- will assume the post Rockefeller once filled, heading the Lincoln Center board. Miss Sills recently discussed her latest career move in her comfortable ninth-floor office in the center's new Rose Building, overlooking the complex. 
 "Nat came to me and said, 'I think we should be having a lot more fun,' " she explained, referring to Nathan Leventhal, the president of Lincoln Center. "He felt I could bring a little more cheer to the constituents, so they could feel they had a friend in court. I can see both sides."
Cheeriness may be too much to hope for. Problems of competition still exist, particularly as Lincoln Center itself becomes more active in fund-raising and programming; it presents more than 300 events annually and raises more than $16 million a year. But Miss Sills need not fear a free-for-all. The constituents cooperated in Mozart bicentennial celebrations, and Lincoln Center is now far from the fledgling operation that once seemed to lurch precariously from season to season. Its budget has grown from $11.2 million in 1975 and $30.5 million in 1985 to $56.2 million in the coming fiscal year. The center has become precisely what its founding president, William Schuman, predicted it would: the "new establishment" in the arts.
Miss Sills clearly relishes the opportunity to jump in. She praised Mr. Leventhal and expressed satisfaction at the financial condition of the center, which recently completed its largest construction project, the $160 million Rose Building, which houses dormitories for the Juilliard School as well as offices. She discussed new compositions, praising Hugo Weisgal's "Esther," which was performed last fall by the City Opera. She waxed enthusiastic about the future supertitle system at the Met, calling it "the best I've ever seen," and tentatively revived the recurring notion of a chamber-opera-size mini-Met. She dismissed reports of the center's plans to replace Mostly Mozart as "rumors," so they may remain just that. But Miss Sills, who will work closely with Mr. Leventhal, would not disclose her ambitions. The day-to-day struggle for financial survival during her City Opera tenure, she said, taught her to keep them to herself.
But any ambitions must take into account the profound ways the performing arts have been changed as a result of the center's success. Those changes have not always been for the better. The Met may have an acoustically satisfying house, but its stage is gargantuan, and its lobbies are uncomfortable and contorted; it nearly bankrupted the company and permanently decreed an oversize budgetary and artistic scale. Avery Fisher Hall was built because Carnegie Hall was to be torn down, leaving the Philharmonic homeless; the hall's acoustic history, which may finally be reaching a satisfactory conclusion, has been an epic of disillusionment. And as for the City Opera. . . .
"Listen," Miss Sills said about the company that was once her musical home, "you're looking at the girl who said, 'We should never have left City Center.' We should have asked the city for possession." She cited City Center's small downstairs theater for workshop performances, the more manageable budget, the character the 55th Street location gave the company -- all traded for another acoustically troubled building that now costs $80,000 a week even when it is idle. That move also had artistic consequences. But there is no turning back, and Miss Sills hastened to point out the benefits: the attractiveness of a central location, the clout of leadership, the possibility of an international impact.
OVERALL, HOWEVER, THE CHANGE IN economic scale has created a change in substance. The stakes are higher; fewer chances are taken. Mr. Leventhal may have begun to focus attention on these problems. The center added another small hall to the city with the Walter Reade Theater. Jane S. Moss, a vice president at the center, is attempting to design new programming. And Miss Sills said she wanted to expand educational programs, attract teen-agers with dances and get young listeners into the halls so they could find out that the center is "not as intimidating, not as formal, not as stuffy a place as they think."
More fun? Perhaps, but in the search for immediacy and responsiveness, the center can also risk diluting its artistic mission. Similar problems face many musical institutions that have grown up on the Lincoln Center model.
"I always stretched myself, taking risks," Miss Sills said of her singing years. She preferred learning difficult roles to repeating old ones. What she most misses, she added, is opening a new score and beginning work. The project she has undertaken this time requires a different kind of risk and virtuosity; her words are just the cheerful overture.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "I always stretched myself, taking risks," Miss Sills said of her singing career as she prepared for a risk of an altogether different sort. (Ozier Muhammad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
Laying Out the Route to a Fairer Assessment System

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
DURING their study of how to reform the New York City tax assessment system last year, members of a commission appointed by former Mayor David N. Dinkins came upon a steep cliff. They then proved themselves no mountaineers.
The steep cliff, to use the description of Stanley E. Grayson, chairman of the Real Property Tax Reform Commission, is the underassessment and undertaxation of Class 1 property -- 600,000 parcels most of them one- to three-family houses -- relative to other property. Higher effective tax rates on this class of property are widely considered a prime condition of moving toward equity in the property tax system. 
 Effective tax rates are the ratio of taxes imposed to the market value of property. New York's jerry-built assessment system over the years has produced widening disparities in effective rates. To make recommendations for improving the system there would have to have been a "consensus on objectives" in the commission, Mr. Grayson said. So the commission made none.
The fact that Rudolph W. Giuliani, as mayoral candidate, disdained the study hardly encouraged the Dinkins appointees to make a set of recommendations that would inevitably stir up controversy. So it made none, limiting itself to a description of how the problem evolved, the views of various parties and a financial analysis of alternative solutions.
Even if there were agreement on the need to raise effective tax rates taxes on homeowners as a class, there are other issues. The rates vary greatly within classes of property, as well as between classes. One reason in Class 2 (rentals, co-ops and most condominiums) is that co-ops and most condominiums are by law assessed in relation to their value as rentals.
Therefore, a very low valuation occurs for older co-ops in older but prime locations where rent regulation has held rents -- and therefore building income, from which an assessment is derived -- below market levels. Should co-ops and condominiums be assessed in relation to their sale value, or their value as market-rate rentals, instead?
There is also the question of how classes should be realigned. Should rentals be classed with residential property, or with commercial property on the ground that rentals and commercial properties are both income-producing. And should a reformed approach begin with a total reassessment of all property at 100 percent of market value? Varying tax rates could then be set for different types of property.
The present system, with assessment caps for Class 1 property and certain categories of smaller buildings within Class 2, promotes inequity within the classes. Over time, market values rise, but more so in better neighborhoods than in poorer neighborhoods. The caps prevent the property-tax system from reflecting this change.
In any new system that implies large tax increases for some payers, the increased tax liability could be capped in any given year. The figure most frequently mentioned for houses is 10 percent.
But that is still higher than the average increase in recent years, and homeowner representatives oppose any new system that would bring higher effective rates. "My constituents feel they are overtaxed already relative to the services they get," said Councilman Sheldon S. Leffler, a Democrat representing northeastern Queens communities.
This month the City Council is setting the budget for fiscal 1995, which starts July 1. The budget will determine the level of property taxes that will be set to achieve the necessary revenue.
What is already anticipated is that the class share of the tax burden will change, the result of changes in the relative market value of property. The market studies used are those done by the New York State Board of Equalization and Assessment.
The city has disputed the board's findings, which are adjusted from data collected in 1991, and the figures are not yet final. But legislators expect they will in the end increase the tax burden for all classes except Class 4 (commercial property) which will decrease about 4.8 percent.
Other classes will increase to the maximum 5 percent allowed by state law in any one year. Two years ago, when the study implied the need for a major increase in Class 2's share (8 percent had it been uncapped), the Legislature stepped in. It capped the increase in Class 2's share at 2 percent and allocated the balance between Classes 1 and 3 (utilities).
ORGANIZED co-op leaders pressed the campaign for assessment reform in the wake of the Class 2 increases. They have been stung by the size of tax increases in Manhattan locations for several years. Part of these increases are the result of the culmination of tax benefits under the J-51 program, which created apartments through conversions of older commercial buildings in the 70's and early 80's. Another factor was the general rise in land assessments in many Manhattan locations in the 80's.
The Finance Commissioner in the Dinkins administration, Carol O'Cleireacain, also was a voice for reform. She set in motion many administrative reforms, several aimed at educating taxpayers about how the system works.
Is there a path to reform that would distribute the tax burden more fairly? In New York City, the variation in effective tax rates appears to be greater than it is anywhere in the country. Businesses pay more and homeowners pay less.
The study found that the average homeowner paid $1,400 a year while the average house is worth $180,000. That produces an effective tax rate of 0.77 percent in Class 1 in the current fiscal year. In single-family neighborhoods outside New York City, it is more typical for the effective rate to be close to 2 percent. At a rate of 1.8 percent, for example, a house worth $180,000 in the suburbs would be paying an annual tax of $3,240.
The effective tax rate on Class 2 property in New York overall was 2.50 percent last year, the study commission found. But disparity within the class is enormous. Many valuable co-ops in prime Manhattan locations pay effective rates as low or lower than those in private homes. Larger rentals as a subcategory of Class 2 pay 4.58 percent. For Class 4 property the effective rate is 4.74 percent.
The reform commission explored many scenarios based on the principle of putting all residential property in one category and all commercial property in another. The Real Estate Board of New York, representing commercial owners, contended that that should be done only if a fixed, permanent ratio of effective tax rates were established between the classes. Otherwise they would be vulnerable to the inclination of legislatures to systematically shift the burden to commercial property, a tendency well proved by experience.
Under one plausible scenario for a two-class system, an effective tax rate of 1.56 would be established for the new residential class, consisting of all houses, rentals, co-ops and condominiums. That rate is a blend of the existing rates for various forms of residential property.
To achieve revenue neutrality under this scenario, the new commercial class would have to have an effective rate of 4.49 percent, creating a ratio of commercial-to-residential tax burden of 2.88 to 1.
"The total levy from the current Class 1 would double, with the tax on a typical $200,000 house rising from $1,557 to $3,124," the tax commission says. "The overall levy on current Class 2 properties would decline by 37.5 percent."
The magnitude of the decline results mainly from the benefit this would give to rental property. Older rentals in low-income neighborhoods pay high effective tax rates.
For those residential owners whose taxes would rise, the increase in tax liability could be capped at 10 percent a year. The homeowners paying $1,550 a year would never see an increase of more than $150.
But 10 percent is unacceptable, said Councilman Leffler. He maintained that equity might be established in residential property while keeping rentals in the commercial category, where taxes should be a "separate issue."
MANY high-end co-ops in exclusive Manhattan neighborhoods might also pay higher taxes in a two-class system. Assessors would have to be freed of the requirement that comparability to rental buildings is the only method permitted for valuing co-op buildings, now the case under Section 581 of the Real Property Tax Law. If Section 581 remained in place, homeowners would pick up an even larger share of the burden.
But taxes in many other co-ops, especially outside Manhattan, would probably be decreased in a the two-class system.
If rentals were omitted from the merger with Class 1 property, and only co-ops and condominiums are taken, there becomes a 22 percent reduction on the levy on co-ops and condominiums, the tax commission found. Then the tax on a $200,000 house goes up to $2,744 instead of $3,124. But that approach fails to correct some of the worst features of the present system, overtaxation of rentals.
The virtues of reform in the assessment system could be far reaching. "As the system works now there are excessively high taxes on less affluent New Yorkers who live in older rental buildings and older co-ops in less affluent neighborhoods," said Dick Netzer, professor of economic and public administration at New York University. Thousands of low-end rentals should be taken off the tax rolls entirely, in his view.
He also noted that the current system of assessment caps within classes works to the disadvantage of people living in poorer neighborhoods -- by definition those where market values are not rising as fast as they are in other neighborhoods. Assessors bound by the cap rules cannot take the relative changes in neighborhood values into account.
But as the history of rent regulation in New York demonstrates, reforms that hit voters in the pocketbook are slow in coming. There is no evidence yet that Mayor Giuliani will get behind assessment reform.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1; Column 5; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2174 words

HEADLINE: Reading the Giuliani Spending Blueprint

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
WHILE Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's first capital budget has drawn the most attention for what it doesn't finance, like a new Police Academy in the Bronx, the $5.294 billion spending plan does include dozens of significant real estate projects.
These range from the enhancement of neighborhood institutions (a new Flushing branch of the Queens Borough Public Library) to the creation of entirely new neighborhoods (the first streets, sewers and parkland in the Queens West development on the Hunters Point waterfront). 
 Money has been earmarked to plan, design or build major new courthouses in the Melrose section of the Bronx, lower Manhattan, downtown Brooklyn and Jamaica, Queens. There is money for the reconstruction of the Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn. The long awaited renovation of the New Amsterdam Theater on West 42d Street is funded in the plan, as is the acquisition by the city of privately owned buildings nearby where pornography outlets still thrive.
Because the capital budget deals with construction, reconstruction and acquisition, it profoundly influences the shape of the city, even though it is overshadowed by the high-stakes political battles over the operating budget, which governs day-to-day spending.
The City Council is to adopt both budgets in coming days. It is not expected to make many significant changes to the capital plan that Mr. Giuliani proposed in April, although it may well restore the new Police Academy, for which the Mayor allocated exactly zero dollars.
Last week, Borough President Fernando Ferrer of the Bronx said the prospects for reviving the Police Academy were "pretty good," adding that the $230 million project "may be scaled back a little bit" in the process.
Playing it closer to the vest, City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone, whose support would be critical, would say only that the academy "was in the budget last year and clearly is still the subject of negotiations this year."
With hundreds of commitments that stretch out over years, if not decades, the capital budget is less susceptible than the operating budget to dramatic reshaping, either by the Council or by a Mayor who has held office only six months. So the first Giuliani budget is, in part, an extension of the spending plans from the mayoralties of David N. Dinkins and even Edward I. Koch.
"The primary goal of the capital program, as it has been revised by this administration, is to achieve a state of good repair in the city's capital plant," said Mark Page, deputy director and general counsel of the Office of Management and Budget. "It's focused very strongly on things like bridges but it also includes money for mundane but necessary items like strengthening the floors in firehouses so they can actually support the weight of trucks."
"The political appeal of a capital program is to open new facilities," he said, "and there's actually little of that here. Even when you're talking about new facilities, you're talking about court facilities that we are required by the state to build or prison construction for increased capacity."
UNDER Mayor Giuliani's proposed budget, New York would commit almost one-third of its capital budget next year on city operations and facilities -- courthouses, sanitation garages and plants, prisons, municipal office buildings, police stations, parks and fire houses. In all, such projects would amount to $1.633 billion, up from $1.052 billion in 1990, making this the largest major category of spending in the capital budget.
"The first capital budget of the Giuliani administration is an activist budget that will give the people of the city many of the facilities that have so long been lacking," said William J. Diamond, commissioner of the General Services Department, which would develop many of these projects on behalf of other agencies.
At the same time, Mr. Diamond acknowledged that "every year there are more mandates" that dictate the nature of capital spending. But he said the city was "taking charge of what has to be done" in building courthouses and prisons, as well as in renovating structures to comply with the Americans With Disabilities Act of 1990.
Housing and economic development projects, on the other hand, would amount to $627 million, down from $816 million five years ago, making this the smallest major category. (Other categories include water and sewer projects, mass transit, bridges, highways, schools and hospitals.)
During his term, Mr. Dinkins began to shrink New York's capital budget to take pressure off the operating budget, which pays the debt service on the bonds used to finance capital projects. Mr. Page said Mayor Giuliani "has followed through on the commitment made last year to reduce the size of the capital program."
Indeed, the Giuliani capital budget for the fiscal year 1995, which begins next month, is about 25 percent less than the budget forecast for this year by the Dinkins administration, said Stuart Klein, associate director of the city's budget office. The 25 percent reduction does not apply to certain projects like hospitals, water supply and sewers.
Smaller capital budgets have strained the resources and tested the ingenuity of institutions that depend on city support, like the New York Public Library. It began an "Adopt-a-Branch" program in 1991, seeking private partners to supplement city funds.
The latest product of that partnership is the Sedgwick Branch Library at Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard (University Avenue) and East 176th Street in the Bronx. The small structure, designed by David W. Prendergast, is to open Tuesday.
Almost one-third of its $1.6 million cost was met by the Louis Calder Foundation. City funding came through Mr. Ferrer, using that portion of the capital budget -- 5 percent -- over which borough presidents are given discretion by the City Charter.
"We've had very little funding from the executive branch," said Catherine Carver Dunn, the library's vice president for government affairs. "Our capital funding has predominantly come from borough presidents and the City Council."
Mr. Ferrer said he tried to use his discretionary allocation as leverage. "The pot isn't big enough to create grand projects all by itself," he said. "The best strategic use is to induce the investment of other funds, both public and private."
The trend toward smaller capital budgets in which emphasis is shifted away from development is one that has been noticed approvingly by the Citizens Budget Commission, a private research and watchdog group. Its deputy research director, Brian Perlee, said: "The cutback of the capital program is something initially committed to by Mayor Dinkins in response to concerns by rating agencies. Mayor Giuliani has decided that's really the way to go."
Mr. Perlee cited the city's efforts to find ways to ship sludge out of state rather than building composting plants on Newtown Creek in Maspeth, Queens, and at Newark Bay on Staten Island. He also mentioned the Giuliani administration's push to lease space for schools rather than building anew.
"It seems to be a movement toward maintaining what we have," Mr. Perlee said. "In the long term, it'll end up saving the city money. It's a wise decision."
Others, like the New York Building Congress, see the trend as short-sighted.
"ATTEMPTING to preserve what we have by itself is simply not good enough," said Richard T. Anderson, president of the group, which includes builders, developers, contractors and architects.
He said the Giuliani budget was a "reasonable effort" that "fails on important counts: to keep the city in a state of good repair, to address an enormous capital needs backlog and to invest in our longterm future."
"It's business as usual with marginal modifications," Mr. Anderson said. "They're still spending billions for major social service, environmental, education and transportation projects and millions for economic development. That, to me, doesn't square with the administration's announced emphasis on economic development and jobs."
Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan also warned that diminished capital investment for building new apartments and preserving existing units would "only worsen the city's longtime housing shortage and exacerbate homelessness."
In addition, Ms. Messinger said, "Cuts in capital spending for mass transit would make this an infinitely less attractive city for future business development."
In Brooklyn, the principal concern was the fate of the $1 billion Kings County Hospital Center reconstruction project, on which the Giuliani administration declared a moratorium in February in the midst of long delays and cost overruns. Last month, however, the Office of Management and Budget included Kings County in the capital plan.
"We're very hopeful that the project will proceed," said Greg Brooks, executive assistant to Borough President Howard Golden. "That is a critical capital project to the borough, to the health-care system and to the people who use the hospital. We were very pleased to see that it was included."
The reconstruction of the Queens Hospital Center is a "very high priority" in that borough, said Peter Magnani, Deputy Borough President of Queens, noting that the administration had allocated $220 million for the project in its four-year capital plan.
"We're very pleased that the Mayor included most of our high priorities," Mr. Magnani said. "We don't really have a problem with what's not included."
Another significant budget line, he said, was more than $14.5 million for the first phase of infrastructure at the enormous Queens West development.
The president of the Queens West Development Corporation, Rosina K. Abramson, said: "This is capital money that will leverage Federal money and private money."
Ground will be broken in the next couple of weeks, she said, for streets and sewers around the block where the first building, a 550-unit co-op apartment tower, is to be developed by M.O. Associates, an American and Japanese group, with mortgage insurance from the Federal Government.
Phase one also includes an entrance boulevard to the project from 48th Avenue, as well as a one-acre park between Fifth Street and Vernon Boulevard. "The new building will be tied to the existing community," Ms. Abramson said, "so it won't be a lone pioneer in the wilderness and so the existing community will have an immediate benefit."
OTHER economic development items in the capital plan include the 42d Street project, the Audubon Biomedical Science and Technology Park in Washington Heights, pier reconstruction and the continuing renovation as a light-industry center of the Brooklyn Army Terminal in Sunset Park.
As part of the courthouse program, there is money in the capital budget for a new civil and housing court on Sutphin Boulevard in Jamaica, Queens; for a freestanding annex on State Street to the Brooklyn Central Court; for the first two phases of a "superblock" court complex between 161st and 163d Streets in the Bronx and for a new criminal court in lower Manhattan, perhaps atop an existing building at 80 Centre Street.
On a smaller scale, the budget for the coming fiscal year provides the first $8 million toward the $15 million Flushing Regional Branch Library, at Main Street and Kissena Boulevard, a glass-fronted structure designed by Polshek & Partners Architects.
City money only goes so far -- in this case, as far as the third floor of what is meant to be a four-story structure. The Queens Borough Public Library is seeking $6 million to build and equip the fourth floor as an Asian center, said a spokeswoman, Dianne Blancato. "The fourth story at this point is more of a vision than a reality," she said.
Perhaps the single most contested line in the capital budget is item No. PO-0205: "Construction of a New Police Training Facility, the Bronx . . . $0." Instead, there is a $10 million commitment for the redesign of the existing Police Academy in Manhattan.
"That's like putting money in a pile and setting fire to it," said Councilwoman Lucy Cruz of the Bronx, speaking of the plan to renovate the Manhattan structure, which is "obviously quite obsolete." Building the academy at East 153d Street, she said, was a priority both for the Bronx delegation and the black and Latino caucus.
The cause is also championed by the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects. Its president, Bartholomew Voorsanger, said the Police Academy project had attracted international notice thanks to a design competition that was won by Peter Pran of Ellerbe Becket in association with Michael Fieldman & Partners.
"It sends a very difficult signal that the first thing that's cut is a building of such design distinction," Mr. Voorsanger said. "There has been a long, long policy of make-do in the city. The inventory of our public buildings is in a deplorable state which needs a huge capital investment. What was extraordinary was the possibility of lifting everyone's vision."

COMPANY: NEW AMSTERDAM BOOKS (56%); OFFICE OF MANAGEMENT & BUDGET (59%); OFFICE OF MANAGEMENT & BUDGET (59%);
