HEADLINE: Q. & A.

 BODY:

10-Year Battle Over Rent
 
Q On Aug. 1, 1984, my wife and I took out a lease on a one-bedroom apartment in the West Village at $1,100 a month. We then received apartment registration showing that the apartment was rent-stabilized. The previous (controlled) tenant had paid $184 a month. We filed a fair market rent appeal that Dec. 11. 
 The owner, a New York limited partnership, was notified of the appeal by the Division of Housing and Community Renewal and given time to respond. Their response showed no cause for extra rent increase, and in December 1989 (five years later) D.H.C.R. ordered the rent reduced and the overcharge refunded. By that time we were paying $1,361 a month, which was reduced to $399. Retroactive reductions brought the original lease down to $308 a month. Overcharges totaled more than $55,000.
The owner continued to attempt to collect the illegal rent, so we began withholding rent completely. At this time a lawyer stepped in with a verbal agreement to receive 20 percent to handle the recovery. He advised us to resume paying rent, as at least one of the owners was a "millionaire" and we were sure to receive the full amount plus interest.
After several months the owner did reduce the rent to the legal level. As we began paying rent again, we had withheld $4,400. There was no sign of the refund, however, and the owner began to file PARs (petitions for administrative review) with D.H.C.R. Following two PARs, the ruling stood.
Our lawyer then served a summons and complaint to the owner, and the New York State Supreme Court index number was obtained on April 4, 1990. The owner was then allowed to petition D.H.C.R. again.
After the filing of the third PAR, the owner proceeded to allow the obviously unprofitable building to go into receivership in July 1991, and apparently this dissolved the partnership, though it is not shown at the County Clerk's office as being dissolved. The final PAR was rejected in May 1992, with 60 days allowed for objections. No objection came from the now-silent partnership.
Around this time my lawyer decided to stop answering my calls. I could get no information from him by letter, either. Though it appeared to me that a request for judicial intervention could have been filed as of July 1992, I waited until the end of November 1993 before releasing him and filing the request myself.
This was served on the owner, who continued not to respond, and the case was then resolved by the Supreme Court. The owner was ordered to pay the full amount plus interest. Now, of course, I'm told by the owner's lawyer that no recovery can be made since the partnership was dissolved.
D.H.C.R. had made it clear that this ruling was binding on the owner who overcharged me; a free market rent appeal is not passed on to later owners. So, in order for the bank to sell the building, I didn't mind signing a document stating later owners would not be liable.
Was it legal for the partnership to dissolve without notice or settlement while this case was under way? Am I actually out $51,000? . . . Brad Bealmear, Manhattan
 
A Getting the money back will not be easy, said Michael Finder, a Manhattan lawyer, but it is possible.
"If the prior landlord were a corporation, Mr. Bealmear probably could not succeed, but since the prior landlord was a limited partnership, if the general partners have money he has a viable judgment to pursue," Mr. Finder said. "The tenant's claim against the prior limited-partnership owner is not extinguished merely by reason of the alleged dissolution of a partnership. The dissolution does not eliminate the liability of the general partners and perhaps against the limited partners as well."
Enforcing the judgment against the partners, however, will not be easy. "Mr. Bealmear is first required to go after partnership assets before he can seek to go after the personal assets of the partners," Mr. Finder said. "Assuming the only partnership asset was the building, which they have since lost by foreclosure, the tenant will probably need some post-judgment discovery of the individual partners in order to try to locate their other assets."
That discovery can take the form of depositions of the partners or written interrogatories seeking written answers. "Depositions are more costly, because you have to pay a stenographer," Mr. Finder said, "but if cost is not an issue lawyers prefer depositions because that way the other side doesn't get a chance to nonspontaneously formulate their answers."
Although the D.H.C.R.'s position is that the current owner is not liable in this situation, Mr. Finder said there were a few court decisions that would support an action against the new owner. In addition, Mr. Bealmear might want to consult with a lawyer as to whether there is any impropriety in his previous lawyer's not responding to his calls and not taking aggressive action in the case.

HEADLINE: Vote in House Primary May Signal End of Era

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
THE Kean era in New Jersey Republican politics appeared to some Republicans to have ended last week in a bitterly fought primary for Congress in southern New Jersey, in which Assemblyman Frank A. LoBiondo of Vineland, a conservative, defeated a better-known moderate, State Senator Bill Gormley of Margate.
Former Gov. Thomas H. Kean, the longtime leader of the party's moderate wing, had endorsed Mr. Gormley and campaigned for him over the final weekend of the campaign, but Mr. LoBiondo's strong opposition to taxes and big government carried the day. Mr. LoBiondo was able to tap into these core Republican issues after Gov. Christine Todd Whitman made them the hallmark of her victory last November. 
 In an interview after the primary election, Mr. Kean said that he was concerned about where New Jersey Republicans were headed and that he intended to become more involved again.
"I worry about the party ideologically," he said. "And I intend to get involved on that side, not on picking candidates.
"The party has to get more comfortable with people, including blacks," he said. "I think this is the best time to begin addressing some things that are not being addressed."
He said the trend toward low taxes and tight government had always been a tenet of the party, but added the party could find itself too far to one side politically if it did not also recognize a responsibility to try to improve social conditions for all citizens. He said Mrs. Whitman was basically from the wing of the party that is economically conservative but socially moderate.
The race in the Second District, which includes Atlantic, Cape May, Cumberland and Salem Counties and parts of Burlington and Gloucester, became the most closely watched of the party contests for House nominations after Representative William J. Hughes, a conservative Democrat who won his first term in 1974 in the wake of the Watergate scandal, decided against running again this year.
Republicans say they have an excellent chance in November to recapture the seat they held before Mr. Hughes's victory, but Louis N. Magazzu, a Vineland lawyer who won the Democratic nomination, said he planned to keep the seat in the Democratic column.
Stephen A. Salmore, a consultant to the LoBiondo campaign, said, "We were able to picture the race as one between a Democrat and Republican, with LoBiondo running as the 'real' Republican."
But conservatives have a history of running well in Republican primaries and then losing in the general election when independents, who make up about half of the state's registered voters, go to the polls. Mr. Gormley's campaign aides were worried about moving too far to the right to try to defeat Mr. LoBiondo and then having a difficult time returning to the middle of the political spectrum for the fall.
Brendan Thomas Byrne, the New Jersey Democratic chairman, said he was happy that Mr. LoBiondo had won the nomination rather than Mr. Gormley, who he believes would have been a more formidable candidate in a general election.
Mr. Byrne also said he did not agree with the post-election analysis that depicts Mr. Magazzu as the underdog, and pointed out that President Bill Clinton carried the district by a narrow margin against President George Bush and that Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, who is on the ballot again this year, received 52.9 percent of the vote in his last campaign.
 
Write-In Campaign
 The Democratic primary in the 11th District also attracted wide public attention when the party's choice as a candidate, Daniel G. Tauriello, 34, an administrator at Middlesex County College, was thrown off the ballot after a dozen or so signatures on his nominating petition were challenged by John Kucek, an outspoken Holocaust revisionist. Mr. Kucek became the only name in the Democratic column for Congress in a district that includes Morris County and parts of Essex, Passaic, Somerset and Sussex.
Although the Democratic nomination in the predominantly Republican district has never been considered a prize, party leaders and Jewish groups conducted a successful write-in campaign for former State Senator Frank Herbert, who had represented Bergen County in the State Legislature and who now lives in Sussex County.
Mr. Byrne said he was "thrilled and grateful" for Mr. Herbert's victory. "The first thing we had to do was convince people not to vote for the Nazi," Mr. Byrne said. "Then we had to ask them to vote for Frank Herbert, and lastly, we had to teach them how to work the voting machine to register their write-in vote."
Mr. Kucek, 66, an accountant, has been a vocal supporter of David Duke, the former Ku Klux Klan leader turned Louisiana politician. But he denied being the bigot that his political opponents claim. "I'm not anti-Semitic or anti-Jewish," Mr. Kucek has said. "I'm pro-American."
On Wednesday, the day after they won party nominations to run for the Senate, Frank R. Lautenberg, the two-term Democratic incumbent, and his Republican opponent, Assembly Speaker Chuck Haytaian, were at the State House to open their general election campaigns.
Each man accused the other of distorting his record and each promised a hard-fought campaign, but no telling points were made during their separate meetings with reporters. Still, Mr. Lautenberg, who has earned a reputation for waging tough campaigns, said he expected his contest with Mr. Haytaian to be "the ultimate roller derby."
In his opening salvo Mr. Lautenberg depicted Mr. Haytaian as a strong opponent of effective gun control. He said that in 1988 Mr. Haytaian sponsored and pushed through the Assembly a bill that would have repealed New Jersey's seven-day waiting period for handgun purchases and would have allowed lifetime handgun permits.
The 70-year-old Democratic incumbent contrasted that with his co-sponsorship of the Brady Bill, which mandates a waiting period and background check before a gun may be bought, and of his support for legislation to ban assault weapons across the country. New Jersey in 1990 enacted its own ban on the sale or possession of a number of assault weapons.
In his first appearance as the Republican standard-bearer, Mr. Haytaian resumed a theme that he began during the primary election campaign, calling Mr. Lautenberg the "silent Senator" who is trying to win re-election without discussing issues.
The 59-year-old state legislator looked back to Mr. Lautenberg's first campaign for the Senate, when he defeated Millicent Fenwick, a popular Congresswoman and the inspiration for the character Lacey Davenport, in the Doonesbury comic strip.
At that time Mr. Lautenberg was the lesser-known candidate, and Mr. Haytaian said the Democrat wrote a letter to Mrs. Fenwick that said, "A select series of public, face-to-face debates is a critical opportunity to evaluate candidates."
Mr. Haytaian then issued a challenge of his own, a series of weekly debates in each of the state's 21 counties -- "with a week off for the Fourth of July."
"I'll debate the silent Senator any time, any place, with no strings attached," Mr. Haytaian said.

HEADLINE: The False Promise of Development by Casino

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
ONCE a forbidden pleasure confined to a few oases of sin, legal gambling is on a roll: From Oregon to Mississippi to Connecticut, communities are betting that betting is the ticket to economic resurrection. And no wonder. Building a gambling industry is widely viewed as the painless route to development -- prosperity, just around the corner, without the cost and effort of retraining workers, negotiating tax breaks for businesses or luring executives with good schools, efficient transportation and low crime rates.
But even as the $30 billion-a-year gambling juggernaut gains momentum, economists and regional planners are predicting that it will chew up more income than it creates. "If we end up with gambling within 100 miles of where virtually every American lives," warns William Thompson of the University of Nevada at Las Vegas, "it will be worse than a zero-sum game," leaving most towns with added social problems and nothing in compensation. 
 While casino gambling has been a big-money industry since the rise of Las Vegas in the 1950's, its reach was proscribed both by religious opposition and by lingering associations with wiseguys who made business offers that couldn't be refused. These political barriers were weakened by the success of state lotteries, argues Robert Goodman, a professor at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst who directed the recently completed United States Gambling Study, financed by the Ford Foundation. And they crumbled after 1988, when Congress required the states to negotiate terms for gambling on Indian reservations and a dozen revenue-starved states decided to permit gambling on their own turf.
Spurred by examples such as the Foxwoods Resort Casino, the Mashantucket Pequot Indians' casino in Ledyard, Conn., that is now the most profitable gaming establishment in America, multitudes are rushing to join the fun. Some 70 Indian groups currently operate casinos in 17 states, with the number expected to double within a few years. Riverboat casinos line the Mississippi from Illinois to the Gulf Coast. New Orleans will soon open a giant floating casino; meanwhile Philadelphia, Washington, Providence and Chicago are all salivating for a piece of the action.
But gambling as an economic development tool is, at best, problematic, for reasons that communities with visions of sugar plums are choosing to ignore.
One is the industry's apparent tendency to overbuild. Casinos in communities that are the first off the mark are often overnight successes, drawing crowds from huge areas. But once the competition grows, the party can turn grim. "Two-thirds of the 80 casinos in Deadwood, S.D., are in bankruptcy or in trouble," notes Mr. Goodman. Atlantic City is feeling the shock from the huge casino operation in Ledyard, which is roughly the same distance from New York City. And if, as expected, Philadelphia opts for riverboat gambling, Earl Grinols, an economist at the University of Illinois, predicts that "Atlantic City will be dead meat."
Free markets are supposed to reward productive decisions and punish wasteful ones. Why, then, would savvy entrepreneurs throw money at gambling ventures that are fated to become uneconomic? The gambling industry is unusual, argues Mr. Grinols, because the interests of the casino companies diverge widely from those of the community.
For one thing, a new casino may be risky for a community but a very safe bet for the principals if virtually all the money comes from lenders or limited partners, as it often does. The big gambling companies like Caesar's World and MGM Grand presumably can't make money unless their investors do. But they may earn back their investment plus a hefty profit within a few years, leaving communities to cope with the problems of shrinking tax bases and job opportunities.
EVEN places that avoid the cycle of boom and bust face special economic problems related to gambling. Every business creates "negative externalities" -- costs born by others. A store, for example, may add to traffic congestion, litter and noise. But Mr. Grinols believes that these externalities are exceptionally high for legal gambling.
Compulsive gambling, bred by easy access, reduces labor productivity, he notes, and has been linked to increases in white collar crime -- embezzlement, fraud and the like. Late-night gambling adds to the cost of policing traffic, not to mention the toll from drunk driving and other alcohol-related violence. This isn't precision engineering. But all told, Mr. Grinols estimates that these externalities equal roughly half the revenues of casino gambling -- and these costs, ultimately borne by Government, are far more than the direct and indirect taxes on the industry.
To control gambling's unwanted side effects, "small is beautiful," argues Peter Reuter, an economist at the University of Maryland's School of Public Policy. The best hope for making gambling compatible with balanced economic development, he suggests, is to mimic the European model of restricting hours and access to discourage gaming by local residents. While towns could hardly bar locals from the casinos (as some in Europe do), the United States Supreme Court has ruled that they can prohibit local advertising. And casinos could be required to charge stiff fees for entering the premises -- fees waived for certified conventioneers or hotel guests.
Mr. Thompson would go further, permitting casinos only as rewards for new hotel construction, and then matching their capacity to the expected number of gamblers who will come, lose and go home. "When more than 50 percent of gambling is by locals," he reckons, "gambling is a sure loser." In Las Vegas, incidentally, just 10 to 20 percent of the gambling revenue is home grown.
But a community's interest in curbing the costs associated with gambling is not shared by those who own the businesses. Nor, equally insidiously, points out Mr. Goodman, is the interest shared by elected officials, who are apt to focus on the immediate benefits of beefing up tax revenues rather than abstract worries about keeping local paychecks out of the slot machines.
State lotteries, initially rationalized as an alternative to illegal "numbers," games, now spend $300 million a year to promote sales. "Don't try to fight it." advised one ad for the Massachusetts game. "It's bigger than you are." And while casino gambling is often adopted with assurances that its reach will be circumscribed, promises have often proved to be only promises.
IN Atlantic City, the casinos successfully pressed for all-night wagering in response to stagnating business. Iowa is now debating the idea of erasing limits on gambling stakes in response to wide-open betting across the river in Illinois.
Most disturbing, in the view of those who want to keep the lid on, is the spread of gambling machines. Slots, along with electronic gizmos for playing poker and the bingo-like keno, attract less knowledgeable and less affluent gamblers, who are more apt to be residents. And the machines are thought to be more addicting than table games, arguably because the time between action and response is reduced.
But casinos like machine gambling, at least in part, says Mr. Goodman, "because they always come to work on Monday and never go on strike." And customers like the machines as well. Since 1990, reports Mr. Goodman, betting at Nevada and Atlantic City table games such as blackjack and craps has fallen 15 percent, while slot machine revenues have gone up by 40 percent.
IF the increased use of slot machines in casinos is seen as an ominous turn, the broader trend toward decentralized electronic gambling is viewed by many as a guarantee that the community-borne costs of gambling will escalate.
In some cases, decentralization has been the paradoxical consequence of sagging revenues from competing games. West Virginia and Rhode Island responded to declining parimutuel betting at racetracks by allowing the tracks to supplement their income with electronic betting machines. And in South Dakota the lottery managed to keep itself financially fit by blanketing the states with 10,500 machines. The state's total annual take from the machines (before expenses) is about $150 per resident.
While not everyone wants to gamble, analysts argue that the likely economic consequences of bringing it within reach of everyone would still be deeply sobering. Once betting on three cherries is as easy as buying a pack of Marlboros, Mr. Thompson reckons that the great bulk of the industry's revenues will come from income now spent elsewhere -- in particular, on entertainment and travel. What's more, the impact of the external costs, such as compulsive gambling, could become large enough to become a measurable drag on economic productivity.
Mr. Grinols prefers to make this latter point in a more colorful way. Extrapolating from areas already saturated with gambling opportunities, he estimates that the loss would average $200 per American, "the equivalent of cleaning up after one Hurricane Andrew each year."

HEADLINE: Profile;
An Accountant in Ad-Land: A Survivor at the Top

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
FOR a change, Charles Scott had something to smile about. The chief executive of the Saatchi & Saatchi Company, the world's fourth-largest advertising company, had just gotten word that its London office had won one of the biggest accounts up for grabs in Britain for years, a $68 million campaign to introduce a new national lottery.
"It's exciting news, wonderful," Mr. Scott said. "For whatever reason, new business wins seem to be what send morale sky high." After four and a half grueling years at Saatchi & Saatchi, first as finance director and for the last 14 months as chief executive, Mr. Scott is only now finding sporadic cause for celebration. 
 Mr. Scott, a self-effacing 45-year-old accountant who until coming to Saatchi & Saatchi in 1990 had never worked a day in an ad agency, has never completely quelled doubts that he is the right person to reinvigorate a company that lives and dies by its creativity and marketing savvy.
But he can now point to signs of success in his efforts to restore the company to growth through winning new business at its three big agency networks, especially in the United States, reversing years of lethargy.
He has also won public backing from the board. And at the annual meeting on Thursday in London, it became clear that he had held his own in a running feud with the chairman, Maurice Saatchi, a quarrel that had led to questions about whether the two could continue to work together.
"There is the capacity between any chairman and chief executive in any company for tension," Mr. Saatchi said at the meeting in unusually frank terms. "I am happy to say that although there have been those tensions in our boardroom, they have had a cathartic effect, and good and constructive ways of moving forward have come out of that creative tension."
In an earlier interview, Mr. Scott said that from his perspective there was no problem with Mr. Saatchi, and that the only important thing to him was that the company appeared to be turning the corner.
"My job was extremely unenjoyable for the first two years," Mr. Scott said. "But every day it's getting more enjoyable."
Hired to help clean up the mess from one of the most ill-conceived and ill-executed corporate strategies of the 1980's -- Saatchi & Saatchi's headlong expansion from shrewdly creative London ad agency into a debt-ridden behemoth with delusions of dominating businesses as far-flung as consulting and banking -- Mr. Scott spent several years scrambling just to keep the company afloat.
Along with his predecessor as chief executive, Robert Louis-Dreyfus, Mr. Scott helped persuade reluctant bankers to refinance the nearly $1 billion in debt run up by the company's founders, Maurice Saatchi and his brother, Charles. The Saatchis had borrowed heavily as they snapped up agencies like Ted Bates, Backer & Spielvogel and Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, and nonadvertising companies like the Hay Group, a consulting firm, and Yankelovich Skelly White/Clancy Shulman, a market research firm.
At the same time, Mr. Scott helped Mr. Louis-Dreyfus enact a plan to slash employment by 22 percent, to 11,600, and to sell most holdings other than the ad agencies.
Mr. Scott was appointed chief executive last year when Mr. Louis-Dreyfus left to try to turn around another troubled company, Adidas A.G. And with the financial crisis at Saatchi & Saatchi now under control, Mr. Scott has turned his attention to the trickier problem of arresting the slide in the market share and reputation of the company's agencies: Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising, Bates Worldwide (formerly Backer Spielvogel Bates) and Campbell Mithun Esty.
There are signs of tentative progress. Mr. Scott has continued a process begun last year of moving some highly successful executives from London to New York to shake up the American agencies, bruising some egos on Madison Avenue but also injecting new energy into drifting operations.
Bates has won several big accounts, including assignments from Miller Brewing and Warner-Lambert, and executives at Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising in New York said they expect to announce some prizes soon from their campaign for new business. After years in which recession led companies to slash ad budgets, the economies of the United States and Britain are growing steadily, leading many clients to increase their budgets, albeit cautiously. Elsewhere, Mr. Scott has stepped up investments in local agencies to give Saatchi the global reach increasingly demanded by big advertisers.
But Mr. Scott's job is far from over. With the company having focused so long on mere survival, it still needs considerable work in developing unified cultures and advertising philosophies within the three agency networks, each of which was created out of disparate agencies in the late 1980's.
IT still needs to address some big strategic issues, like whether to fold the three agencies into two, and whether to expand its successful Zenith media-buying agency from Europe into America. And, analysts say, it needs to focus management attention on helping clients and creating good ads.
"The tumor's gone, but the patient isn't back to health yet," said Alan J. Gottesman, an analyst at Paine Webber in New York. "It still needs physical therapy. It still needs vitamins. That's the job that Charlie's doing, and it ain't done yet."
An army brat, Mr. Scott grew up in Africa, Germany, Cyprus. Returning to Britain, he attended Dover College and qualified as a chartered accountant in 1972. In 1977 he went to work for IMS International, a pharmaceutical market research firm, and eventually became chief financial officer.
In late 1989 the Saatchi brothers hired Mr. Louis-Dreyfus, known for his skill at financial restructurings. Mr. Louis-Dreyfus, a flamboyant Frenchman who had previously run IMS, persuaded the easygoing and far more laconic Mr. Scott to come along.
Mr. Scott has no illusion that he is an advertising executive in the creative mold and does not try to serve as the company's public face. He rarely meets with clients, worrying that he will be wasting their time. His base salary of $450,000 last year was dwarfed by those of Saatchi's agency heads (Carl Spielvogel, the chairman of Bates Worldwide, earned $1.1 million).
Mr. Scott has long pushed for pay to reflect performance, and on Thursday, Maurice Saatchi said he had been converted to Mr. Scott's approach. Mr. Saatchi said he would give up his $900,000-a-year base salary for a $300,000-a-year contract with incentive clauses.
Mr. Scott sees his job as two-fold: lifting from the shoulders of operating executives the task of dealing with financial management, and creating an environment in which the agencies can hire the best people and focus on serving clients' needs.
"I am impressed with what Charlie has been trying to do in bringing greater fiscal responsibility to the operations," said Mr. Spielvogel, who has long been critical of management at London headquarters.
Yet in a company rife with factions, Mr. Scott, lacking experience at any agency, does not have a power base of his own. Maurice Saatchi, although no longer running day-to-day operations, remains a powerful force, especially in London. (Charles Saatchi, once the agency's creative guru, resigned from the board in December and now concentrates on his first love, art collecting.)
Mr. Scott was among those board members who pressured the reluctant Saatchi brothers into moving their offices from a modern, expensive building in London's Berkeley Square into the far dowdier quarters that are home to the holding company and to the Saatchi & Saatchi agency.
APPARENTLY concerned about the company's leadership, the outside directors met at the end of March and discussed whether Mr. Scott, and Mr. Saatchi for that matter, were the right people.
The board quizzed both men, and also quietly canvassed investors and clients. Then, on March 31, as rumors flew in London and New York, it issued this statement: "Following consultation with shareholders, clients and employees, the board has resolved that the interests of the company are best served by the continuation of Maurice Saatchi and Charles Scott in their present roles as chairman and chief executive."
But, the board added, it had also instructed the company to search for and hire a third executive on the corporate level who would be responsible for winning new business.
Now, however, Saatchi & Saatchi has decided it does not need that new executive, Mr. Scott said. "The board was concerned that we were losing market share," Mr. Scott said. "I believe that is the prime responsibility of the chief executives of our agencies around the world and myself and Maurice. It's up to us to prove we can do it. Until the last few months we didn't have any evidence that the things we were doing were working. Now I think everybody's feeling much better about our ability to deal with the problems."
Mr. Scott said he is now happy with the executive lineup in the agencies, and in particular with the new managers sent from London to New York: Michael Bungey, a Briton who formerly headed Bates in Europe and is now chief executive of Bates Worldwide, and Bill Muirhead, the Australia-born former head of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising in Europe, as head of that agency's operations in North America.
"We need more business from existing clients and from new clients," Mr. Scott said. "The particular area in which we have not been doing well over the past four years is the United States, which happens to be not only the biggest advertising market but also home to 60 percent of the world's multinational companies. It's one place you don't want to be underperforming."
With the company's outlook improving, Mr. Scott said he can foresee a day when he will have done all he can at Saatchi & Saatchi. But he said he has not gotten there yet.
"I don't know if it's fun," he said. "It will be extremely gratifying when the company starts performing as well as it ought. Satisfaction comes from winning, quite honestly. It's been exceedingly hard work, and at the end of the day you want to win."

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Wanna Buy a Bridge to Brooklyn?

BYLINE: By Alison Leigh Cowan 

 BODY:
THE day Wilbur L. Ross, Jr., a very busy investment banker, has time to go to lunch with a reporter is a day when the bankruptcy business must be slow.
But when Mr. Ross wants to go to dinner something more must be afoot. "I thought you'd like to know what my next gig will be," he said.
Career changes are seldom big news. But among Wall Street honchos, Mr. Ross is a bellwether banker who has always had an exceptional nose for where the money is. So dinner was called for. 
 An able chameleon, Mr. Ross has reinvented himself once before -- in 1985 when his bread-and-butter corporate finance business wasn't doing anything worth yakking about, and Corporate America was about to be swept up in a wave of big bankruptcies.
Before you could say Chapter 11, Mr. Ross had transformed himself and his firm, Rothschild Inc., into a leading champion of the rights of bondholders against companies in trouble. And at time when so many professionals face the threat of dismissal because of downsizing and bottom-line pressures, the story of someone who lives by the motto, "adapt or die" is instructive.
So here, Wall Street, is Mr. Ross's humble oracle: "Privatizations are going to be the wave of the 90's," he confides. "Every city has assets it has no reason to have that can be probably managed on a more efficient basis by the private sector," he said. "Corporations deleveraged. Now, I think it's time for governments to go through that process."
Got that? Corporate bankruptcies are out. Government workouts are in.
True, Mr. Ross is hardly the first to discover that more and more governments will want to sell their assets or refinance their debts to bridge their financial shortfalls.
Alliance Capital, the money management firm, has just raised a $1 billion war chest from retail investors to invest in government-controlled entities that are about to go private or have recently done so. And others investors appear to be following suit.
Internationally, there have been plenty of deals to feed the demand. According to Privatisation International, a monthly newsletter in London, $53.7 billion worth of securities were sold last year by Britain's telephone company, Argentina's oil company, and other state-owned enterprises. That total was roughly $10 billion more than in 1992, and is the highest yearly figure since the newsletter began keeping track six years ago.
Mr. Ross's point is that even though the business is well-developed overseas, domestic privatization is in its infancy. And his dinner chatter was vintage Wilbur. He had the sweep. He had the statistics and, of course, he had his spin.
In his view, state and local governments are under increasing pressure to maintain services without raising taxes. And one way to do it is to sell off assets that underperform or have little to do with their mission. More than half the cities in the U.S., he notes citing statistics from the National League of Cities, had budget deficits last year.
New York's new Mayor, Rudolph Giuliani, for example, is exploring whether to sell the city's FM radio license and its luxury hotel near the United Nations. Likewise, Mr. Ross notes, other cities have stadiums, convention centers, hospitals and other sidelines they might be better off relinquishing. "There's no reason why an offtrack betting parlor should lose money," said Mr. Ross, noting that New York City's $800 million a year gaming business is in the red.
Mr. Ross could, of course, have simply retired a wealthy man. Just one of the many deals he did in his heyday was an investment he engineered in a company called Mego. When his investor group purchased Mego, it was nothing but a shell that had prepaid its taxes for years to come. The company has made his group some $37 million in profits.
But at 54, Mr. Ross is not ready to hang up his spurs. And in looking for his next frontier, he used three criteria. "I'm interested in things where you can create a market, have a big share and have it last a while," he said. "Privatizations and capital-raising by governments will go on for years. And it's a fairly chaotic market. So I thought here was room for someone that knew a lot about markets, turmoil and restructuring."
Rodney Lord, the editor of Privatisation International, gives Mr. Ross a fair shot at success. "He's late by my standards in the sense I started this paper six years ago," said Mr. Lord. "But he's certainly not too late. We could be at the beginning of a something very big in the States."
Mr. Ross has been at his new career a few weeks now, and has one albeit modest deal to show for himself. He has just closed a $75 million bond deal for Bermuda, which earned his firm $375,000. It is the first time the island has turned to the bond markets for its long-term capital.
Mr. Ross, looking tanned from the ten trips he has taken to visit that client so far this year, is a big believer in the notion that when you are doing a makeover on yourself, you have to work with what you have.
He has also elbowed his way into a select circle of ten firms that will be allowed to bid for New York City's privatization business, even though his own track record in privatizations is nothing to speak of. The only performance he can point to is that of his firm's parent company, Rothschild Group, which is based in Europe. Measured simply by the sheer number of assignments it had, though not necessarily by the value of the deals, Rothschild Group edged ahead of First Boston last year as the market leader, according to Mr. Lord. Mr. Ross also understands the importance of doing some unpaid work just to gain experience. For instance, he accepted a spot on President Clinton's Fund for Large Enterprises in Russia that will dispense $500 million to Russian companies. The appointment could ultimately cost him business. "Obviously we can't do things for institutions they're investing in," said Mr. Ross. "But you have to get credentials somewhere."

HEADLINE: DRIVING SMART;
Looking Ahead at Headlights: Improvements Down the Road

BYLINE: By MARSHALL SCHUON 

 BODY:
MY first car was a well-used 1936 Ford, and I loved it dearly, although it did have some problems, particularly in its electrical system. For a while, when I stepped on the brakes the horn would blow, a difficulty I remedied by yanking out the horn.
But the headlights were something else. The lenses were hinged, and inside were little incandescent bulbs that emitted almost no light. Their failure was abetted by reflectors that had dulled with time. 
 That car was one of the last to use such lights; even when the Ford was new, sealed beams were finding a market. They were a marvelous advance, round and sealed in heavy glass, and they remained essentially the same in this country until 1974, when General Motors developed a rectangular bulb.
Since then, sizes and shapes have changed, but sealed beams are still with us, notwithstanding brighter halogen bulbs and the increasing use of plastics for lenses and housings. Computer design has also helped to put more light on the road and make vehicles safer.
But the latest advance is "high-intensity discharge" lighting, or H.I.D., a system that uses a control module, a transformer and a quartz tube that is filled with gas and contains two electrodes. When current passes through the electrodes, an arc jumps through the gas, producing light.
The Inland Fisher Guide division of General Motors, which supplies G.M. and many other manufacturers with lighting and other components, has been experimenting with this type of lighting, and its engineers say they think the system will be widely used within five years.
Vic Walters, product director of the division's lighting operations in Anderson, Ind., said an arc was far more efficient than a filament. The lights are cooler and they operate at lower wattage, which translates into better fuel economy, since a car burns gas to generate current. Also, Mr. Walters said, "H.I.D. gives you about twice as much light to work with, and you can produce a more desirable beam pattern. It gives you more foreground light, more spread light and so forth."
Barbara Sanders, engineering director of Inland Fisher's advanced development group, added that H.I.D. also produced a different color of light that reflected more brightly from road signs, meaning greater safety and less driver fatigue.
Further in the future, she said, fiber optics offer exciting possibilities. In such a system, a single light source -- say, under the hood -- will distribute light through optic cables. Glass fiber is expensive, however, and widespread use of fiber optics depends on the development of cheaper plastic fibers.
"We will probably light interiors with fiber optics before we do exterior lighting," she said. "Headlights are a more challenging problem, because they operate in a pretty hostile environment."
G.M. will take a big step in lighting this fall by putting daytime running lights on some cars; it will have them on all lines within three years. The system, required in Canada since 1988 and now mandatory in Sweden, Norway and Finland, turns on lights when the engine is running.
Brian O'Neill, president of the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, says daytime running lights make cars easier to see and thereby reduce two-vehicle daytime crashes. He said research by the institute involved more than 2,000 modified vehicles in commercial fleets and showed fewer accidents than similar vehicles without the running lights.
A Chrysler spokesman said that company had no plan to put daytime running lights on its cars and saw no inherent safety advantage, although G.M.'s progress -- and the popularity of the lights -- will be monitored. Ford has also taken a wait-and-see approach.
In Canada, most cars use reduced-intensity low beams during the day. On vehicles with retractable headlights, however, steady-burning turn signals are lit. Fuel economy suffers a bit, but David Moore, manager of forward lighting at Inland Fisher's operation in Anderson, said the safety factor made it worthwhile.
"In any case," he said, "the impact is very low. We estimate that daytime running lights will cut economy by only about a tenth of a mile per gallon."

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Success Overseas Hurts China at Home

BYLINE: By Laurence Zuckerman 

 BODY:
EVERYONE seems to agree that China is the mother of all emerging markets. In recent months the heady prospect of gaining a share in what promises to become the world's largest purchaser of everything from shampoo to heavy industrial equipment has infected not only chief executives and bankers but also ordinary investors.
So why then have China's two domestic-share markets hit the skids? 
 Since last year, the fledgling exchanges in the cities of Shanghai and Shenzhen have fallen inexorably from record highs. Last month's decision by President Clinton to continue to allow Chinese imports to enter the United States at minimum tariff levels sparked a brief rebound. But it has not been nearly enough to offset the year's heavy losses, which now amount to a 37 percent decline in the all-China stock index compiled by Credit Lyonnais Securities.
Investors and traders attribute the drop to factors that they say befall every emerging market. The seemingly boundless enthusiasm about China's economic boom has given way to worries that an overheated economy and rising inflation may lead to unrest. Politically, traders wonder what will happen after Deng Xiaoping, China's ailing leader, dies.
But the biggest cause of the decline may be the success of China's overall effort to tap the world's financial markets. When shares reserved for foreigners began trading in Shen zhen and Shanghai in 1992, they provided one of the few ways overseas investors could cash in on China's rapid growth. But now Chinese shares are listed on exchanges in Hong Kong, New York, Vancouver and Melbourne.
Because these exchanges are more mature, have more stringent listing and reporting rules, and are overseen by regulators with proven track records, the stocks are more attractive to investors. "If I were a foreign investor, I would prefer to invest in a more liquid market with better disclosure requirements and lower trading costs," said Lawrence Ang, head of China research for Swiss Bank Corporation in Hong Kong.
Now that fund managers have the luxury of choice, they are no longer so willing to look the other way when Chinese companies use their equity capital to play the stock market or make other speculative investments unrelated to their core businesses.
Christopher Legallet, a director of Jupiter Tyndall (Asia) Ltd. and manager of its London-listed China Investment Trust, believes that only a handful of the 50 companies listed in Shenzhen and Shanghai that have issued stock reserved for foreigners, known in the trade as B shares, are worthwhile investments. "Therefore, you are not going to put all your money as a China fund manager into B shares," he said.
Such thinking has caused turnover on both the Shenzhen and Shanghai exchanges to dry up. That in turn has made it even more difficult for institutional investors -- the primary buyers of B shares -- to accumulate large blocks of stock, creating a downward spiral in share prices.
Chinese shares listed in Hong Kong, known as H shares, have attracted wider interest and trade at a premium compared to the prices of shares in the same companies that are reserved for Chinese. Nine H shares are currently listed in Hong Kong but as many as 17 more are in the listing pipeline.
This has dealt a particularly harsh blow to the stock exchange in Shenzhen, which is only an hour's train ride from downtown Hong Kong. "It's virtually dead." Mr. Legallet said of the Shenzhen market. Last week's turnover was a paltry $2.1 million, and on some days many stocks didn't trade at all.
Shanghai's exchange is viewed more favorably by foreign investors because China's central government has committed its prestige and a large amount of resources to return the city to its pre-revolutionary status as Asia's financial capital.
"I personally don't believe that the Shenzhen market justifies its existence," Mr. Ang said. After Hong Kong reverts to Chinese sovereignty in 1997, he pointed out, there won't be any need for another stock exchange on the city's doorstep.
But Zhang Hongyi, Shenzhen's vice mayor, disagreed. Describing the two exchanges as "complementary," he said "both will exist for a very long time. There is no question of one replacing the other."
Mr. Zhang, who was traveling in New York last week with a delegation of Shenzhen officials, regulators and company executives to drum up support for the exchange, was frank about its shortcomings and counseled patience. "We are fully aware that there is a gap between the domestic market and the international market," he said. "That is why we are here."
For all his criticisms, Mr. Legallet is optimistic. "There are risks," he said, "but the long-term story, based on the growth in the per capita consumption of basic commodities, make China, to me, the most compelling investment opportunity in my lifetime."
Now that B-share prices have fallen, Mr. Legallet finds them increasingly attractive. He prefers companies that manufacture an internationally competitive product but are positioning themselves to take advantage of China's huge domestic market.
One example is Shenzhen China Bicycle Company (Holdings) Ltd., which exports the Diamond Back-brand bicycle to the United States and Europe but has begun developing a distribution network inside China.
"We have an emerging economy," Mr. Legallet said. "We have to accept that and accept the volatility. But to me the volatility is what makes for opportunity."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: When Husbands Can't Find Jobs

 BODY:
Re: "Helping the Wives of the Unemployed" (April 10):
I hope now that their husbands are unemployed, these women have learned not to turn their noses up at other people. I have dealt with some of these women, and they felt that they were better than other people because they had nice homes and mink coats.
Most of them did not vote for Bill Clinton and were against his plan for national health care. I can bet they are singing a different tune today. These women felt that people who could not find jobs were just lazy and wanted to stay home and collect welfare checks. These women all had the same question: "Why did this happen to me? I did everything right."
Just think, most of these so-called affluent husbands had big corporate jobs and college degrees, and they cannot find jobs. They have fancy cars and fancy clothes and never thought the day would come when they would have to use food stamps.
Life has a way of catching us on the blind side, and that is what happened to these women. I hope they have learned the lesson that we need to be understanding of all people -- cashiers, busboys, gardeners, maids, etc. And to the woman who is going to have a second child even though her husband is unemployed: I hope the next time she hears of a woman who is having a baby and neither she nor her husband has a job, she will take a look at her second child and say, "I can understand it."
DEBBIE A. O'BRIEN
Bernardsville

HEADLINE: Journal;
The Other Agenda

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
Bob Woodward is the reporter who helped bring down a criminal Presidency. Mike Wallace is the television muckraker who nailed a thousand malefactors. Put them together on "60 Minutes" to lift the lid on Mr. Woodward's new book, "The Agenda: Inside the Clinton White House," and a vast audience has every reason to believe that a scandal of Watergate proportions is about to explode.
The two men did all they could to further that perception last Sunday. Both looked solemn, and Mr. Woodward was seen in such tight close-ups that even his mildest innuendos about the Clintons ("The American taxpayer has gotten two for the price of one") took on the gravity of an impeachable offense. The viewer was also tantalized by shots of Mr. Woodward's vast cache of seemingly incriminating tapes -- containing "deep background" interviews with confidential sources reaching "up to the very top" -- and a replay of Gennifer Flowers. "Are Bill and Hillary Clinton going to like this book?" asked Mr. Wallace, who then answered, "I don't think so." 
 Actually, the Clintons may not mind "The Agenda." Its characterization of them is familiar -- he can't make decisions; she can't stop making them -- and Mr. Woodward provides no new reportage about Gennifer Flowers or any other scandal. But ordinary readers, lured by "60 Minutes" into anticipating a "Son of All the President's Men," may well be peeved. Mr. Woodward's book, a plodding account of the evolution of the Clinton economic plan, has its farcical Washington snapshots, but never reaches the ludicrous heights of the hype surrounding "The Agenda" itself.
"At one point Clinton got so frustrated he used the f-word!" exclaimed Mr. Woodward, posing as America's oldest living Boy Scout, in another promotional television interview. Well, so what? To flog this book, Mr. Woodward has had to turn unexceptional, even flattering "revelations" about the President into spuriously shocking sound bites that make Mr. Woodward and the journalistic profession he so prominently represents look more disingenuous than his subject.
Not only does Mr. Clinton cuss, Mr. Woodward and his TV hosts darkly inform us, but the President also loses his temper, tolerates intellectual prodding by his wife and Vice President, thrives on the detailed debate of policy, makes pragmatic political compromises to win Congressional votes and sows chaos by refusing to enlist a chief of staff who will stifle dissent.
If these are crimes, then no doubt an ideal President would be an ideologically rigid Washington lifer who nurses enemies' lists rather than letting off steam, has a golf caddy for a Vice President and a cipher for a spouse, makes policy pronouncements from index cards written by aides and is too arrogant to get a bill through Congress. The ideal chief of staff? John Sununu.
Presumably voters turned to the Clinton-Gore ticket to reject this status quo. Mr. Woodward, whose own ideology seems to be terminal inside-the-Beltway-itis, finds Mr. Clinton most wanting when measuring him against Lloyd Bentsen.
The President's indecisiveness is indeed a serious flaw. But we hardly need "The Agenda" to tell us that. The book's journalistic flaws are often more newsworthy. The problems begin on the first page, where a breezy conversation between the Clintons in bed sounds fake. (Mrs. Clinton says "Yeah" as much as the Beatles.) While the gist of the conversation, like much of "The Agenda," may be accurate, the book's lifelessly reconstructed scenes show what can happen when a journalist sands down a variety of off-the-record accounts to arrive at a composite reality.
Connie Bruck's recent profile of Hillary Clinton in The New Yorker presents much the same picture of the White House that Mr. Woodward's book does, but because most of her sources are named, speak in their own voices and own up to their sometimes conflicting points of view, the Clintons are seen with the perspective and depth missing in "The Agenda." So prosaic is most of what Mr. Woodward's sources have to say that their Deep-Throated anonymity often seems superfluous -- just another way to puff up the smoke of hot news where there is no fire.
But at least no one can accuse Mr. Woodward of trashing Mr. Clinton to serve a covert political line as he hypes "The Agenda." The only agenda here, and it's not very well hidden, is sales.

HEADLINE: Students Care Far Too Much About Grades

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Making the Grades" (editorial, June 5): Having completed my last final exam as an undergraduate at Stanford University not more than an hour ago, I believe I am in an excellent position to evaluate the media frenzy over alleged grade inflation at Stanford University. 
 Yes, a surprising number of A and B grades are received by students here. But very little coverage has focused on how the nature of Stanford students contributes to this trend.
Students here are motivated almost to a fault when it comes to grades. Most students who come here had a straight-A average in high school. I remember an orientation discussion of my freshman dorm mates titled "What Will You Do When You Get That First B?"
But one need only observe the solemn mass of students staggering out of the library at closing time, observe the playing fields during finals week, empty despite another gorgeous California day, observe the glassy-eyed, sleep-deprived paper writers packed into the computer cluster, to see that Stanford students work too hard for their grades, not too little.
What I find unfortunate, and what most disappointed me about my time at Stanford, is that our narrow focus on letter grades has allowed us to forget that a university should be about learning and knowledge, rather than class rank and one-upmanship. It is a shame that when the national media turn their eyes on a great university, the most interesting thing they can discover are statistics about grade point averages.
But I can hardly blame them. Not while students ask, "Is this going to be on the exam?" Not while our faculty senate spends more time debating how to make the grading system more punitive, than discussing how to improve our education. The letter grade has become a convenient way for students, faculty and administrators to shirk our responsibility to a deeper evaluation of the state of our education.
 
RAFE SAGARIN
Stanford, Calif., June 7, 1994

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: The Bondholders Are Winning;
Why America Won't Boom

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
"IT'S the economy, stupid." When James Carville coined the slogan, he meant that his client, Bill Clinton, would be well served by thumping for a stronger economy. Mr. Clinton did, and he won. But now, it turns out, there are an awful lot of people out there who favor a weak economy.
Favor a weak economy? Who would do that? Enter that mysterious and slightly sinister entity, The Bond Market, the pre-eminent force in the economy today. More than any other group, the bond market's members determine how many Americans will have jobs, whether the jobholders will earn enough to afford a house or a car, or whether a factory might have to lay off workers. 
 In sum, the American economy is governed by the bond market -- a loose confederation of wealthy Americans, bankers, financiers, money managers, rich foreigners, executives of life insurance companies, presidents of universities and nonprofit foundations, pensioners and people who once kept their money in passbook savings accounts (or under the bed) and now buy shares in mutual funds. While some would recoil at being called enemies of economic growth, the fact is that the confederation has ruled in recent months that the economy should lose strength, not gain it.
 
The Message: Smaller
 "The bond market's members speak in a monologue, and their message is contract the economy," a senior Administration official said. "They want the weakest economy they can have, as long as it does not get so weak that loans are defaulted."
Through the Bush years they were quiescent. The economy was pretty weak on its own most of the time, and the bond market fraternity did not feel compelled to take action. But the surge in economic activity that started last fall got juices flowing. And with a rapidity that took the breath away, the fraternity exercised its power over interest rates, pushing them up so that people had to pay more for things like mortgages, car loans and new machinery. After rising sharply from February to May, interest rates have leveled off for now, but inevitably the surge in economic growth so evident last winter has lost some of its bloom.
"There are other things that affect interest rates, but point number one is where is the economy going," said Paul A. Volcker, former chairman of the Federal Reserve. "If you have a weaker economy, you have lower rates. That is not a great world, but that is the way it is."
The Clinton Administration does not aggressively challenge the bond market's preference for subdued economic growth. Top officials argue that the economy is still strong enough to withstand most of the recent drag from higher rates. Congress is similarly reluctant to challenge the bond market's power. And early in the Clinton Presidency, Mr. Carville himself recognized the problem with the aphorism he had made famous. So he came up with a new one.
"I used to think that if there was reincarnation, I wanted to come back as the President or the Pope or as a .400 basball hitter," he said. "But now I would like to come back as the bond market. You can intimidate everybody."
Most Americans have only a rough notion of the bond market's nature. The name itself suggests financiers on Wall Street. In fact, the fraternity, which is as old as the Republic, has changed over the decades and has appeared in different eras under different names -- as the Eastern banking establishment, for example, or the sound money faction.
Some of its newest members are ordinary Americans, who enter by buying shares in mutual funds that invest in bonds -- and they may be unaware that they have joined such a heavyweight club.
"A lot of times they move money into the fund from a passbook savings account or a bank certificate of deposit and they don't realize that they are moving into another world where they can get hurt," said James Benham, chairman of the Benham Group, whose various mutual bond funds have 425,000 shareholders.
While Mr. Benham, who manages their money, is definitely concerned about too much economic growth, his shareholders don't always realize that in letting him manage their money they are joining his cause. These shareholders may in fact be on two sides of the argument -- as bond market members favoring slower economic growth and as wage earners rooting for a vigorous economy.
"They may advocate reduced job prospects for themselves and their offspring," said Clare Hushbeck, a senior policy analyst at the American Association of Retired Persons, which is open to anyone over 50, working and retired. "But that is not apparent to them; these are tough connections for most people to make."
What does help to make the connection is some understanding of the essential nature of the bond market. Whatever its name or its membership through the decades, one defining characteristic has endured. The bond market is a huge storehouse of accumulated wealth -- a giant vault, so to speak, from which saved money is loaned out not for a few weeks or months, but for years at a time.
Those multi-year loans totaled more than $10 trillion at the end of last year, according to the Federal Reserve's most recent data. That is a huge sum. If the $10 trillion were somehow to disappear, refilling the vault would absorb the entire national income -- all wages, salaries and profits -- for a year and a half.
Naturally, when they lend from the vault, the people who own the $10 trillion, or their agents like Mr. Benham, want it paid back intact, undiminished by inflation. And keeping down inflation has come to mean weakening the economy.
 
Borrowers All Over
 The loans go to the Federal Government to finance the budget deficit, or to corporations to buy new machinery, or to municipalities to build roads and schools, or to millions of Americans to buy homes and cars.
In the case of a car loan, the vault might lend $10,000 for five years to purchase a new vehicle. When the loan is finally paid back, the amount should be sufficient to purchase the latest model of the same vehicle.
That is the bond market's goal. So if inflation pushes up the car's price to, say, $13,000 -- or if the bond market even thinks this might happen before the loan is repaid -- then it demands higher interest payments, to cover the $3,000 inflation cost, plus some profit for the lenders. The higher interest payments, in turn, eventually discourage more borrowing, weakening the economy.
Inflation, however, is not a problem today. While the economy is stronger than it was a year ago, the inflation rate has barely risen. What's more, the Administration and many private economists believe that it won't rise much, even with brisk economic growth. Even the Federal Reserve's top officials, who usually side with the bond market, don't see much inflation ahead.
Until the 1970's, the bond market fraternity was more willing to accept such a view. Preserving wealth from the inroads of inflation, even at the expense of economic growth, was not such an obsession. But the double-digit inflation in the 1970's vaporized big chunks of the wealth in the bond market's vault. Although interest rates rose above 15 percent for a while, that extra income failed to offset much of the damage. And that memory remains fixed in the bond market's collective mind.
"When economies go through a major bout of inflation, it leaves a lasting imprint," said Paul Romer, an economist at the University of California at Los Angeles. "It may be that in the population at large, there is a greater fear of inflation than there was in the 1960's, and a greater willingness to stop it."
More to the point, when the bond market reacts, that reaction is more pronounced than in the past. Interest rates move faster. One reason: some of the $10 trillion can be pulled out of loans in America, converted into marks or yen and lent in Germany or Japan -- if rates in those countries are higher or the dollar is losing value against those currencies. Getting the money back requires higher American rates.
Then there are mortgages. In the past, a bank that issued a $100,000 mortgage at, say, 8 percent interest, kept the loan on its books, whatever the inflation problem. Now the bank packages the mortgage with, say, nine others, each for $100,000, and sells the package as a bond.
The new owner is often quick to sell the $1 million bond if inflation, or the threat of it, erodes its value. That would happen if interest rates were to rise to, say, 9 percent while his bond is paying only 8 percent, or $80,000. To turn that $80,000 into a 9 percent return for a fresh owner, he has to sell the bond for $890,000, losing money. And that sale reinforces the 9 percent rate in the bond market.
Hundreds of billions of dollars in mortgages and car loans, once never traded, are now bought and sold in this fashion. The bond market's influence grows as a result, and the balance between borrowers and lenders, between more growth and less inflation, shifts again -- toward a slower economy.

HEADLINE: The World;
Facing Up to the Legacy Of an Unresolved War

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
In public last week, President Clinton commemorated the 50th anniversary of the D-Day landings, one of the boldest and most decisive military strokes of the 20th century. The heroes of 1944 should prompt Americans of today, he said, to make "common cause" with other countries once again; he asked members of his own generation "not only to praise their deeds but to pursue their dreams."
In private he and his aides wrestled with a foreign-policy crisis whose solution, again against daunting odds, will require all the conviction and all the commonality of cause that the United States and its allies can muster: the possession or potential possession of nuclear bombs by a unpredictable, egomaniacal ruler in North Korea. 
 Unlike World War II, which ended in the unconditional surrender that the allies had sought from the start, the conflict in Korea in the 1950's was far more ambiguous. Described in classic double-talk as a "police action" and not a war, it ended in armistice.
It is America's unresolved war, seldom discussed or analyzed, but still there, ticking lethally away. Only the occasional news photo of American troops peering through binoculars across the Demilitarized Zone or television film of American Presidents visiting them serve to jog dormant memories.
Now the danger is that like World War I, also halted by an armistice that left one party full of grievances, it will prove not to have ended at all. The geopolitical situation all around him has been utterly transformed in the last two decades, but Kim Il Sung retains the same goal, dominance in the Korean peninsula, and the same willingness to take big risks.
He is waging a campaign of terror, evident first in the bombings in Burma, in Seoul and on a South Korean airliner orchestrated by Pyongyang. His scientists appear to have been working on nuclear weapons. As with Stalin and his successors, the world fears that an isolated, power-mad, ideologically obsessed leader will hold it to nuclear ransom or through miscalculation blow his corner of it to smithereens -- which is the fundamental fear of the post-war era.
In the United States and Europe, so far, it has been a matter for specialists. However enormous the stakes for Japan and South Korea, and thus for the world's economy, however awful the implications for nuclear nonproliferation and hence world peace, there is an undeniable complacency, not only on the streets of London and Chicago, but even in the chanceries where the crucial decisions are made.
Why? Why, especially in the United States, has no more been done to make the stakes clear to the public? Why have we heard not even the rudiments of a debate over whether Korea, unlike Bosnia, is a place where this country would be willing to use force?
Surely one reason, on this matter as on so many others in the post-cold war world, is that the proper course of action is hard to discern.
Many experts thought for a long time that if only the right package of economic or other incentives could be established, including a reduction in the level or visibility of American military action in South Korea, a deal could be arranged. Give them the means to prop up their failing economy and to preserve their authoritarian rule, it was said, and Kim Il Sung and his heir-apparent son, Kim Jong Il, will give up nuclear projects. If not, economic sanctions, whether voted by the United Nations or not, would do the trick. But last week's promise by Pyongyang that sanctions would produce reprisals against Japan and the devastation of South Korea has given pause to Western policy makers.
Mr. Clinton would rather not spend a lot of time this summer on Korea. His big goal in the weeks ahead, apart from the successful completion of a second European trip, is the passage of health care reform; to that end, he would prefer to keep foreign crises and their inevitable divisiveness as far from center stage as possible.
 
Fuzzy Goals
 But that will only serve to prolong the public complacency about Korea, and to further defer any meaningful discussion about where and under what circumstances certain things are worth fighting for. In his inaugural and again in Normandy, the President spoke of his generation's need to emulate their forebears in sacrificing for the common good, but he has left it all pretty fuzzy.
He said last week that he wanted no "saber-rattling." He and Secretary of State Warren Christopher have drawn tight lines of restraint around the use of American force abroad, allowing only the most symbolic gestures in Bosnia, pulling sharply back at the first signs of trouble in Haiti and Somalia, abstaining in Rwanda. They may well have acted exactly as most of the American people wish, but their policies entail major costs.
So has Mr. Clinton's scattershot method of making policy, the vagueness and seeming contradictions in his message du jour. Socratic dialogues are not the best means of enunciating national goals.
One cost is the loss of confidence of allies. Only the United States is in a position in the current crisis to put some steel into the spines of Japan and South Korea, both fearful that terrorism would result or that their successful economies would be disrupted.
Last week the Japanese were reported to have refused even to contemplate cutting off the flow of hundreds of millions of dollars a year from North Koreans working abroad in Japan to families at home. Such remittances are Pyongyang's largest source by far of hard currency.
In this and other matters, the Europeans are still waiting, as a foreign minister said last week, for the moment "when Mr. Clinton thumps the table, a la Margaret Thatcher, and says, 'This is where we're making our stand, with you or without you.' "
A second cost is making adversaries bolder. That seems to have happened with the Bosnian Serbs; it certainly happened in 1950 when Dean Acheson seemed to suggest in a National Press Club speech, whether he intended to or not, that the United States would not defend South Korea. The repeated changes in policy on Haiti and Bosnia, the sense that the Administration is engaged in on-the-job training, cannot have sent a message of stern resolve to North Korea.
Bill Clinton, the political child of the Vietnam war, had as his first mentor one of the most eloquent of that war's foes, J. William Fulbright, but he sometimes seems to have learned only half of the lesson the former Senator tried so hard to teach his country.
The Fulbright doctrine held that attempting to project power into areas of secondary interest, where the chances of achieving the desired effect were small, only diminished that power. Such was the case in Vietnam, he said, and Mr. Clinton and his team of advisers, many of them old Vietnam hands, think often about the war.
But Mr. Fulbright wanted to maintain American power, wanted to avoid diminishing it, so that it could be used at the right moment. Failing to do so, failing to check the ambitions of a Hitler or a Stalin (or a Kim Il Sung) is as bad as fighting the wrong battles, if not considerably worse.

HEADLINE: U.S. IS CONSIDERING MILDER SANCTIONS FOR NORTH KOREA

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 11

 BODY:
Senior Clinton Administration officials have agreed on a plan for North Korea that would put off strict economic sanctions while proceeding with lesser measures intended to deepen the country's diplomatic isolation, Administration officials said today.
They say that by withholding stricter sanctions, the plan is intended to deter North Korea from taking further steps to make nuclear weapons.
 But the plan is likely to draw criticism from some in Congress who charge that Washington has failed to turn its tough talk of punishing North Korea for its nuclear program into action and has backed down in the face of resistance from Japan and other allies. 
 The outlines of the Administration plan, which was worked out at a four-hour White House meeting of Cabinet-level officials and President Clinton on Friday, will defer a cutoff in the hundreds of millions of dollars that Koreans living in Japan send to North Korea.
Senior Administration officials said the emerging approach reflects a general consensus among top officials, but one official cautioned that President Clinton has yet to adopt it.
Administration officials said they hoped to discuss the plan next week at the United Nations and to circulate a sanctions resolution. But they say it may take weeks before the Security Council votes on the measure.
Under the emerging plan, Washington would ask the Security Council to quickly impose some modest sanctions such as barring United Nations technical assistance and stopping scientific and cultural exchanges.
But a cutoff in remittances from Japan, an oil embargo and other tough measures would be held in abeyance and imposed later if the North rejected any constraints on its nuclear program and continued down the nuclear path.
"It is designed to build almost unanimous international pressure on the North Koreans with respect to actions they have already taken and to provide a deterrent against further unwise steps," a senior Clinton Administration official said.
Still, some American officials and Asian diplomats said the plan was weaker than the one initially suggested by Robert L. Gallucci, the Assistant Secretary of State who is the Administration's point man on North Korea. They said he initially suggested a quicker cutoff of financial transfers to North Korea, while the Pentagon favored a more gradual approach.
In drafting the plan, Administration officials said they were conscious of two main problems.
Washington believes quick steps are needed to signal international concern over North Korea's decision to destroy evidence of past plutonium production. But officials also believe that some tough economic measures must be kept in reserve to dissuade the North from withdrawing entirely from the nuclear nonproliferation treaty, reprocessing fuel it recently removed from its reactor to make new weapons and abandoning restrictions on its nuclear program.
Diplomatic considerations are also influencing Washington. The Administration is trying to design a plan that would avoid a Chinese veto in the Security Council and satisfy Japan, which opposes any fast action to end remittances to North Korea.
While Administration officials said there was broad agreement on the plan, some important elements appear to remain unsettled, including whether an arms embargo would be part of the initial sanctions.
And a senior official also cautioned that Washington would reconsider if North Korea evicted international monitors from its Yongbyon nuclear complex or took other steps to proceed with nuclear development.
North Korea's representative to the International Atomic Energy Agency said on Friday that the agency's two monitors there would have to leave. His remarks came after the agency's board of governors voted to cut off $250,000 in technical assistance to North Korea.
 
Inspectors Remain
 But a spokesman for the agency, an arm of the United Nations, said today that the inspectors remained there and had not been told to leave.
Their presence is important because they can provide a quick alert if the North Koreans begin to move fuel rods from a cooling pond to a plutonium reprocessing plant to make material for nuclear weapons.
If the inspectors are evicted, the agency can still monitor the rods using cameras, which will be less reliable.
The Administration's plan follows consultation with Japan, China, South Korea and other countries.
 
A Matter of Leverage
 Some critics have complained that Washington has moved too slowly and that if the United States wants to get North Korea's attention after a year of unproductive diplomacy it needs to press Japan to immediately cut off money to North Korea, which amounts to between $600 million and $1.6 billion a year. By putting off that sanction, Washington may keep Japan happy, but it is unlikely to persuade Pyongyang that it means business, the critics say.
But in a television appearance on Friday, Madeleine K. Albright, the United States representative at the United Nations, defended the idea of holding tough sanctions in reserve.
"Sanctions are a tool so that we can make sure of several things," she said in an interview on the "MacNeil/ Lehrer Newshour."
One object, she said, was to persuade the North Koreans to come back to the negotiating table and to encourage them to let international monitors try to determine how much plutonium might have been diverted in past years.
"But the more important, or as important, part of this is to protect the future so that we can make sure that they do not have the capability to produce more weapons-grade material and weapons themselves," she added.
She also defended the time the Administration has taken to craft a resolution, saying it was more important to achieve some measure of international consensus than to force a vote at the United Nations.
"It's going to take days, if not weeks, to put the sanctions resolution together," she said
North Korea has reacted harshly to the threat of economic sanctions and has sought to frighten the West, describing such measures as an act of war. Today, a report in a North Korean Government newspaper said support of sanctions would be "an act of self-destruction" for South Korea.
