HEADLINE: As Military Pay Slips Behind, Poverty Invades the Ranks

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 11

 BODY:
Like other airmen at Hickam Air Force Base in Honolulu, 21-year-old Jason Edwards worries about tensions far away in North Korea that could erupt into fighting and involve his supply base.
But Airman Edwards has more immediate concerns, too. He is worried about how to feed his 22-year-old wife, Beth, and their two small children on his total pay and allowances of $1,330 a month. In desperation, the Edwardses last month began drawing $228 a month in food stamps to get by. 
 "It's a very tight squeeze for us," Mrs. Edwards said. "We haven't bought any steaks since we've been here, and whenever I want to cook something with ham, I substitute Spam for it."
In a trend that has senior Pentagon officials deeply troubled, an increasing number of military families are turning to food stamps to make ends meet. Three-quarters of America's enlisted forces earn less than $30,000 a year, and the gap between civilian and military wages is growing.
To be sure, no one ever joined the military to get rich. But neither did they expect to have to go on welfare. Military officials worry that a growing demand for food stamps and other Government assistance may signal larger personnel problems in a culture that preaches self-reliance and self-discipline.
The overall number of military personnel on food stamps is small and difficult to measure because the Government does not track military recipients.
But a 1992 survey by the Defense and Agriculture Departments found that about 3 percent of the 1.7 million service members qualified for food stamps and that 1 percent, or about 17,000 people, received them monthly. The Agriculture Department manages the food stamp program.
The Defense Department said the total value of food stamps redeemed at military commissaries increased to $27.4 million last year from $24.5 million in 1992. That amount included those redeemed by retired military recipients. Food donation centers are bustling at bases from Hawaii to Florida.
And in Liberty County, Ga., which serves Fort Stewart, 30 percent of the 2,400 households receiving food stamps each month are military families.
Top military officials voice concern that Pentagon budget cuts in areas like pay could impair both morale and retention of service members. The Clinton Administration tried to freeze military salaries this year and increase them by 1.6 percent for next year. Congress instead approved a 2.2 percent increase for this year and will probably approve a 2.6 percent raise for next year, but neither raise will keep pace with inflation, which is about 3 percent.
"We cannot expect service members to lay their lives on the line when back home their families have to rely on food stamps to make ends meet," said Adm. William A. Owens, the vice chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
 
Conflict in Cultures
 The vast majority of service members on food stamps are sergeants or below in the Army, Marine Corps and Air Force and petty officers or below in the Navy. The families usually have more than two children, and the spouse does not work. Very few officers qualify for food stamps.
In a culture that promotes a fierce ethic of taking care of one's own, soldiers' reluctant embrace of food stamps and other financial assistance has wounded military leaders.
"We've always told our soldiers that we'll provide for them a quality of life that's at least equal to the civilians for whom they serve," Richard A. Kidd, the Sergeant Major of the Army, the senior enlisted soldier, said in an interview. "It's getting tough to do that now."
For most people who join the armed forces, the lure is not money but adventure, education and patriotism. The military also offers good medical and commissary benefits.
But since 1982, the gap between civilian and military wages has widened to 13 percent, and it is projected to be near 20 percent by the end of the decade. The military wages include housing and other allowances.
At the same time, the rising pace of deployments abroad is placing greater strains on the shrinking number of service members and their families. "There's only so long you can ask them to do more without recognizing it before people just start to leave," said Sydney T. Hickey, associate director of government relations for the National Military Family Association in Alexandria, Va.
In addition, more young people than ever are entering the military with spouses and children -- and added financial burdens.
 
'The Military Poor'
 Seventy percent to 80 percent of all enlisted men and women earn less than $30,000 a year, including housing and food allowances, according to a study by Senator John McCain, an Arizona Republican on the Armed Services Committee. Among those, 45 percent in the Army and 46 percent in the Marine Corps earn less than $20,000 a year. Mr. McCain coined a new term for these people: "the new military poor."
Specialist Kimberly Southworth, a 29-year-old Army truck mechanic stationed at Schofield Barracks outside Honolulu. She is separated from her husband and living with her three children on post. Specialist Southworth said her monthly income was $1,700, but after taxes and bills, including $6 an hour for baby sitters, she has about $50 left each month.
"I don't like having to apply for food stamps, but I don't have a choice," said Specialist Southworth, who has received $390 a month in food stamps since January 1992. "The cost of living is so high in Hawaii and the pay for my rank is so low. If I didn't have food stamps, I'd be in debt up to my neck."
At the Navy base in Norfolk, Va., Petty Officer 1st Class Gary Benfield and his wife, Suzanne, said they and their four children -- ages 5 months to 7 years -- rely on another Federal program, this one for nursing mothers and children under 5, the Women, Infants and Children program, for $100 a month in food coupons.
Over all, the value of W.I.C. coupons redeemed at military commissaries increased to $15.2 million last year from $12.4 million in 1992. "It bothers me because no employee of the Federal Government should qualify for Federal assistance," Mrs. Benfield said.
Eligibility for food stamps is based on a combination of income, other financial resources and household size. Federal officials say as many as 40 percent of military families on food stamps live in free military housing. They qualify for stamps because their incomes are not raised above the cutoff by the housing and food allowances they would receive if they lived off base.
 
Personal Conditions
 Pentagon spokesmen say the issue is not strictly pay but individual family circumstances. "We don't compensate people for having nine people in their family," said Maj. Bill Buckner, an Army spokesman.
Military officials say they encourage service members with financial problems to take advantage of food stamps, and a variety of other programs, from emergency loans to financial planning seminars. But many families balk at stepping forward for what they consider a handout.
"We've tried to identify them, but they just don't come forward," said Chief Master Sgt. Eddie Morgan, the senior enlisted airman in the 33d Fighter Wing at Eglin Air Force Base in Florida. "It's a pride thing."
To get around that, the senior enlisted airmen at Eglin manage a fund called Operation Care that distributes $10,000 in yearly donations from other service members to needy families, usually around the holidays. Last year, 247 families, some with as many as seven children, received gifts of $25 for each family member.
Some branches of the military are reluctant to discuss the subject at all. When asked to help contact families on food stamps who would be willing to talk about their plight for this article, a Marine Corps spokeswoman, Lieut. Col. Robin Higgins, declined, saying, "The commandant prefers to emphasize the positive things about the quality of life in the Marine Corps." She was referring to Gen. Carl E. Mundy Jr., the Commandant of the Marine Corps.
 
Paying More Off Base
 So painful is the perceived stigma of using food stamps that some service members pay more to avoid being seen using them. A highly decorated chief petty officer in Norfolk, who received $200 to $400 a month in food stamps from 1982 until 1993, said he and his wife shopped in supermarkets rather than Navy commissaries, even though commissary food prices are on average about 25 percent cheaper.
"We didn't want to be seen by anyone we knew, so we went to the community store even though it was more expensive," said the chief petty officer, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
Defense Department officials say that about 50 percent of military spouses have full-time jobs to help pay the bills. Since military personnel transfer frequently, however, spouses often must start over each move and miss out on promotion opportunities.
Many service members work part-time as fast-food servers, gas station attendants, grocery baggers and hotel-room cleaners. A 22-year-old combat medic in an artillery unit at Fort Carson, Colo., started his second job today as a security guard in a city park. The medic said he needed the $4.25-an-hour weekend job to supplement his $1,000 monthly base pay, not including allowances, to support his wife and their three children, a 2-year-old boy and year-old twin boys.
"When I joined the Army, I expected good benefits, decent pay and job security, just like the commercials say," said the medic, a Persian Gulf war veteran who spoke on condition of anonymity. "But it's been a lot harder than I ever imagined."
Commanders expressed concern that working two jobs could hurt military performance. "It's something we pay attention to," said Chief Master Sgt. Mike Burbage, the senior enlisted adviser at Eglin Air Force Base. "But it's tough to tell a guy to quit a job if he needs it to feed his family."

HEADLINE: New York Area Climbs Out of Recession

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
After its worst downturn since the Depression, the economy in and around New York City is once again generating more jobs and higher incomes for a wide array of residents throughout the region.
Initially propelled by Wall Street's prosperity, which has spilled over into other sectors of the economy, the recovery is now being driven by entertainment businesses and the news media, culture and tourism, health services and a resurgence of consumer spending on cars, home furnishings and other big-ticket items. 
 The rebound, borne out by new figures released this month that showed a sharp drop in unemployment in the region, comes after New York, New Jersey and Connecticut lagged far behind much of the rest of the country in coming out of the recession.
The rate of the region's recovery is still slower than in past expansions. Employment gains are being held back by new rounds of layoffs at major corporations like Nynex, which plans to cut almost 17,000 more jobs in the next two years, and further cutbacks expected in the defense industries centered on Long Island and in Connecticut. A critical worry is that Wall Street, which has been a driving force behind the regional recovery, is threatened by unstable financial markets and higher interest rates that may weaken the upturn even before it can gather steam.
Still, for all the negatives, almost everywhere one looks, the economy in the New York region is clearly coming back to life.
On the avenues and side streets of Manhattan south of midtown, all the way to Canal Street, young businesses like the Voyager Company, a publisher of sophisticated CD-ROM disks that moved to New York this year from southern California, are establishing fresh business beachheads in the city.
These new businesses are being joined at street level by dozens of popular specialty stores -- from Bed, Bath and Beyond and Pottery Barn to Comp U.S.A. and Barnes & Noble's flagship bookstore -- that have followed Barney's and ABC Carpet to turn Chelsea and the Flatiron district into New York's snazziest new shopping areas.
And at the remodeled Army Terminal and Navy Yard in Brooklyn, scores of smaller industrial companies, like Edgar Berebi Associates, a rapidly growing jewelry maker, are spearheading a remarkable, if still modest, revival of manufacturing.
The recovery is taking root in the suburbs, too. On South Moger Avenue, the main shopping street of Mount Kisco in Westchester County, a new Starbucks expresso bar opened last weekend, the first suburban link of what may soon be an extensive New York chain of the popular gourmet coffee bars from Seattle.
Hiring by businesses like these has helped add more than 50,000 jobs to the region's economy since the beginning of the year. That figure may be modest, but it represents the first solid gains in the last five years and should lead to a year-over-year rise of more than 1 percent. Roughly 7.5 million people are employed in the 18 counties that make up the metropolitan area.
Unemployment, which averaged 9 percent in 1992 and slightly more than 8 percent in 1993, now appears to be close to 7 percent.
 
A Slow Expansion From Wall Street
 To be sure, the regional economy is a long way from regaining its previous vitality. While the United States economy surpassed its previous employment peak early last year, the New York region has restored only about one in seven of the 750,000 jobs lost in the recession.
Analysts now believe that the region actually began emerging from the recession more than a year ago. The initial improvement, however, was fitful and confined mostly to the plush offices of Manhattan's financial elite and along the edges of the region in the suburban townships of central New Jersey and the commercial centers of affluent Fairfield County, Conn.
Only in the last few months has growing economic activity started to seep into the nooks and crannies of daily life across much of the nation's largest urban conglomeration.
At her day-care center at a church in New Providence in Union County, N.J., for example, Blanca Knoll has recently expanded to the point where she employs up to 19 other people. She is opening a second day-care center in another local church and has started a popular language school to teach Spanish. She started caring for children in her own home in the late 1970's, with just her mother and aunt.
Demand for high-quality child care is strong because more parents are working, said Ms. Knoll, adding, "I've got a waiting list three years long with the names of 80 families." Three couples with children already in her program are on the list even though the women are not even pregnant.
Rail commuting, which closely tracks the economy, is up this year. Traffic on the PATH trains between New Jersey and Manhattan rose 2.3 percent in the first quarter of 1994 and is running almost 10 percent above its low point in late 1991. Both Metro-North and the Long Island Rail Road are currently outpacing their 2 percent gains of last year, when the number of passengers rebounded after falling two years in a row.
Business failures in New York City were down sharply in the first quarter, according to Dun & Bradstreet, which reported 444 failures, compared with 635 during the same period in 1992 and 532 last year.
Contrary to popular belief, the economic fates of 17 million residents in the New York metropolitan area now appear more intertwined than ever. This comes despite a vast buildup of shopping centers and offices in outlying areas that broke the physical and emotional connection millions of suburbanites once felt toward New York City, with its dominant business center in Manhattan.
But instead of actually sundering those ties, the exodus of many headquarters and back offices out of Manhattan to the rest of the region helped knit the city and the suburbs together more closely by forging an elaborate network of business relationships and telecommunications links within the metropolitan area.
"More than ever, we're all in this together," said Richard W. Roper, the economic director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. "Unlike the past, both the urban core and suburbs entered the recession at about the same time. The sharp pattern of job losses was similar and the timing of the recovery followed in close step. All this suggests a much higher level of regional interdependence than is generally recognized."
The regional recession has already taken its toll on Democratic chief executives in New Jersey and New York City. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who presided while New York State lost more than 500,000 jobs in the hard times, hopes the emerging recovery will help him escape voters' wrath this fall.
 
Where Profits Lead, Taxes Follow
 At the heart of the region's fortunes, for both good and ill, is the financial industry. Just as the stock market crash of October 1987 ushered in the end of New York's economic boom of the 80's and foreshadowed the onset of the severe recession that began in early 1989, the immense wealth generated by Wall Street in the last three years has finally helped pull the local economy out of its slump.
"This is a recovery that started at the top," said Rosemary Scanlon, a leading regional economist who is now deputy state comptroller for New York City, "and then filtered everywhere else with all that money earned on Wall Street kicking around the region."
Nearly one-third of all the wages earned in New York City are produced by the finance, insurance and real-estate sector alone, even though those services account for only 14 percent of the city's jobs.
Local government revenues reflect the nature of the recovery. Profits in banking and securities translated into a 100 percent gain in New York City banking tax receipts in the first quarter compared with a year earlier. Sales taxes, which have been depressed for several years, are now expected to rise 6.2 percent for the fiscal year that ends this month. Meanwhile, despite a sharp upturn in leasing, rents are still a bargain and new office construction is practically nonexistent, leaving property and commercial rent taxes to lag $105 million behind expectations.
Randy Gerner, who runs KPF Interior Architects on West 57th Street, can testify to the recent burst in New York business. "In literally the last two months, the number of requests for our services has been phenomenal," he said. "Now that real estate and office rental prices have bottomed out, everybody seems to have decided all at once that this is the time to move."
Known for its stylish office make-overs for companies including Bear, Stearns and Viacom International, KPF's business in New York City has almost doubled in little more than a year, from projects involving about 1.2 million square feet to 2 million square feet today.
While still down from 3.5 million square feet in projects at the height of the 1980's building boom, "we haven't seen the New York atmosphere this active in years," Mr. Gerner said. "It's being driven by investment-banking and entertainment firms."
 
More Money, Travel And New Businesses
 There are other straws in the wind, too.
Air traffic finally took off this winter at the region's three major airports, with passenger traffic up 20 percent in March at Newark International from a year earlier and about 10 percent at both La Guardia and John F. Kennedy International Airports.
State personal-income tax receipts are also up in the region, with Connecticut reporting a 10.7 percent increase for the first quarter, New Jersey up 12.7 percent, and New York registering a more modest 5.9 percent.
Vacancy rates in prime midtown Manhattan office buildings, helped by a 50 percent increase in leasing this winter, fell to 14.5 percent, down from 16.3 percent a year earlier. Except for the Hudson Valley, suffering because of I.B.M.'s retreat, suburban office vacancy rates are also heading down sharply.
Over all, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York concluded in a recent report to Washington that economic developments in New York and New Jersey "were by and large more favorable, suggesting that the pace of economic activity has been picking up."
Voyager, the multi-media publishing company that moved from California, is an example of the new types of businesses that are beginning to cluster in New York. It prides itself that its CD-ROMs, which are used on personal computers and carry titles like "Poetry in Motion" and "The Society of Mind," are not just mindless fun and games.
Together with Interval Research, a computer research center, and Wired, the magazine for the multi-media industry, Voyager is sponsoring a New Voices, New Visions contest. "Do Not Enter," reads a sign at the entrance to its office on lower Broadway, "if you want home shopping, encyclopedias and video games to define the information superhighway."
"The intellectual life here is more exciting than in California," said Robert Stein, who started Voyager a decade ago. "We're surrounded by innovative artists and authors we want to work with and who want to work with us."
 
Some Gaps Widen As Confidence Builds
 Still, there are vast stretches of poor urban areas in New York City, Paterson, N.J., Bridgeport, Conn., and other cities that remain bleak and forbidding zones, largely out of touch with the mainstream economy and dependent mostly on Government support and income from illegal activities. The shift to higher-skilled jobs makes it harder for those areas' residents, mostly minorities, to escape their plight.
And New York, never an easy place to live under the best of circumstances, has become even meaner and harder as the gap between the rich and the poor in the city widened to a point far in excess of anywhere else in the nation.
For all its problems, economists see many more bright spots in the region these days. Even areas like Long Island and Connecticut, hardest hit by the collapse of military orders, are reporting a turnaround.
"The recession is over, and the retail sector is leading a recovery here," said Pearl M. Kamer, the chief economist of the Long Island Regional Planning Board. "But because the process of corporate downsizing has yet to run its course, we're not going to reach our full growth potential for several years."
While several large corporations continue to cut jobs, the hidden strength of the regional economy is its vast array of mid-sized companies. Chemical Bank, which dominates lending to companies with $10 million to $500 million in annual sales, reports that demand for loans improved over the last few months.
"Our customers feel a lot better than they did two years ago," said Frank Lourenso, the Chemical Bank executive responsible for middle-market banking. "It won't be an explosive recovery, but this expansion should build a better foundation than the last one."

HEADLINE: Old Southern Documents Give Lie to Theory of Happy Slaves

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: GREENVILLE, S.C., June 11

 BODY:
For the past three years a history professor has been unearthing thousands of court documents that he says debunk a popular theory about slavery: that wealthy slave owners were a paternalistic lot who treated slaves like children and that enslaved families stayed together while making the most of their lives by singing and telling stories.
The professor, Loren Schweninger of the University of North Carolina at Greensboro, says the long-forgotten records of court petitions and pleadings from slaves and their owners tell of lost loves (slaves were forbidden to marry), broken promises and the selling of babies. 
 For example, Joseph Antoine, a free black in the late 1700's, fell so deeply in love with a Virginia slave that he indentured himself to her master for seven and a half years to gain her freedom. But when the time came to free them both, the master reneged and sold them.
Mr. Antoine sought justice from a chancery court and eventually won. But it was too late. The woman had died enslaved.
The court record that chronicles Mr. Antoine's despair is one of more than 12,500 petitions collected over the past three years by Professor Schweninger from courthouse basements in 10 of the 15 slave-holding states. He has been using $100,000 in grants from the National Historical Publications and Records Commission, part of the National Archives, to amass the records, dating from 1775 to 1866.
There was Hannah, an elderly slave in Kentucky who brought only 50 cents at auction in 1830 because of her "age and decrepitude."
And in 1845 in the same state a slave trader sued a man for selling him two babies, a 4-month-old and a 9-month-old, who the trader said were "worth nothing at all" because they were too sick. He had traded a horse, worth about $160, for the babies.
As to the theory of paternalistic owners and happy slaves, Professor Schweninger said: "The harsh realities were different in most cases. The family was under severe, severe strains and the economic aspects are shown so clearly, it's difficult to see the family survive. It's very bleak."
Only one in four white families in the 10 states owned slaves, because they were expensive. Two slaves were often worth more than a man's land, house and all his belongings, according to the records.
"They show the impersonal market forces that were at work everywhere slavery was," Professor Schweninger said. "Even in areas where there were large numbers of free blacks, there was a tremendous pressure pushing them back toward slavery."
In South Carolina, where laws prohibited free blacks from returning if they left the state, a man who had once managed a prominent Charleston hotel pleaded for permission to return to his home state to die.
 
Turner Uprising Survivor
 In Virginia, a petition from a family member sought the return of property swindled from a woman driven crazy from having watched her family killed in the slave uprising led by Nat Turner in 1831. The woman, Harriet Whitehead, had hidden under a bed in her home. In all, more than 50 whites were killed in the uprising.
Professor Schweninger said he stumbled on the documents in Equity and Chancery Courts in the late 1960's while working on a doctoral dissertation about James Rapier, the black Reconstruction leader from Alabama. He found a deed of emancipation for Mr. Rapier's uncle, which told the family's history.
In 1991, Professor Schweninger obtained the first $25,000 grant, which has been annually renewed. He plans to finish his work in the five remaining former slave-holding states by August 1995.
Professor Schweninger will publish an edited version of the collection in two volumes next year. In addition, all the names will be fed into a computer database that can be used by used by genealogists and others.

HEADLINE: Legal Gambling Bedevils Louisiana

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, June 7

 BODY:
Asked about the indictments and accusations lurking like buzzards around Louisiana's gambling industry, Mary Palmer looked up from her 25-cent Double Dollars slot machine at the Showboat Star Casino recently and gave her best "Does-a-crawfish-love-mud?" shrug.
"It's Louisiana," said Ms. Palmer, a 45-year-old hairdresser from the New Orleans suburb of Harvey. "Louisiana's crooked. It's true. It's a fact. What's to be surprised about?" 
 No one expected an innocent stroll in the moonlight. Louisiana, after all, is famous for its elastic ethics. This is a state that has lurched toward legalizing almost every form of gambling known to man, a state where big-time gambling in America reached its first flower after the Civil War in an infamous $30 million dollar lottery run by ex-Confederate generals.
But with a high-stakes gambler, Edwin W. Edwards, now the Governor and with the indictments of organized-crime figures accused of skimming proceeds from video poker machines, Louisiana's reborn gambling industry is already being viewed inside and outside the state as the gambling boom's train wreck in progress.
 
But Is Louisiana Alone?
 "You just look at what the whole thing represents, there's just one word for it, and that's sick," said William N. Thompson, an expert on the gambling industry at the University of Nevada at Las Vegas.
Still, at a time when casino earnings nationally jumped to $10.1 billion in 1992 from $4.2 billion in 1982, the real question may be how much is unique to Louisiana and how much reflects the state's brassy tradition of doing flamboyantly what other places like to do furtively.
Last week, 17 men with links to organized crime were charged with plotting to skim profits from some of the 13,256 video poker machines proliferating in bars and truck stops around the state. Since November, a grand jury in Baton Rouge has been investigating how the state awards licenses for riverboat casinos amid allegations that political ties are more important than economic merit. The grand jury has heard from Governor Edwards once and expects to call him again, although there is no indication he is a target of the investigation.
There have been new reports about the way his four children have tried to get casino business, with one of them handling business inquiries from the Governor's Mansion and another involved in negotiations with his father at the mansion over a disputed gambling license.
The companies that have obtained the 13 riverboat casino licenses that the state has granted thus far have been laced with longtime Edwards friends and associates; moreover, the Governor's son Stephen is the lawyer for four of the companies.
Governor Edwards has said that his children did nothing improper, but aside from Stephen Edwards's legal representation, the children have agreed to stop their business transactions with casinos.
 
Edwards a Gambling Winner
 There is also Mr. Edwards's $308,000 in casino gambling winnings last year; the wild scramble to get a piece of what is scheduled to be the world's biggest casino in New Orleans, and a top New Orleans police official dismissed after it was disclosed he had also been working for a video poker company in Las Vegas.
It might have seemed like business as usual when the president of the State Senate, Sammy Nunez, ambled through the chambers the other day handing out $2,500 campaign contributions from one of the state's gambling boat owners.
But critics say the combination of back-scratching politics and boatloads of casino money are creating the potential for corruption that is off the charts even by Louisiana standards. "It's huge amounts of money interacting with bad old-fashioned Louisiana politics," said State Representative David Vitter, a Republican, who has been one of the Legislature's few outspoken critics of gambling. "That's a very deadly combination."
Proponents of the industry say the public relations may be bad, but the process is not.
 
'We've Been Flamboyant'
 "These are highly regulated companies," said Steve Rittvo, a gambling industry consultant in New Orleans. "They will not take a chance in doing something that is illegal or really unethical for fear they're going to lose their licenses in other locations. I don't think we've done anything wrong. I think we've been flamboyant."
Governor Edwards, who has been regarded as the ringmaster of the gambling circus, took pains this week to stand up for his own integrity when he stunned state legislators by announcing he would not run for a fifth term. "Regardless of what was said, I went by the rules and obeyed the rules," he said.
And, for all the furor, it appears Louisiana has cut a tough deal with gambling operations. Because of Louisiana's higher tax rate, the four riverboat casinos already operating provided the state with $44 million in tax money for the first four months of the year, while the 24 casinos in Mississippi contributed only $36 million to that state.
 
Big Casino Opening Delayed
 There are at least five major areas of concern in Louisiana: the chaotic licensing process and bitter legal battles that have stymied the land-based casino in New Orleans; the involvement of Mr. Edwards's family; allegations that political insiders have had the upper hand in securing licenses for riverboat gambling; the video poker indictments and the games' willy-nilly spread, and a disjointed regulatory process some say has made gambling in Louisiana almost impossible to regulate.
Louisiana's Legislature approved a single land-based casino in New Orleans in 1992. A temporary casino that was expected to open in the spring is now scheduled for December. The permanent casino will not be open until a year after that at the earliest.
"I can imagine going back to Edwards's election, and having him say, 'Listen, folks, I want to have legalized gambling, and I want the casino run by 10 of my best friends,' " said a lawyer in one of anti-casino lawsuits, Thomas Tucker. "Ninety-five percent of the people would have said, 'No.' But that's what happened."
A broad concern is that the state has established a toothless, disjointed regulatory framework in which each form of gambling is regulated by a separate body. Almost everyone agrees that events thus far have not inspired confidence.
"The surprise isn't that all this is happening, but that it all happened so quickly," said C. B. Forgotson, who last year represented the state's anti-casino forces. "I went to Houston recently to talk to some folks who are worried about casino gambling there. I told them I now know exactly what to do, because we've done everything wrong here."

HEADLINE: A Nuclear Plant's Expansion Raises Neighbors' Concerns About Safety

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: FORKED RIVER, N.J., June 9

 BODY:
Several hundred yards from the giant concrete cube that houses the nuclear reactor of the Oyster Creek electric generating station, Scott Hook, 32 years old, whipped a baited fishing line into the middle of the plant's wide discharge canal and waited for a bite.
Water used to cool the reactor and tons of nuclear waste stored inside the plant is about 10 degrees warmer in the canal than in Barnegat Bay, where it is headed, a condition that attracts baitfish and larger fish like striped bass that feed on them. 
 "I eat a lot of fish out of here, and I ain't glowed yet," joked Mr. Hook, repeating a line heard from oldtimers: that the danger of a nuclear plant as a neighbor is overstated.
 
New Fears Over Safety
 Recently, however, there is less joking and more nervous grumbling about the safety of the 25-year old Oyster Creek plant, located about midway between New York City and Philadelphia, the oldest operating nuclear plant in 11 northeastern states.
The change in attitude has been focused around the recent decision by GPU Nuclear Corporation, which operates the 630-megawatt plant for Jersey Central Power and Light Company, to open a $15 million storage site in concrete bunkers outside the plant's current containment building. The bunkers would be closer to Route 9, a busy highway paralleling the Garden State Parkway along most of the Jersey Shore.
Without the "dry" storage capacity, the plant would run out of storage space by 1996 and would be forced to shut down, company officials say; with it, the plant can continue operating until its license expires in 2009. Moreover, there is new worry here that the site will remain a storage depot for nuclear waste long after the plant stops generating electricity.
 
A Change in Attitudes
 A permit for the change in storage was granted by Lacey Township, where the plant's 1,416 acres are located. But anti-nuclear advocates and some local officials recently filed suit in Superior Court to force the township to review the action, on the grounds that no environmental impact statement was required.
The suit reflects a change in attitudes about Oyster Creek, which have always been dominated by the economic benefits provided by the plant -- 960 jobs and some $10 million in local taxes annually.
In recent years many new residents have moved into the waterfront communities and retiree villages in the eastern reaches of Ocean County, with much of the recent growth in the Forked River area, about 80 miles south of New York City. The county's population has doubled to about 450,000 residents since the Oyster Creek plant began operations in 1969.
The increased population, combined with summer congestion, have added to concern about evacuation along crowded shore routes in case of a nuclear accident. And many of the new residents have fewer economic ties to, and more questions about, the Oyster Creek plant.
"I have a real problem with them sticking plutonium on the side of Route 9," said Tim O'Connor, a professional planner who lives about four miles from the site. "Isn't that what's behind all the trouble we are having with North Korea, accounting for the plutonium in their nuclear plants?"
 
Terrorists Discounted
 While plant officials say there is plutonium in the stored waste (about six parts per thousand, or 12 pounds for every ton), they say ample safeguards are being taken to protect the bunkers from potential terrorists, or natural or manmade disasters.
Mr. O'Connor was one of about 100 local people who turned out for a meeting tonight on the plant held in the neighboring town of Berkeley. Its Mayor, Bill Zimmerman, a party to the suit, said he opposed keeping the plant and wanted leaders of other towns to present their views at a meeting he hoped to arrange.
No problems are expected in the transition to dry storage, said Keith M. Bromery, an Oyster Creek spokesman. He said radioactive waste removed from the spent-fuel pool would be packed in helium, to inhibit corrosion, and sealed inside 15-foot steel canister assemblies placed in outside vaults protected by three-foot thick walls of concrete.
Twenty vaults could eventually hold 2,600 assemblies, each weighing about 900 pounds, representing all the uranium-235 and its byproducts used over the 40-year lifetime of the reactor, he said.
The vaults are seen as temporary storage, but the Federal Government is still at least 15 years away from creating an underground national nuclear fuel repository at a proposed site at Yucca Mountain, Nev.
In case that option does not materialize, the N.R.C. has issued a general permit allowing plants like Oyster Creek to continue storing the canister assemblies up to 120 years. Skeptics say that the assemblies at Oyster Creek are not fitted for transportation off the grounds.
 
Reactor a Main Concern
 It was clear from the tone of the meeting that the safety of the reactor itself, not the storage adjunct, was what concerned most people.
The plant's reactor is one of 15 still operating around the country that were identified in a Nuclear Regulatory Commission report last year as possibly subject to failing metal strength before their licensing terms expired. Another veteran reactor, Yankee Rowe in Massachusetts, was retired last year for this reason.
Federal officials notified Jersey Central two months ago that a review found "no abnormal concerns" with the reactor's wall.
Nonetheless, beginning in September, the reactor will undergo extensive ultrasonic inspections for cracks and other flaws, Ron Hernan, a senior N.R.C. project engineer in Washington, said in an interview.
At tonight's meeting, two officials of the Nuclear Information and Resource Service, a clearinghouse in Washington for groups concerned with nuclear safety, questioned whether an aging boiling-water reactor like the one here could contain a potentially disastrous meltdown.
Paul Gunter, director of the Washington group's Reactor Watchdog Project, called Oyster Creek "one of the most controversial plants in the country" and said deficiencies in its 1960's design "continue to plague it."
Instead of addressing the danger, he said, the commission has called the chance of a meltdown remote.
But Jerry Beer, a mechanic with 19 years of service at the Oyster Creek plant, said Mr. Gunter was distorting quotes from the N.R.C.'s experts.
Newcomers, he said after the meeting, should not have been surprised to find they had bought a house next to a nuclear power plant with a venting stack as high as the Washington Monument. "They either should not have moved here or, once here, keep quiet," he advised.
 
Fearing the Unknown
 Residents of the area have mostly followed his advice. Dan Siracusa, a retired New York Housing Authority worker, said he was untroubled by the talk. "Everyone's dealt with it this long, so I don't know what the fuss is about," said Mr. Siracusa, 67, as he sat on a railroad trestle and reeled in fish from the discharge canal.
"Some people tend to be scared of anything they don't understand," mused Joe Ruiz, an insurance broker from Colonia, N.J., who lives on a boat at the Southwinds Harbour marina several months of the year.
A neighbor in the marina, Richard Morehouse from Chatham Township, a retired clothing executive who lives aboard a 38-foot sailboat, said he had confidence in the safety of nuclear technology. "They do their normal shutdowns and inspections and I trust them," he said.
Willie deCamp, president of the Izaak Walton League of Ocean County, an environmental group, had a different view.
"The risks we feel are evident at Oyster Creek are not ones faced only by people at the Shore," he said. "We are just 80 miles from New York. Ask people in Kiev, which is 50 miles from Chernobyl, if they feel lucky to have survived that disaster because the wind was blowing the other way."

HEADLINE: At S.R.O.'s, Quality Varies Yet Squalor Is Common

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
They range from the squalid, degrading and dangerous at the bottom to the spare, poor but reasonably clean and safe at the top.
At 111th Street just off of Riverside Drive, for example, the exterior of one building housing mostly destitute single men afflicted with AIDS is so well maintained that it blends into a gracious neighborhood of co-ops and brownstones. 
 On West 17th Street, by contrast, is a place of drugs, crime and prostitution, of dangling wires, unattached radiators and scabrous walls.
On West 45th Street, diagonally across the street from the Martin Beck Theater, where "Guys and Dolls" is being performed, is the Longacre Hotel. It is a place of tiny rooms but clean hallways and bathrooms where, as one staff member put it, "There is no drug dealing here -- never."
All three buildings are single-room-occupancy hotels, generally known as S.R.O.'s, and they demonstrate that there is a certain variety in the quality of this particular form of housing, which the city defines as a building for single people in which the residents share baths, toilets and, sometimes, small kitchens.
 
The Kenmore's Owner
 Last week, the largest S.R.O. in the city, the Kenmore on East 23d Street, was seized by Federal authorities because it had become infested with drug dealers who were terrorizing residents. But the man who owns the Kenmore, Tran Dinh Truong, also owns the Longacre, a building in reasonably good condition which seems at the opposite end of the S.R.O. scale from the Kenmore, which he had evidently allowed to deteriorate.
In general, residents, building managers and officials at social service agencies, which often use S.R.O.'s to house their clients, characterize the Kenmore as unusually squalid and dangerous, more so than almost any other building of the same type. But even though other S.R.O.s are generally not as bad as the Kenmore -- and even though some stand out as efficiently run and are regularly cleaned -- the typical S.R.O. is still rundown and depressing, with some having conditions of filth and danger similar to those found at the Kenmore.
"The Kenmore is reasonably typical, but it is the bottom of the barrel," said Gene M. Estess, executive director of The Jericho Project, a nonprofit organization that provides housing and services for homeless and indigent people in several S.R.O.s on Manhattan's Upper West Side.
For many, S.R.O.'s are often the last thread saving them from a life on the streets. Mired in controversy for decades because of their often poor conditions, homeless advocates nevertheless acknowledge that they often provide a vital function in housing people who are unable to afford a place to live. Their tenants are often people on the margins who are dependent on government help or, sometimes, the underground economy, which can make these buildings breeding grounds for crime.
"The saddest thing about these buildings is that most of the elderly persons in them are afraid," he said. "Inasmuch as these places are dumping grounds for people who are really down and out in New York City, then inevitably things are going to happen that will scare the hell out of the elderly."
Among the problems at many S.R.O.'s are deteriorating physical conditions, rats, mice and roaches. A man at an S.R.O. on West 107th Street, just off Broadway, described as common the menacing people in the hallways who do not live in the building, drug use in the rooms, thefts in rooms with chronically broken locks, the yelling and the banging of mentally disturbed people, and a pervasive seediness.
"But it's O.K.," the man, who would not give his full name, said of the brick building he has lived in since November. "It's not the best, but there are worse places, believe me."
In all, according to an official at the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, there are more than 40,000 rooms in S.R.O.'s in the city, a substantial reduction from the 52,000 rooms in 1986 and more than 100,000 in previous decades.
 
Demand Is High, Supply Low
 S.R.O.'s in New York have had a long and often troubled history. Many of the current S.R.O.'s were once reputable apartment houses or hotels that were converted to single-room buildings to accommodate the flood of single workers who came to the city during and after World War II. When the demand for new apartments began rising in the 1970's, many were converted to ordinary rental buildings or co-ops. In 1983, the city, worried about the shortage of cheap, single-room housing, imposed a moratorium on such conversions, but the courts struck down the moratorium in 1989.
Meanwhile, with the drug epidemic, the advent of AIDS, and the increase in homelessness during the 1980's, S.R.O.'s became places where destitute and indigent people, including many elderly people, ended up. Some of these tenants were mentally unstable or used drugs, creating dangerous living conditions.
Social welfare agencies that place people in S.R.O.'s find themselves in a curious position. On the one hand, they are critical of the conditions prevailing in many of these buildings. On the other, they do not want the authorities to close them down, because they are, in many cases, the only places left to house the drug the homeless and the AIDS patients who have no place else to go.
"Some are in horrible shape," said Elizabeth Kane, the director of West Side S.R.O. Project, a private group that tries to improve conditions for S.R.O. residents. "But this is housing of last resort for poor, single adults who would otherwise be homeless."
In unannounced visits to S.R.O.'s in Manhattan, many were found to be in far better condition than the Kenmore, even though every one of the dozen or so buildings suffered from cramped conditions and a seediness that no amount of new paint or cleaning could cover up.
"The management really makes a big difference," Mr. Estess said. "You can have a building that's poor, but if you keep out the criminal element, you can be all right.
"But, when management allows drug dealers to set up inside, then everybody is high, everybody is a danger, and the little people huddle fearfully in their rooms."
The building on 610 West 111th Street, the one that is virtually indistinguishable from others on the street, is run with firm control by Sajid Ali, an immigrant from Pakistan who is both part owner and manager. About 80 percent of its 87 rooms are occupied by single people who are H.I.V. positive, Mr. Ali said, adding that most of them were homeless men placed in the hotel by the Department of AIDS Services, which pays their rent of $210 a week.
 
The Tour of the Hotel
 Mr. Ali showed a visitor through the hotel, asking residents to open their rooms for inspection. The hallways were clean. Each cluster of rooms had a bathroom and a small kitchen, which, Mr. Ali said, are cleaned twice a day. The rooms were very small and unadorned. There were beds on metal frames, stained carpets, small chests of drawers.
"The most important thing is that the front of the place be clean," Mr. Ali said. "This is an expensive neighborhood and we don't want our people hanging around outside.
"There is nobody selling drugs," Mr. Ali continued, "but most of them are drug users and they can walk two blocks to Amsterdam Avenue and buy what they want."
Downtown, an S.R.O. at 105 West 17th Street is in far worse condition. In fact, neighborhood residents have issued public statements complaining that the building is, as one press release put it, "overrun by crack dealers and prostitutes."
 
<gfcrossline>No Lock or Doorknob
 The front door has no lock or doorknob. The vestibule door, adorned by a no soliciting sign, is off its hinges. Anybody can walk into the building unchallenged, and, according to some residents, many of the rooms are occupied by squatters who did just that.
Extension cords have been attached to the exit sign and used to carry electricity into the rooms. The plumbing leaks onto exposed wires that dangle from ceilings. Tenants complain that there is no heat and usually no hot water. The walls and ceilings have flaking paint. Pools of water lie on the bathroom floors. Shower fixtures are nonexistent. The bathtubs have large black stains.
"There's too much drugs," said Mirabel Baez, who has lived in the building since 1979. "There's no heat. The walls would collapse if you pushed on them. The toilets work one day a week so you have to run up and down the stairs to find a toilet you can use. There are people who are sick."
 
S.R.O.: Single Room Occupancy
S.R.O. stands for Single Room Occupancy and is considered by the city to be housing where tenants have single rooms but share bathrooms or kitchens.
Beyond that definition there are housing types that are sometimes grouped with S.R.O.'s, including Class B hotels, which do not have full baths but sometimes provide linen and maid service; rooming houses, and Section 248 S.R.O.'s, units in former tenement buildings that have been converted to S.R.O.'s.
In the 1980's, when the city was overwhelmed with homeless families, many hotels, like the Holland and Martinique in Manhattan, were used as emergency housing for homeless families with children.
Many of the places the city used were decrepit and dangerous, but had room rates that were affordable. These came to be known as welfare hotels.
Most tenants of S.R.O.'s are poor, single adults.
Each year the Rent Guidelines Board sets rent increases for long-term tenants of S.R.O.'s.

HEADLINE: Korean Worries Transcend the Bomb

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, June 9

 BODY:
The plot of this country's best-selling thriller seems right out of the evening news. South Korea's longtime enemy threatens it with annihilation, and the Government in Seoul, after deceiving the White House and the C.I.A., secretly develops its own nuclear weapon in self-defense. Overheated oratory and misguided diplomacy eventually lead to war, and to protect its factories and airfields from bombing the South launches its first nuclear missile.
But in "The Rose of Sharon Has Blossomed," the enemy invader is Japan, and the Americans prove to be useless wimps, unwilling to live up to their treaty obligations to defend South Korea. In a triumph of Korean nationalism over ideology, the capitalist South is saved by an alliance with the Communist Government in North Korea, which contributes its own nuclear expertise to save the Korean Peninsula. 
 The novel's success -- the tale is spread over three volumes that have sold a total of 2.7 million copies -- says much about South Korea's nervous ambivalence these days as to who is its real enemy. On the streets of Seoul, many South Koreans say they simply do not believe the North Korean Government of Kim Il Sung would use nuclear weapons -- if it has them -- against other Koreans. And even many who denounce the North's Government as a crazed and desperate regime wonder aloud about the motives of the American talking heads who, from the safety of Washington, beam into their living rooms talking about preparing for war.
 
Worry Increases Overseas
 One of the many oddities of the North Korean nuclear standoff, from its start several years ago, is that the sense of crisis increases the farther one is from Korea.
The Europeans and the United States have been the most insistent on taking a hard line, saying the future of limiting the spread of nuclear weapons is at stake. The Japanese, Chinese and Russians, all within missile range, have shared one idea above all others: Preserve the status quo, because anything else is too horrible to contemplate. And the South Korean Government has swung wildly from conciliation to hardline -- this has been a hard-line week -- prompting the country's leading newspaper to say that President Kim Young Sam "has no consistent principle on this issue."
Principles may be hard to come by because the confrontation with the North has conjured up a contradictory mix of national emotions, and a sense that Korea, once again, is becoming the playground of bigger powers with their own agendas. Lee Hong Koo, a scholar and now the country's Minister of Unification, laughed the other day when a visitor mentioned the popular trilogy.
"I have to admit, though, it hits every insecurity in the South Korean psyche," Mr. Lee said. "The small-country mentality, the fear of being a pawn of bigger powers, the Japanese. It's all there."
 
Easy Artillery Range
 That is hardly to say no one is worried about the North Koreans. A few months ago people waved off the threat; these days they are a little twitchy, wondering if the North might possibly mean what it says when it declares that economic sanctions would constitute an act of war.
Before, people would say that when you live in a city within easy artillery range of the Demilitarized Zone and only a 10-minute flight for North Korean bombers, one or two untested nuclear weapons didn't seem to change the equation much. Now, as the Government is checking thousands of underground air raid shelters to see if they are stocked with water, no one seems quite so sure.
In Seoul's prosperous financial district, workers say that while they are worried about the North, they are more worried the United States will mishandle the talks and push the North into a corner.
"When you think about the size of their economy and ours, I think the chances of the North attacking the South are not so high," Kim Kwang Hyung, a computer salesman, said the other day. "If they have a bomb, it is just for diplomatic advantage. But if we all push too hard, they may strike out."
 
Fear of Reunification
 War scenarios aside, what really scares people about economic sanctions against the North is that they just might work -- causing the Government in Pyongyang to collapse and speeding a ruinously expensive, socially disruptive reunification of the Korean Peninsula.
Long gone are the days when ordinary South Koreans talked dreamily of reunification, when the DMZ would be wiped away and families torn apart by war four decades ago would reunite once more. While reunification is still the supreme national goal and the source of endless political platitudes, it was easier to talk about when it did not seem like a real possibility.
Now the nuclear confrontation has made that possibility seem even more real, and the talk is about a "soft landing," -- that is, a reunification that comes with a minimum of costs and social disruptions.
Every Government study has suggested that in fact the costs would be staggering, far greater than the price of reunifying Germany. Though the North was by far the richer of the two through the early 1960's -- it got the rich natural resources, and the United States thought the South would be a perpetual basket case -- in pure economic terms South Korea now grows a new North Korea every year.
 
High Costs and Refugees
 So it is no surprise that when television programs here talk about reunification, the heartwarming stuff of sisters and brothers finding each other quickly gives way to more practical concerns. What will happen when cheap Northern labor floods the market, pulling down South Korean wages? Who will handle millions of refugees pouring into Seoul, an island of wealth 30 miles from the DMZ? Who will pay for rebuilding the decayed infrastructure of the North?
In Japan, many ask the same questions. The Government in Tokyo, never known for its generosity when it comes to taking in immigrants, is already struggling with contingency plans in case North Korean boat people come ashore.
"The reason everyone in Asia is handling the nuclear issue so gingerly is that no one in the area wants a collapse," Sung Chul Yang, a political science professor at Kyunghee University and author of one of the most detailed comparative studies of the North and South Korean political systems. "But they all know that if we push the North, we are precipitating collapse.
But there is another level to the arguments, a sense among some South Koreans that the confrontation is being directed by outside powers. The suspicion is often directed at the Japanese, who first invaded the Korean Peninsula in 1592 and colonized it for the first half of the 20th century.
 
Japan Seen as Threat
 These days, polls consistently show that South Koreans view Japan as a bigger long-term threat to the country than the North. Some prominent South Koreans voice the opinion, usually in private, that Japan would like to see Korea remain divided because, once unified, it would become a far tougher competitor.
"The collapse of North Korea has to happen some time," Oh Yun Joon, the president of a small pharmaceutical company, said the other day on his way back from lunch in Seoul's financial district. "But we don't want a lot of pain and suffering, because in the end the national power of the Korean people will be lessened."
Similarly, young people here often express suspicion that the United States has its own agenda, and that it is using the Korean situation to reassert militarily the influence it has lost in Asia economically.
Some of this may be paranoia in a country that has always been overwhelmed by more powerful neighbors. But even South Korean officials who are delighted with the cooperation of Washington and Tokyo in facing down the North say the various sides are driven by very different motives.
"We all see this through a different lens," a senior South Korean official who has been dealing with the North's nuclear program since the late 1980's, said here this week.
"Washington cares about the nonproliferation treaty, especially because it is up for renewal next year," he said, referring to the 24-year-old treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear arms. "It is worried about how to prevent the export of nuclear weapons to other places, places it is going to have to police."
"The North Koreans could care less about the treaty," he said. "For them, the issue is their relationship to the South. One or two bombs, or the plutonium for it, is sufficient in the North Korean mind to make a new North-South balance of power. They are not irrational. They know that anything beyond that, a truly big nuclear arsenal would incite a huge reaction from the U.S."
And the Japanese? "What you would expect," he said. "Wars are bad for exports."

HEADLINE: German Postal Union Is Resisting Benefit-Cutting Plans

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BONN, June 11

 BODY:
Workers' benefits have to be cut to improve Germany's economic competitiveness, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Government and its big business allies keep saying.
But determined resistance by labor unions this week against plans to slim down postal and telecommunications services before privatization showed this is easier said than done. 
 The Government plans to turn postal services, telephone and telecommunications and the postal bank, with their 670,000 employees, over to the private sector beginning next year. But those plans were thrown into doubt when negotiations with the Postal Union over post-privatization fringe benefits broke down Thursday.
On Friday, as millions of letters piled up in post offices closed by a wave of strikes called by the union, newspapers began reporting what the unions said they were battling to save after privatization. About 300,000 of the employees are civil servants with lifetime job security who are barred by law from striking. They have not taken part in the strikes.
A negotiator for the Postal Union, Gunter Heidorn, said the employees' organization opposed the privatization plan, which the Government hoped to get approved by Parliament on June 29.
The Government, he said, was trying to force "a massive cut in our standards of welfare" and reduce the number of seats employees have on worker-management councils of the private enterprises. About 90 percent of postal employees take home only about $350 a week, the union says.
It appeared to be counting on support from the opposition Social Democratic Party, which could block approval.
The most important of the union demands, spokesmen said, was the guarantee of a clear basis for employees' pensions and health insurance funds after private industry takes over.
Some things accepted as normal by all German workers and undreamed-of by most Americans are not even in dispute now, like an extra month's salary at Christmas and a vacation pay bonus. After privatization, postal employees would have to negotiate for the vacation bonus with their employers, but so far the Christmas bonus has been sacrosanct, even in private industry.
But the Government wants to keep private buyers from being frightened away by the need to guarantee such longtime benefits to postal workers as these:
*A cold soft drink for postal employees in hot weather, when the outside temperature exceeds 80 degrees.
*A warm beverage for employees working outside when the weather is colder than 14 degrees Fahrenheit.
*Funeral-wreath payments for families of employees and retirees -- $100 in summer, and $112 in winter.
*Interest-free salary advances of up to $3,000 for newlyweds.
A spokeswoman for the postal service said that some additional benefits would continue for existing employees, but that management would not guarantee them indefinitely.
These include such things as 90,000 subsidized rental apartments in Berlin, Frankfurt, Munich and other big cities for low-paid employees.
The postal authorities also keep 3,200 places in 12 German summer vacation resorts for low-income employees, and underwrite 7,000 places in Austria, Italy, Switzerland, France and the Netherlands.
"These self-designated employees' representatives apparently think cold drinks and a vacation on the Cote d'Azur are more important than future guaranteed jobs," said Helmut Ricke, chairman of Telekom, the German telecommunications giant.
Telekom, the postal service and the postal bank were split off as separate entities at the beginning of 1990 to set the stage for privatization. Next year, all three are to be converted to joint stock companies.
Unions and Government negotiators are to resume talks on Sunday night.

HEADLINE: Time Out From Bond Market Craziness

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As a psychiatrist and avid investor, I read with interest Thomas J. Friedman's "A Bond Market That Could Use a Psychiatrist" (Market Watch, May 22). In the old days, a psychiatric patient would go to an analyst for many years, spending four or five hours a week on the couch. It was expected that through extensive exploration of the unconscious mind patients would develop insight into the nature of their essence and that this process was therapeutic. Today, however, in the age of information superhighways, "900" numbers and Prozac, the need for ever quicker, painless fixes is the mode. 
 Likewise, in the old days investors would buy stocks and bonds, hold them over time and achieve a steady, regular inflation-beating return. Today, with derivatives and super-derivatives, the search for increasing returns and the technology to move vast sums, we have stopped searching for meaning and insight.
As it is with therapy, it is with investing: today, the baby-boomer generation just doesn't want to do the work necessary to understand the nature of markets. With knee-jerk responses to everything but the fundamentals, the bond market will continue its wild ride. What we need is to take a time out, evaluate the economic fundamentals and invest accordingly. If not, the craziness will continue.
 
BLAISE AGUIRRE
Boston, May 22
 
The writer is a resident at the Boston University Psychiatry Residency Program and a partner in the Bound Hat Investment Group.

HEADLINE: Students Care Far Too Much About Grades;
Love of Knowledge

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Making the Grades" (editorial, June 5) makes professors like me who opposed the change in Stanford's grading -- to restore the failing grade and to award C's and D's -- seem obstacles to intellectual life, opponents of excellence by students, lazy and dishonest, "pandering to consumers." A fine tribute, in my case, to 33 years of teaching at Stanford! 
 We were arguing that a record of achievement, rather than a historical record that includes failure and late withdrawal from courses as well as achievement, has served Stanford's students well and that the "dazzling" student transcripts -- not all of them dazzling -- are far from being "misleading" because they announce that they are precisely a record of achievement. We believe that potential employers, deans of graduate and professional schools and committees awarding scholarships need to know what our students know, not what they are ignorant of.
If our transcripts were perceived as misleading, our students would not, for example, have won this year alone six Marshall Scholarships, two Truman Scholarships and one Churchill Scholarship. I served on the California Rhodes Scholarship Committee for six years, and no one ever questioned the integrity of a Stanford transcript. If our transcripts were perceived as misleading, our students would not be accepted, as they are, in first-rate graduate and professional schools and, despite the bad job market, in good jobs.
Failure and late withdrawal from courses are usually the result of intellectual curiosity gone awry: students realize toward the end of a busy quarter, sometimes not soon enough, that they have taken on too many courses. I would rather have them take on too much than play safe by taking only the courses they know they can pass.
As for grade inflation, I'm not sure it exists in the fields I know. Our students are extremely bright. Admitting 1,600 undergraduates from a pool of more than 14,000 and, in the English department, 12 graduate students from more than 500 explains why we have bright students.
If, in a class of a reasonable size, I can't get achievement up to a level where students deserve a B or an A, I am a poor teacher. Your argument that students have a "false sense of their own worth" because they have been "operating in a mistake-proof system" is fatuous. Students know when they have failed and internalize a sense of failure without needing it inscribed on a piece of paper.
The unfortunate consequence of Stanford's debate and change, and the publicity that it has received is that students will become more conscious of grades as motives for learning. Love of knowledge, not fear of failure, should be the motive for learning that teachers at every level should encourage. In every other respect, Stanford's new policy and your editorial are solutions seeking a problem.
 
RONALD A. REBHOLZ
Professor of English
Stanford University
Stanford, Calif., June 6, 1994

HEADLINE: Students Care Far Too Much About Grades;
Bring Back the C

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Making the Grades" (June 5) is a true and timely editorial. Grade inflation, however, has not inflicted equal injury upon all parties. The smartest undergraduates may now need an A+, but they still are admitted to the best graduate schools. The "gentleman C" student may have become a gentleperson B-, but he or she still receives the treasured diploma and cares for little else. 
 It is the considerable number of hard-working high achievers who have suffered by our overgenerosity. When I began teaching in 1966, B or B+ was an honorable grade, evidence of intelligence, understanding and steady effort. The grade of B+ now indicates either dullness or just exactly nothing at all. Students who 25 years ago would have been delighted by a B+ are now insulted by it and don't hesitate to say so.
Stanford's restoration of the F will probably have little effect; national restoration of the C might benefit us all.
 
JOHN MCWILLIAMS
Middlebury, Vt., June 6, 1994
