HEADLINE: Lessons in Survival: Robeson High, '94 -- A special report;
Graduation: Where 500 Began, 150 Remain

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, June 11

 BODY:
Very soon now, what is left of the senior class at Paul Robeson High School will walk up the narrow steps and across the stage at the Third Baptist Church on the South Side for the 1994 commencement. The boys will wear red caps and gowns. The girls will wear gold. An alumna who is an engineer will give the commencement address. "Pomp and Circumstance" will play.
The seniors who managed to avoid being swallowed by the streets will finally touch a diploma, some becoming the first in their families to do so. The teachers expect it to be an exuberant occasion when their pleas for silence are likely be ignored by overjoyed aunts and foster parents. 
 The class does not look like it did freshman year before some girls had babies and some boys started selling crack and the shootings began to take their toll in the Englewood section of Chicago. From a class that began with 500 students, some 350 names will be missing from the program.
Gabrielle Joiner died in his junior year in a drive-by shooting over, people at Robeson say, some bad drugs a customer thought he had sold. Nikia Bell, a pallbearer at Gabrielle's funeral, is in Cook County Jail on drug charges. Johnny Elverton, a popular senior who helped paint the school mural in the front hall, is at Oak Forest Hospital in a coma after being shot outside his house last October. Irving Willis would be with his classmates, but he fell behind sophomore year and is now in the Class of '95. Many others have transferred or dropped out or will go to summer school in hopes of graduating later.
The seniors who will wear the robes on June 27 include Felicia Cribbs, who works at Popeye's and wants to be a nurse, and Carlos Burnes, the football captain who says he is sick of the violence, is going away to college and hopes never to live in Chicago again. At least 30 seniors are parents, and 3 girls are now expecting.
For those who make it to commencement, the journey has not been one simply from grammar school to the 12th grade. Some people at Robeson have taken to calling them the survivors of '94, not the seniors of '94 because they live lives with no guarantees.
"When I'm walking to school, I think about what would happen if someone drives up and pulls a gun on me," said Maurice Hill, a 19-year-old senior who was shot in the leg four years ago. " 'Would you be able to react to it in time? Are you going to run or try to get out of the way?' You got to think like that."
At big-city schools like Robeson, violence is a fact of life. The football team, which lost the city championship this school year by two points in the closing seconds, was real good, one coach said, at dropping to the ground when members heard the popping of gunfire across the practice field.
In a survey of 40 seniors, two-thirds said they had friends who had died violently. Rabashia Wright said she had lost eight friends since her freshman year.
Asked where they thought they would be in 10 years and what their dreams were, one girl said: "A wonderful husband and beautiful children. I will be teaching the second grade." One boy said, "I don't have a dream."
In official measures like truancy or dropout rates, Robeson is neither the worst nor the best school in Chicago. It may be on the rougher side of average and shows what many urban high schools must do to have any graduates at all. Teachers and staff members buy disposable diapers for students' babies, visit students in jail, find shelter for them if their parents put them out or pick up assignments from students who are at home after a birth but still want to do their work.
A big fear for counselors is that a family will run out of money to pay the telephone bill. "We can save them if they don't lose that phone," said Eudell McKenzie, a counselor. "I can keep bugging them then. But when the phone is disconnected and then the emergency number is disconnected, that child is almost lost."
Robeson sits in a gang war zone where a detente has been reached, but peace is theoretical. The school administration does what it says it must to keep the building safe. Students are neither permitted to use lockers nor encouraged to carry knapsacks that could be used to conceal weapons or drugs.
Class periods are twice the normal length -- 100 minutes -- to cut the time students could spend hanging out in the halls. Coats and sweaters are carried from class to class and hung on peg boards. Students pick up textbooks and notebooks from the day before and put them back when class is over.
Teachers say they do not have enough books to go around, and students say they rarely do homework because they cannot take the books home. In classes like physics, students try to write down as much as they can from the book to study at home.
While it seems that almost anything could happen in the streets, there have been no shootings in the school, which was named in 1977 for Paul Robeson, the black actor. The building, with its plain brick face, scratched plexiglass windows and house plants across from the metal detectors, has become a safe house of sorts. Students stay well past the final bell, and teachers sometimes have to shoo them out of the building.
The teachers know the students and their stories. "See that boy in the Bulls jacket?" Rosemarie Nicholes, the instructional coordinator said, standing in the hall. "Smart as a whip -- doesn't want anyone to know it. See that one in the black jacket -- both his parents are dope addicts and another lady took him in."
Most students return at the end of the day to homes headed by a single mother, many on welfare. Only 15 out of 100 seniors surveyed by the school last month were living with both parents. One in five does not live with a parent at all.
Chaunti Bryla lives with a cousin. Latrell Shelton lives with an aunt. Anthony Currie and Theresa Stilwell live by themselves.
School may be the safest part of their day. "I don't worry about them when school is in session," said Dr. Jacqueline Simmons, Robeson's principal. "But on weekends and spring break, I worry. I can't wait to read the papers to check whether anything has happened to one of them."
The senior class overflows with dreams and war stories. Here are four members who will be among the graduates:
 
The Gang Widow
Dropout Becomes An Honor Student
 In her starter jacket, baseball cap, big gold earring in the shape of a Nike logo and attitude from here to Ohio, Marlo Willies may not fit everyone's image of an honor student. But last quarter she earned one A, two B's and two C's, enough to make the honor roll.
She is also a gangster widow. Two years ago she bore the son of a high-ranking member of the Black Disciples street gang. Last year the father was killed by some rival Vice Lords. Her position means that she can depend on her late boyfriend's associates to give her rides, buy things for the baby and warn her if shooting is about to break out.
She is a Disciple herself -- in "the organization" as members call it. "Ain't too much I'm scared of," she said. "I ain't scared of nobody."
She dropped out of school before her son, Keitero, was born and came back because she wanted to make a better life for him. She is in a dropout prevention program. Counselors call and prod the students to come to school, often showing up in their living rooms if the students miss a class. Since joining the program, Marlo has gone from mostly F's to most-improved student.
 
'The Downtown People'
 Her father, who once worked in the post office, reared her after her mother left. He learned to braid Marlo's hair by buying a doll at Toys R Us and practicing until he got it right. "Being raised by my daddy, I'm not a typical girl," Marlo said. "Blood doesn't bother me. I can put a worm on a hook with no problems, and I don't mind getting dirty."
Right now she says she wants to be a nurse or work in a bank. She is dreaming of being one of those purposeful people she sees running to catch buses or trains to the Loop. Her fantasy is to work in an office and wear stockings like them. "The downtown people," she calls them.
"I see them walk by every day," she said. "I like the pretty white stockings and the gym shoes and the purse and umbrella. The downtown people -- they got money and self-esteem. Sometimes they look tired. They probably feel good about themselves. They're working and getting paid. They don't have to wait on no aid check or no man."
 
The Loner
One Finds School Easier Than Life
 The yellow school bus pulled from the curb next to Robeson filled with sequined students dressed a few octaves higher than the time of day would call for. It was 10 A.M., and some were in full evening gowns. They were headed to the senior luncheon aboard the Odyssey 2 and the first boat ride for many of them.
Their group pictures on deck had tall glass buildings in the background. The Gangster Disciples showed up in their black suits and fedoras. The G.D.'s had their own picture taken and did not let any boys who weren't G.D.'s in it. One G.D., Davion Fleming, came in a limousine, set his fedora, crown down, on the table to eat his roast beef and potato salad, did not dance to Snoop Doggy Dog at all and left in a limousine after it was over.
Hiram Hill did not go to the senior luncheon. He did not have the $37 for the cruise or money for a suit. He did not have a grandmother to give him some of her Social Security check or any money stashed away from a side job dealing drugs. That's not the kind of guy he is. He has one set of clothes -- jeans, a black T-shirt and an Adidas jacket.
Hiram, who is not related to Maurice Hill, saw the classmates off that morning, hands tight in his pocket, looking down at the sidewalk. Then he headed home.
His teachers say he is a nice boy who never gets a break. There were times in the last four years when there was no food in his refrigerator, no heat or hot water and no coat to get him through the winter. His mother, who always seems to be between jobs, has had trouble with alcohol. His father, a janitor, left the family years ago because "he could not deal with her addiction," a teacher said.
Some days Hiram would come to school late because it took extra time to heat the bath water on the hot plate. "School is easy compared to my life," he said.
Hiram will be the first of the four Hill brothers to graduate from high school. One brother is in jail. One has a son and a girlfriend who live with Hiram and his mother. "It seems like the only one proud of me is me," Hiram said.
He wanted to be different from his brothers and finish school. "If I get killed, I just get killed," he said. "I wasn't going to let it keep me from coming to school."
He did not go to the prom. His girlfriend -- it took him two years before he got the nerve to call her that -- broke up with him last week. But he said he would not have gone anyway because he could not afford it.
Recently he found an after-school job as a stock boy at a Walgreen's drug store, paying $4.25 an hour. It took a year of constant searching to get the job. "I'm doing this by myself," Hiram said. "I don't know where I'll be in 10 years. I don't even know if I'll be alive."
He keeps mostly to himself, says he does not trust anyone and has no role models. He seems to confide only in the journal in his social studies class. This is how Hiram explained his world earlier this semester in an essay where emotion gets more attention than spelling:
"The reason why teenagers are killing each other is because teenagers are struggling to survive more than animals are. It is not the teenagers that are to blame. The government does not want to put any recreation or counseling in the community. All of these drug addict parents are the real reason teenagers are killing each other. I think everybody knows what the problem is. It's just nobody wants to do a dam thing to help 'cause they are all scared.
"It is like haveing a broken step on your stairs and haveing the tools to fix it but not fixing it 'cause you are scared you will hurt your finger or something."
Hiram says he wants to go into marketing or maybe psychology. He heard there is money in that. A teacher got him to apply to Barber-Scotia College in Concord, N.C., but Hiram does not know whether he will even go. He had to confront the issue a few weeks ago when he filled out the school's senior survey. On the line for career choice, he wrote, "N.A." for "Not Applicable."
 
The Valedictorian
A Student Leaves The Others in Awe
 In home economics class the other day, a knot of students sat staring impatiently at a television screen, waiting for a glimpse of their hero. They were watching a replay of the state track finals in the 800-meter run and were getting antsy because, even though they knew the outcome, they could not see Nathaniel Omar. Why didn't those other runners get out of his way?
A blur of red, a corner of his jersey, appeared at the edge of the screen. "That's him! That's him!" one said.
"Come on, Omar! Come on, Omar!" another yelled.
"He's locked in now," said a third.
Nathaniel Omar came in sixth that day, but the Robeson students did not care about numbers. When the winner crossed the finish line, one girl said, "He runs like Omar."
They call him Omar, and he can do no wrong. When he walks into a room, the girls check their pin curls and ponytails. The boys rush over to slap him on the back.
He is everything at Robeson -- the valedictorian, track star and football player with a 3.6 grade point average, who works at Walgreen's after school. He has an amiable, angular face. Everybody knows him.
The seniors voted him Most Popular, Most Athletic, Most Articulate, Most Intelligent, Best Personality, Best Physique, Most School Spirited, Most Confident and Most Likely to Succeed.
Even the roughest gang members seem to be in awe of him. They leave him alone. He is aware of the violence and takes precautions but does not like to worry about it. "You have to keep your eyes open and pay attention to who's around you," he said. "You got to have a mind of your own. I don't follow what other people do. Can't nobody tell me nothing."
Ivy League schools do not come recruiting at places like Robeson. He did not apply to the prestigious area institutions like Northwestern University and the University of Chicago, which want higher scores than his on standardized tests. He is going to Southern University in Baton Rouge, La. and plans to major in business administration.
One of the few Robeson seniors in a two-parent home, he is the only boy among 10 children. His twin sister, Salimah, is also in the top five in the class. Unlike most other parents, their mother, Carolyn, is often at school, helping decorate the bulletin board or chaperoning the senior class luncheon.
 
The Model
Changing Vanity Into a Motivation
 For weeks, Monika Williams, the shortstop on the girls' softball team and the most fashionable girl at Robeson, walked around school toting a shopping bag filled with the paperwork of her twin obsessions. One is the prom. Tucked into her little shopping bag was a glossy catalogue with a picture of the navy sequined prom dress she had put in layaway in April. She would peek at the picture occasionally or warily show it to a few people who she knew would not copy it.
The other obsession is college -- her ticket to the fame and fortune she feels she was born to have. To Monika, it is an accident of circumstance that she lives in the Robert Taylor housing project and not in Beverly Hills. She carries business cards with a picture of herself announcing her availability as a model, shops the sales racks for the floppy hats and palazzo pants she sees in magazines and has little patience for the girls who have babies by different men.
"It's not slip-ups all the time, you know," she said.
She has bigger plans for herself. "I'm not going to be another sister out here struggling," she said, "knocked up with two or three babies, on aid and the father's out there with somebody else. You're sitting on the porch and he's out in the street somewhere. He's just sucking up oxygen."
 
Trying for Grambling
 Monika has turned vanity into a motivational tool. "I'm pretty much into myself," she said. She is the second oldest of six children and lives with her mother, who is on welfare. Her father is disabled and lives in Louisiana.
To reach her goal to be either a broadcast personality or chairwoman of her own company, she has to go to college. So, in her shopping bag are the letters and forms from Grambling State University in Louisiana, where she plans to be next fall.
One letter last week brought bad news. She would not receive the financial aid she needed. Grambling said she missed a financial aid deadline and would have to come up with $3,500 her family does not have.
All of this happened before the most important day of her life -- that of the prom. The whole thing cost her $697.41, including her dress, shoes, gloves, the prom ticket and a garter she got for 50 percent off because the sales clerk was flirting with her.
Thursday, the day before the prom, she had her hair styled into pin curls that made her look like Josephine Baker and slept on her right side, careful not to toss and turn too much. She had to look perfect because she was certain to be prom queen. She said she hoped she would get roses. She likes roses.
Omar was king, to no one's surprise. Monika braced for the sound of her name. But a girl named Jessica Silas, who wears glasses and said she did not think she had a chance, got the tiara and roses Monika wanted. She was near tears but tried to make the best of it. She remembered the good news she got that morning. Grambling extended the financial aid deadline. She would be going to college after all, and she said maybe she could become Miss Grambling.

HEADLINE: A Wary Congress Retreats From Bank-Rate Legislation

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 12

 BODY:
When the most populist panel of the House Banking Committee -- the subcommittee on consumer credit -- met on Thursday, the most remarkable development lay in what was not said.
Democrats criticized the Federal Reserve for raising interest rates, and assailed commercial banks for passing along the increase to borrowers, but not to depositors. But nobody suggested that solutions lay in legislation. 
 The general cautious tone reflected the extent to which Congressional Democrats, like Clinton Administration officials, have become wary of upsetting financial markets and regulating interest rates.
The subcommittee has the most liberal Democrats on the already liberal House Banking Committee. This year, the panel has fought to slow the expansion of big commercial banks into other states. It has also tried to force credit report companies to correct errors quickly and to make copies of credit reports free to consumers. But when it comes to proposing legislation on interest rates, the subcommittee has sat on the sidelines.
While enthusiasm for financial regulation has been eroding on Capitol Hill for years, the watershed seems to have been an unsuccessful effort two and a half years ago by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, to impose a 14 percent limit on credit card interest rates. Senate approval of the idea contributed to a 120.31-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average on Nov. 15, 1991; the idea quickly died in a House-Senate conference.
Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, the Massachusetts Democrat who heads the consumer credit subcommittee and ran the panel hearing, cited that experience as having discouraged any new legislative proposals on interest rates this year. "It's very difficult, as I have found out over the years, to legislate anything to do with interest rates," he said after the hearing.
Representative Stephen L. Neal, a North Carolina Democrat and 20-year veteran of the Banking Committee, said the wariness at Thursday's hearing was an example of a worldwide loss of faith in the ability of government to run financial markets. "Look around the world," he said. "People are electing governments that don't do such things -- these ideas are just generally discredited and are thought not to work."
Even if members of Congress were inclined to introduce legislation, nobody knows what it should say, said Representative Maurice D. Hinchey, a New York Democrat on the consumer credit panel.
"People are trying to come up with something that will be effective, but that something has not yet materialized," he said. "I don't think anybody has any solutions at the moment."
 
Following the Fed
 Banks have raised rates for many loans in step this spring with the Federal Reserve's four increases in short-term interest rates, totaling 1.25 percentage points, and the accompanying sharp rise in long-term interest rates for bonds. Rates on highly competitive loans, like those for autos, remain low, but others, like mortgages and small-business loans, are on the rise.
At the same time, rates for checking and savings accounts and certificates of deposit have risen much more slowly.
Testifying on Thursday, Lawrence B. Lindsey, one of the five sitting governors of the Federal Reserve Board, cited a study by the Consumer Federation of America that indicated banks were raising their loan rates faster than their deposit rates and keeping the difference. The study was made public last month.
"The evidence shows that rates on NOW accounts, savings deposits and money market deposits have been very sticky," he said. "They have been especially slow to respond to upward movements in market interest rates, although they have also been sluggish in the downward direction."
But Mr. Lindsey also said that no legislative action was needed concerning the widening spread between the rates. "The key here is for consumers to shop around," he said.
Politicians and financial industry analysts cited other reasons why interest rate legislation is unlikely this year. The rates remain relatively low by recent standards, so any limits would be set at levels that would seem cheap by the standards for most of the 1980's. President Clinton has said little about rising rates, making it harder for Congressional Democrats to move on their own. Also, Congress will be in session only a few weeks in the five months left before the November elections, with health care legislation tying up the House and Senate for much of that time.
The high cost of the savings and loan bailout may also have made Congress more reluctant to limit profits that strengthen the capital bases of banks. "The populists just finished paying for the savings and loan bailout," Karen D. Shaw, president of the Institute for Strategy Development, a bank consulting company, said. "They really understand that the deposit insurance funds make up the losses."
To be sure, members of Congress have not renounced all interest in regulating banks. Considerable enthusiasm exists on the committee for strengthening laws aimed at forcing banks to lend money in poor neighborhoods, for example.
Asked after Thursday's hearing whether his views on banks were softening, Mr. Kennedy replied, "Where I come from, you do particularly well taking on the banks."
But Mr. Neal seemed to express the general sentiment in Congress when he said, in an interview on Friday, "There have been times when these ideas have been much stronger -- of the Government setting rates and doing other things that people don't think are a good idea now."

HEADLINE: China Tells Why It Opposes Korea Sanctions

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to the New York Times 

DATELINE: BEIJING, June 12

 BODY:
China said today that it still believed that United Nations sanctions against North Korea would be "ineffective" and warned against using "violence" in trying to end North Korea's nuclear weapons program, a Japanese spokesman said after a meeting between the Chinese and Japanese Foreign Ministers.
At the same time, the Chinese Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, told his Japanese counterpart that Beijing would play a "positive" and "constructive" role in the coming Security Council debate over punitive measures aimed at forcing North Korea to give up its nuclear program, the spokesman said. 
 The Japanese Foreign Minister, Koji Kakizawa, reportedly did not press Chinese officials in two and a half hours of talks on whether Beijing would use its veto to block a resolution on sanctions in the Security Council.
"We did not come here expecting a detailed discussion with China on what measures are to be taken at the United Nations," the spokesman said.
He said one purpose of his trip "was to stress the importance of China's role" as the nation best suited to "transmit the atmosphere of the international community in the best manner" to the Government of President Kim Il Sung.
In its account of the meeting, China said sanctions "could only intensify the contradictions and even lead to results that all parties would not like to see."
The official New China News Agency also reported that Mr. Qian had expressed regret that the board of the International Atomic Energy Agency had voted to end its technical assistance to North Korea in response to North Korea's refusal to allow inspections of nuclear installations.
"We appeal to the parties concerned to make efforts to open dialogue, mitigate contradictions and seek a way of settling the problem step by step," Mr. Qian was quoted as saying.
The visit by Mr. Kakizawa, after an agreement by the United States, Japan and South Korea to press ahead with a graduated set of sanctions in the Security Council, reinforced the image that China was going to remain engaged in the United Nations debate while continuing to express reservations about sanctions.
"The Chinese told us they have been making a variety of contacts," the Japanese spokesman said. "Mr. Qian Qichen told us that applying sanctions to North Korea would be ineffective judging from the fact that it has been already isolated and has little economic contacts with the rest of the world."
The spokesman also referred to China's "behind the curtains" role of carrying on a dialogue with the North Korean Government in Pyongyang. That dialogue came into sharper view last week as President Jiang Zemin was host in Beijing to the chief of staff of North Korea's Army, Choi Kwang. It was the highest-level visit by a North Korean since the nuclear crisis began more than a year ago.
Photographs of President Jiang greeting the North Korean military leader were prominently featured in Chinese newspapers.
"China deems it an unshakable policy to strengthen and develop the blood-bound friendship between the two countries," Mr. Jiang was quoted as saying by the official China Daily.

HEADLINE: A Haiti Invasion Wins Hemisphere Support

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 12

 BODY:
A majority of Western Hemisphere countries have quietly told United States officials that they are prepared to support military intervention in Haiti if sanctions fail to oust its military rulers, senior Administration officials say.
Although the leaders of several countries have publicly attacked the idea of intervention, United States diplomats have received quite a different message in private meetings over the last two weeks with officials from about 30 Caribbean and Latin American countries: most support intervention, although often with strings attached. 
 "A majority are willing to consider intervention if all else fails," a senior Administration official said. "There are some countries that are prepared to join a multilateral intervention force if sanctions don't bring these folks down."
The renewed emphasis on sanctions by the Administration, and its playing down of immediate intervention, are meant in part to show that Washington is intent on exhausting all diplomatic and economic means in hopes of lining up as much support as possible before any military action.
"This ratcheting up of the pressure is part of an effort to bring people along with you toward stronger measures," a senior Administration official said.
According to United States diplomats, several nations that just a few months ago attacked calls for intervention have warmed to the idea because the repression in Haiti has grown worse and Haiti's military leaders have shown only contempt for international pressures.
"A lot of countries are increasingly concerned about the implication of the coup leaders' being successful and how that might encourage coups elsewhere," a senior Administration official said. "They're wondering what does this mean for democracy in the hemisphere."
At a meeting of the Organization of American States in Brazil last week, foreign ministers from several countries made it clear to Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott and William H. Gray 3d, President Clinton's special adviser on Haiti, that they would support intervention now.
Others nations backed intervention but first wanted to try tougher sanctions for several months. Several others indicated that they would support an invasion, but only after receiving a mandate from the United Nations or the Organization of American States. Several said they were strongly opposed. More nations say they would back intervention than would contribute troops to an invading force.
In Congressional testimony on Wednesday, Mr. Gray said the Caribbean nations were the biggest supporters of force. Comparing the hemisphere to a large neighborhood, he suggested that Haiti was a burning house and that those who lived nearby, who see the repression up close and are being swamped by Haitian refugees, are the most eager for intervention.
Barbados, the Bahamas and Trinidad and Tobago have all strongly backed intervention, while officials from Jamaica say they will support it only if the United Nations or the Organization of American States first gives the green light.
"Those whose house is adjoined, next to Haiti, are very concerned and don't want to debate how many buckets of water will be thrown on the fire per minute," Mr. Gray said. "Those who are across the street have a different point of view."
Several officials at the Brazil meeting said Venezuela and Argentina also supported intervention. On the other hand, several of the hemisphere's heavyweights, most notably Mexico and Brazil, remain strongly opposed. That is why United States officials acknowledge that it might be harder to win approval for intervention from the 34-member Organization of American States, which works by consensus, than from the United Nations Security Council.
With the international community fed up with the intransigent and repressive Haitian regime, which ousted the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide as President in September 1991, United States officials voice confidence that they can persuade the Security Council's 14 other members to approve intervention.
In the view of Administration officials, some Latin American officials have denounced intervention mainly to play to their domestic audience. In a hemisphere where the image of Yanqui imperialism still lingers, many people have unhappy memories of Washington's sending in the Marines in the past to install leaders to its liking. But Administration officials say that if there is intervention, most of these Latin American officials will either keep silent or announce grudging support.
 
'Sense of Some Urgency'
 The Clinton Administration has often said it will not wait indefinitely for sanctions to work. Mr. Talbott and Mr. Gray refuse to give any deadline for sanctions, although they say the Administration will assess day to day how well the embargo is working.
"We do feel a sense of some urgency here, for the very simple reason that people are dying," Mr. Talbott told reporters last week.
According to ABC News, Dante Caputo of Argentina, the United Nations special envoy on Haiti, sent a memorandum to Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali saying Mr. Talbott had told him that Washington was considering a July 31 deadline for intervention. In an interview this weekend, Mr. Talbott denied that he had said any such thing or that there was any deadline. In addition, Mr. Caputo issued a statement denying that there was a deadline.
Some countries have eagerly and publicly backed President Clinton's suggestion that force should not be ruled out. At the Organization of American States meeting in Brazil, Peter Laurie, the Foreign Minister of Barbados, said his Government "will support whatever measures are necessary, including a lawful multilateral armed intervention."
Echoing the views of his own Government, Mr. Caputo, a former Argentine Foreign Minister, delivered an equally tough message. "There is still room for a final diplomatic and political effort," he said, "but the message has got to be, 'This is your last opportunity.' "
Describing the results of recent talks about the crisis over Haiti, a senior Administration official said: "Some nations want the force to be multilateral. Some first want a mandate from the U.N. All want to make every diplomatic effort. They say, 'If you do all possible sanctions and it doesn't work, you either have to walk away or take stronger action,' and they don't want to walk away."
 
Sanctions Are Tightened
 Administration officials say they have not approached other nations to contribute troops to a multi-nation invasion force. They have, however, asked other nations to contribute soldiers and civilians to a United Nations task force of more than 3,000 to retrain Haiti's military and police and maintain order if the military cedes power.
On Friday, President Clinton tightened sanctions by barring commercial flights and financial transactions between Haiti and the United States, three weeks after the United Nations stepped up the embargo to exempt only food and medicine.
United States officials say their preferred solution is for the United States Ambassador in Haiti to receive a phone call soon from Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, the head of the army, Col. Joseph Michel Francois, the Port-au-Prince police chief, and Gen. Philipe Biamby, the army Chief of Staff, saying they are ready to cede power and flee to another country.

HEADLINE: Lillehammer Journal;
Snug Future Sought in the Snows of Yesteryear

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LILLEHAMMER, Norway

 BODY:
The only snow is on the highest mountain plateaus, far above the pitched roofs and pastel houses of Lillehammer, the site of the 1994 Winter Olympics. But all through the town and the greening countryside, the glow of the Games still lingers like the long northern twilight.
At City Hall, clerks have been keeping the world's love letters to Lillehammer on public display, neatly arranged in loose-leaf binders. A note from Charlotte, N.C., asks for an autographed picture of Audun Tron, the town's Mayor. A letter from a Minnesota woman says she is determined to visit Norway. 
 "What a great host country," she wrote. "You cheer for everyone!"
By nearly any measure, the Games were a boon to Lillehammer. Not only did the town win rave reviews for its cheerful and seamless handling of the Olympics, but it has also inherited, debt free, millions of dollars worth of new roads, sewers and sports arenas, which were built for the Games by the Norwegian Government.
Still, for all the good vibrations and shiny new installations, the more enduring challenge facing Lillehammer's civic boosters still lies ahead: what does this dozy sub-Arctic town of just 23,000 people do now to keep the tourists coming to this remote corner of Norway?
"The rest of 1994 and 1995 should be very good, but we need to think beyond that," said Steinar Soerlie, the city manager. "We must convert what we accomplished during the Games into real commercial possibilities."
For now, Lillehammer is getting back to normal. On the edge of town, convoys of flatbed trucks are still hauling away the hundreds of modular buildings erected as temporary housing for the Games.
There have been a few sour notes. In May, for example, a handful of business people filed for bankruptcy after their investments in land deals and tourist camps tied to the Olympics did not work out.
Like other Olympic hopefuls, Lillehammer embarked on its quest to land the Games nearly a decade ago because it saw them as a way to spur the economy of Norway's sleepy central mountain region, a scenic but remote area fewer than 400 miles south of the Arctic Circle.
"The preparation and the Games themselves have jumped this city forward 30 or 40 years in just one decade," said Petter Ronnigen, a local banker who was the deputy director of the Lillehammer Olympic Organizing Committee.
Almost overnight, the town acquired a new community college campus, built around what used to be the Olympic press center. Its telecommunications grid is the most sophisticated in Norway. And the area has some 14,500 hotel beds, 75 percent more than just five years ago.
Lillehammer, along with the nearby towns of Hamar and Gjovik, is now home to four world-class indoor sports arenas, which can seat more than 33,000.
Olav R. Spilling, a research fellow with the Eastern Norway Research Institute, said one of the biggest problems would be sustaining the kind of tourism to keep Lillehammer's new hotels and arenas in the black.
According to a study supervised by Mr. Spilling, the main Olympic installations, because of operating costs, will lose money for the foreseeable future. Hakon Hall, for example, the 10,000-seat arena used for ice hockey during the Games, has just one public event on its schedule: the Norwegian national scholastic table tennis tournament.
Still, Lillehammer has been spared the financial burdens that have crippled other Olympic towns. For one thing, Lillehammer and other towns in the region that played host to Olympic events will be able to dip into a special $62 million Olympics fund -- twice as large as projected because of the success of the Games -- to help cover the cost of operating the new sports arenas.
Over the next year, tourism revenues should be strong. Two big conventions, including a Baptist conference, have already booked into Lillehammer. The city is planning a winter cultural festival for next February, and a full schedule of skiing, bobsledding and skating competitions is booked for the coming winter.
The ski jumps have a special porcelain finish so they can be used by competitors and instructors year-round. The town plans to buy wheeled carts that visitors will pay to steer, slalom-style, down the steep face of the hill used for free-style skiing.
North of town, on the bobsled and luge course, tourists are already paying the equivalent of $14 apiece to ride wheeled bobsleds down the winding course. Strapped into helmets, they crouch three at a time behind a Norwegian driver as he steers down the steep valley at nearly 65 miles an hour.
"It rained all day yesterday, and we still had 50 people who wanted to go down the mountain," said a smiling Berndt Harjo, who helps guide the tourists into the bobsleds for the two-minute dizzying ride. "They saw Norway on television, and don't want to miss a thing."
Mr. Soerlie, the city manager, is upbeat about the future. "For five years, it is all you plan for, and then all of a sudden the Olympics are over," he said. Are people depressed? "No," he said. "For the man in the street, for me, I think the Olympics were like a good dessert. We had it, and it is a very nice memory."

Viacom has stepped up efforts to sell the New York Rangers and the New York Knicks even as the teams press for league championships. Detailed financial information about the properties was mailed last week to a small group of potential bidders. [Page A1.] 
 Macy executives met with officials of Federated Department Stores to consider for the first time Federated's merger proposal. Macy had previously refused to even consider a merger. [D1.]
In a sign of how Wall Street is bracing for leaner times, Merrill Lynch will no longer provide lunch to its traders. The end of the free lunch, once a traditional Wall Street perquisite, comes at a time when Merrill Lynch has been posting strong profit gains. [D1.]
 
International
 Colombia, Mexico and Venezuela will sign a pact to create a duty-free trade zone of 150 million people. South American business leaders and United States exporters hope the alliance will provide momentum for the eventual creation of a Latin American free trade zone stretching from Mexico to Argentina. [D1.]
Italy's fashion industry is in the midst of a transformation as it adjusts to slower growth and cheaper foreign competition. Though some big names have stumbled in recent years, the industry has proved resilient, a result of an essentially family-owned structure in which more than 68 percent of the workers are employed by companies with fewer than 10 people. [D1.]
Estonia has proven an economic success story following the breakup of the Soviet Union, but its coalition Government is now torn by dissension, jealousy and some hints of corruption. [A8.]

 Congressional Democrats have become wary of upsetting financial markets and regulating interest rates. The degree of this caution was shown last week at a hearing of the House Banking subcommittee on consumer credit. Although Democrats criticized the Federal Reserve and commercial banks, no lawmaker suggested that the solutions might involve legislation. [D1.]

The fall television season already looks bleak: advertising executives predict that not a single new series will be a hit. The agencies attribute their forecasts to highly competitive prime-time schedules as well as a programming shift toward dramas. [D7.]

HEADLINE: President Would Not Limit Welfare Plan's Public Jobs

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 12

 BODY:
President Clinton has resolved a central question about his welfare plan by deciding to let recipients placed in government work programs remain there indefinitely, as long as they are genuinely seeking private jobs, officials said.
The decision places the Administration at odds with Congressional proposals sponsored by both Democrats and Republicans. Those plans would let states end all assistance, both cash payments and subsidized jobs, to welfare recipients whether they could find private work or not. 
 "People who play by the rules can keep working," Bruce Reed, a White House aide, said today in a telephone interview. But he added, "One of the rules is that if there are jobs available, you have to go out and get one."
Mr. Clinton's decision ends months of sharp debate among his aides over an issue that cuts to the welfare program's philosophical core. The aides asked Mr. Clinton to resolve the issue last month, sending him a memorandum warning that "this issue is a crucial one for the left."
Mr. Clinton's aides say that in offering extended eligibility for work programs, the President is trying to protect people who simply cannot find private jobs, despite their best efforts. The memorandum warned that denying such people cash and subsidized work could force children into "homelessness or foster care."
 
Criticism is Likely
 Congressional critics might argue that indefinite eligibility would lead to a large and costly work program that would violate Mr. Clinton's pledge to "end welfare as we know it." The memorandum, while not advocating a position, warned Mr. Clinton to expect such a charge.
It said that even some Democratic allies might say "the rhetoric of 'ending welfare' requires some sort of ultimate end" and that he might be accused of creating "a large guaranteed-for-life job creation program."
Mr. Clinton is expected to announce his welfare plan as early as Tuesday. His plan would expand the amount of training available to welfare recipients during their first two years of aid but would require those still on the rolls to join the work program.
Mr. Clinton's welfare pledges were a crucial aspect of his claim during the 1992 campaign to be a "New Democrat." But he has slowed the welfare bill to keep it from conflicting with his health care proposal, which must travel through the same Congressional committees. With time running out, few people expect the welfare bill to pass this year.
Unlike Mr. Clinton's bill, a proposal by 163 House Republicans would let states drop poor people from a work program after they had been in it for three years. A bill co-sponsored by 29 Democrats would go further, requiring the cutoff for participants but letting states re-admit 10 percent of those dropped.
It is unclear how many of the five million families on welfare would be unable to move to support from private employment. Administration officials have argued that the number will be very small, but estimates from outside economists have ranged from 300,000 to 800,000 families.
In today's interview, Mr. Reed said Mr. Clinton was keeping his pledge to end welfare "by requiring people to go to work."
Mr. Reed took pains to argue that the Administration's plan would avoid a large Government jobs program by continuously pushing people into the private sector.
Recipients would be required to search for private jobs before they would be placed in the work program, he said, and the subsidized positions would last only one year. Participants would then have to go through another period of searching for a private job before they could re-enroll in the work program.
Those who turned down a private job offer without a good reason would be dropped from the rolls for six months, receiving neither cash nor a subsidized job. That penalty would be much stiffer than the ones in current law, which reduce, but do not eliminate, the grants to welfare recipients who break rules.
The President's plan would also give people an economic incentive to find private work, Mr. Reed said. People with private jobs could receive up to $3,300 a year in refundable tax credits, which they could not get while working in the Government program at the minimum wage.
If recipients received two work assignments without finding private employment, states would be able to enroll them in an "intensive job-search program," Mr. Reed said. That would require poor people to demonstrate that they were going to interviews and making efforts to find private work.
Mr. Reed said that those who were not making a good-faith effort would then lose assistance for six months. After that time, they could re-apply to the work program.
Advocates for the poor had lobbied hard for extended work-program eligibility, and they praised Mr. Clinton's decision.

HEADLINE: Washington Memo;
It's Still the Economy, but It's Not Helping Clinton

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 10

 BODY:
The good news for Bill Clinton is that the economy, the issue that defined his Presidential campaign, is bouncing back. The bad news is that it is not doing him much good.
While Americans give the President reasonably good marks for his handling of pocketbook issues, and increasingly believe that the national economy is improving, there has been no corresponding increase in their enthusiasm for Mr. Clinton himself. 
 "Clinton is not getting the mileage and bounce out of the basic state of the economy," said Fred Greenstein, an authority on the Presidency at Princeton University. "And the fact that he's not getting credit reduces his political clout."
Throughout most of his Presidency, Mr. Clinton's approval ratings in opinion polls have stagnated, at about 50 percent or less, even though the proportion of people who rate the national economy as performing relatively well has risen substantially, to roughly 50 percent from about 30 percent in early 1993.
The inability of Mr. Clinton to ride the economy's coattails is confounding his political advisers. Even if the economy grows stronger in the coming months, the advisers fear that Democrats who face re-election in November may not benefit as they should -- and Mr. Clinton may not be in a position to help them.
But their trepidation is more about 1996. If the economy is soaring, or even coasting comfortably, in the spring and summer of 1996, Mr. Clinton wants to reap the rewards, as have past Presidents. Many experts on President Richard M. Nixon contend, for example, that despite his momentous trip to China and other accomplishments, a turnabout in the economy did as much to assure his re-election in 1972. In 1984, President Ronald Reagan also benefited from a sharp recovery.
Though it is still early, some Presidential advisers worry that Mr. Clinton's failure to gain popularity in recent months may be a sign that he would need an even healthier economy than past Presidents if he is to be re-elected.
 
A Curse of Incumbency
 As evidence of their nervousness, White House aides are already seeking advice from academics on the "political business cycle" -- theories that there is a close connection between the economy and electoral prospects.
In his new book, "The Agenda" (Simon & Schuster), Bob Woodward depicts a White House that is obsessed with the ups and downs in the bond market. The President's senior adviser, George Stephanopoulos, found himself with the unexpected duties of tracking the bond market "like some Wall Street wizard," according to the book.
But for all their concerns that Mr. Clinton is not getting the proper credit, his advisers neglect one curse of incumbency: bad times damage the President and his party more than good times help them.
Were the economy in a slump, the President would surely be in far worse political shape than he is today.
"If this was a bad economy, I think we'd see Clinton's popularity ratings in the 30's," said Allan J. Lichtman, a professor of history at the American University. "Should the economy turn downward, the President would have far greater difficulty than he's experiencing at the present time."
Mr. Clinton and his advisers know only too well the power of the economy as a political issue. They exploited it relentlessly to defeat President George Bush in 1992, and they view it as a ticket to re-election.
But the strong economy has, in effect, given the public time to worry more about other issues, like crime.
Asked to explain why the economic news has not helped Mr. Clinton more, David Wilhelm, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, shakes his head and offers one word: "Whitewater." He said that inquiry into the Clintons' real-estate investments and other problems -- while not in themselves major public concerns -- have distracted attention from Mr. Clinton's accomplishments.
His counterpart in the Republican Party, Haley Barbour, puts forth another theory. People, he said, "don't think the economy is improving because of what Clinton's done but despite what Clinton's done."
Both men are right -- to a point. The emergence of voter concerns about Mr. Clinton's character and his floundering in foreign policy make it even more difficult for the Administration to focus attention on positive economic news.
And some analysts do argue that people are so uncomfortable with Mr. Clinton that they are hesitant to attribute any economic successes to him. For a President who drew only 43 percent of the popular vote, this could be lethal.
Moreover, many Americans remain untouched by the overall economic improvements. Higher productivity statistics, for instance, have not translated into higher wages for everyone.
A nationwide poll by the Gallup organization for CNN and USA Today, conducted May 20-22, found that 56 percent of Americans believed that Mr. Clinton's economic policies were not having much effect on the economy, 16 percent said they were hurting the economy, and 24 percent said they were helping the economy. The survey of 1,005 adults nationwide had a margin of error of plus or minus three percentage points.
"Typically, this kind of brightening economy would have had more of an impact on the average American than it has had so far," said Mr. Lichtman, who has examined the links between Presidents and the economy. "The fact that Clinton is not getting as popular as you might expect a President to be in his kind of economy is due to his other problems -- and to the fact that people are still cautious about the economy."
Paul Begala, a Clinton political adviser, said: "There is something deeply ironic about Clintonomics that I don't think anyone has noticed. The benefits from Reaganomics flowed directly from the Government. The benefits of Clintonomics flow from the private sector. I refinanced my house, but I didn't go to a Government agency to do that."
Missing from the debate is the notion advanced by some economists that as Presidents come and go, they often find that controlling the economy is beyond their reach.
In what has been their refrain for months, Mr. Begala and other Presidential advisers said that Mr. Clinton and the Democrats needed to communicate the economic gains better, particularly before this year's midterm elections.
"Here we've got three million new jobs, we've cut the deficit, but I don't think we talk about it enough," Mr. Wilhelm said. "If we can't go out and make the case, well, shame on us."

HEADLINE: In Latin America, a Free Trade Rush

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 12

 BODY:
Creating a huge building block for a Western Hemisphere free trade zone, the presidents of Colombia, Mexico, and Venezuela will meet in Colombia on Monday to place their nations' 150 million people under a duty-free umbrella.
"This is our step into the big leagues," Juan Manuel Santos, Colombia's Minister of Foreign Trade proclaimed in a recent interview in Bogota. "This is a step toward the U.S. market." 
 Many South American business people complain that the Clinton Administration has been slow to expand the North American Free Trade Association, which links Canada, the United States and Mexico. They hope this new trade group, whose three nations have a total of $400 billion in economic activity, will provide momentum for the eventual creation of a Latin American free trade zone stretching from Mexico to Argentina.
Even as the ink dries on the accord, Ecuador will ask to join, and it is likely to be accepted.
For exporters in the United States, the Latin excitement over free trade is good news.
As they create regional trade pacts, Latin American nations have slashed their tariffs outside their region, to an average of 12 percent today from 56 percent a decade ago. As a result, United States exports to Latin America have doubled in the last seven years, reaching $80 billion last year.
"American exports to Colombia have gone up 80 percent" since Colombia opened its borders three years ago, a United States diplomat said. "During the same time, Colombia's exports to the United States have gone up 7 percent."
Further fueling demand for United States goods -- from Jeep Grand Cherokees to jars of peanut butter -- Latin America's economy is expected to grow by 3 percent this year. This expansion is taking place despite political uncertainty surrounding presidential elections later this year in the region's two most populous nations, Brazil and Mexico.
Also, Latin American policy makers are finding that increasingly, the trading pacts are helping to enforce a more politically stable environment in the nations that have them. The pacts, which are predicated on orthodox free market rules -- free exchange rates, free prices, and free access to investment -- are smoothing the policy zigzags that have plagued Latin nations for decades.
"We are discovering that free trade agreements are not just about free trade," said Moises Naim, a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment and former Venezuelan Minister of Industry. "Trade agreements lower the risk of sudden policy changes. It now takes more than a stroke of a pen by a new government to undo what a preceding government has done."
Trade among Latin America's 11 largest economies has increased by 50 percent since 1991, reaching $23.5 billion last year.
In a trade revolution with subtle political consequences, country after country in Latin America is discovering that, after the United States, its most important trading partners are its neighbors.
Trade between Colombia and Venezuela, for example, more than doubled after a customs union took effect in 1992, dropping tariffs to zero.
 
A Trip to Caracas
 Reflecting a new political integration between two countries that nearly went to war in 1987, Colombia's President, Cesar Gaviria Trujillo, and his entire Cabinet flew to Caracas last month for two days of talks with Venezuela's President, Rafael Caldera, and his Cabinet.
On Colombia's southern border, another free trade pact led to a near-doubling of trade between Colombia and Ecuador last year.
Brazil's trade with Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay has more than tripled since the four countries formed an embryo common market, Mercosul, in 1991.
Throughout Latin America, companies increasingly plan investments in regional terms. Citroen said recently it would set up operations in Uruguay to assemble cars for the Mercosul market. The Eastman Kodak Company has set up a tariff-free shipping depot outside Sao Paulo to distribute $80 million of film and cameras throughout Mercosul.
"For us, Colombia is like another part of our domestic market," said Pedro Vallenilla, president of Venepal, a Venezuelan paper manufacturer. "When we sell to Colombia, we don't even feel as if we are exporting. We are the same market."
With intra-Latin trade the fastest growing trade relationship in the region, new steps are taken daily to abolish centuries-old barriers. By the end of the 1990's, economists predict, most trade within Latin America will be duty-free.
Last week, Chile became the first nation to respond to a Brazilian proposal to expand Mercosul into a continental free trade zone.
"Our project is to establish a South American Free Trade Area that would unite, in a common market, the countries that make up Mercosul, the Andean Group, the Amazon Initiative, and, finally, Chile," President Itamar Franco of Brazil proposed last week at a regional meeting of Latin foreign ministers.
 
Expanded Customs Union
 In response, Chile proposed joining a duty-free customs union with Mercosul nations on Jan. 1. Chile would retain the right to set its own external tariffs. Next year, Brazil hopes to expand this kind of customs union across South America, signing Mercosul free trade agreements with the seven other nations of South America.
In a major step toward regional integration, the five nations of the Andean Pact -- Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru and Venezuela -- agreed last month to create the Andean Free Trade Zone on Jan. 1, with duty-free trade.
Mexico, whose trade with other Latin American nations has doubled in the last five years, has also started looking south. Today's agreement with Colombia and Venezuela comes as trade between Mexico and Venezuela has tripled since 1989.
Last April, Mexico signed a free trade treaty with Costa Rica. Next month, Mexico is to start negotiating a treaty with El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras.
As the momentum for free trade builds, leftist opposition has largely shriveled. Last month, for example, Luis Inacio Lula da Silva, a socialist and a front-runner in Brazil's presidential race, endorsed Mercosul. In Colombia, Ernesto Samper Pizano, the center-left candidate in presidential elections set for Sunday, said recently: "The opening is an irreversible fact. I would like to see Colombia enter Nafta."
Indeed, in the region, Colombia has emerged as the most energetic proponent of free trade. Three years ago, when President Gaviria created a Foreign Trade Ministry, Colombia had no free trade pacts. By August, when Mr. Gaviria's term expires, he expects to have signed such pacts with 22 nations.
On Friday, Colombia and the 13 nations that are members of the Caribbean Community agreed to sign a free trade treaty.
"No other Latin American country has duty-free access to so many countries," Mr. Santos, Colombia's Trade Minister, said. "We slashed tariffs in a planned, deliberate strategy to make our economy more competitive."
Reflecting a new emphasis on trade in United States-Colombia relations, Myles R. Frechette, a career diplomat with trade promotion experience, is to arrive here in July to serve as the United States Ambassador to Colombia. He succeeds Morris D. Busby, a career diplomat with experience in counterterrorism.
In August, Mr. Gaviria is to become Secretary General of the Organization of American States, a post the Colombian plans to use as a pulpit for reinvigorating the vision of a hemispheric free trade region stretching from Alaska to Argentina promoted by President George Bush.
But many Latin leaders sense that United States interest has cooled in expanding the North American Free Trade Agreement. That view has some proponents in the United States, as well.
"The Administration has to send a message that we want a free trade agreement with Chile," Jerry Haar, a senior research associate at the University of Miami's North-South Center, said. "If nothing is done, it sends a really bad sign to Latin America about our belief in free trade."
In Washington, White House attention is concentrated on winning Congressional approval by August for the complex trade agreements of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the world organization that oversees trade.
"The Clinton Administration favors the extension of free trade throughout the hemisphere," Jeffrey E. Garten, the United States Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, said last week. "It's important that regional agreements create more trade and do not create pacts that are inward-looking and that create more barriers."
To demonstrate United States interest in South America's markets, Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown is to conduct a one-week trip through Argentina, Brazil and Chile at the end of June. Though the United States has traditionally accounted for half of Latin America's foreign trade, Mr. Brown may find interlopers poaching on what American exporters have long considered their turf.
Encouraged by a 33 percent jump in European exports to Latin America in the last two years, European Union officials traveled to Sao Paulo a few weeks ago to conduct preliminary talks about granting preferential tariff treatment to Mercosur.
In the last three months, Colombia joined two Pacific Basin councils, and Ecuador's President, Sixto Duran Ballen, led a 180-member business mission to Japan.
"This is a fundamental step in our policy of diversifying away from the Paris-London-New York axis and bringing ourselves closer to the world's most dynamic region," Mr. Santos of Colombia said last month after his country joined the Pacific Basin Economic Council, a business group. "Colombia's Atlantic trade is 15 times its Pacific trade."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

LUBAVITCH GRAND RABBI DIES
Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneerson, whose charismatic leadership built the Lubavitch Hasidic movement into an enormously powerful and sometimes divisive force among the world's Jews, died at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 92. Within hours of his death, thousands of his followers began gathering on the streets around Lubavitch World Headquarters in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, to mourn a teacher and scholar that most of them had hoped would reveal himself to be the Messiah before he died. Many took hastily arranged charter flights from Israel, Europe and elsewhere around the world. A1. 
 Rabbi Schneerson was a Russian-born, Sorbonne-educated scholar who took an insular Hasidic group that almost ended in the Holocaust and turned it into one of the most influential and controversial forces in world Jewry. B2.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
A MOTHER DIES SAVING HER SON
As a livery cab driven by a drunken motorist sped toward them, a homeless woman walking across a Queens street pushed her 4-year-old son out of the way, only to be struck herself by the car, the police said. The woman, Castelli Ellison, 38, whom the police said had lived at a shelter for homeless families near Kennedy International Airport, died later of internal injuries at Mary Immaculate Hospital. When the police arrived, they found her son, Germar Ellison, weeping over his mother's mangled body. B3.
 
CHANGE PROPOSED FOR INQUIRIES CHIEF
Public Advocate Mark J. Green, suggesting that Mayor Giuliani had given the appearance of using the Department of Investigation for political purposes, proposed legislation that would give the Commissioner of Investigation more independence from the Mayor. A spokeswoman for the Mayor said he had not seen the proposal but that he was focusing now on getting a city budget completed. B3.
 
FOUNDATION TAKES ON A CORPORATION
They are curiously matched adversaries. One is Intel Corporation, which is building the world's largest computer-chip plant, at Rio Rancho, N.M. The other is the Jessie Smith Noyes Foundation, a small family philanthropy based in Manhattan, which owns 3,000 share of Intel stock and is challenging Intel's projections of the benefits the plant will bring. In doing so, the foundation is pioneering an aggressive approach by foundations to corporate policies. B3.

EFFECTS OF CUTS IN TAXES DEBATED
Although the business tax cuts signed into law by Governor Cuomo have been promoted as an important stimulus to the state's slowly improving economy, many economists and fiscal analysts are skeptical that the cuts will generate significant job growth. B5.
 
NO MOVES TO INTERVENE IN RAIL TALKS
Even though there has been little progress in talks to avert a strike by Long Island Rail Road workers, lawmakers said they would hesitate to intervene before any walkout for fear of upsetting the negotiations. The last walkout by Long Island Rail Road workers, in 1987, ended after 11 days when Congress imposed a 60-day cooling-off period during which agreements were reached. B5.
 
TRACK PLAN DRAWS OPPOSITION
Railroad tracks already cut through the leafy, affluent community of Bronxville, in Westchester County, and many residents depend on the trains to get to work in Manhattan every day. But a plan to add a third track to the Harlem line of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad here has upset residents, who see it as a threat to the beauty of the village and the the serenity of their homes. B5.
 
PROBLEM IN PARADISE: FORE!
William M. Becker, a sculptor and former golfer, said he always had considered golf "a more or less gentle pursuit" with an etiquette that set it apart from rougher sports. He can recall a time when golfers in country settings took pains not to hit the cows grazing in nearby fields. Now, Mr. Becker, who lives next to the sixth hole of the Ridgeway Country Club in White Plains, would like the same consideration. B4.

HEADLINE: Italy's Fashion Industry Turned on Its Head, Again

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MILAN, Italy, June 8

 BODY:
Italy's fanciful designers and apparel makers, the Medicis and the Borgias of contemporary taste, are approaching the fashion business as if almost everything they did right in the 1980's has to be done differently today.
"There's an epochal change going on now, and the climate of the 90's is making people reflect," said Santo Versace, the 49-year-old chief financial officer of Gianni Versace S.R.L. "After 15 years of continuous growth, they're no longer leaping like grasshoppers, but crawling cautiously like ants." 
 In the 1980's, designer labels with names like Armani, Versace and Valentino were often enough to sell their fashions at any price, most often to the affluent nations of Western Europe and the United States. Designer-driven trends fueled the market for clothing made in Italy, and big buyers came twice yearly to the ready-to-wear shows of the principal designers.
 
Expectations Are Higher
 Now the markets are spread farther afield to Japan, India, Russia and China. And customers everywhere are expecting to find quality clothing at competitive prices.
Although Italy's textile business has been around for hundreds of years, its designer fashion and apparel industry is a relative newcomer.
With the exception of a few large groups like GFT, Ermenegildo Zegna, and Marzotto, the industry consists of thousands of small companies, often just tailors and seamstresses, grouped in pyramid fashion beneath the large manufacturers, which turn to the smaller companies as needed, thus reducing costs and providing flexibility.
In the 1960's and 1970's, labels based in Paris like those of Emanuel Ungaro or Christian Dior drifted to Italian clothing manufacturers. Italian labor costs were low, and the industry boasted pockets of quality manufacturing like the silk makers clustered around Como or the wool manufacturers of Biella, in Piedmont.
With the industry's growth, local talent emerged, like Gianni Versace, who learned to design clothes by watching his mother, Franca, at work in her seamstress shop in his native Reggio Calabria. Some designers like Mr. Versace, Giorgio Armani and Laura Biagiotti, became industrialists.
And during the 1980's, they and Gianfranco Ferre and Romeo Gigli became the arbiters of international elegance. Their spectacular designs, and equally spectacular personalities, challenged French dominance, and set Milan, with its semiannual fashion displays and elegant showrooms, alongside Paris and New York as meccas of design.
 
Paying Italy's Bills

Their success also made the apparel industry a pillar of Italy's export economy. Last year, the textile and apparel industry had a trade surplus of $18 billion, roughly equal to the country's deficit in food and energy sources like oil.
"You can see, we're paying Italy's food and energy bill," said Vittorio Giulini, 53, owner of Liola, a prominent knitwear manufacturer, and president of Milan's clothing fair association.
After so many profitable years, the Italian fashion industry has found that defining itself has become more complicated than it used to be. Executives like Santo Versace, the bookkeeping brain behind Gianni Versace's creative genius, can talk easily about opening a store this year in Moscow or looking hard at potential new markets in South Korea and Indonesia, expanding new products like jeans, or providing fresh products year-round instead of just for the seasonal trade fairs in late September and February.
"As long as I've known the industry, it's been in a state of permanent change," Mr. Versace said. "Every six years or so it reinvents itself with extraordinary speed, to preserve what is after all a very mature industry."
 
A Year of Setbacks
 If there were doubts about the health of the Italian fashion industry, they arose last year when several large participants stumbled badly.
The first was Benetton, the clothing group that in the 1980's became a household word like McDonald's. Though Benetton remains profitable, the company found its products were too expensive to compete against cheaper competitors in the United States. Benetton has 150 stores in the United States, down from 800 in 1988.
Then Mr. Armani suffered a setback. After reporting a substantial loss, Simint S.p.A., a designer clothing group controlled by the Armani family, announced recently that it had sold Armani A/X, its American retail chain, to a retailer in Singapore for $13 million to raise cash as part of reorganization.
The worst trouble hit Gruppo Finanziario Tessile S.p.A., known as GFT, which is based in Turin and run by the innovative Rivetti family. The company almost single-handedly brought the craze for Italian designer fashions to the United States, where its sales grew to $304 million in 1989, from $7 million in 1980, with licensed designer names like Armani and Valentino.
By 1993, the growth had stopped and GFT was saddled with $250 million of debt. Creditors led by Mediobanca, an investment bank, took over the company, reducing the role of the Rivetti family.
What has provided the industry's resilience has been an essentially family-owned structure in which today more than 68 percent of the workers are employed by companies with fewer than 10 people. Only two sizable companies, Benetton and Simint, are publicly traded. A third, Versace, plans to go public.
Clemente Signoroni, a former finance specialist with Fiat S.p.A. whom the banks installed last year as chief executive of GFT, described how the system worked. "If our designers want lace this year, we go to our lace specialists," he said. "If next year's trend is silk, we go to the silk people."
But with the market saturated with designer fashions, a designer name no longer suffices to sell clothing. "Paradoxically, the very success of designer fashions in the 1980's means that consumers have become more educated and more discerning about fashion," said Robert Howard, a consultant and former editor of the Harvard Business Review who has studied GFT.
Customers still want quality, but at competitive prices. As a result, large-volume Italian manufacturers are following the lead of American companies like Donna Karan that pioneered so-called bridge lines, which are designer labels for less money.
This has transformed the old seasonal cycles into an almost steady flow of styles from the large fashion centers. In Milan, the big semiannual trade fairs now stand alongside the showrooms of designers and manufacturers like Krizia and Moschino that offer new styles at almost any time of the year.
With trade barriers falling, Italian manufacturers are facing cheaper competition from countries like India and China. Alfredo Ciampini, the secretary general of the Confederation of Textile and Apparel Manufacturers, said lower tariffs would open Italy to cheap imports during the next 10 years. He said he was not totally pessimistic as long as developing countries agreed to buy Italian clothing.
"I will import 1,000 cotton shirts from India at a dollar apiece," Mr. Ciampini said, "if I can export one Armani suit for $1,000."
 
Reality Check
 Prominent among those adjusting to the new realities is Carlo Rivetti.
Last year, Mr. Rivetti and his sister, Cristina, sold their stake in GFT, at which their cousin, Marco Rivetti, remains president, and acquired C.P. Company, a subsidiary that specializes in designer sportswear. Last year, he said, C.P. did $50 million in business.
Working out of a refurbished 18th-century palazzo on Milan's Via Bramante, Mr. Rivetti, a vigorous 38-year-old with red hair and a beard, borrowed a concept pioneered by Benetton of taking neutral-hued jackets or sweaters manufactured at low-wage sites in places like Albania and Tunisia, and increasingly in Italy, and using complex dyeing processes to reproduce designer models at an Italian factory.
"You know, you can go to sea in a huge tanker, but to turn a tanker around you need about two and a half kilometers," Mr. Rivetti said, reflecting on the experiences of the last several years. "Now, I prefer a small sailing boat, with just my crew, and the smell of the wind."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Many stars of Italian design are finding they must sell at competitive prices and in more countries to remain successful. But the eye for detail is largely unchanged. At Gianni Versace S.R.L., cloth is draped over a mannequin, top; beads are attached to a garment, bottom left, and visions are put to paper. (Maki Galimberti/Daylight for The New York Times)
