HEADLINE: Wife and Lover Held in Murder Of Executive

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER 

 BODY:
It was not, the authorities said, a conventional suburban marriage and it ended in murder.
He was a wealthy 54-year-old senior vice president for merchandising at the Grand Union supermarket chain. She was a 23-year-old former topless dancer with a history of arrests in petty crimes. Brooke D. Lennon and his wife, Michelle, shared what the authorities said was was a craving for liquor and their relationship was so fractious they spent much of their one year of marriage living apart, he in a condominium in Edgewater, N.J., and she in a tumbledown bungalow in Monsey, N.Y., rented by her lover. 
 "He knew whom he was marrying and tolerated more than the typical suburban husband," said Kenneth Gribetz, the Rockland County District Attorney. "They were separately together."
Early Friday morning, in the Monsey bungalow, the relationship turned deadly. Mr. Lennon, the authorities said, was beaten over the head with a baseball bat and strangled with a telephone cord. His body was placed in the trunk of his company-leased Lincoln Continental Mark VIII and, after the car mired in a muddy path two miles away, the body was dumped in nearby woods.
Mrs. Lennon and Robert Tomassi, a 25-year-old unemployed motorcycle repairman whom the authorities described as her lover, were arrested Sunday evening and charged with his murder.
So unorthodox was the Lennons' marriage that the authorities said Mr. Lennon spent the last night of his life drinking with his wife and Mr. Tomassi in Mr. Tomassi's bungalow. Mrs. Lennon and Mr. Tomassi smoked crack as well, Mr. Gribetz said. Mr. Lennon, Mr. Gribetz said, had even told Grand Union officials that he was planning to move some belongings to the Monsey bungalow.
Mr. Gribetz said the murder had been planned and one likely motive was Mr. Lennon's $2 million life insurance policy and $280,000 bank account. He said Mr. Tomassi and Mrs. Lennon have made statements to the Ramapo town police, but he declined to classify them as confessions.
Neither Mrs. Lennon nor Mr. Tomassi have been assigned court-appointed lawyers.
Mr. Lennon, a stocky man with brownish hair, was described as an industry authority on how products should be displayed on supermarket shelves. Starting as a buyer in 1966, he worked his way up the hierarchy of Grand Union, which is headquartered in Wayne, N.J., and has 254 stores in seven northeastern states. He became a vice president last year.
 
Dancing at the Bar
 Mr. Lennon was born in Providence, R.I., and was a business graduate of the University of Rhode Island. He was married at least once before and had no children, Mr. Gribetz said. He met the former Michelle Fintzy, a longtime Rockland resident, while she was working as a dancer.
As husband and wife, the Lennons enjoyed dancing and drinking at Billy B's, a bar near their Edgewater condominium. Dick Reynolds, a patron and friend of Mr. Lennon's, said some evenings Mr. Lennon would put $20 in the jukebox and dance the evening away with Mrs. Lennon.
"We called him Fred Astaire," said Mr. Reynolds. "They were so lovey-dovey you'd never know anything was wrong."
But as time passed it became obvious to some at Billy B's that the marriage had its tempestuous side.
"Michelle was like a homing pigeon," said Mr. Reynolds. "They'd break up, get back together again, she'd leave again. One time she brought a boyfriend down to this bar."
Two months ago, neighbors said, she moved in with Mr. Tomassi, a Californian who graduated from Spring Valley High School and was known for the tattoos on his body, including the Harley-Davidson logo.
 
'It's Such a Dump'
 Timothy M. Smith, a Monsey neighbor, said he frequently heard the roar of motorcycles on the dead-end road leading to the bungalow. To his surprise, he also noticed Mr. Lennon at the bungalow many times.
"We all wondered what a guy with that stature was doing over here," he said. "It's such a dump."
Mr. Gribetz said that Mr. Lennon went to the bungalow Thursday night and, lounging shoeless and in black sweat pants, spent the night drinking with his wife and Mr. Tomassi, passing out around 2 A.M. Friday. It was then, Mr. Gribetz said, that Mrs. Lennon bludgeoned her husband with a bat and Mr. Tomassi stomped on his head.
The pair, he said, pulled three plastic bags around Mr. Lennon's head to stanch the blood and then tied a telephone cord around Mr. Lennon's neck. They drove with the body to Brick Church Road in the village of New Hempstead and turned down a dirt path leading to an unfinished home development. The car became mired in the mud and they had to abandon it and dump Mr. Lennon's body about 30 feet from the path.
The two started hiking home, Mr. Gribetz said, then hailed a passing taxi and returned to the bungalow to clean up evidence, burning the blood-soaked sofa cushions. The car was discovered Friday evening by children on their way to synagogue. They alerted nearby residents.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury-Issue Prices Hit by Selling Pressure

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities came under selling pressure yesterday as the dollar dropped in currency markets.
The bond market was also buffetted by the reappearance of trade tensions with Japan, increased unrest in Mexico ahead of the presidential elections there, and the general malaise in the Eurobond market. For some traders it was all too reminscent of the spring bear market in Treasuries when there was fear of a trade war with Japan and a Mexican presidential candidate was assassinated. 
 The 30-year bond dropped 15/32 , to 8627/32 for a yield of 7.35 percent, up from 7.31 percent on Friday. Bills and notes also ended a few basis points higher, with the discount rate on the three- and six-month issues up slightly in the weekly Treasury auction to 4.16 percent and 4.55 percent, respectively.
 
Lifeless Session Seen
 Matthew F. Alexy, a government trading strategist for CS First Boston, described yesterday's market as pretty much a lifeless session. "The market opened lower and spent most of the day bouncing around in a rather narrow range," he said, "with the weak dollar and higher commodity prices having their greatest impact overnight. And that prevented the market from doing better."
Mr. Alexy says today's Consumer Price Index report for May is not expected to help the market since most market participants believe it will indicate that inflation is still something they need to worry about. "The monthly retail sales figures due out today," he added, are expected to show how quick the economy is growing and has implications for Fed behavior."
Analysts said the market was also still under pressure from last week's comments from the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan. James Hale, a fixed-income analyst with MMS International said the Fed chairman, while acknowledging that inflation indicators like the Consumer Price Index and the Producer Price Index are restrained, emphasized that they are lagging indicators. And the Fed's policy, Mr. Hale said, is forward looking. This means that the Fed is still likely to push short-term interest rates higher in the near future.
Yesterday a Fed governor, Susan Phillips, in Basel, Switzerland, said there were some slight signs of inflationary pressure developing in the economy, particularly in the commodity markets.
Mr. Hale said he believed the "recent talk of a slowdown in consumption to be undermined by June data, which are expected to be stronger." He added: "Last week's strong Johnson Redbook retail report gave a hint on that regard. As long as the economy maintains its forward momentum, another 25-basis-point Fed tightening should be expected out of the July Federal Open Market Committee meeting."
 
No Rate Increase Is Expected
 But Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen gave a different view yesterday. He told news service reporters that he thinks that the Federal Reserve will not raise its short-term interest rate target when the Fed's policy-making committee meets July 7.
"Interest rates have stabilized for the present anyway," Mr. Bentsen said. "I would not say anything beyond that. The Fed has signaled it reached neutral policy."
As has been the case for months, dealers and some retail accounts, were selling into upticks in the bond market. The market was already struggling with the comments from Fed governor Phillips and the weak dollar, and then commodity prices added to the negative tone.
The Commodity Research Bureau index, a measure of 21 commodity prices, rose 2.62, to 235.50, despite prospects for rain in the midwest.
In the corporate bond market, Morgan Stanley & Company will be the sole manager for $500 million of Tennessee Valley Authority power bonds that are expected to be priced today. As far as Morgan Stanley knows, these 50-year bonds will be the first corporate long bonds with a five-year noncall.
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: U.S. Seeks Law on Foreign Cartels

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 13

 BODY:
Contending that United States antitrust laws are no longer adequate for an increasingly global economy, the Justice Department is seeking legislative authority to move against as many as 20 international cartels that are outside the reach of American prosecutors.
Attorney General Janet Reno proposed legislation today that would allow the Justice Department to conduct joint investigations with foreign governments of international price-fixing cartels. United States law already allows joint investigations with foreign governments of criminal and securities cases. 
 Ms. Reno, in an appearance with two senior Congressional Democrats who support such legislation, said the cartels were virtually immune to United States prosecution because incriminating documents were in foreign countries, beyond American subpoenas.
But the bill's prospects in Congress this year are murky because only a few more weeks remain in the legislative session. The House and Senate Judiciary Committees, through which the bill must pass before reaching the floor, are busy with the President's crime bill and may not have time to handle another ambitious measure.
Representative Jack Brooks of Texas, who heads the House Judiciary Committee, and Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum of Ohio, chairman of the Senate Judiciary antitrust subcommittee, joined Ms. Reno in announcing the legislation. They said they would formally introduce the bill later this week or early next week.
But Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, the ranking Republican on Mr. Metzenbaum's panel, said that while he supported the bill's goal of bringing international range to the nation's antitrust laws, he wanted safeguards in the measure before he would support it. The bill should not allow foreign governments to use joint investigations with the Justice Department to obtain national security information, or to obtain American commercial information and pass it to companies in their home countries, Mr. Thurmond said.
 
Safeguards to Be Added
 Anne K. Bingaman, Assistant Attorney General for antitrust policy, said the final version of the bill would include such safeguards. The United States and other nations would have full discretion in deciding what, if any, information they shared, she said.
Even if the legislation is approved this year, it is likely to take two years to negotiate a series of agreements with foreign governments that would allow each country's law enforcement officials to serve a subpoena in another country, Ms. Bingaman said. Because each nation's officials would have the option of refusing to serve the subpoenas, most requests for foreign assistance would likely come as part of joint investigations.
Speaking at the same news conference as Ms. Reno, Ms. Bingaman said there were at least 10 and possibly 20 cartels that the Justice Department could barely investigate now and where the proposed law would help.
She declined to identify the cartels by country or product, but said the Justice Department had been frustrated in efforts to root out collusion in the international uranium industry because documents were in Scotland, Australia and elsewhere.
Even without the legislation, Ms. Bingaman added, the department would file an international antitrust case within a month involving "a major consumer product."
James F. Rill, Assistant Attorney General for antitrust policy under President George Bush, said Ms. Bingaman's estimate of up to 20 cartels was plausible. The illegal business alliances are probably as common in Europe as Japan, he added.
Last month the Justice Department settled its first antitrust case in more than a decade involving allegations that a company used monopolistic practices to restrict United States exports. Pilkington P.L.C., a British glassmaker, agreed on May 25 to begin allowing all American licensees of its technology to set up factories abroad. Only one of the licensees had previously had the right to open overseas factories, and it only had that right in certain foreign markets.
The Pilkington case was unusual because a private arbitration proceeding had brought all the crucial documents to the United States before the Justice Department stepped in. In most cases involving international businesses that appear to be colluding, the documents are in foreign countries, Ms. Bingaman said.
In cases like Pilkington, which involve foreign restrictions on United States exports, the Justice Department believes that it has jurisdiction when the foreign company has an American subsidiary, said Diane P. Wood, a Deputy Assistant Attorney General for antitrust policy. Many big international companies do business here and have American subsidiaries.
For cases involving conspiracies to raise the price of American imports, the Justice Department can pursue a foreign company if it ships large quantities of goods to the United States, regardless of whether the company has an American subsidiary, Ms. Wood said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Ben Leaving as Ben & Jerry's Chief

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
Ben Cohen, the Ben who helped build Ben & Jerry's into a $140 million company without ever abandoning his blue-jean image, plans to resign as the ice cream company's chief executive.
With the kind of marketing flair that made a household name out of a business begun in an abandoned gas station 16 years ago, the company announced a contest inviting its customers to explain why they should succeed Mr. Cohen. 
 But with a concession to financial reality and at the expense of the social activism for which Ben & Jerry's Homemade Inc. also became famous, it said it had abandoned its policy that no executive be paid more than seven times the salary of the lowest-paid employee. The company said it knew it would have trouble finding qualified executives who would take the job with that restriction.
Wall Street had expected a change. Ben & Jerry's stock has slumped as competition has increased in the slow-growing superpremium ice cream segment of supermarket sales and as the company has had trouble exploiting expansion opportunities in stores and overseas.
The company, based in Waterbury, Vt., earned $7.2 million on sales of $140.3 million in 1993. Its shares, which are traded over the counter, fell from $32 just over a year ago to $14.75 early this year. They closed at $13.25 yesterday, up 25 cents.
"We have never had an experienced C.E.O. and we have reached the point in our life when we need one," said the 43-year-old Mr. Cohen. He plans to continue as chairman and concentrate on what he called "fun stuff" like product development.
Still, Mr. Cohen's step away from the helm may worry some of the company's fans, who have been attracted not only to its numbingly rich products but also to its longstanding commitments to social activism and taste for outrageous fun.
Both the products and the counterculture corporate style are traceable to the quirks of the bearded Mr. Cohen, a man who taught crafts to emotionally disturbed teen-agers before starting the company, and of Jerry Greenfield, his childhood friend, fellow hippie and co-founder, who is vice chairman but who has been less involved in the business in recent years.
Mr. Cohen said he did not expect a big change in style or social commitment from anyone chosen as his successor.
The company said it was retaining an executive recruiting firm to handle the job search.
Under the company salary policy, Mr. Cohen last year was paid $133,212, the highest at the company, and received no bonus, according to filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
"It's a bit sad that they have to abandon the 7-to-1 ratio, because it was a noble experiment at a time when pay disparities are rising," said Joan Bavaria, president of the Franklin Research and Development Corporation, a Boston company that manages investments for clients who have social concerns as well as monetary goals for their funds. "But they will probably always have a more equal pay structure than most and it's a sign of maturity that they can move on."
Ben & Jerry's started as a scoop shop in an old gas station in Burlington, Vt. It has since made headlines for paying Vermont farmers more than market rates for their milk to help support the family-farm economy, for buying nuts from Amazon rainforest tribes, for its extensive environmental programs and for tie-ins with a wide variety of charities through its policy of contributing 7.5 percent of profits to a foundation controlled by employees.
The company also won kudos for its promotional talents, which included developing exotic products and funky names for them, like Cherry Garcia, its popular cherry and chocolate chunk ice cream named after Jerry Garcia of the Grateful Dead rock band. Recently, the company began a campaign to reach an older audience with television and print ads featuring celebrities like Spike Lee, Pete Seeger, Bobby Seale and Daniel Berrigan.
In the contest announced yesterday, customers are being asked to send a lid from a container of their favorite flavor and a short essay on why they would make a "great C.E.O." The company expects a flood of entries, not so much from people who want the job as from those hoping for the second prize -- membership in its "Ice Cream for Life Club" -- or the honorable-mention T-shirts and "rejection letter suitable for framing."
 
Haagen-Dazs the Chief Rival
 Ben & Jerry's leading competitor, Haagen-Dazs, a subsidiary of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., had 53 percent of the $277 million market in grocery stores for premium ice cream in the year ended May 15, compared with 42 percent for Ben & Jerry's, according to Information Resources Inc., a Chicago-based market research firm. But the same survey concluded that Ben & Jerry's was the leader in the faster-growing $130.1 million frozen yogurt segment, with sales of $44 million, up 34 percent for the year, compared with $26.5 million, up 13.9 percent, for Haagen-Dazs.
Mr. Cohen and three other insiders with smaller holdings controlled 47 percent of the company's voting shares as of March 11. How Mr. Cohen, Chuck Lacy, who is president and chief operating officer, and the new chief executive will interact will depend on the strengths of the person chosen, Mr. Cohen said.
"I think we are looking for a rare bird," he said. "I guess there are about five or ten executives who will be interested and have the skills."
The key, Mr. Cohen said, is experience in keeping "everyone aligned and moving in the same direction" as the company grows, a skill he says he is learning but is not good at.
"I haven't found the happy medium between autocratic and laissez-faire," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ben Cohen, right, and Jerry Greenfield announced a contest inviting Ben & Jerry's customers to explain why they should become chief executive of the ice cream company. Mr. Cohen plans to step away from the helm. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Oil-Patch Congressmen Seek Deal With Clinton

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DALLAS, June 13

 BODY:
With a Congressional vote on a health care bill still months away, some of the 119 members from the oil patch who plan to meet with President Clinton on Thursday say that breaks for oil producers could sweeten the odds of success in health care.
Some Administration officials have little appetite for any measures that would widen the deficit or raise energy costs, especially since Congress balked at most of the President's energy plans. But the meeting at the White House might offer a preview of the trade-offs members of Congress will demand for their health care votes. 
 The President has already shown himself willing to clinch the sale of his legislative merchandise -- a tax bill, the North American Free Trade Agreement -- by throwing in all manner of incentives. Now, even lawmakers who are inclined to take his side first often state their price.
Domestic oil producers have seized the moment to pursue their campaign for higher exploration and production incentives. They say that oil prices, despite a recent rebound, remain so low that many smaller producers may have no choice but to plug their wells.
In Dallas today, the producers told a Commerce Department panel that production cuts would leave the nation dangerously dependent on imported oil and at risk of another Middle East war.
"How many American lives will be lost next time?' asked Louis W. Powers, a consultant for the Independent Petroleum Association of America, as he played Persian Gulf War footage on a screen above. "Are we willing to allow our economic system to be controlled by the sheiks?'
 
A Sign of Receptiveness
 George Alcorn, the association's chairman, considers the decision by Ronald H. Brown, the Commerce Secretary, to hold hearings on how oil imports affect national security as a sign of the Administration's increasing receptiveness to his group's views.
Mr. Alcorn says he regrets that Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, although a former Senator from Texas, now worries that any favors for the energy industry could slow the economy. "They want to get the President re-elected,' Mr. Alcorn said.
The President's prospects are bound to depend as well on his health care program. Here, the lawmakers with the greatest influence over energy policy say they can be of help.
J. Bennett Johnston, the Louisiana Democrat who heads the Senate Energy Committee, has joined two committee members and Representative John D. Dingell, the Michigan Democrat who is his powerful House counterpart, in linking the oil and health issues -- "both of which affect the long-term economic security of this nation," they said in a letter to the President earlier this spring.
 
A Strange Alliance
 They propose tax breaks for oil exploration, drilling on the outer continental shelf and production from the smallest, most marginal wells, as well as import taxes on foreign refined oil.
It's an unusual alliance. Mr. Dingell, whose Committee on Energy and Commerce also considers many health care matters, more often opposes subsidies for the energy industry. Senator Johnston and many other oil-patch lawmakers represent conservative states and interests that have been uneasy over the President's initial health care program.
"Socialized medicine," Mr. Alcorn of the oil producers, said. "That's clearly what it is."
Senator Jeff Bingaman, a New Mexico Democrat who also signed the letter, said that Thursday's gathering will also take up what the President can do without going to a Congress already preoccupied with health reform. "That's the 900-pound gorilla,' he said.
The President could reduce royalty charges and liberalize leases on Federal property, on land and offshore, said Mr. Bingaman, who joined 118 other members of Congress in requesting the meeting.

HEADLINE: Jan Tinbergen, Dutch Economist and Nobel Laureate, Dies at 91

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
Jan Tinbergen, the Dutch economist and Nobel laureate whose technical accomplishments and passion for effective public policy have led some to compare him with John Maynard Keynes, died last Thursday at the age of 91. News of his death was withheld by his family until yesterday to allow his funeral to take place without publicity.
Mr. Tinbergen was trained as a physicist (he received a doctoral degree in the subject from the University of Leyden) but switched to economics in the late 1920's. During the early 1930's he was a professor of development planning at the University of Rotterdam and staff member of the Dutch Central Bureau of Statistics, where he applied mathematical techniques from the sciences to the question of why industrial output fluctuated in nonrandom ways -- the classic puzzle of the business cycle. 
 As an adviser to the Social Democrats in the Netherlands, he was co-author of a plan for coping with the unemployment that had swept across Europe with the Great Depression.
 
Econometric Models
 But Mr. Tinbergen first gained prominence with his pioneering efforts to build mathematical models of how whole economies work -- more specifically, how shocks like harvest failures or stock market crashes ricochet through an economy to influence employment, output and inflation. Others had used mathematics to add intellectual rigor to economic theory. But in the view of Paul Samuelson of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, "Tinbergen's combination of analytic versatility and good policy judgment" gave him an enormous advantage over most of his contemporaries.
His model of the American economy, produced for the League of Nations in 1938, was the precursor of the giant computer models now used to forecast everything from the size of next year's budget deficit to the exchange rate of the Mexican peso.
In the decade after World War II he served as the director of the Dutch Central Planning Bureau and as a key policy adviser to the country's Social Democrats. Indeed, his reputation as a guru of the democratic left was reportedly so sacrosanct that he was able to broker a wage pact between the Government and the country's militant labor unions that prevented mounting inflation. But he remained a world-class theorist and practitioner as well, helping to transform economics into a true policy science.
One idea generally attributed to Mr. Tinbergen is that governments must have at least as many independent policy instruments as policy targets. For example, if a country wishes to control both the exchange rate of its currency and the rate of economic growth it must use a minimum of two levers -- say, the supply of money and the rate of deficit spending. That notion comes as second nature to the current generation of economists, who were put through their mathematical paces in graduate school. But it was a revelation at the time, an insight that had eluded the greats.
In 1969 Mr. Tinbergen shared the first Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science with the Norwegian Ragnar Frisch. And while his intellectual force as an economist was by this time largely spent, he remained, in the words of James Tobin of Yale, "a congenital do-gooder," who used his fame and prestige to further the cause of rational economic policy in the third world.
Failure to help impoverished countries, he told an interviewer during his tenure as the chairman of the United Nations Development Planning Committee, would result in "mass unemployment, increasing internal conflicts, disaster." Part of his prescription was a sharp increase in development aid, a fashionable view at the time. But he had the foresight to understand that barriers to imports from the third world were potentially more important obstacles to growth.
The voice of a man whom Mr. Samuelson dubbed a "humanist saint" was not stilled until his last days. Just a few weeks ago, Mr. Samuelson reports, he received a letter from the Dutch economist asking him to sign a petition calling for an end to the exploitation of children.
The cause of Mr. Tinberg's death and information about his family were not immediately available.

HEADLINE: Tribes See Jobs Hardship In Tax Ruling

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 13

 BODY:
Indian leaders in New York State said today that a United States Supreme Court decision allowing the state to tax some sales transactions on reservations could devastate Indian-owned smoke shops and gas stations that have become the backbone of some tribal economies.
"I don't think there is any doubt it will cause economic hardship for the Mohawk people," said Joseph D. Gray, a spokesman for the tribal council of the St. Regis Mohawks. "People who in the past have been on public assistance found they could open small smoke shops and make some money." 
 Those Indian businesses have thrived largely because of one major advantage: they did not charge state sales or excise taxes, even though under law they were required to assess those taxes to non-Indian customers. Today's Supreme Court decision upholds a state plan to collect taxes on those sales to non-Indians.
In the last five years, tax-free smoke shops and gasoline stations on the state's 10 Indian reservations have proliferated as state taxes on cigarettes and gasoline have risen sharply, allowing Indian entrepreneurs to undercut non-Indian competitors by larger amounts.
 
A Boon on Reservations
 In that period, state excise taxes rose by 167 percent to 56 cents a pack for cigarettes and by 67 percent to 30 cents a gallon for gasoline. Today, between 100 and 200 Indian businesses routinely sell gasoline for 15 to 20 cents a gallon less and cigarettes for $5 to $8 per carton less than stores just outside their reservations.
That has proven a boon to Indian business owners and created jobs and economic stimulus for hard-pressed reservation economies. But it has siphoned away millions of dollars in business from non-Indian retailers.
"This decision should get us back to where we should be, making money instead of making debts," said Salvatore Aronica, owner of Tubby's Corner Quick Stop just outside a Seneca reservation in western New York.
Barry Snyder, president of the Seneca Nation, said his tribe would consider suing the state for violating treaties if it attempted to implement its taxation plan. "There is nothing in the decision that changes the basic principle of Indian law that treaties are the supreme law of the land," he said.
Ray Halbritter, the elected leader of the Oneida Indians near Rome, said he would seek to negotiate a favorable agreement allowing the state to collect some taxes from sales to non-Indians. But he said that today's ruling could cause protests or encourage black-market sales on other reservations.
"It's just not something the Indian people are going to take," he said.

HEADLINE: $17.4 Million Loss Covered

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, June 13

 BODY:
The BankAmerica Corporation paid $17.4 million in May into its Pacific Horizon Prime Money Market fund to cover losses on securities, some of which were derivatives.
"The amount injected into the fund was equal to the losses realized," John Keane, a spokesman for BankAmerica, said on Saturday. Investors did not lose money, he said. 
 The payment was needed because of the rise in interest rates in March and April, Mr. Keane said. The higher rates prompted many investors, mostly institutions, to take their money out of the fund and put it directly into securities, he said. As a result, the fund had to sell securities at a loss before they matured.
The banking company, based in San Francisco, sold certificates of deposit and other short-term money market assets. The impact on BankAmerica's earnings from the payment will not be material, he added.

HEADLINE: 5 New Yorkers Among MacArthur Recipients

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH 

 BODY:
Jazz musicians, choreographers, a poet and other artists won half the 20 fellowships awarded yesterday, 5 of them to New Yorkers, by the Mac Arthur Foundation of Chicago. Proportionately, it was the largest group of winners in the arts since the program began 14 years ago. The fellowships have traditionally been dominated by academics and researchers.
Coincidence, not a policy shift from science to culture, decided the choices, said Catharine R. Stimpson, director of the foundation. 
 In addition, 9 of the 20 recipients belong to minority groups, the highest proportion ever, demonstrating further, Ms. Stimpson said, that "creative people come in all sizes, shapes and colors."
The fellowships will range from $235,000 to $375,000 to be paid over five years.
The program was established by the John D. and Catharine T. MacArthur Foundation to free exceptionally gifted individuals from money cares. For the recipients, there are no strings. No reports need to be filed, just an address where checks can be sent. Applications are not accepted; candidates are proposed by 100 anonymous nominators, and the foundation's board selects the recipients.
Among this year's winners are Bill T. Jones, the dancer and choreographer, and Arthur Mitchell, who founded Dance Theater of Harlem and was the first black principal dancer with the New York City Ballet.
Ornette Coleman, the jazz musician and composer who is widely regarded as one of the most influential figures in jazz; Anthony Braxton, a musician and pioneering composer who is a professor of African-American music at Wesleyan University, and Sam-Ang Sam, a musician who works to preserve and reinvigorate Khmer performing arts in the United States, were also named fellows.
Prizes went to the poet Adrienne Rich, whose most recent work is "What Is Found There: Notebooks on Poetry and Politics" (Norton, 1993), and to Robert Adams, a photographer of Western landscapes.
Another winner, Willie Reale, a theater arts educator, founded the 52d Street Project in Manhattan, a theater company that puts inner-city children together with professional actors and playwrights to help the youngsters produce their own plays.
Another MacArthur also went to Hugo Morales, the Mexican-born co-founder of Radio Bilingue, one the first bilingual radio stations in the United States. Mr. Morales was also the leading force behind Satelite, a nationwide Spanish-language radio network.
Prof. Faye D. Ginsburg, head of New York University's ethnographic film and video program, also received a prize. Her fieldwork has taken her to Australia to make documentaries about the Aborigines.
Professor Ginsburg said she intended to give part of her award to the Dysautonomia Foundation, which promotes research on a genetic disease of the nervous system. She and her husband, Prof. Fred Myers, head of the university's anthropology department, have a 5-year-old daughter, Samantha, who has the rare disease.
These are the 20 recipients:
Robert Adams, 57, photographer from Longmont, Colo.
Jeraldyne Blunden, 53, artistic director of the Dayton Contemporary Dance Company of Dayton, Ohio
Anthony Braxton, 49, of Wesleyan University
Rogers Brubaker, 38, sociologist and political historian, associate professor, University of California, Los Angeles
Ornette Coleman, 64, jazz musician and composer, New York City
Israel Moiseevich Gelfand, 80, mathematician and biologist, distinguished visiting professor, Rutgers University, New Brunswick, N.J.
Faye D. Ginsburg, 41, associate professor, New York University
Heidi Hartmann, 48, economist and co-founder of Institute for Women's Policy Research in Washington
Bill T. Jones, 42, co-founder, Bill T. Jones/ Arnie Zane Company, New York City
Peter E. Kenmore, 41, entomologist with the Food and Agriculture Organization, working in Manila
Joseph E. Marshall, 47, educator, executive director, Omega Boys Club, San Francisco
Carolyn McKecuen, 54, executive director, Watermark Association of Artisans, Elizabeth City, N.C.
Donella Meadows, 53, environmental writer, adjunct professor, Dartmouth College, Plainfield, N.H.
Arthur Mitchell, 60, founder and artistic director, Dance Theater of Harlem, New York City
Hugo Morales, 45, co-founder and executive director, Radio Bilingue, Fresno, Calif.
Janine Pease-Windy Boy, 44, president, Little Big Horn College, Crow Agency, Mont.
Willie Reale, 31, founder and artistic director, 52d Street Project, New York City
Adrienne Rich, 65, poet and essayist, Stanford, Calif.
Sam-Ang Sam, 44, musician and scholar, director of the Cambodian Network Council, Washington
Jack Wisdom, 41, physicist, professor, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Mass.

HEADLINE: North Korea Courts Confrontation

 BODY:
North Korea moved a step closer to disastrous confrontation with the rest of the world yesterday by announcing its withdrawal from the International Atomic Energy Agency and by banning I.A.E.A. inspectors from its territory.
Pyongyang has not yet carried out its threat. Two I.A.E.A. inspectors, along with monitoring cameras, remain at its reactor site, watching recently removed spent fuel that could be transformed into as many as five nuclear bombs. If North Korea does expel the inspectors, it could fatally compromise the Clinton Administration's efforts to resolve the nuclear dispute peacefully. 
 To keep diplomacy alive, the U.S. and its Asian allies must not flinch in the face of this and other North Korean provocations. Instead they should proceed with their plan to ask the U.N. Security Council to enact a sequence of phased sanctions as soon as the Council's five permanent members reach a consensus on how to do it.
North Korea's withdrawal announcement came in response to last Friday's decision by the I.A.E.A. to suspend most international technical assistance to Pyongyang's nuclear program. That I.A.E.A. vote, reflecting frustration at North Korea's breaches of agency monitoring rules, provided a test run for any forthcoming U.N. sanctions resolution. The U.S. was glad to see that China did not try to block I.A.E.A. punishment, raising hope that China will also permit Security Council action.
What is most important for now is not North Korea's announcement of its intentions or even formal withdrawal from the I.A.E.A. After all, North Korea withdrew from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty a year ago only to "suspend" its withdrawal a few months later. The most urgent requirement is that North Korea allow effective international monitoring of that recently removed spent nuclear fuel. Inspectors must retain necessary access to the storage site. Monitoring cameras must be kept supplied with batteries and film without interruption. That is the surest way to keep North Korea from building new nuclear bombs.
Until now, the main issue between North Korea and the I.A.E.A. has been over collecting evidence bearing on whether North Korea built bombs in the past. Through analysis of spent fuel rods and access to nuclear waste sites, the I.A.E.A. hoped to establish exactly how much plutonium North Korea may have diverted when the reactor was briefly shut down five years ago. The C.I.A. estimates that if North Korea had the necessary technology, that could have been enough for one or two nuclear bombs. On the other hand, it remains possible that the North has not yet built any.
The spent fuel whose monitoring is now at issue contains far more plutonium, perhaps enough for five bombs. North Korea's threat to disrupt monitoring of this new cache of potential bomb fuel, coupled with its warnings of military reprisals against Japan and South Korea, forces the world to think hard about the worst-case possibility: that North Korea is not merely seeking diplomatic concessions but wants to make nuclear weapons and will wage war to protect its ability to do so.
Pyongyang continues to assert that its nuclear program is peaceful and that the whole crisis can be resolved by direct talks with the U.S. But when the Clinton Administration braved domestic criticism to offer such talks, North Korea repeatedly answered with provocations -- "suspending" its adherence to the Nonproliferation Treaty, thwarting I.A.E.A. inspectors, refusing to preserve evidence and now threatening to quit the I.A.E.A.
As the world moves toward sanctions, it cannot afford to abandon diplomacy. The costs of confrontation would be very high. Even without war, sanctions could trigger collapse of the Northern regime, sending millions of refugees over the South Korean and Chinese borders and into Japan.
The U.S. and its allies must try to use the threat of sanctions to push North Korea into a diplomatic solution, while preserving continuous monitoring of that dangerous fuel.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Supping With the Bigot

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
The offense of the Rev. Benjamin F. Chavis Jr. was not simply to invite Louis Farrakhan to a conference of black leaders but to treat Americans as total fools.
Every important argument he makes to defend the invitation, to justify the damage he did to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, is grounded in obvious intellectual, political and moral distortion or demagoguery. 
 Since the N.A.A.C.P. affects black-white relations -- particularly among Americans who want to better them -- non-members as well as members should pay close attention.
The demagoguery is painfully easy to spot.
A white man in an audience asks Mr. Chavis why he invited Louis Farrakhan. Mr. Chavis is prepared. He says he has denounced bigotry. But about the invitation he cries: "The N.A.A.C.P. will not be dictated to."
Mr. Chavis knows better. He knows that peaceful protest or questioning are not dictation but the very right on which the N.A.A.C.P. was founded.
Charging that protest is dictation is the lie that Mr. Farrakhan himself, and his hand-trained bigots, trot out when anybody denounces their hate-mongering. This phony bravery brought applause and Amens from the audience; it always does. It is a terribly old trick -- used by every demagogue to squash opposition.
These are three of Mr. Chavis's other major arguments, repeated endlessly in the press:
1. Inviting Mr. Farrakhan is not endorsing him.
Maybe not, but it is a plain mark of respect and respectability that will increase the standing of Mr. Farrakhan and his clones -- and therefore increase their influence.
2. Mr. Farrakhan attracts more and more young blacks -- exactly the kind of active people the N.A.A.C.P. wants.
There is a phrase for this kind of thing: sickening opportunism.
If Mr. Chavis and the N.A.A.C.P. have any moral status or political value to the U.S., it would be to fight the attraction of Mr. Farrakhan by talking straight to young blacks about the danger of black bigotry to them and their future -- not by endowing the Farrakhans with respectability.
The argument Mr. Chavis uses -- the popularity of the bigot-in-chief -- is the very reason not to invite him. It was the argument used by the German elite when they saw Hitler's popularity, cowered before it and tried to profit from it.
3. The civil rights movement should be redefined to embrace self-help and economic improvement, and Mr. Farrakhan leads the Nation of Islam in that direction.
Once again, it is an old argument used to move toward bigots -- Mussolini's trains running on time, Hitler's rosy-cheeked Nazi youth, the glories of Stalinist production lines. That argument amounted to a statement of the inadequacy of tolerance and democracy -- and respect for leaders who use physical or intellectual brutality for their "achievements."
The invitation did damage inside and outside the N.A.A.C.P. Inside are members who oppose Mr. Chavis and his philosophy and are under heavy pressure for it.
Also, around the country are politicians, intellectuals and other prominent African-Americans who have spoken out against Mr. Farrakhan without counting the consequence, because they detest what he stands for. Inviting him is a slap at the political and racial decency that these men and women represent.
(Among them is Representative Major R. Owens of Brooklyn. He faces opposition from an African-American who has earned his racist reputation. I hope all his constituents, black and white, rally around Mr. Owens in justice to him and themselves).
When Mr. Chavis extended that invitation to Mr. Farrakhan, his guest brought his baggage with him -- including his suitcase full of threats. He has already pulled out economic holy war -- "in the name of Almighty God," a boycott of American companies that dare reduce or end contributions to the Chavis-led N.A.A.C.P.
But Mr. Chavis gambled the reputation of the N.A.A.C.P. and its political and economic support when he invited Mr. Farrakhan. He knew what he was doing. He lost -- for himself and the N.A.A.C.P.
Now the threats of his guest can deepen the damage but not repair it. That will take the stamina and courage of N.A.A.C.P. members who are fighting both the guest and the director who brought him to the table.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Observer;
Talking The Talk

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER 

 BODY:
The car radio was saying, "Public awareness is building." I had to deal with an orange traffic light just then, so missed the rest of the bulletin and by the time I'd finished the decision- making process the schmoozemeister had moved on to "dysfunctional families."
"Public awareness is building." "Decision-making process." "Dysfunctional families." Why do people talk like this, especially on radio and television, though also in newspapers, magazines and my very own house, to be honest. 
 In the first place, I don't believe public awareness is building. Maybe it is, but for each piece of evidence suggesting that public awareness is building there is an equal and opposite piece suggesting that public awareness is crumbling.
I suspect there may not even be any public awareness, either building, crumbling or just sitting around passively minding its own business. This is based on observation of the few dozen people I see now and then.
If you want to know what glazed-over eyes look like, ask any of these people about public awareness. These glazed-over eyes, of course, are "only anecdotal evidence," another mess of wordage that's highly fashionable with the big-talk crowd these days.
Economists, I believe, coined "only anecdotal evidence" to shrug off tales of individual human misery that threaten to spoil their statistical pictures of general and abundant happiness.
"Only anecdotal evidence." It is such a depressingly governmental way of voicing contempt for people. Government in all its vastness can no longer visualize each person out here as an individual caught in his own singular anecdote of a life. It can see us only as numbers on statistical printouts.
As I guided the car masterfully through traffic, headed for my laundry-and-dry-cleaning establishment, I chided myself for becoming sentimental about the individual in his struggle against statistical oblivion. I have always been too soft. "Soft-nosed" is what the old hard-nosed, brilliant crowd in Washington called me in the old days. Just recently an obscure journal dismissed me as a tribune of "soft liberalism."
Am I a man or a pillow? This sentimental distaste for being a statistic must be abandoned. I must learn not only to "talk the talk," as street kids say, but also to "walk the walk." Well, I had instinctively talked the talk back there when the traffic light went orange. Had I not thought, "Now I must enter the decision-making process"? I had. And noticing that there was a police car on my rear bumper, I had concluded the decision-making process by declining to floor the gas pedal and, instead, had come to a complete stop.
And who was I to sneer at those who say "Public awareness is building"? Perhaps there really was a fresh set of statistics proving conclusively, at least until the next set of statistics comes in, that public awareness is indeed building.
Could these statistics, I wondered, be collated in the vast Public Awareness Building? And what in the world did "collated" mean anyhow? How do you collate a statistic? Is it done with a digital collater? How many megaherz does it take? How much RAM, ROM, RUM does the typical collation require?
"Steady, man, steady," I cautioned myself as I pulled onto the 2,000-acre Steaming Asphalt Shopping Mall. "You're losing it again, you're letting the old brain slip out of talk-the-talk mode and going irritable, human . . . soft, soft as a feather mattress."
Getting a grip on myself was essential, because any minute now I would have to confront the dry-cleaner. That meant being ready to walk the walk, for he could be an arrogant devil when my white shirt was not ready on time, as it often wasn't when I needed it for a special evening, as I did this day.
I would have to be prepared to give him a good tongue-lashing, make him promise never to fail me again and see him bow with respect for my anger. In short, this was no time for soft nose or soft liberalism. I must be ready to walk the walk.
Stepping from the car, I braced for the encounter by talking the talk and said, sotto voce, "Public awareness is building." Also, "spiritual fulfillment," "raised consciousness," "dysfunctional," "the counterculture" and "gender-neutral."
The dry-cleaner was all smiles. "Your white shirt is ready this time," he said, handing it to me. I accepted it, very unhappily, because I knew it was only anecdotal evidence.

HEADLINE: As Union Negotiations Continue, L.I. Braces for a Railroad Strike

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
With the Long Island Rail Road's biggest union threatening to strike at midnight tonight, the region prepared yesterday for a commuting nightmare as negotiations continued on a contract that could influence deals to come for New York City subway and bus workers.
The United Transportation Union, which represents 2,300 workers, from conductors and bartenders to mechanics and track workers, wants raises of more than 18 percent during four years, about double what management is offering. The railroad is insisting on work-rule changes that it says would improve productivity and cut costs. 
 Last night, both sides were predicting a strike, although Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who controls much of the railroad's financing, said a settlement "doesn't look impossible." If workers walk out, he said he would call on the state's Congressional delegation to push for binding arbitration to end the strike quickly.
Union and management negotiators met late into the night under the auspices of the National Mediation Board.
For the railroad's 107,000 commuters and many New York City employers, the threat of a strike, the first on the railroad since 1987, has led to elaborate plans to avoid spending hours on the expressways. [Page B4.]
But for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the parent agency of the railroad, the subways and other transportation agencies, the talks, which have been going on for more than two years, are complicated by broader concerns.
M.T.A. officials say the settlement will set a pattern for all of its 64,800 employees, and each additional percentage point increase in wages that it pays, worth $1.3 million for the Long Island Rail Road employees, comes to $30 million if extended to all workers.
Since the railroad gets nearly half its budget from Albany, the dispute presents a challenge for the Governor, who will need the votes of Long Island commuters if he is to be re-elected this fall. But he will also face a conservative Republican opponent who could accuse him of being soft on labor unions if he endorses a generous settlement.
It is also a test for the railroad's president, Charles Hoppe, whose management skills have been questioned since the breakdown of service in a snowstorm early this year, and for Peter Stangl, the chairman of the M.T.A., whose appointment has expired and has not been formally renewed, because of conflicts in Albany between the Governor and the Republican-controlled State Senate.
 
A Challenge for All
 In a personal and financial sense, a strike would be a challenge for all who struggle to get to New York City for work every day, or who employ those strugglers.
"Obviously a prolonged strike is bad for the economy of the city and Long Island, and Long Island's economy doesn't need the blow," said Jeffrey M. Zupan, a transportation expert at the Regional Plan Association, a private civic group.
Transportation officials planning for a strike said that they would suspend road maintenance that was not urgent, extend the hours of operation for bus and car pool lanes, and take other steps to increase transportation capacity in the hours before and after rush hour, but at peak hours, they said, there was nothing they could do.
"The very best thing would be to keep your cars at home," said Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in a news conference at City Hall yesterday. "The second best is to park them in Queens and come in by public transportation."
"The worst possible thing to do would be to come into Manhattan in a car, and we will be encouraging people not to do that," he said.
 
Congressional Role
 A spokesman for the railroad, Michael Charles, said that agreement had been reached with the union to allow the departure of eight trains after the Knicks-Houston Rockets basketball game on Wednesday night, even if that is after midnight.
But the preparations also had a certain air of temporariness, with the union predicting that if the dispute is not settled quickly, Congress would probably step in to impose a "cooling-off period," which is the way the last strike ended after 11 days. In this dispute, the second of two "cooling-off periods" expires tonight.
The union is subject to the Federal Railway Labor Act, and an act of Congress could force the union back to work. Local Representatives have said they would seek such action in the event of a strike.
With that threat hanging over the union, the M.T.A. is trying to hold the Long Island workers, who are among the highest paid railroad employees in the nation, to the same pattern of raises that the Transit Workers Union agreed to in 1991: 2 percent that year, 2.5 percent in 1992, and 2 percent in 1993.
The subway and bus workers' union, the Transit Workers Union, has 43,700 members and its contract expires on June 30. The United Transportation Union at Metro-North is also negotiating a new contract; it has 4,900 members. In all, the M.T.A. has 56,600 unionized employees.
Management employees received no raises last year or the year before, but a 4 percent increase this year.
 
Work-Rule Changes
 The L.I.R.R. union is asking for wage increases that amount to a total of 18.1 percent; management is offering 9.3 percent. There are also work-rule changes that would save money for management, including being allowed to schedule some workers on Saturday and Sunday who now collect overtime for working those days.
An M.T.A. study found that as of Dec. 31, 1991, when the last contract ended, Long Island Rail Road conductors had a base salary of $46,500: $500 more than those on Metro-North, $4,500 more than PATH and $6,600 more than Amtrak.
But Edward J. Yule, general chairman of the United Transportation Union, emerging from a bargaining session in Melville yesterday afternoon, said, "We can't be saying we're the highest paid people in the railroad industry without noting that we have the highest paid cops, the highest paid schoolteachers and the highest paid phone workers. But we also have the highest-priced 7-Elevens in the country and the highest priced taxes. Everything here on Long Island is higher than anywhere else."
The M.T.A. has promised no increases in subway or suburban railroad fares before July 1995. With favorable trends like increasing ridership and a good labor settlement, that could presumably be pushed further into the future. But it is hard to imagine Metro-North and transit workers getting smaller increases than the Long Island employees.
Nonunion workers will also get increases largely based on what the union gets.
"If costs go up, fares go up and that discourages ridership," said James T. B. Tripp, the executive director of the Tri-State Transportation Campaign, a coalition of environmental groups and planners. The goal, he said, should be productivity improvements that would allow expansion of service, and with that, expansion of union jobs.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Philips Seeks Market Share For Its Technological Power

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: EINDHOVEN, the Netherlands

 BODY:
Having pioneered such products as the videocassette recorder, the compact disk and high-definition television, Philips Electronics N.V., Europe's largest electronics maker, has a deserved reputation for technological prowess.
But when it comes to turning that technology into market share and profits, Philips, best known in the United States for its Magnavox, Norelco and Sylvania brand names, has often fallen on its face. Its VCR format never caught on. Its video laser disk was one of the great flops in consumer electronics. Its latest hope, the digital compact cassette, an audio tape with CD-quality sound, is off to a slow start. 
 After several years of trying to revitalize Philips, the Dutch company's aggressive chairman, Jan D. Timmer, has another ambitious but risky target in his sights: the rapidly evolving world of interactive media -- where computers, television, communications, entertainment and information come together -- and particularly the software that combines pictures, sounds and words stored on compact disks for entertainment, educational and business uses.
The company has built a wide range of holdings through Philips Media, its New York-based subsidiary, which is headed by Scott C. Marden, a former investment banker at Bear, Stearns. Set up by the parent company last year, Philips Media encompasses cable television and teletext operations in Europe, stakes in the American video chain Blockbuster Entertainment and in Whittle Communications, the educational media company, and alliances with a variety of entertainment and software companies.
Its initial product for the market, a $399 CD-Interactive player that hooks up to a television set, has generated only lackluster sales so far, although the company insists that sales are growing. Whether CD-Interactive will succeed is a matter of debate within the industry; most analysts think the product will be squeezed out on the high end by personal computers equipped with CD-ROM, and on the low end by video games capable of using compact disks.
But this time Philips seems determined not to fall victim to another format war or to wager everything on the hardware side of the business. Indeed, Philips Media is being built on the premise that no matter which hardware formats catch on, there will be great demand for games, movies, music, educational programs and business-oriented software that runs on compact disks.
By the end of this year, there will be 10 million computers in the United States equipped with CD-ROM, Mr. Marden said. Add in other formats like Philips's own CD-Interactive or similar products being sold or planned by such companies as Atari and Sony, and there are "tremendous opportunities for us to exploit our development of software," Mr. Marden said.
Philips is already selling 200 CD-based titles, ranging from an interactive version of "The Joy of Sex" to games like "Alien Gate" and "Voyeur," movies like "Top Gun," music videos, educational programs and interactive programs used by companies for sales training and in-store promotions. Philips and its partners have 100 more titles in development, and most other big consumer electronics companies are developing similar programs. Philips soon expects to be able to offer such products as the Yellow Pages on CD.
As one of the inventors of the compact disk and as a pioneer in putting music, pictures and data into digital form, Philips has a head start in the development of a CD-based software and interactive media industry.
Philips is no stranger to the software side of the business, either. It owns 75 percent of Polygram N.V., the world's third-largest recording company and an increasingly ambitious producer of movies, including the recent hit "Four Weddings and a Funeral." Polygram is often mentioned as a possible bidder for a Hollywood studio like MGM.
"The industry, broadly defined to include a variety of software as well as new delivery systems, is very large already and presents huge opportunities for sustainable long-term growth," Mr. Marden said. "Philips has a long history of innovative technology that services this emerging business."
Philips Media is just one example of how the parent company has begun expanding its horizons, after years in which its primary goals were to slash employment and inject new energy into a fossilized corporate culture. When Mr. Timmer, the chairman, asked the heads of the parent company's business units at a meeting several years ago to write down the names of their 10 biggest customers, he was horrified but not totally surprised when many could not do so.
 
New Blood Brought In
 Since then Mr. Timmer has brought in new blood -- often non-Dutch blood. For example, Frank P. Carrubba, an American who had been a top executive at I.B.M. and Hewlett-Packard, joined Philips two years ago to oversee its technology and product development. Today, in a company that was once run almost exclusively by Dutch executives, only four of 13 members of the management board are Dutch.
Needing to slash costs, Mr. Timmer eliminated 22 percent of the company's work force over the last four years, bringing employment down to 238,000 worldwide. Philips pushed responsibility and authority down to the managers of its sprawling operations in lighting, consumer electronics, small appliances, semiconductors and electrical components, telecommunications and medical products. This led to further cost reductions and more aggressive product development and sales efforts.
Philips closed plants and sold assets, notably its 35 percent stake in the Matsushita Electronics Corporation, helping stabilize a precarious financial situation that got worse as its home markets in Europe sank into recession several years ago.
 
'Fundamental Reorganization'
 "This company really had to undergo a fundamental reorganization," said Dudley G. Eustace, the executive vice president and chief financial officer, who was brought in two years ago from British Aerospace.
"We were too fat, and we needed to make our assets work harder," Mr. Eustace said. "The results have started to show through. But you can't cut costs forever without damaging the company, so we have to start reinvesting in the company."
Having seen its profits rebound last year to $1.05 billion from a net loss of $511 million in 1992, Philips is now feeling prepared to act. Analysts expect to see a string of medium-sized acquisitions, or maybe even a few big ones, especially in the fields picked as targets by Philips Media.
"If Philips is to continue to show good earnings growth beyond the next two years or so, it cannot rely on cost cutting alone," Angela Dean, an analyst at Morgan Stanley in London, said in a recent report. "Organic growth will obviously help drive earnings -- and there are good opportunities for businesses such as lighting, in terms both of fast-growing, added-value products and of strong geographic markets such as China, India and Eastern Europe. But acquisitions are an answer, too, and the media sector, with potentially higher margins and higher growth rates, has obvious attractions."
Analysts said they were still not convinced that Philips had learned the skills needed to make the most of its technology. The poor sales of the digital compact cassette, for example, show "that they still have a learning curve to progress along," said Dennis Exton, an analyst at Merrill Lynch in London. In that case, he said, Philips misjudged consumers' willingness to pay for yet another music format, especially so soon after the compact disk's introduction.
In interactive media, Mr. Exton said he thought the hardware and software might be ahead of their time for many consumers, and that Philips might be pursuing "too broad a range of applications to enable it to be a success in any one of them."

HEADLINE: For Mexico's Indians, Promises Not Kept

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN JUAN TOTOLZINTLA, Mexico

 BODY:
More than 100 Nahua Indians streamed out of the parched, stony villages of central Guerrero State not long ago and marched a dozen days to Mexico City, emboldened by the battle cries of Indian rebels in southern Mexico and hoping to win their own set of Government promises to improve their lives.
Armed only with anger, they occupied the city's heart for several days until President Carlos Salinas de Gortari listened to their complaints about poverty, discrimination and injustice, facts of life for nearly all of Mexico's nine million or so Indians. After Mr. Salinas agreed that something had to be done and promised to meet them again in 60 days, they went home. 
 But like the armed uprising by Maya Indians in Chiapas State, which seized the nation's attention in January, the protest by the Nahua seemed to raise expectations without really changing anything. Life in most villages remains a mixture of dust and racism, made all the more bitter by unfulfilled promises.
"They told us lots of things just to ease the pressure, and we're no longer that important for them," a leader of the march said after Mr. Salinas did not appear at a state congress of Indians in May despite his promise to do so.
In the heat of the Chiapas conflict, Mr. Salinas told all of Mexico's Indians, "We will not abandon you," and promised many things, including paved roads, new schools, health clinics and economic development plans.
Paving was the easy part. The other promises have yet to materialize on any significant scale.
In some respects, it is not surprising that so little has changed for the Indians who rebelled in Chiapas, or for those in Guerrero or anywhere else in Mexico. Oppression of the Indians began as soon as the Spanish landed almost 500 years ago.
What many political analysts find surprising is that so soon after the shock from Chiapas, the Indians -- one in every 10 Mexicans -- can once again be so easily forgotten.
Communiques from the masked rebel leader, Subcommander Marcos, used to be front-page news; some now are printed on the letters page. A package of laws drafted after the uprising began is still months from being passed even though the national legislature is controlled by Mr. Salinas's party.
[On June 11, guerrilla leaders in Chiapas rejected the Government's proposed peace settlement. They offered to reopen talks, but only if the talks address demands for political changes at the national level. Government officials said that despite the rejection, they would keep the promises they made to build roads and other projects in Chiapas, but only in areas outside of rebel control.]
The demands of the Indians are as diverse as their customs, but basically they come down to wanting their share of the Mexican pie. Usually that does not mean jobs so much as passable roads on which to take their corn, beans and coffee to market; hospitals close enough to get to and schools that teach in their own languages; electricity and telephone lines that connect them with the rest of the country, and, as always, the right to a piece of land, without which there is no life for them.
 
Seats of Power Empty of Indians
 For the presidential election in August, Indian concerns have been reduced to a sound bite. As he campaigns, the governing party candidate, Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon, makes earnest but vague pledges about Indian independence and dignity, yet does not promise to change the land laws that are at the heart of the Chiapas conflict.
Although the revolt galvanized Mexico, Indians do not hold much political sway. All ballots are printed in Spanish, and since many Indians do not speak Spanish, many do not vote. Of those who do, many allow local bosses to tell them how to vote, and this results in huge pluralities for the governing party.
Few Indians are ever elected to positions outside their own small villages. They hold only a handful of federal legislative positions, and the list of candidates for legislative races includes only a few Indians.
In Chumpon, a steamy, ramshackle village carved out of the jungle about 125 miles south of Cancun, Rolando Cen Tun, a descendant of the Maya who built the temples of Chichen Itza and Tulum, slapped his moneyless pockets and said life would go on just as it did before Chiapas rose up in anger because Indians do not even have enough to fight back.
Half a country away in Guerrero, about 100 miles from Acapulco, Indians of San Juan Totolzintla gathered under a small pavilion that offered shade to describe Indian life in Mexico. There were six men, all in their 20's or 30's. Not one had even a peso in his pocket; not one could remember the last time he had eaten meat; all had had family members stricken by cholera in an epidemic two years ago; only one had ever been to a hospital; only one could read.
"I'm more curious about things then my companions," said Anacleto Viegas Dimas, 37, who was one of those who marched to Mexico City in February. Learning Spanish and spending time with political organizers may have changed the way he sees the world, but his experience of life, his anger and his despair equal his friends'.
"They brought this here from outside," he said, rapping a huge church bell that hangs from the timbers of the pavilion. The bell is dated 1736, and was brought in by Augustinian missionaries who added "San Juan" to the village's Indian name.
"They tried to change our religion with this, they tried to change everything we had," he said. "But we were already here long, long before they came."
 
Land Transformed, But Not Their Lives
 Before the outsiders showed up, a fragile island in Mexico's distant corner was the whole world for a Maya fisherman named Gabuch. Life there meant caring for the stone monuments of his ancestors and gathering a Caribbean harvest so bountiful that even his dog ate lobster.
Now 51, Gabuch still lives on the island. His one-room hut is still without water, electricity or telephone but now it is surrounded by the luxury hotels that have turned his paradise into the glossy resort called Cancun.
Wherever they live, Mexico's Indians have seen their country transformed and, like Gabuch, most have watched progress pass them by.
"I knew this beach from when I was a child," he said. "Now I'm one of the forgotten ones."
Gabuch's situation represents what many Indians say is the same basic problem, which is not poverty but rather Mexico's inability to treat the Indians as an integral part of society, to honor their traditions without ignoring their hardships.
It is said that Mexico loves its Indians, so long as they are dead. Mexico builds proud monuments to Aztec warriors and strives to protect ancient ruins (now big tourist attractions), but the largest single concentration of Indians in the country lives on Mexico City's streets or sleeps in its doorways, selling 35-cent boxes of gum at street corners or knocking on the windows of stopped cars, palms turned up to beg.
If the rest of Mexican society seems to have trouble connecting today's Indians with the glorious past, so too do the Indians.
"The colonial period was very brutal," said Arturo Warman, former head of the National Indigenous Institute and now in charge of settling rural land disputes. "For the Indians to have maintained any connection with their past was in effect to have put their lives in danger."
As bad as is the discrimination in Mexico City, Mr. Warman said, it is often worse in the provinces. As late as the 1950's, Indians in San Cristobal de las Casas in Chiapas were expected to step off the narrow sidewalks when a white person came by. They still hold no political or economic positions in the city, although they are present on every street and in every market.
 
Language Barrier As High as Ever

At Totolzintla, in sight of a multimillion-dollar bridge on the just-opened superhighway to Acapulco, a dozen Nahua Indians in the town's primary school gather haphazardly under an awning. A pile of sticks serves as a desk, and they try to read a textbook written in Spanish, which most do not understand. The lesson on this day is the heroes of Mexico, including the Indian President, Benito Juarez, but not much is getting through.
"What good does it do for me to have a teaching certificate and to try to teach these kids anything if I only speak Spanish and they only understand Mexicano?" asked Vicente Cabrera Alonzo, 28, whose chair is a tin container. He used the term "Mexicano" to mean Nahuatl, the ancient idiom of the Aztecs and the language Emiliano Zapata used to win the loyalty of his revolutionary followers. About 1.4 million Indians speak Nahuatl, more than speak any other of Mexico's 56 Indian languages.
[President Salinas recently presented new textbooks written in 20 indigenous languages and 6 dialects that will be used by 170,000 Indian schoolchildren next year. The others will continue to use Spanish books.]
 
A Hunger for Justice Goes Unmet
 Mexican leaders have lamented the deficiencies and injustices Indians face. Years before Chiapas erupted, President Salinas said that erasing the inequities must be a priority.
In January 1992 the Mexican legislature approved a constitutional amendment that for the first time recognized Mexico's pluralism and acknowledged the right of Indians to their own culture and language. For some Indians, the measure was too ambiguous and too late.
"To be an Indian in Mexico is to be a human being without rights," said Marcelino Diaz de Jesus, a leader of the Nahua Indians of Guerrero. "I think it is that simple. Even a human being without rights struggles with ancestral hunger -- not a material hunger for what you eat, but a hunger for justice. This is what the Indians of Chiapas have shouted to the world."
Mr. Diaz de Jesus is unusual in that he is a Nahua who has attended a university. Last year he won a MacArthur Foundation leadership award, which helps him work with the Indians who live in the raw villages along the Balsas River. They all know his name and use it to exert authority and sway opinion almost as readily as they use the name of Subcommander Marcos.
Mr. Diaz de Jesus was one of those who marched to Mexico City. He met with Mr. Salinas and heard the President promise to respond to the demands in 60 days.
The President's word was enough for the Indians to believe that when they held their annual congress 60 days later in Guerrero, he would be there. After Chiapas, they reasoned, they would at least be listened to. But by the time the congress ended, neither the President nor anyone from his office had come.
That has not been the only disappointment. After Chiapas exploded, Mr. Salinas set up a national commission for the development of the Indian people, which held hearings across the country. A resulting package of legislative reforms is still months from being considered.
Many Indians never really expected much to change after Chiapas. Too much time had passed, too many demands were unfulfilled, too many complaints had gone unheard. To those like Juan Bautista Tux Ku, those with the most hardened eyes and the least ready smiles, it was clear that the bark of a rifle may be the only sound that is heard, but even violence is not an option for most.
Recently he was encountered on the long sandy road leading to Chumpon with a rifle over his shoulder.
"A rifle is all that counts, but look at what we have," he said, showing how his ancient firearm, used for hunting, was held together with an automobile hose clamp and a bent nail. "We are poor. Where are we going to find the arms to rise up?" Every shell is an expense. Every missed shot, a step closer to starvation.
"When it comes to us," he said, leaning on his rusty bicycle, gazing toward the sea, "the country just ends."
