HEADLINE: An End to Welfare?

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
For all its complexity, the welfare plan that President Clinton put forward today will be judged by one, seemingly simple standard: Does it deliver on his famous pledge "to end welfare as we know it"?
He has reasons to argue that it does. The President has proposed a set of work requirements far stricter than those advocated by his predecessors, and penalties that are far more severe. When his program is fully in place, women who refuse to join a work program will get no more money. Period. 
 But it is less certain whether Mr. Clinton's program will satisfy the expectation of fundamental change that his own, insistently bold language has helped create, and that his political opponents are eager to exploit.
Republicans moved quickly today to denounce the plan, with its slow phase-in, as tepid and small, a defense of welfare rather than an end to it. "Tinkering," said Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin.
 
Stealing the Welfare Issue
 But their fervor may reflect a fear that the President is stealing the issue. Though Congress is unlikely to act in the time left this year, Mr. Clinton's plan would bring the most significant change since the program began in the New Deal.
"This plan is a step toward ending the current welfare system," said Judith Gueron, president of the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation, a New York firm that evaluates welfare programs. "It's not as large a step as was promised, or as the public anticipates. But greater change would require spending a lot more money."
Mr. Clinton's plan would primarily affect women and children, the 14.3 million who receive monthly checks from Aid to Families with Dependent Children. Its rules would not apply to the mix of state welfare programs that cover single men and women or people with disabilities.
The President's plan would give recipients additional training, but would require those still on the rolls after two years to join a work program. For those who had not found jobs on their own, the programs would offer subsidized jobs at the minimum wage, whether with private employers, governments or nonprofit groups. For the public, the first surprise may be that the Clinton plan, like all work programs, would cost more than the status quo.
 
Expensive Phase-In Program
 It would spend $9.3 billion over five years on training, child care and job subsidies, and even that sum buys a phase-in so gradual that by 1999, only about 8 percent of the nation's welfare recipients will be working for their benefits.
And while the documents made public today do not say so, the plan is expected to cost more than twice as much in the second five years. An impatient public, recognizing little change, might balk at the bill before the program ever hits its stride. If the Government does not have the money to create the subsidized jobs, it could not enforce the two-year limit.
Beyond the pace at which it takes effect, Mr. Clinton's plan raises a more fundamental question: just how many of the nation's five million welfare families can really support themselves in the private economy?
The President took pains today to highlight success stories, standing beside a woman who had left public assistance for a clerk's job in the same Kansas City bank that once employed Harry S. Truman.
 
Marginal Impact of Training
 Mr. Clinton is betting that he can create more successes, especially if health care passes, since many women stay on welfare simply to get medical care for their children. "We ought to be able to do this in every community in the country," he said.
But many welfare mothers have woefully few skills, and research shows that even the best training programs only marginally trim the welfare rolls. If Mr. Clinton intends to make all welfare recipients work he may have to place many of them in a subsidized work program and endure the criticisms of cost and waste that government job programs attract.
With all the talk of "ending welfare," there has been little discussion of a related issue: ending poverty. The two are not the same.
The President hopes to tackle both problems, in part by providing health care and expanded tax credits to welfare mothers who go to work. He is also trying to collect more child support payments from absent fathers, so that one parent will not have to do the financial work of two.
And he is trying to fight poverty by deterring the soaring rate of out-of-wedlock births. The time limit is meant to supply one deterrent, by making welfare less attractive.
Mr. Clinton is supplementing that effort with a crusade against teen-age pregnancy that features grants to 1,000 schools and his own invocations to form stable families. "Governments don't raise children, people do," he said.
 
Praise From Moynihan
 Indeed, Mr. Clinton's strong remarks today about out-of-wedlock births pleased one of his critics, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who chastised the President earlier this year for dragging his feet.
"He's the first President in our history to have the courage and nobility to address the problem of out-of-wedlock birth," Mr. Moynihan said. The Senator has criticized time limits, but he was so pleased to hear the President talk about family breakdown that he vowed to co-sponsor the bill in the Senate.
Still, it is possible that the plan would leave the nation with more poor people, rather than fewer. The average mother with two children now receives cash payments of about $380 a month. Mr. Clinton's proposal does not raise that amount, and for some families it could lessen it.
For example, he would allow states to deny increased payments to families that have additional children. The difference is about $60 a month -- not much to many Americans, but a lot to those facing hunger or eviction.
The work program that Mr. Clinton proposes would impose tough penalties on women who refuse to join the program: cutting off all cash to the family for at least six months.
In a confidential memorandum last March, Mr. Clinton's aides acknowledged "the danger that in rare circumstances families will find themselves homeless or unable to care for their children."
There are also antipoverty implications in the President's financing strategy. About $7 billion of the $9.3 billion he would spend comes from cuts in other programs for the poor, including those now serving indigent immigrants and addicts.
While many Republicans were accusing Mr. Clinton today of sham reform, the differences between their proposals is less dramatic than their rhetoric. A bill sponsored by 163 House Republicans would also impose a two-year limit on benefits and place recipients in a work program.
 
Some Important Differences
 The Republicans would implement their program faster and finance it by cutting deeper into programs for immigrants. And after welfare recipients had spent three years in the work program, the Republicans would allow states to drop them altogether, leaving some families neither benefits nor a subsidized job, on the optimistic assumption that they will somehow manage.
Mr. Clinton, by contrast, has guaranteed a work program spot for all recipients, as long as they demonstrate they are genuinely seeking private work.
As it happened, Mr. Clinton made his announcement on the same day that Ms. Gueron made public a new study of what is often described as the nation's most successful welfare training program, in Riverside, Calif.
Three years after joining the program, participants were earning 40 percent more than a similar group of women who received no training. Still, their average earnings remained quite low -- less than $3,600 a year. And 41 percent of those who had entered the program were still on the rolls three years later.
What does that suggest for a two-year limit? "You'd have to have a very large, expensive work program at the end," Ms. Gueron said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Will Seek Voluntary Curbs on North Korean Arms Deals

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration decided today to seek a voluntary embargo on North Korean arms purchases and sales as part of its initial set of sanctions, American officials said today.
The effectiveness of a voluntary arms embargo against North Korea, which has become a worrisome exporter of weapons in recent years, has been vigorously debated within the Administration. But with the North continuing to defy international monitors and the Clinton Administration under fire from Congressional critics for its handling of North Korean issues, top Administration officials agreed at a White House meeting today to propose the arms trade ban. 
 The arms embargo is to be included in a proposed sanctions resolution that Madeleine K. Albright, the United States delegate to the United Nations, plans to circulate to members of the United Nations Security Council in the next day or two.
While the arms measure would strengthen the initial package of sanctions Washington is proposing, officials acknowledged that the Clinton Administration was keeping to its basic plan of delaying any move to impose strict economic sanctions, like a cutoff in the millions of dollars that Koreans living in Japan send to North Korea and an oil embargo.
Those tough measures would be held in reserve in an effort to deter the North Koreans from abandoning all constraints on its nuclear program, withdrawing entirely from the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and beginning to process the spent fuel from the reactor to make plutonium for nuclear weapons.
Or as a State Department spokesman, Michael McCurry, put it today, the Clinton Administration intends to proceed with its "phased-in approach" on economic sanctions. "It would address not only the past actions and behavior of the D.P.R.K. but it would also be designed to provide leverage for future possible actions by the North," Mr. McCurry added.
The White House meeting today on North Korea included Secretary of State Warren Christopher, Defense Secretary William Perry, Gen. John M. Shalikasvili and Ms. Albright.
It took place against the backdrop of rising concern over North Korea's nuclear weapons program and its continued defiance of the International Atomic Energy Agency.
North Korea alarmed American officials on Monday when it said it would withdraw from the agency and said the agency's inspectors would no longer be allowed inside the country. The agency had decided to cut off $250,000 in technical assistance after North Korea destroyed evidence of its past plutonium production.
The North Korean announcement, which it reaffirmed today in an official notice to the Clinton Administration, increased fears that the North Koreans would be able to begin producing additional plutonium without international monitoring.
But North Korea also has yet to follow through on its threat to expel the inspectors and allowed the monitors to do their routine checks at the nuclear reactor at Yongbyon today.
But the White House has also warned that Washington would consider pushing for quicker implementation of tough economic sanctions if North Korea evicted the inspectors.
Arms sales have become an important source of income for North Korea. The ballistic missiles North Korea has sold to Syria and Iran have also contributed to Mideast tensions.
Pentagon officials, who have favored a go-slow approach on sanctions, support the voluntary arms embargo to deter nations from buying and selling arms to North Korea.
But some Administration officials have been concerned that the voluntary arms embargo might become an empty gesture and undercut the credibility of American sanctions policy.
The embargo would not be enforced by a blockade. Instead, the Security Council would urge countries to obey it. And Administration officials say it is unlikely that Iran and some other countries would comply.

HEADLINE: U.S. Seeks Other Countries to Help Resettle Haitian Refugees

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
Worried that a flood of Haitian boat people will create major political and economic problems, the Clinton Administration is urging other countries to help resettle Haitians who are granted asylum.
So far only a few positive responses have been received, but Administration officials say they hope other countries will accept at least 5,000 Haitian refugees -- a figure some refugee groups say is far too optimistic. Last year, the United States accepted 1,700. 
 Expecting Florida and other states to be unhappy about accepting more Haitian refugees, Administration officials say their efforts demonstrate that they are doing their best to spread the burden.
 
Internationalizing Relocation
 "We want to internationalize the resettlement process," a senior official said. "We hope a large share will be taken by other countries."
Many Administration officials expect a surge in emigration once the United States begins interviewing Haitian boat people, probably this week, on a 1,000-bed Navy hospital ship anchored off Jamaica.
Some predict that about 2,000 Haitians a week will be interviewed aboard the ship, far more than the average number of Haitians, 130, that the Coast Guard intercepted at sea each week in the first five months of this year.
Administration officials discussed resettlement with other countries in the hemisphere last week in Brazil at an Organization of American States meeting.
Canada is one of the few countries to suggest that it is prepared to resettle some Haitians. One official predicted that countries with a tradition of accepting refugees, including France, Venezuela, New Zealand and Australia, were strong candidates for resettling Haitians.
The United States has asked the United Nations High Commissioner on Refugees to help it find other countries to accept Haitians.
After more than a week of wrangling, the Administration and the High Commissioner agreed last weekend on procedures for processing Haitian boat people that include giving them a very limited appeal process.
 
Interviews on Shipboard
 The Haitians are to be interviewed after Coast Guard vessels intercept them on the high seas and take them to the Navy ship anchored in Kingston harbor. The boat people will be given an opportunity to rest and receive medical attention before their interviews.
Concerned that many applicants would be rejected without thorough consideration of their claims, the High Commissioner pressed the Administration to grant an appeal process. The appeal will be a limited one in which Haitians can add information to their files after the interviewer informs them that their claims will be rejected.
Then a "quality assurance officer" from the Immigration and Naturalization Service will review the file and decide whether further discussion with the applicant is appropriate. Representatives of the High Commissioner can review applications and counsel Haitians to add information. The quality assurance officer will then make a final determination.
Haitians who are rejected will be sent back to Haiti within a few days. If accepted, they will be resettled in the United States or in other countries.
Advocates of Haitian refugees attacked the planned screening procedures today, especially the limited appeal process.
 
'A Very Meager Process'
 "It's probably a misnomer to call it an appeal," said Arthur Helton, director of migration programs for the Open Society Institute. "There is an effort to portray this as an extraordinarily generous arrangement. In my view, it's a very meager process in terms of procedural safeguards."
Many lawyers for Haitian refugees complain that the procedures neither allow the Haitians to have counsel nor give them time to assemble documents or witnesses.
In a letter to State Department officials, Kosi Asomani, the High Commissioner's special envoy for Haiti, did not hide his ambivalence about the agreement, saying he hoped that the procedures would be reviewed once land-based processing began.
The Administration plans in several weeks to begin land-based processing of Haitians in the Turks and Caicos Islands in the Caribbean.
One signal that worries lawyers for Haitian refugees is that some Administration officials predict that the percentage of Haitian boat people who are granted refugee status will not be much higher than the 5 percent who have been accepted in the last year.

HEADLINE: Under More Ethical Scrutiny, Many Senators Curbed Perks

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
Senators still traveled the world in 1993, but many of them held down the number of trips during a period of ethical scrutiny, financial disclosure reports showed today.
Trips financed by outside groups were not the only perk substantially down from past years. With all speakings fees required to go to charity, many senators reduced their number of speeches to special interests. 
 Some senators were more meticulous than ever in providing details in the annual disclosure forms.
For instance, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Delaware Democrat who heads the Senate Judiciary Committee, noted on his disclosure that he and his wife "drove to Syracuse at their own expense" so he could address his 1968 Syracuse University law school classmates.
Mr. Biden's only assets were six life insurance policies worth $1,001 to $15,000 and a Senate credit union account worth less than $1,001.
Senator William S. Cohen, Republican of Maine, noted that he had received $20,000 from Tri-Star International Creative Management in Los Angeles for a script he is writing. In addition, he will receive $5,000 when the script is completed.
Senator Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon, listed only one asset valued at more than $1,000 -- a Senate credit union account worth $5,000 to $15,001.
Some senators are multimillionaires, but others have little beyond their $133,600 Senate salaries. Senator Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island, has several investments of more than $1 million. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, has two blind trusts, each worth more than $1 million.
Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan, said on his form, "I do not accept honoraria, nor do I have payments made to charitable organizations in lieu of honoraria."
But Senator Carol Moseley-Braun, Democrat of Illinois, took a half-dozen trips last year, including trips to Boca Raton, Fla., and Toronto. She also earned $616 for charity with an appearance on the Arsenio Hall television show.
Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, made seven trips, including one to Switzerland for an economic conference and another to Tokyo for an international environmental conference.

HEADLINE: Croatian Leader Tours Sarajevo on Behalf of Bosnia Federation

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, June 14

 BODY:
Once reviled in this ravaged city, Croatia's President, Franjo Tudjman, visited Sarajevo today for the first time in the 26-month war to discuss a nascent Bosnian federation of Muslims and Croats allied to his country.
"We are at the end of the tragedy that this city and the Muslim nation, and together with it the Croatian nation, had to experience," Mr. Tudjman said as he formally dedicated a new Croatian Embassy here. 
 Just five months ago, Mr. Tudjman stood behind the Croatian nationalists fighting Bosnia and Herzegovina's Muslim-led Government. Since then Muslims and Croats have joined in an alliance against the Serbs, who have captured 70 percent of Bosnia since the war began in April 1992.
After meeting with Bosnia's President, Alija Izetbegovic, Mr. Tudjman strolled on Sarajevo's main downtown street under heavy security to the embassy, shaking hands with pedestrians as some shouted in approval and others jeered.
Dedicating the embassy, he said his trip was "proof of our support for the Croat-Muslim federation as well as the formation of a future confederation with Croatia." Mr. Tudjman's visit came on the eve of a scheduled parliamentary session in which Croatian and Muslim leaders are to fill positions in the Government.
The Parliament has already approved a constitution and linked Muslim and Croatian military commands. But Western diplomats lament the lack of progress in organizing the federation, especially on the local level.
In most areas of Bosnia with mixed populations of Muslims and Croats, often antagonistic local administrations are still in place. Restrictions still prevent refugees in divided areas from returning to homes in areas controlled by the other side.
Fierce fighting between the Croats and Muslims in central Bosnia claimed thousands of lives and uprooted tens of thousands of people before the United States and Roman Catholic clerics persuaded Mr. Tudjman early this year to replace the nationalist Croatian leader, Mate Boban, and agree to form a federation.
Today local radio reports described renewed clashes between Croatian and mostly Muslim Bosnian Army forces near the western town of Mostar as well as fighting that has pitted Muslim against Muslim in a pocket of Muslim separatists near the northwestern town of Bihac.
The fighting is marring a four-week cease-fire that took effect in Bosnia on Friday. Still, clashes in the country have sharply declined overall since last week, the United Nations military command says.
Some analysts say the Bosnian Government Army and the Croatian militia are using the one-month respite to stock arsenals, and several are predicting a surge in fighting against the Serbs this fall.
Bosnian Government officials openly admit they are buying weapons from the Croatian militia in Bosnia, which is supplied by Croatia's Army, and obtaining arms shipped by Muslim countries through Croatian ports and airports. The United Nations has maintained an arms embargo against countries of the former Yugoslavia since September 1991.
A joint statement issued by Mr. Tudjman and Mr. Izetbegovic indicated that the mostly Muslim Bosnian Government has pledged to help Croatia form economic ties with Islamic countries in exchange for economic cooperation from Croatia, including the use of ports, roads, railroads and telecommunications links.
Mr. Tudjman and Mr. Izetbegovic, who once made little effort to hide their mutual dislike, also agreed today to form embassies with mixed delegations and other diplomatic missions for Croatia and Bosnia.
Mr. Tudjman and his retinue, which included at least one former Croatian commander condemned as a war criminal, flew later by helicopter to Vitez and Busovaca in central Bosnia for meetings with Croatian political and military leaders.

HEADLINE: Centrist Presidential Hopeful in Brazil Trips on Racial Remark

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 13

 BODY:
Wearing a monogrammed shirt that recalled his days teaching at the Sorbonne, the Brazilian presidential candidate gamely posed for photos astride a peasant's donkey.
Responding to a Brazilian reporter who asked if he was the country's "great white hope," Fernando Henrique Cardoso, who seems white to most observers, responded hotly, "I really am mulatto." 
 "I have one foot in the kitchen," Mr. Cardoso continued, using an archaic phrase that refers to Brazil's long history of sexual liaisons between members of the European elite and their household servants, largely of African descent.
In the ensuing uproar, black rights leaders denounced the candidate as racist and newspaper cartoonists painted him brown and depicted him walking with one foot in a cooking pot.
With less than four months to go until the Oct. 3 presidential election, a series of stumbles are frustrating Mr. Cardoso's ambitions of becoming the centrist candidate capable of defeating Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva.
Three opinion polls taken in recent weeks show Mr. Cardoso, a former Economy Minister, stalled in second place with 17 percent of voter preferences. In first place, Mr. Silva, candidate of the Workers Party, enjoyed support ranging from 35 to 40 percent.
Jose Sarney, a former President with a keen eye for discerning power flows, commented on the polls, "There is no human force in the world capable of keeping Lula from winning these elections."
In retort, members of Mr. Cardoso's fractious center-right coalition argue that today's polls are largely irrelevant.
Next Friday, the monthlong World Cup soccer championship is to start in the United States, and Brazil is expected to go on a monthlong political siesta. Then, in August, free political advertising starts on television.
In the 1989 presidential campaign, a few weeks of television exposure was enough to raise Mr. da Silva from 5 percent of opinion preferences to 40 percent. This time, to sabotage the leftist candidacy, Congress has passed a law restricting television advertising to candidates talking in studios.
Mr. Cardoso's goal is to deny his socialist opponent a majority victory in October, forcing a runoff on Nov. 15. To do this, his backers have adapted a two-pronged strategy -- heavy campaign spending and close identification with a new economic plan.
According to campaign budget estimates filed last week, Mr. Cardoso's coalition plans to outspend the Workers Party by more than a 2 to 1 ratio -- $75 million to $30 million.
In the economic plan, Brazil is to change currencies on July 1, selling reserves to maintain parity between the dollar and the new currency, the real.
Several months of low inflation and of greater buying power are supposed to make Brazilian voters forget that prices have risen by 4,000 percent over the last 12 months and that today's per capita income is slightly less than the level of 1985.
Possibly spoiling this strategy, Brazilian voters increasingly seem to be "vaccinated" against pre-election "miracle" plans, political scientists here warn.
For his part, Mr. da Silva has steadily repositioned himself closer to Brazil's political center.
"I'm going to fight for foreign investment to come to this country," the former trade union leader bellowed at a public rally in Sao Paulo on Sunday.
Last week, the Workers Party approved a "Lula Brasil" campaign symbol that drastically reduces the use of socialist red. For use on T-shirts, flags and bumper stickers, the new symbol prominently features the green, blue and yellow colors of Brazil's flag.
Further bolstering Mr. da Silva's centrist, presidential image, Mr. Sarney, the former President, hinted last week that he might endorse the Workers Party candidate.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Picks Up Support From Rally in U.S. Bonds

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar was little changed yesterday against leading currencies, rebounding from early losses after the American bond market rallied on a report showing that inflation remained subdued.
"The rally in bonds gave the dollar some support," said Earl Johnson, foreign exchange adviser at Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago. "When there's demand for Treasury bonds, there's demand for dollars." 
 In late trading yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 1.6470 German marks, up from 1.6455 marks Monday. It had dropped as low as 1.6412 marks before bonds advanced.
 Bond prices rallied after the Labor Department said consumer prices rose two-tenths of a percentage point in May. The report suggested that the economic recovery would not overheat and fuel inflation, which erodes the value of bonds.
"If bonds had tanked, the dollar would have been in real trouble," said Win Thin, an economist at MCM Currency Watch, a market consulting firm.
The dollar fell in European trading amid growing speculation that central bankers in Germany and Japan were under less pressure to lower interest rates now that their countries' economies were showing signs of picking up. At the same time, fewer traders expect the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates soon given the mounting evidence that economic growth may be slowing. Higher rates and economic performance tend to bolster the value of a country's currency.
Speculation that the Treasury might call on the Fed and other central banks to buy dollars also kept the American currency from falling further yesterday, traders said. Based on yesterday's exchange rates against the mark, the dollar is below the levels at which the Fed and 18 other central banks teamed up to buy dollars on May 4.
The dollar fell slightly against the yen yesterday. The dollar was quoted in late New York trading at 102.78 yen, down from 102.90 yen.
Tensions between the United States and North Korea have not helped the dollar against the yen, traders said, because many investors are skeptical of President Clinton's ability to handle the conflict. Investors often buy dollars as a haven during international crises. But many are now buying Swiss francs instead because of that country's policy of neutrality.
In other trading, the British pound was quoted at $1.5195 late yesterday, down from $1.5215 late Monday. The dollar fell to 5.6040 French francs from 5.6125 francs and rose to 1,597 Italian lire from 1,594 lire.

HEADLINE: New Law Against Age Bias on Campus Clogs Academic Pipeline, Critics Say

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
The historian Richard Pipes, who will turn 70 next month, can go on teaching at Harvard University for the rest of his life if he so chooses. But his departmental colleague Bernard Bailyn was obligated to retire last year, after his own 70th birthday.
The two professors saw the later stages of their working lives take such contrary directions not because of differences in their performances at Harvard -- both are highly regarded in their field -- but because of a new Federal law that took effect in January prohibiting mandatory retirement on the basis of age for tenured faculty members. 
 Since the new law has given professors like Mr. Pipes far more control over how and when to retire, many are now continuing to teach after the age of 70. And that, critics of the new arrangement say, is just the trouble: they fear not only the prospect of graying faculties teaching from yellowing notes but also the possibility that young academicians will be blocked from advancement in an already tight job market.
 
Some Unintended Effects
 "Clear the deck," said Cheryl Rock, 40, an assistant professor of human nutrition at the University of Michigan, who opposes the elimination of mandatory retirement. "The old professors are holding back the university."
Oscar Handlin, 78, an emeritus professor of history at Harvard, agrees. "The new law clogs the arteries," said Professor Handlin, who has published five books since his retirement eight years ago. "It won't allow young people to move in."
Moreover, Thomas Bisson, chairman of the department of history at Harvard, said that although the new law, an amendment to the Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967, had been intended to eliminate age bias, it was having the reverse effect: deans and department chairmen, he said, are now reluctant to hire elderly job candidates for fear that they might later cling to their jobs.
And attempts to remedy the situation by creating inducements to voluntary retirement have created unforeseen problems of their own.
 
Studies on Consequences
 While most academic administrators say it is still too soon to know how the new arrangement will ultimately affect faculties, there has been plenty of time for colleges and universities to contemplate the possible consequences.
In 1991, a National Research Council committee concluded that a high proportion of faculty members at the nation's elite research institutions would choose to work past the age of 70 because they found the life congenial and their work stimulating. (The panel also reported that there was little evidence that scholarly ability diminished with age. But Saunders MacLane, an 84-year-old emeritus professor of mathematics at the University of Chicago, challenged that claim. The research council's study, he argued, did not take into account the experience of professors past 70 because under previous retirement practices, few such faculty members existed.)
A second study on the possible effect of eliminating mandatory retirement -- this one conducted in 1991 by Stephen Stigler, a professor of statistics at the University of Chicago -- suggested that the top-tier research universities would not be alone in retaining an elderly faculty.
"We studied not only the elite private universities like Columbia, Stanford and the University of Chicago, but also public institutions like the University of Michigan and California State University at San Diego, and we found no significant differences in the rate of departure," Professor Stigler said. "We projected that by the year 2000, 10 percent of the faculty at all of these institutions will be above the age of 70. What's troublesome is not that they will be undesirable but our inability to hire young faculty at that point."
Some administrators do worry about the quality of teaching with an older faculty. Jeremy Knowles, dean of the faculty of arts and sciences at Harvard and a former professor of molecular biology, said the loss of ability to teach with increasing age was most pronounced in the sciences. "Methodological changes tend to be much more rapid in the sciences than in the humanities," he said, "and that gets increasingly difficult to keep up with as the years go by."
 
Inducements to Retirement
 To guard against being overrun with elderly professors, a number of research institutions recently began to take steps to make retirement more attractive.
"We don't say 'retired' anymore; we say 'emeritus status,' " Dean Knowles said. "We've done things to make the transition less like dropping off the end of the earth. For example, some emeriti may be asked to teach freshman seminars."
Because of a separate economic trend, however, incentives for retirement are nothing new, and they are a mixed blessing. Decreasing appropriations from financially beleaguered state legislatures have prompted some public colleges and universities -- notably the University of California at Berkeley and several New England schools -- to use well-funded pension plans to finance buyouts of senior professors and thus help lift the burden of large, perhaps too large, faculties.
For several years, these institutions have been encouraging senior professors to retire, because in many cases the buyouts and subsequent pension payments are financed by budgets separate from those that finance university operations; the schools are thus provided substantial savings.
Many professors responding to the early-retirement incentives have left their institutions in random patterns. That has frequently disrupted the curriculum. Moreover, relatively few openings have been created for younger teachers, because the incentives were conceived not to make way for a new generation but to reduce overall faculty size with the aim of trimming budgets.
 
A Flight of Faculty
 Since these buyouts must be offered across the board, there is no telling which faculty members will take them. As a result, some departments have been battered. Berkeley has lost 28 percent of its faculty over the last three years, prompting Chancellor Chang-Lin Tien "to lay down on the tracks," as he puts it, in an effort to curb the practice.
Bruce Stave, chairman of the department of history at the University of Connecticut, said the State Assembly "created havoc in 1992 because it offered golden handshakes but refused to authorize replacements."
"This year is also very hard for us," he said, "with 4 retirees in a department of 31."
Some educators look upon this wave of retirements approvingly, regarding the windfalls as being well deserved by dedicated and hard-working teachers.
Neil Smelser, 63, a widely published sociologist at Berkeley, will double his salary in September, when he retires from the university at full pay and starts work as the director of the Center for Advanced Studies in the Behavioral Sciences at Stanford University. "It should happen to everyone!" he said.
Others see the phenomenon more ominously. "The Smelser case," said Ernst Benjamin, general secretary of the American Association of University Professors, "is an example of a hard-pressed public university losing someone of great quality to a private institution. That's a matter of concern."
Some observers of higher education express surprise that there has been no widespread protest against the new law by the young faculty members who are sure to be thwarted by it. Interviews with a number of college and university teachers in their 20's and 30's suggest that many see the long-range benefits to themselves as outweighing the short-range cost.
Daniel Gordon, 33, an assistant professor of history at Harvard, spoke for many in his generation when he said: "It takes so long to get a Ph.D. these days -- 10 years at Columbia or Berkeley -- that people in the humanities tend to start their careers later. For that reason, I'm glad about the change in the law, because I myself may not wish to retire when I'm 70."

HEADLINE: Once a Resort, Village Struggles With Urban Problems

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SPRING VALLEY, N.Y.

 BODY:
Claudie Pierre owned a clothing boutique on Main Street here not long ago. But as this once-rustic village changed, so did her line of work.
Like a charity worker, she now helps people find jobs and housing, provides children with a place to stay while their parents work and offers translation in French, Creole and Spanish for new immigrants -- all from a rundown storefront on the street where she once catered to fashion tastes. 
 "I do a little bit of everything," she said the other day while receiving clients at her new venture, The Open Door, the private social-service agency that she started with her own money last year. "There are many people who need help."
Ms. Pierre is dealing with many of the problems that in a generation have transformed Spring Valley from a thriving summer resort to a community facing a range of urban ills.
 
Increase in Violence
 Struggling families -- many of them new immigrants but many with roots in the area -- double and triple up in apartments and houses in Spring Valley. Unemployed men stand on street corners awaiting offers of jobs as day laborers. Young men walk the streets peddling drugs. And violence -- including the killing of three people in recent months -- is on the rise.
It wasn't always that way in Spring Valley. Just a generation ago, city dwellers flocked to its bungalows, camps, lodges and resort hotels in the summer to escape the city.
But Spring Valley lost its allure as a vacation destination beginning in the 1960's as suburbanization and the advent of modern highways and the Tappan Zee Bridge made Rockland County more accessible to New York City and Westchester commuters.
The village became a magnet for struggling families. Landlords began converting vacation houses into cheap rentals. In a county where most people own their homes, Spring Valley has the highest number of rental units, and 59 percent of the village's residents are renters.
"All of these modern pressures have contributed to the problems in the village," said Bob Rubin, Spring Valley's historian. "The changes have turned Spring Valley into a place of typically urban problems."
 
A Cosmopolitan Flavor
 Still, there have been some advantages to the urban atmosphere that Spring Valley has acquired. The steady arrival of the new immigrants, mainly from Haiti, Jamaica, Guatemala and El Salvador, has given the village new energy and a cosmopolitan flavor.
In the heart of Main Street, there are Haitian political and social clubs, a law office specializing in immigration and restaurants and groceries offering spices, jerk chicken, curry goat, stewed oxtail and beef patties. The parks and playgrounds are filled with West Indian cricketers and soccer players on most weekends.
The village still has many solid neighborhoods of working- and middle-class families, including large numbers of Hasidim who have been in the village for decades.
"There is a kind of vibrancy and diversity here that one doesn't usually find in suburbia," said Winsome Downie-Rainford, the president of a social-service group called the Martin Luther King Multi-Service Center. "We've got 25 nationalities in one small village."
But a measure of the pressures that the changes have brought is the rapid growth of Spring Valley's population. This rise has been fueled by the steady influx of the new immigrants attracted here by cheap rentals and opportunities for unskilled laborers.
According to the 1990 Census, some 22,000 people live in the three-square-mile village of Spring Valley. But village officials and community leaders say that just based on increased garbage collection, for instance, the village actually has some 50,000 people, including a large number of illegal immigrants.
 
Looking for More Aid
 As a result, officials have been grappling with a variety of problems, including landlords in the poorer sections who have been illegally converting one- and two-family houses into overcrowded multifamily dwellings. Two months ago, the village hired an additional housing inspector to keep pace with the problem.
The situation is so severe that the new Mayor, Allan Thompson, recently proposed having the village declared a city to make it eligible for more state and Federal aid.
"We can't afford to let these problems fester," said Mr. Thompson, an immigrant from Jamaica who said he overcame poverty and homelessness.
Juan Nunez, 21, has shared a two-bedroom bungalow with five other men since he arrived from Guatemala several weeks ago. On most mornings, he and his roommates, also from Guatemala, stand near the edge of Route 59 in the hope of securing low-paying jobs like laying bricks, planting trees, mowing lawns, tending gardens and cleaning homes.
It is a hard life, he said. But Mr. Nunez plans to make do until he has saved enough money to return to his homeland and family with a stake for a better life. "I wish it could be different," he said.
 
Emerging Drug Trade
 In a village where 12 percent of the official population lives below the poverty line and the official unemployment rate has soared to 13 percent, community leaders say that services like job training, youth counseling and family assistance are so scarce that problems like crime have been aggravated.
The village's crime figures for 1993 list 180 burglaries, 58 stolen cars and 872 cases of larceny. There were also 172 crimes committed with guns, up from 16 in the previous year. There have been 2 killings, 5 rapes and 40 assaults.
The potential for violence has been magnified with the emergence of a small but steady drug trade. The drug problem has taken root here in part because the village -- a crossroads of bus lines and highways -- is a convenient spot to buy and sell drugs.
"Any time you add drugs to a community that is struggling you will have a combustible situation," said Nathan Mungin 3d, the program director for the King Center.
Thinking that he had left behind the kind of problems he had faced in East Harlem, Wayne Scurry Jr., 16, settled here recently with his father. But he discovered that Spring Valley was not the suburban haven he expected. His cousin was slashed during a fight in a local playground.
"It's still a lot different from the city," he said. "But I was surprised at finding so many bad things here."
Last November, 30 people stood by as a man was shot dead in the village's downtown. Not a single witness has come forward.
"We even had one teen-ager who said she didn't want to talk about it because she didn't care," Police Chief Howard Goldin said. "That's scary."
To combat the crime, Spring Valley has begun an aggressive campaign. The police department plans to hire three officers for community policing in a troubled section known as The Hill. The first police precinct station separate from police headquarters is being built near Main Street. Seven part-time officers were hired to patrol the downtown district at the urging of residents and business people.
In a county whose population is largely white, Spring Valley has become a magnet for both fears and enthusiasm.
David Zuber, a mortgage consultant who lives in nearby Pomona, said that many people in his town fear that Spring Valley's struggling population will ruin the local school district that both communities share. But he disagrees.
"Some of the fears are based on reality, and some of them are based on perception," he said. "But I'm happy to be living near a place with so much variety and diversity."
He added, "If I'm in the mood for plantains or any other Caribbean food, I go to Spring Valley; I'm not going to find it at the Grand Union."

HEADLINE: Cruise Lines Betting That Bigger Will Be Better

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
Driven by resurgent bookings, younger passengers and a bit of "our ship is bigger than your ship," the cruise industry is in the midst of a construction boom that will create some of the biggest passenger ships ever seen.
At least 28 ships are scheduled to be launched through 1998, including a 100,000-ton giant from Princess that is expected to carry 2,600 passengers and will be far larger than the 76,049-ton Norway, the biggest ship afloat. 
 The Princess ship topped by 5,000 tons a Carnival ship announced last June, but industry analysts said they would not be surprised if Carnival again raised the ante. Even the Walt Disney Company is getting into the act, starting its own cruise line and ordering two jumbo vessels, each holding 2,400 passengers.
 
Most in Half a Century
 The construction boom will add at least 44,000 passenger berths -- a 40 percent gain over current capacity and the biggest four-year gain, by far, since the golden age of ocean liners more than a half a century ago.
Executives in the cruise industry do not think they will have trouble filling those cabins. Despite the recent recession, the annual number of passengers has jumped from 1.4 million in 1980 to a projected five million this year. And the Cruise Lines International Association, a trade group, predicts eight million passengers annually by the year 2000.
More younger people are taking to the sea in ships for their vacations. Twenty-nine percent of first-time passengers before 1989 were 25 to 40 years old; that is now up to 46 percent, and the mean age of first-time passengers has fallen from to 43 percent from 51 percent.
"The recession is over," said Janice Farmer, formerly a cruise-line analyst for Raymond James & Associates in St. Petersburg, Fla. "The industry's now targeting people 35 to 54, a sector that will grow 30 percent by the year 2000 and will take longer vacations and spend more."
To fill the ships, cruise lines have been advertising heavily. Between them two industry giants, Carnival Cruise Lines and Royal Caribbean Cruises, spent almost $82 million in advertising last year. And lines are developing a variety of niche markets, including conferences and meetings, honeymoons, family cruises and cruises built around themes like sports, music and education.
And taking a page from the airlines, which use yield management to fine-tune supply and demand, they have discounted some fares rather than see ships sail with many empty cabins.
But with construction costs for the new ships running as high as $160,000 for each passenger berth compared with $105,000 per berth for big ships ordered in the mid-1980's, the industry needs higher yields per passenger and expects to get them. Although cruise prices are not expected anytime soon to rise above current fares, which average $175 to $225 a person a day, usually including return air fare, new ships typically charge a premium of 25 percent to 30 percent.
"New ships stimulate demand so they're able to charge premium prices," said Warren H. Lieberman, a cruise analyst for Decision Focus Inc., a management consulting company in Mountain View, Calif. Mr. Lieberman estimated that industry revenue would reach $8 billion to $10 billion by the year 2000, compared with about $6 billion this year.
 
Where the Money Is
 "The mega-ships are generating a 20 to 30 percent return on investment," said Paul Mackey, a cruise-industry specialist at Dean Witter. "As long as they can do that, they'll continue to build ships."
The industry now has 131 ships and 103,000 berths. Although some of the new ships will be replacing older ones being retired, most of those berths are likely to be added capacity, which most analysts said the industry should be able to absorb.
"But it begins to get a little hairy when you get into 1998," Mr. Mackey said. "We'd better be right that the industry is going to keep growing about 10 percent a year."
More Stringent Fire Regulations
Moreover, late in 1997, cruise ships will be required to comply with tighter fire codes. "Ships built before 1960 have the greatest probability of being retired from service," Ms. Farmer said. "It may not be worth it to spend $20 or $30 million to bring them up to code."
But with the industry growing so rapidly, cruise lines are not likely to automatically consign older ships to the scrap heap. The S.S. France, built in 1960 for voyages between New York and Le Havre, now sails between Miami and the Caribbean as the Norway of the Norwegian Cruise Line -- after a $50 million overhaul.
The Orient Lines' Marco Polo, a luxury liner with menus created by Wolfgang Puck, was originally a Soviet spy ship, the Aleksandr Pushkin, built in East Germany in 1965.
The new vessels will have atriums, multimillion-dollar art collections, high-tech gymnasiums and spas, plush casinos and theaters that seat as many as 1,200.
Towering high above the new ships -- at least on the drawing board -- is the Phoenix World City, a $1 billion giant that its backers envision as having three hotel towers above deck and more than a dozen restaurants for its 6,400-passengers -- almost 4,000 more than any cruise ship sailing today.
"The Phoenix World City won't be just a floating hotel when it's built, it will be more like a floating island," said Ernst Frankel, professor of ocean systems at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Mr. Frankel is the senior adviser to the World City Corporation of New York, which hopes to build three such ships, although many industry officials are skeptical that the often-postponed Phoenix World City will ever be built.
 
No Boon for U.S. Shipyards
 The construction binge will be good for passengers, but is expected to do little for the United States' moribund shipbuilding industry, as almost all the new vessels will be built in Europe. It will have little direct effect on other American jobs because most crew members are expected to be foreign nationals.
Yet a Price Waterhouse study last year said that while the cruise industry provided 64,000 jobs directly, it was the indirect source of 385,000 more in industries like farming and ranching -- which supply the ships with fruit, vegetables and beef -- as well as restaurants that serve passengers in port cities.
These are among the cruise lines and their plans:
*Royal Caribbean has contracted for two 1,800-passenger ships for delivery in 1995 and 1996, and for a 1,950-passenger ship late in 1996 with an option for a second delivered in 1997.
*Princess Cruises will spend almost $1 billion for three ships to be delivered by 1997, including the record-breaking 100,000-ton vessel. The ships will increase the Princess fleet to 12 and passenger capacity by 70 percent.
*Celebrity Cruises, in business only since 1991, has ordered two new 1,740-passenger ships for delivery no later than 1997.
*Crystal Cruises is building a 960-passenger ship, for delivery next year, with what it says will be the largest penthouses at sea and a casino managed by Caesars Palace.
*Carnival Corporation, one of only a few public cruise companies (along with Royal Caribbean and American Classic Voyages Company), spent more than $3 billion on 11 ships from 1990 through 1996. That includes four ships for its Holland America subsidiary, which added two 1,200-passenger ships last year and will add two more by 1996.
To increase space in cabins and restaurants, and because the Caribbean is the biggest destination, the mega-ships being built for Princess and Carnival will each be too wide to transit the 110-foot-wide locks of the Panama Canal. They will remain in the Caribbean -- the first passenger vessels in years to forgo cruising in both the Atlantic and the Pacific.
With all these huge ships coming from the big companies, the smaller cruise lines fear being squeezed. Many of the smaller companies have focused on niches, like personalized, luxury cruises and adventure trips, and are expected to do more of that as the biggest ships are launched. And even the smaller lines are building ships.
 
The High End
 Silversea Cruises, for example, is adding two 296-passenger luxury vessels this year and is building two 350-passenger luxury ships for delivery in 1996. Radisson, the hotel company, is building a 232-passenger, all-suites ship, which will cater to business people. Seabourn Cruise Line, whose two luxury ships carry fewer than 300 passengers each, expects to build three more by 1997.
The most unusual small ship may be the American Queen, the $60 million, 420-passenger steamboat being built for the American Classic Voyages Company at McDermott Inc.'s shipyard in Amelia, La. Although small compared with the mega-ships, the American Queen will be the biggest vessel for overnight cruises built in a United States shipyard in more than 40 years.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Wrongly perhaps, traders find soft drinks less than refreshing.

BYLINE: By Kenneth N. Gilpin 

 BODY:
INVESTORS willing to buck the stock market's current inclination to look no farther than the end of its own nose might consider shares in beverage companies, a long-term growth segment that has fallen badly out of fashion lately.
The beverage group was shaken last week when Pepsico Inc. disappointed Wall Street by disclosing that second-quarter profits would be flat, rather than ahead of last year, as had been expected. 
 Pepsi's shares plunged $3 that day, to $31.50, and the shock has still not worn off. Pepsi closed yesterday at $31.875, up $0.50, which is a discount of more than 25 percent from its 52-week high of a little more than $41 a share.
Analysts attribute Pepsi's current problems to vicious price competition among colas and so-called New Age beverages, and to slow growth at its restaurant chains.
Some of these difficulties are unique to Pepsi, but investors have apparently assumed they are shared by its competitors, because the stock prices of most of its rivals are also trading near the bottom of their 52-week ranges.
Coca-Cola, for example, which derives only 6 percent of its total worldwide business from supermarket sales in the United States, where price competition is the stiffest, closed at $39.875 yesterday, $1 a share over its 52-week low of $38.875.
Dr Pepper/Seven-Up Companies closed yesterday at $23.625, just over $2 a share above its 52-week low of $21.25, even though Dr Pepper is one of the country's fastest-growing soft drinks.
And Snapple Beverage, one of Wall Street's hottest initial public offerings two years ago, has also fallen back, even while volume growth of its real-brewed tea and juice-based drinks continues to expand at annual rates of more than 100 percent. On the over-the-counter Nasdaq market yesterday, Snapple's shares closed at $24.50, just above the 52-week low of $21, adjusted for stock splits.
Some Wall Street analysts said this pressure on stock prices showed more a lack of perspective among investors than a seminal change in the economics of the beverage business.
"The soft drink industry has been intensely competitive for about two decades," said William Leach, who follows it for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, and what is going on now "is not that different from what we have seen historically."
Analysts who are bullish on the industry's future say that investors are overlooking growth prospects in foreign markets. Huge capital investments have been made in these markets over the last few years, and a cyclical upswing overseas will lift soft drink revenues, they said.
"It is within consumer nondurables industries that American companies possess unassailable worldwide competitive advantages," Roy D. Burry, an analyst at Kidder, Peabody, wrote in a recent report on the beverage industry's outlook.
"Major returns from this investment are anticipated during the second half of the 1990's."
Given Coca-Cola's extensive global reach -- 80 percent of its revenues come from outside the United States -- Mr. Burry upgraded Coke's shares to a "strong buy" recommendation.
Mr. Leach said that at the $31 level, Pepsi looked like a "dandy buy," but he laughingly admitted he had the same thought at a higher price. At current prices, he said, he also likes Coca-Cola.
"Statistically, Pepsi's price looks cheap," said George Thompson, a beverage industry analyst at Prudential Securities.
"But I don't think that is going to make any difference at the moment, because people are not looking at the long haul right now."
Pepsi's announcement last week caused Joseph Doyle, Smith Barney's beverage analyst, to downgrade Pepsi to "outperform" for the next year from "buy." He cautioned, "For the next six months, I think it will be dead money."
Emmanuel Goldman, the beverage anlayst at Paine Webber, currently has a buy recommendation on Snapple and Dr Pepper/7-Up shares.
"Snapple's whole product category is exploding," he said, "and while there is price competition, it is not the same as in carbonated soft drinks."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Lofty Copper Prices Tumble And Commodity Index Falls

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Copper prices tumbled yesterday, and an important commodity index fell for the first time in five trading session.
The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities declined two-tenths of a point, to 235.30, helped by stabilizing prices for commodities from coffee to grains. The index, a closely watched gauge of inflation, rose 2.62 points on Monday, and is up nearly 5 percent this year. 
 "The current rally by the C.R.B. index is temporarily taking center stage in the financial markets," Gary Thayer, senior economist with A. G. Edwards, said before yesterday's dip in the index.
 Copper prices had recently climbed to 21-month highs. Stocks of copper held in warehouses have been shrinking as a result of growing demand from recovering industries. But prices retreated yesterday. The copper contract for delivery in July fell 1.4 cents, to 110 cents a pound.
 
Comments on Copper
 "I think the climate in the copper market right now is speculative," one trader said. "But the market will go higher in the long term due to improving fundamentals."
Mike Frawley, an analyst with Dean Witter, said, "We view the market as still being somewhat vulnerable price-wise but over all the long-term fundamentals are still quite positive and higher prices are expected."
Grain prices also stagnated after a volatile two weeks caused by unusually dry spring weather. Much of the activity, however, was in the options market, where traders sought to take advantage of increasing concerns about crops.
On the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday, the July contract for soybeans edged down 0.25 cent, to $6.905 a bushel; July corn firmed 0.5 cent, to $2.7525, and July wheat declined 3.75 cents, to $3.375 a bushel.
 After a sharp rally on Monday, coffee prices steadied yesterday, with the July contract up 0.15 cent, at $1.3845 cents a pound, on the New York Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange. Estimates of a smaller world coffee crop this year and next caused prices to jump to around five-year highs.
July crude oil firmed 16 cents, to $18.95 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, where analysts were anxiously awaiting weekly inventory data.
After the close of trading, the American Petroleum Institute reported oil stocks fell 2.2 million barrels, but by only 12,000 barrels in the closely watched Midwest region where supplies have been tight.
July unleaded gasoline gained 0.26 cent, to 52.18 cents a gallon, and July heating oil rose 0.29 cent, to 47.93 cents.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
USAir Sees Initial Savings Of $175 Million Under Plan

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: ARLINGTON, Va., June 14

 BODY:
USAir Group Inc. said today that it would save $175 million starting this year under an ambitious, previously announced plan to slash its operating costs during the next three years.
USAir said the initial $175 million in savings would take place through management and staff reductions and subcontracting of cargo and air-mail handling. The carrier did not disclose the details of planned cuts in the work force. 
 The airline, which is based here, lost nearly $197 million in the first quarter and has some of the highest fixed costs in the United States airline industry. USAir said it was discussing salary and benefit reductions with its labor unions.
USAir added that as soon as one of its three unions agreed to a cost-cutting program, the airline would institute the plan with all its nonunion employees.
The airline's previously announced plan called for savings of more than $1 billion annually during the next three years.
 
 
Labor Cost Cuts Needed
 "While improved operating efficiencies and innovative new service products are certainly key elements in our total plan, we need labor cost reductions of at least $500 million annually, or about one-half of the total," Seth E. Schofield, chairman and chief executive of USAir, said.
About half of USAir's 44,000 employees are represented by unions. Many took wage cuts in the last several years as the airline industry lost billions of dollars because of the weak economy and overexpansion.
Mr. Schofield added that the cost savings "will enable us to meet our short-term goal of being cost-competitive with the low-cost carriers that have obviously targeted USAir's East Coast markets."
USAir said in its 1993 annual report that competition could have an impact on its ability to sustain operations.
Last Thursday, union officials representing USAir's pilots, flight attendants, machinists and dispatchers met in Pittsburgh to discuss strategy and review an analysis prepared by their financial advisers.
The airline appealed to its unions in March for potential concessions in a bid to revamp its operations and slash expenses.
Shares of USAir were up 12.5 cents, at $6.625, on the New York Stock Exchange today.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Ad Spending Forecast Is Revised Upward

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT 

 BODY:
The straws in the wind indicating growth in advertising spending after years of sluggishness are beginning to accumulate into a tidy haystack. But no one is yet trying to spin the straws into gold.
After a first quarter in which marketers of products like automobiles, packaged foods and computers spent more money than anticipated, in turn enriching advertising media like network television and magazines more than anticipated, the growth is continuing. 
 And yesterday, Madison Avenue's leading forecaster revised upward his projection of ad spending for 1994, noting trends that seemed more robust than they did six months ago.
"There's a lot more reason to be more optimistic," Robert J. Coen, the senior vice president and director of forecasting at McCann-Erickson U.S.A., said at a seminar at the University Club in Manhattan.
"We're seeing budgets restored and a little heavier spending reappearing again. The firmness in demand for media time and space is definitely on the uptick."
Mr. Coen's remarks sparked a boomlet in the prices of stocks of advertising and media companies yesterday. Shares of the Interpublic Group of Companies, which owns McCann-Erickson and other giant agencies, rose 12.5 cents, to $31.875, and shares of the Omnicom Group, which owns large shops including BBDO Worldwide, rose 87.5 cents, to $45.75. Shares of the Gannett Company rose $1, to $52.75, and shares of Times Mirror rose 75 cents, to $32.
Still, there are no forecasts for a boom that would undo the systemic shifts that have fundamentally reshaped the agency industry, resulting in the elimination of thousands of jobs since 1989.
What Mr. Coen called "the restructuring and downsizing" that have shrunk the industry are unlikely to be reversed by a single year of brightening or improving data. Only last Friday, for instance, Lintas New York, which like McCann-Erickson is owned by Interpublic, said it would lay off 12 employees.
Mr. Coen, who has tracked ad trends since 1948, said domestic ad spending in 1994 would total $148 billion, compared with a forecast of $146.8 billion he made in December at the 21st annual Paine Webber media conference.
If ad spending in the United States reaches $148 billion this year, that would represent growth of 7.2 percent from the $138 billion that was spent in 1993. In December, Mr. Coen had predicted a gain of 6.3 percent.
Either way, barring an unforeseen event, ad spending appears likely to increase this year at the quickest pace since it rose at a rate of 7.7 percent in 1988. During recent years, ad spending has uncharacteristically stagnated, trailing the growth in the gross domestic product, and in 1991 even declined for the first time in three decades.
The primary reason for the readjustment, Mr. Coen said, was an accelerating expansion in ad spending at the national level, up 7.8 percent, compared with his prediction of 6.5 percent in December. At the local level, Mr. Coen added, advertisers are somewhat less willing to open their wallets wider, particularly for advertising space in newspapers, where the results remain problematic.
Indeed, Mr. Coen trimmed his forecast for ad spending in local newspapers to an increase of 6 percent, rather than the 6.5 percent he had predicted in December. Over all, his forecast for local spending was for an increase of 6.3 percent, compared with 6.1 percent in December.
Mr. Coen's prediction joined a lengthening list of indicators of an improving advertising environment that includes these:
*The brisk sales being booked by the national television networks in the up-front, or advance, market for commercial time during the 1994-95 season, which are expected to total $4 billion, compared with $3.7 billion in the up-front market for 1993-94.
*Figures from the Magazine Publishers of America showing that ad page gains in April and May were the strongest for those months in a decade.
*Data showing a rise in the demand for commercial time on both local radio stations and national radio networks.
*A report last month at the 76th annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies that so-called spot television time was sold out from April through June "for the first time in six or seven years" in local markets like Atlanta, Las Vegas, Nev., and Washington.
Mr. Coen has become known for forecasts that tend to accentuate the positive. In December, when he predicted a spending increase of 6.3 percent in 1994, Zenith Media Worldwide, a unit of the Saatchi & Saatchi Company P.L.C. specializing in media services, predicted a gain of 3.8 percent.
Karen R. Ficker, an analyst for Wasserstein Perella Securities in New York who follows media companies and attended Mr. Coen's presentation, said that while "it's nice to see the numbers going upward," she would be more inclined to follow Mr. Coen's initial prediction for a gain of 6.3 percent in 1994.
James R. Guthrie, executive vice president for marketing development at the Magazine Publishers of America in New York, who also attended the presentation, called Mr. Coen's magazine projections "a little bit conservative."
Mr. Coen, asked about the assessments of his outlook, said, "When I made a forecast of a 6.5 percent increase for national ad spending in December, nobody seemed to be that confident, and I was losing confidence in my own confidence."
"I think there's a pattern," he said. "When things are bad, people think they'll stay bad. When things get good, people can't believe they're getting good. And then they can't believe it can get bad again."
Still, Mr. Coen's forecast for ad spending outside the United States was less rosy than his outlook for this country, and was also less rosy than his forecast in December. He attributed that to spotty showings in significant markets like Canada, Japan and Spain, which are expected to overshadow what he called "exceptional growth" in countries including Argentina, China, Hungary, South Korea and Thailand.
Mr. Coen projected that spending in 1994 in the rest of the world would total $170.3 billion, up 4.5 percent from $163 billion in 1993, compared with his December forecast that it would total $171 billion, a gain of 4.9 percent.
That would result in total worldwide ad spending in 1994 of $318.3 billion, up 5.7 percent from the $301.1 billion spent in 1993, compared with Mr. Coen's forecast in December of $317.8 billion, an increase of 5.5 percent.
And in his first look at 1995, Mr. Coen estimated that ad spending in the United States would be $157.7 billion, up 6.6 percent from his revised forecast of $148 billion for this year. He said this year's growth should moderate somewhat next year because of the absence of the Winter Olympics and political campaigns that are helping to stimulate ad spending during 1994.
Mr. Coen also estimated that ad spending elsewhere in the world in 1995 would be $181.9 billion, an increase of 6.8 percent from his revised forecast of $170.3 billion for 1994. That would put total ad spending in 1995 at $339.6 billion, up 6.7 percent from his new estimate for 1994 of $318.3 billion.

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
A Sainted Journalist, Blushing In the Grave

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
Agreeable though it always is to be reminded of Edward R. Murrow, tonight's edition of "CBS Reports" leaves one wondering how that serious-minded journalist might have felt about the iconizing he has been subject to since his death in 1965. In particular, the conferring of sainthood by an industry that rarely met his standards and by a network that in effect buried his career (while publicly praising it) might have awakened his cynical side.
"When America Trembled: Murrow/McCarthy," at 10 P.M. (on Channel 2 in New York), focuses on the famous 1954 "See It Now" program that helped do in Senator Joseph R. McCarthy. It's a white hat-black hat story that has been told many times but bears retelling. 
 Evidently in an effort to punch up the daring of Murrow's decision to take on the nation's pre-eminent hounder of Communists and their relatives, defenders and facsimiles, tonight's account sets an overly dire scene of an America in the grip of political hysteria. It adds little to the main facts of what is known as the McCarthy era (which was more a blink than an era) and nothing that runs counter to the conventional history; but Murrow's colleagues provide glimpses from the inside, and the material is professionally packaged.
Old news clips catch the personalities of the bullying Senator and his tough nemesis. As Dan Rather points out in his narration, it was not the Murrow program but the televised Army-McCarthy hearings a few weeks later that toppled McCarthy. Still, Murrow had greased the skids.
"When America Trembled" touches on journalistic issues that troubled Murrow and are worth more attention than they receive tonight. One has to do with the right of a popular journalist to use his power and his medium's power to go after a public figure. Murrow's discomfort over his own exercise of such power gave way to his outrage over the damage McCarthy was doing to individuals and to the country, but it was not an automatic decision for him.
Since his time, producers, anchors, reporters and commentators have taken liberties that would probably have caused Murrow sleepless nights. The 30-minute "See It Now" report consisted mainly of newsreel clips of McCarthy telling lies followed by Murrow's corrections. Although the pictures of McCarthy were not chosen for their flattering quality, little use was made of the visual effects commonly employed nowadays against the targets of television exposes. And nobody seems to be losing sleep over sinister close-ups, dire music and the rest.
And then there is Murrow's up-and-down relationship with CBS, the network where he spent almost his entire journalistic career. It was on CBS Radio that he made his mark as a foreign correspondent in World War II and on CBS Television that he made his fortune as host of "Person to Person," a popular celebrity-interview show about which he was sensibly embarrassed. But "See It Now," the series celebrated tonight, brought little joy to Murrow's network masters. It pleased liberal reviewers more than it pleased local stations and advertisers, and signaled the end of Murrow's television career.
Since Murrow's time, the line between reporting and advocacy has been increasingly blurred on the screen, sometimes with worthy results, sometimes in a worrisome way. It can be a close call. And even as so-so news magazines proliferate, good documentaries on urgent matters are left largely to public television.
Tonight's exercise in recycling is the fifth in the current "CBS Reports" series, reincarnated last year. All have been respectable retrospectives: on D-Day, Vietnam, the assassination of John F. Kennedy and the noisy year of 1968. They made economical use of old clips that featured CBS News stars and gave no headaches to network executives. A safe way to call up a faded glory.
Speaking of news magazines, at 9 P.M. tonight, "America Tonight," the latest CBS clone, tells about an automobile insurance scam and about the American head of an Indian village in the Amazon rain forest who is trying to fight off oil drilling. The subjects are not uninteresting by news magazine standards but will win no awards for innovation. As the man said, if you've seen one report on a rain forest (with slow-motion episodes) or on an insurance scam (through an undercover camera), you may not have to see another for a while.
At 10 P.M., ABC's "Turning Point" puts the blame on the Exxon Corporation for the devastating 1989 Alaskan oil spill and warns of similar catastrophes to come. It's a timely report: on Monday, in the first phase of a multi-billion-dollar suit, a Federal jury decided that Exxon and Capt. Joseph J. Hazelwood, the captain of the Exxon Valdez, acted recklessly in events leading to the spill. The program offers some new evidence and pertinent details on the workings and misworkings of the oil-tanker industry. It is well documented, and opposing views are registered. All in all, the sort of job "CBS Reports" might have done in other years.

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
We, The Jury

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY

 BODY:
Report of juror 30892, Superior Court of New Jersey, County of Hudson:
"The Best of Montel Williams" was on the television in the jury holding room. "They would call me out of the classroom every morning to measure my hair," a girl who was suspended from school because her hair was too big told Montel. Luna caught Max cheating on "One Life to Live" and Bobbi brandished a gun on "General Hospital." 
 Monday there was coffee and cake. Tuesday there was coffee. Wednesday the milk for the coffee was frozen. Thursday there was no coffee.
The clock on the wall had no hands.
The clergyman was not chosen for a jury. The man from Rutgers with the beard and the master's degree was not chosen for a jury. The nervous Irish woman who repeated constantly "I could never judge another human being. Never. I just couldn't" was not chosen for a jury. The plumber who had difficulty reading was not chosen for a jury.
Juror 30892 was not chosen for a jury. Two times in the box: a drug case, a civil suit centering on a bike rack. Two peremptories. Opinion columnist married to a trial attorney? Goodbye.
"If you're excused, don't be offended," said the avuncular Judge Seymour Margulies when he gave a pep talk at the beginning of the week. "Don't be offended," said Judge Richard F. Connors, who gave an ad hoc disquisition on the dangers of tort reform after announcing that one civil matter had been settled while a jury was in the process of being assembled. "Please know you're wanted. Please know you're needed."
I was not wanted. I was not needed. I was offended.
"You made me nervous," said one of the lawyers who wanted me off his panel. "You bring too much to the table," said a former prosecutor.
In a book to be published this fall called "The Jury," Stephen J. Adler, legal editor of The Wall Street Journal, uses case studies to illustrate all that is wrong with the system, how educated jurors either do not serve or are not selected, how lawyers choose jurors based upon imagined partiality rather than the opposite, how jurors clearly decide some cases based on bias and misapprehension.
He includes the criticisms that have become the staples of reports on the jury system throughout the country: that the ways in which jurors are summoned and selected are haphazard and that too many people and classes of people are excused or excluded.
Mr. Adler quotes Erwin Griswold, the former dean of Harvard Law School: "Why should anyone think that 12 persons brought in from the street, selected in various ways, for their lack of general ability, should have any special capacity for deciding controversies between persons?" And Mark Twain: "The jury system puts a ban upon intelligence and honesty, and a premium upon ignorance, stupidity and perjury."
But Mr. Adler writes nevertheless, "I found myself delighting in the spectacle of entrusting whatever was at issue to a random slice of the community." And I agree. To be sure, those long hours sitting in that room with its fluorescent lights and pallid linoleum, the twin curses of shabby places of public assembly, watching the others play Bingo or solitaire, swapping stories about childbirth or construction, were the closest thing to quarantine.
But there came those moments, with a group assembled in a jury box, when it suddenly made some sort of sense. The Filipino man, the black woman, the housewife with the retired husband, the economist, the divorced bus driver, the banker, so many so serious about their civic duty when duty truly called. Funny that this place, whose reason for being is wrongdoing, leaves you with the overwhelming feeling that the world is full of solid citizens.
She also serves who only sits and waits and reads old copies of Cosmo. And listens in on the post-mortems of the jury that found a woman who slipped on soup on the steps of the medical center 7 percent negligent and the hospital 93 percent in the wrong. The pay was $5 a day. The judges told us with conviction that we were doing something essential to the democratic process. There were times when it seemed true.
Often the jury system works. But there should be coffee every day, and newer magazines, and a place at the table for people, like juror 30892, who bring too much to it.
