HEADLINE: Consider the Patient And Not the Insurer

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The A.M.A. -- Deja Vu, Again," (editorial, May 29) shows again that the patient's needs are overlooked in the health care reform debate. 
 Permitting insurance companies to fire doctors "without cause" will not assure patients that their doctors are excellent. Insurance companies will be most interested in the lowest cost of what passes for health care on an insurance form. Was the fired doctor really mediocre or perhaps providing the best care at a cost a profit-oriented insurance company did not like?
The public is not well served by putting insurance company employees, either clerks or doctors not expert in the particular problem, in charge of overruling the judgment of a specialist who has spent years training to diagnose and treat the specific ailments of the patient.
Bringing timely and affordable health care to more Americans should not mean diminishing quality. Financial considerations should not replace medical judgment.
Many of the health care reforms being considered in Congress, as well as those on state and local levels, limit the patient's right to choose a specialist and obtain specialty care. That false economy will undermine quality medical care. Patients want the best medical care available. Doctors want to provide the best medical care, too.
 
NOAH S. FINKEL, M.D.
 Huntington, L.I., June 6, 1994

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Rise by Only 0.2%

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
Two more signs of a slowing economy and restrained inflation emerged today as the Government reported that consumer prices crept up by a modest two-tenths of a percentage point in May while retail sales fell by an equal amount.
Bond investors, greeting the news as a sign that the economy would not overheat and feed inflation, bid up bond prices. Long-term interest rates fell to 7.30 percent from 7.35 percent. The stock market also rose, with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing 31.71 points, to 3,814.83. 
 Inflation erodes the value of future interest payments from bonds and the repayment of principal, so bond prices tend to rise and interest rates fall when inflation seems to be under control.
But some economists and analysts are still divided on what the data are saying.
"The economy seems to have stepped down a notch in the pace it was running at," said Martin A. Regalia, the chief economist at the United States Chamber of Commerce. The figures, he said, were the latest indications that the economy was no longer growing at the 5 percent annual rate that it sustained during the latter half of 1993 and that inflation remained under control.
Kenneth P. Mayland, the senior vice president and chief financial officer at Keycorp, a bank based in Cleveland, said today's figures had forced him to reconsider his forecast of "three-ish" growth in the second quarter of this year. "On the basis of these figures, I'm starting to look a something with a two handle, and something with a one handle is not out of the realm of possibility," he said.
 
A Complex Calculation
 But James F. O'Sullivan, an economist at J. P. Morgan in New York who predicts much stronger growth this quarter, said that it was too soon to start revising economic growth figures. Growth depends not only on consumer spending but also on such variables as international trade and military spending, for which even April figures are not yet available, Mr. O'Sullivan said.
Some Wall Street and banking economists also said that the figures strengthened their view that the Federal Reserve might wait until the August meeting of its interest rate policy committee before raising short-term interest rates again, rather than acting at the next meeting on July 5 and 6. "If we continue to see numbers like this, the Fed is going to wait," said Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch in New York.
But David B. Bostian, the chief economist at Herzog, Heine, Geduld Inc., a New York brokerage firm, is less sure. He said that while he foresaw a sharp slowdown in the American economy during the second half of this year, he was worried about a new Fed study that contends that lower inflation causes higher productivity.
"It looked to me like a rationale for additional rate increases," Mr. Bostian said.
 
Some Rise, Some Fall
 The modest increase last month in consumer prices, which have risen at an annual rate of just 2.3 percent so far this year, reflected a drop in gasoline prices and airline fares. These drops, along with falls in pork and bakery prices, largely offset increases in fruit and vegetable prices and smaller increases in apparel, tobacco and furniture prices.
Excluding food and energy, consumer prices rose by three-tenths of a percentage point in May, the Labor Department said in its report.
The small drop in retail sales reported by the Commerce Department for last month came mainly because of a 1.9 percent drop in sales at car and truck dealerships. Sales rose at outlets like grocery and department stores that sell nondurable goods.
But sales at restaurants and clothing stores, which tend to reflect discretionary consumer spending, dropped in May by 1 percent and three-tenths of a percentage point respectively.
The Commerce Department also revised today its figure for April sales to show a fall of 1.1 percent, compared with a previous estimate of a drop of eight-tenths of 1 percent.
 
Views Split on Car Sales
 There is no consensus among auto industry experts and economists on why car sales have led the way in pulling down retail sales over the last two months. Some experts attribute it to rising car prices and a desire among consumers to start saving more of their money.
But some economists, like Mr. O'Sullivan, attribute the fall in car sales to a shortage of popular models, like the Chrysler Neon. "It sounds like that weakness in spending reflects low inventories," he said.
Despite four increases by the Federal Reserve in short-term interest rates this spring, interest rates on car loans have stayed virtually unchanged. Bankers attribute that to stiff competition.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 16, 1994, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Business Day yesterday with an article about economic indicators that showed slower growth included an incorrect figure supplied by the Labor Department for the change in consumer prices from May 1993 to May 1994. The index rose 2.3 percent in that period, not 2.8 percent.

HEADLINE: U.S. Offers a Plan For U.N. Sanctions On North Koreans

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 15

 BODY:
The United States outlined a plan today for United Nations sanctions against North Korea, including a ban on arms trade, in an effort to force that nation to cooperate with United Nations nuclear inspectors seeking to discover whether it is building an atomic bomb.
The American plan would require United Nations members to halt all trading in arms with North Korea, a move that could cost it between $50 million and $100 million a year in lost exports. But North Korea's arms exports are mostly missiles sent to Iran and Syria, two countries with spotty records of compliance with United Nations directives. 
 The sanctions plan has also been watered down in an attempt to win the support of China, which has a veto on Security Council decisions and has a long record of opposing punitive international sanctions. So the proposals fall well short of the near-total trade blockades the Council has slapped on Iraq, Yugoslavia and Haiti, and they have no enforcement provisions.
China still has not said whether it will approve the sanctions. The positions of the other three permanent members of the Security Council are also unclear, though Britain and France seem likely to endorse the American position.
Unveiling the Clinton Administration's sanctions plan, the United States representative here, Madeleine K. Albright, said sanctions were not an end in themselves but "a tool to show the Democratic People's Republic of Korea that it needs to correct its past behavior and be careful about its future behavior."
As she began what are expected to be long consultations on the plan with other Security Council members, Ms. Albright said Washington wanted the sanctions introduced in phases so North Korea clearly sees the advantages of cooperating with nuclear inspectors sent by the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna, as well as the costs of continued defiance.
But Ms. Albright also underscored the dangers inherent in the crisis building up over North Korea's nuclear ambitions, saying the effort to compel the Pyongyang Government to cooperate with the atomic energy agency is "the single biggest issue" before the Security Council now and "the most important thing I shall be dealing with here."
North Korea has repeatedly warned that it will consider sanctions against it to be an act of war, raising the specter of a second northern invasion of the South, where there are some 37,000 American troops.
 
Plan Would Halt U.N. Aid
 In addition to an arms embargo, the initial sanctions package, which would take effect a month after the Security Council approves it, includes cutting off what remains of a four-year, $15 million United Nations aid program in North Korea that began in 1992 and canceling planned assistance for a big industrial project on the Tumen River.
The size of North Korea's few diplomatic missions in foreign countries and international organizations would also be reduced. And whatever cultural, scientific and educational exchanges that exist with North Korea would be canceled.
North Korea would pay "a heavy price in diplomatic isolation," Ms. Albright said.
Only if North Korea responds to this initial sanctions package by further provocative action -- such as withdrawing from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty -- would the United States then ask the Security Council to introduce a second round of sanctions.
The second round would ban all financial transactions with North Korea. This would cut into the remittances it receives from Koreans living in Japan and further complicate what little trade it has with other countries. The $600 million to $1.8 billion a year that Koreans in Japan now send home is thought to constitute North Korea's biggest single source of foreign exchange.
In what appears to be an effort to placate China, the United States has refrained from proposing the full trade embargo it favored against Iraq, Yugoslavia and Haiti or even a ban on selling oil to North Korea, which gets most of its supplies from China. But officials insist that it still might decide to press for a full trade embargo if North Korea refuses to give way.
To avoid the initial package of sanctions, the United States wants North Korea to cooperate again with the atomic energy agency in its efforts to reconstruct the history of a nuclear research reactor to see how much spent fuel has been removed from it for reprocessing into plutonium, which can be used to make nuclear explosives.
The best way of doing this is no longer possible since North Korea has dismantled the reactor core without allowing the agency's inspectors to make the examination they wanted. But the agency's director, Hans Blix, has said his inspectors could still try to discover what use was made of the reactor if North Korea would allow them access to nuclear waste dumps and provide more technical information about the reactor's past operations.
 
Seeking Cargo Flight Ban
 In an attempt to enforce the planned arms embargo, the United States wants the Security Council to ban all cargo flights to and from North Korea. This means that only the scheduled passenger flights that now link Pyongyang with Beijing, Moscow and Bangkok would be allowed to continue.
Many of North Korea's arms deliveries have been made by air. But ship traffic would not be affected, and in any case officials say the United States is not yet contemplating the kind of naval and air monitoring it has organized against Iraq, Yugoslavia and Haiti because it does not yet want to impose a draconian trade embargo on North Korea.
The atomic energy agency has already established through its inspections that North Korea has manufactured some plutonium from spent reactor fuel, though it does not know how much. But the research reactor was shut down for 100 days in 1989, arousing suspicions that North Korea may have extracted a sizable quantity of fuel and reprocessed it into enough plutonium for one or several bombs.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Former President Jimmy Carter and his wife, Rosalynn, visited Pyongyang yesterday at the invitation of the North Korean Government. Mr. Carter met with Foreign Minister Kim Yong Nam, center, and South Korean press reports said he later visited President Kim Il Sung. (Associated Press) (pg. A12)

HEADLINE: 50,000 Orders For New Fords

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: PARIS, June 15

 BODY:
The chairman of the Ford Motor Company, Alexander J. Trotman, said today that the auto maker already had 50,000 dealer orders for its new Ford Contour and Mercury Mystique compact cars, which go on sale in the United States in September as 1995 models.
Ford will start building the cars next month at a plant in Kansas City, Mo., after a $375 million investment there. The cars, which will also be made at a Ford assembly plant in Mexico, replace the smaller and less expensive Tempo and Topaz compacts. 
 The Contour and Mystique are part of Ford's $6 billion, six-year program to build an all-new car for sale around the world. Their European counterpart is the Ford Mondeo, which is built in Genk, Belgium, and went on sale in March 1993. All three cars share the same basic underpinnings but are styled to suit regional tastes.
Ford expects combined sales of about 800,000 a year, in both right- and left-hand-drive markets. More than 614,000 Mondeos have been ordered in 48 markets.
"It's been a smash hit all across Europe," Mr. Trotman said in a speech today to the International Chamber of Commerce in Paris. "Despite a deep recession, sales are well over a half million."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Countrywide Credit takes a battering from rising rates.

BYLINE: By Michael Quint 

 BODY:
THE ill effect of rising interest rates on mortgage banking companies is no secret. Wall Street expected companies that originate and service mortgages to report lower profits this year because fewer homeowners are refinancing their mortgages. But analysts were still surprised this week by developments at Countrywide Credit Industries of Pasadena, Calif.
On Tuesday, the day before Countrywide officials met with investors and analysts in New York and announced weaker-than-expected earnings for the quarter ended May 31, the company's stock was hit by a wave of selling by large investors. 
 By the end of the day, 5.9 million shares changed hands, including several blocks of more than a million shares each. The trading was more than eight time Countrywide's normal volume and about 6.4 percent of all shares outstanding. The flurry of selling was enough to push the stock down $1.50, to $15.50. Trading was active again yesterday, with 2.56 million shares changing hands as the price fell 12.5 cents, to $15.375.
Stanford L. Kurland, Countrywide's chief operating officer, said he does not yet know who was selling. But he added that the company had reviewed its procedures for compiling and announcing earnings results and was satisfied that there had been no leak of the company's earnings announcement. But one analyst said investors might have decided bad news was coming because the company does not usually schedule meetings with investors on the day that it announces earnings.
The company said profits for the quarter ended May 31 were $33.7 million, or 37 cents a share, down 24 percent from $43.3 million, or 47 cents a share, a year earlier. Davis S. Loeb, Countrywide's chairman, said rising interest rates had reduced mortgage originations, but Countrywide was not matching the moves of some competitors by cutting prices and interest rates on new mortgages.
The combination of higher interest rates and a reluctance to cut its profit margin resulted in a 19 percent decline in the volume of new mortgages. Although the company has been cutting expenses -- its payroll is down 21 percent since October, to 3,499 workers -- overall expenses are still 28 percent higher than a year ago.
"Expenses were not down as much as expected," said David Hochstim, an analyst at Bear, Stearns. He added that the cost of hedging to protect the value of fees on the mortgages the company services -- an activity that greatly benefited Countrywide when interest rates were falling -- was greater than expected. Countrywide officials say the cost of those hedges will decline.
The Countrywide report was discouraging enough, and far enough below the average earnings forecast of more than 50 cents a share, that several Wall Street analysts promptly reduced their forecasts for the remainder of this year and next. Paul Mackey, an analyst at Dean Witter, now expects the company to earn $1.90 a share this year, down from $2.17 he expected earlier. Next year, he expects a rebound to $2.25, unchanged form his earlier estimate.
Despite the weaker-than-expected profits in the first quarter, Countrywide remains one of the most highly regarded mortgage banking companies on Wall Street. The company is only 25 years old, but is the leader in originating mortgages and has kept intact a network of 291 offices which deal directly with consumers. It is also the leader in the servicing, or mortgage record keeping business, with a $93.6 billion portfolio of mortgages that produce fees of nearly half a percentage point, or $470 million annually, a stable source of revenue.
As a market leader, some analysts say Countrywide is a takeover target that is within the reach of banking companies. Seth Glickenhouse, one of the largest investors in Countrywide -- who said he was a buyer, not a seller on Tuesday -- maintained the company would be a great fit for a bank such as BankAmerica. And some analysts have said Countrywide could fetch $50 a share.
"For the past few months there has been a real tug of war between the takeover school and the weak results," said Gary Gordon, an analyst at Paine Webber Inc. "When the results show up, the company gets hit, then that memory fades and there is more talk about a takeover." But estimates of $50 a share are unrealistic, he said, adding that a price of $25 a share would be more appropriate.

HEADLINE: Castro Dons Civvies for Latin Conference

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CARTAGENA, Colombia, June 15

 BODY:
Tailoring his attire to a changing foreign policy, President Fidel Castro of Cuba has broken his 35-year tradition of only wearing olive-green military uniforms in public and has appeared at a meeting with Latin America's civilian heads of state here by wearing a white cotton guayabera shirt.
"We are all used to the general in olive green, and now he is in a guayabera," commented Cesar Gaviria Trujillo, Colombia's President and host to the annual Ibero-American summit meeting. "We think this represents a good change." 
 President Castro looked slightly ill at ease in his public debut in civilian clothes, but it is generally assumed here that he donned the loose shirt out of more than a desire to comply with his Colombian hosts' request for informality at this tropical beach resort city.
 
A Growing Share of Trade
 Gradually emerging from decades of isolation in the Americas, Cuba during the last five years has tripled the amount of trade it does with Latin America, from 7 percent in 1990 to 21 percent today. With trade and investment growing steadily, Latin American leaders are increasingly open in their objections to the United States' 32-year trade and diplomatic embargo of the Communist-ruled island nation.
In an indirect slap at United States policy, the leaders of 19 Latin American nations and of Spain and Portugal approved a communique tonight calling for the elimination "of unilateral coercive economic and trade measures."
The communique was a victory for Mr. Castro, who on Tuesday, as the summit meeting began, complained that "no one has said a word about the criminal and unjust blockade that for more than 30 years has been imposed on my country."
 
'Relic of Cold War'
 But blunt language in support of lifting the embargo was heard last week at a meeting in Brazil of foreign ministers of member nations of the Organization of American States. A Panamanian diplomat described the 1962 suspension of Cuba from the O.A.S. as "a relic of the cold war."
Calls for Cuba's return were heard from some of the organization's most powerful members -- Brazil, Canada, Mexico and Venezuela -- as well as from most of the Central American republics. The organization's Secretary General, Joao Clemente Baena Soares, received a standing ovation when he asked, "Hasn't the time come to re-admit Cuba to the Latin American family?"
The United States ban on business with Cuba costs American companies $6 billion a year in lost opportunities, according to Representative Charles Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan. Mr. Rangel has sponsored a bill to lift the trade embargo, but the Clinton Administration has shown no signs of shifting policy on the issue.
 
Canada Shifting Policy
 Meanwhile, companies in other nations are signing deals with Cuba. Next week, Canadian officials, who have described the United States embargo as "unhealthy," are expected to announce a renewal of Canadian foreign aid to Cuban non-governmental groups. Aid was suspended in 1978 to protest Cuba's military intervention in Angola.
As in much of the Americas, Canada's softer line toward Cuba reflects a steady growth in trade and investment since the collapse of the Soviet bloc five years ago. Last year, 130,000 Canadian tourists visited Cuba, accounting for 28 percent of the island's total.
Two weeks ago, two Canadian companies announced that they had found commercial quantities of oil at a well offshore of Cuba's Manzanas Province. In mining, two Canadian companies signed contracts this year to exploit an open-pit copper mine in eastern Cuba and to prospect for gold, lead, silver and zinc in central and eastern Cuba.
This week, a Mexican company signed a $1.5 billion deal to rehabilitate Cuba's decrepit telephone system. The deal dwarfs an additional $150 million in Mexican investments that have been announced in the 1990's.
 
'Concrete Opportunities'
 "We have been progressively strengthening our relations with the rest of Latin America," Ricardo Alarcon de Quesada, the president of Cuba's National Assembly, said here. "There is important Mexican investment now. Brazil is buying medicines. Tourism is increasing. There are concrete opportunities for Latin American countries to invest."
In recent years, some Latin American nations soured on Cuba when the impoverished country ran up large unpaid import bills -- $30 million to Brazil and $50 million to Colombia. But the liberalization of Cuba's foreign investment climate is sparking new overseas interest in this market of 11 million people.
Two weeks ago, Spain, which accounts for one-quarter of Cuba's 100 joint ventures with foreign companies, signed an investment protection treaty in Havana.
Colombia, which only re-established diplomatic relations with Havana last October, has been among the most aggressive in courting trade and investment with Cuba, which ranks as the fifth most populous of the Caribbean nations.
 
Commerical Airline Links
 Visits to Havana by three Colombian ministers since February have produced an accord for commercial airline service, a 17-fold increase in Cuban exports to Colombia and negotiations over an oil deal in which Colombia would supply Cuba with up to one-third of its oil needs.
"We have no discrimination against Cuba," Juan Manuel Santos, Colombia's foreign trade minister, said in an interview after his March visit to Havana. "But we will not give them any special benefits. We approach Cuba in a businesslike way."
If the oil deal goes through, Cuban exiles threaten to launch a boycott of Colombian products in southern Florida. But Government authorities seem to pay as little heed to this threat as participants in the summit meeting have paid to full-page advertisements published this week in Colombian newspapers by Cuban exiles opposed to Mr. Castro's visit here, his second in less than a year.
"I don't accept any influence by Cuban exiles on Colombian foreign policy," Ernesto Samper Pizano, the ruling party candidate in Colombia's June 19 presidential election runoff, said recently. "The O.A.S. should open a new space for Cuba in the inter-American concert."

Behind them are Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez of Spain, President Guillermo Endara of Panama and President Ramiro de Leon Carpio of Guatemala. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Stock Prices Ebb in Restrained Trading

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
After four consecutive advancing sessions, the stock market fell yesterday in restrained trading. Falling bond prices, a declining dollar and rising commodities prices all contributed to weakness in the leading stock indexes.
The Dow fell 24.42 points yesterday, to 3,790.41, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 fell 1.76, to 460.61. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index fell 0.14 point, to 735.84. 
 Blue-chip issues like I.B.M. and the Aluminum Company of America, telephone companies like BellSouth and conglomerates like General Electric, as well as Nasdaq stocks like Intel and American Power Conversion, all fell.
For more than three weeks, the Dow had been vainly attempting to break a resistance level at 3,800, only to exceed that on Tuesday when the Dow hit 3,814.83, technical analysts said.
But for a variety of reasons, analysts doubt that the blue-chip index can hold its ground for the near future. "The market is very, very overbought," meaning that traders are more likely to sell than to buy, said Don Hays, investment strategist for Wheat First, Butcher & Singer in Richmond.
For the last 20 days, for example, there have been sharp advances in a wide variety of stock groups. "You need a pause to refresh," Mr. Hays said.
The stock market is also getting mixed signals from the bond market. Long-term interest rates rose yesterday, almost by default. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose to 7.39 percent from 7.30 percent in light trading, which accentuates volatility.
At first, a Federal Reserve report provided more evidence of a slow-growth economy, but later, seemingly innocuous remarks by a Fed official reminded bond traders of their quick-to-surface inflation fears and again roused anxieties that the Fed would again increase interest rates.
In the morning, the Fed reported that factory use fell to 83.5 percent in May, from 83.6 percent in April. But John P. LaWare, a Federal Reserve governor, said yesterday that factory use was "approaching a high level" and "that's one of the things that may at some point contribute to inflation pressures."
A declining dollar, which could signal a reluctance by foreign investors to buy American assets, did not help. The dollar fell to 102.75 yen, from 102.78 the day before.
The closely watched Commodity Research Bureau index did not help, either. The index, a proxy for commodities traders' inflation outlook, consists of 21 futures contracts. The index jumped 3.31 points, to 238.61, one of the steepest rises of the year.
The biggest movers were agricultural commodities like soybeans and corn, which rose sharply because weather forecasts for the Midwest indicated possible drought conditions for the next month. Separately, the price of crude oil soared.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.96 point, to 254.14, with advancing stocks lagging behind declining stocks, 950 to 1168. The American Stock Exchange market value index fell 0.38 point, to 442.27.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 269.9 million shares, about 8 percent below this year's average of 295 million shares.
Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 18 fell, led by Exxon, which fell 1 7/8, to 57, in heavy trading.
A Federal jury ruled on Monday that Exxon was reckless in the Valdez oil spill and thus opened the company to billions of dollars in possible legal damages. Yesterday, a Bear, Stearns analyst lowered his Exxon stock assessment to "avoid" from "hold." Of the 500 component stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, 252 stocks fell, led by Exxon and Wal-Mart, which declined 1/4, to 24 5/8, on no apparent news.
The most active stock, at 7.3 million shares, was the Cott Corporation, which fell 3 1/2, to 14 1/2, after management told securities analysts that its rate of growth was slowing.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS Gains Fade On Fears Of Inflation

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prospects for a rally in the bond market on raised expectations of a slowing economy quickly faded yesterday. A sharp rise in commodity prices, a weak dollar and comments by a Federal Reserve official all helped revive investors' concerns about inflation.
Bond prices initially rose on industrial production and business inventory data that suggested a slowdown in the economy, traders said. 
 The price of the 30-year bond fell 30/32 , to 8613/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, rose to 7.39 percent, from 7.30 percent on Tuesday, but still well within the trading range of the last few months. Since April, the yield on the long bond has been as low as 7.10 percent, on April 26, and as high as 7.60 percent, on May 11.
Raymond A. Worseck, chief economist at A. G. Edwards & Sons of St. Louis, said that yesterday's reports were in the range of most economists' expectations. They showed the economy was growing, but at a slower pace, he said.
 
Concern on Inflation
 "Inflation in May was not a problem, but inflation is something to be concerned about," Mr. Worseck said. "It is on the mind of the Fed, on the minds of people investing in foreign bonds and on the minds of people watching commodity prices."
The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities, a closely watched gauge of inflation, surged 3.31 points yesterday, to 238.61, near a three-and-a-half-year high of 239.20 reached on May 24. The price of oil moved above $19 a barrel yesterday, with the July contract for light crude on the New York Mercantile Exchange settling at $19.86 a barrel.
The gain in the commodities index was led by grains and hogs. Mr. Worseck noted that of the three commodity categories, industrial, agricultural and precious metals, the focus has been on agriculture, where one crop failure can cause turmoil in the market.
"Many in the market still live with the memories of 1974, when commodity prices double and tripled," Mr. Worseck said. "But as long as the Fed holds the line, they're making a monetary accommodation that would allow temporary commodity events to spread into general inflation."
Inflation fears in the market were heightened after comments by John P. LaWare, a Federal Reserve governor. In an interview with the Market News Service, Mr. LaWare said that although the rate of capacity utilization in American industry fell slightly in May, it had reached potentially inflationary levels.
 
'Straining the System'
 The Market News Service reported that Mr. LaWare was more concerned about the relatively high level of capacity utilization. "The estimates are that if you get capacity utilization at 85 percent that you are really kind of straining the system," Mr. LaWare was quoted saying.
Another Fed governor, Lawrence B. Lindsey, told the Market News Service on Tuesday that monetary policy was now "within the neutral range" but that mere neutrality could become inappropriate at some point.
But Mr. LaWare's comments bothered the market more, even though he had made similar comments in the past.
The market was helped by yesterday's report showing the decline in capacity utilization. There is much debate, however, whether industries are at or near the point were they will begin to raise prices.
Industrial production rose two-tenths of 1 percent in May, slightly stronger than expected. Capacity utilization slipped to 83.5 percent, from 83.6 percent, with the market trading up on the decline in capacity usage.
Elsewhere in the market, the Treasury announced that next week it would sell $17 billion of two-year notes on Tuesday and $11 billion of five-year notes on Wednesday. In when-issued trading yesterday, the two-year was being offered at a price to yield 5.92 percent, and the five-year at a price to yield 6.69 percent.
 
Massachusetts Issue
 In the municipal market, underwriters, led by Paine Webber Inc., of Massachusetts' $300 million of special-obligation revenue bonds , announced the deal's final pricing. The maximum yield for a bond due in 2014 is 5.90 percent, with shorter-maturity serial bonds priced to yield from 3.40 percent in 1995 to 5.85 percent in 2012.
Moody's Investors Service rated the financing A1. Standard & Poor's gave it a AA- and Fitch Investors Service, A+.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Getting welfare recipients into jobs probably won't be cheap.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
Is America ready to dump a welfare system that permits -- even encourages -- permanent dependence?
President Clinton apparently thinks so, and this week is proposing changes that would, among other things, limit the time that healthy adults could remain on the dole. But findings from an ambitious experiment, released just yesterday, suggest that any reform guaranteeing a living to everyone who plays by the new rules would not come cheap. 
 For while the study, by the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation, shows that modest additional investments in training and job brokering could make a dent in the welfare rolls, it also implies that most people on welfare would need costly, government-supported jobs in order to join the 9-to-5 culture. And as Rebecca Blank, an economist at Northwestern University, points out, "There just isn't enough money to match the rhetoric."
In this latest study, some 33,000 welfare recipients in six California counties were randomly divided into program and control groups. Those in the program group were required to participate in a variety of training and job hunting activities under the Greater Avenues to Independence, or GAIN, program, the state's effort to contain welfare with support from the Federal Family Support Act of 1988. Both the "experimentals" and the "controls" -- those left in the regular welfare system -- were then followed by researchers to see how they fared over three years.
GAIN did make a difference: On average, participants earned 22 percent more than the controls. More striking, those in Riverside County (east of Los Angeles) increased their earnings by 49 percent.
Riverside was also a winner from the perspective of taxpayers: $2.84 was saved for every dollar invested in extra services. On the other hand, Alameda (Oakland), Los Angeles and largely rural Tulare County spent twice as much as they saved on welfare payments. Over all, GAIN was a drain in the six counties, with a dollar spent for every 76 cents recouped.
But that is a "narrow perspective" to judge success or failure, said James Riccio, director of research at the nonprofit Manpower agency, since it ignores the extra income of those able to reduce their dependence on welfare. When the Government's total costs are compared with the benefits to both taxpayers and welfare clients, GAIN comes within a hair of breaking even.
Substantial losses were recorded in just two counties, Los Angeles and Alameda. And by no coincidence these were the two counties with a large, chronically poor underclass -- the people who, in Ms. Blank's words, "start with five strikes against them."
It is relatively easy to see why the going was rough in those two counties. But what explains the success in Riverside?
While the county did offer training, Mr. Riccio said, Riverside's staff insisted that everyone look for jobs and put serious effort into matching them with prospective employers. "What stood out most was the message," Mr. Riccio concluded -- the message that welfare is a temporary safety net rather than a way of life.
The Manpower executives are inclined to put a positive spin on the results from GAIN, emphasizing the win-win nature of the Riverside experience and the fact that the overall taxpayers' loss was offset by benefits to poor people. But they are too committed to objective research to ignore the darker implications of this controlled experiment in trimming the welfare rolls.
GAIN's cumulative outlays on training and job search (ranging from $1,597 a person in Riverside to $5,597 in Alameda) raised the number holding jobs by just six percentage points. That left more than half on welfare at the end of the third year, said Judith Gueron, the president of Manpower -- an enormous number who would need help in finding and keeping jobs in the brave new world of workfare.
President Clinton has promised that Washington would assume the responsibility as employer of last resort -- a promise designed to win political support from the states, which fear they will be stuck with the cost of making workfare work. But the promise is not worth much unless Congress comes up with the money.
Mr. Riccio imagines circumstances in which the Government job guarantee would not be as expensive as the GAIN experiment implies. The incentive to leave welfare was beefed up just last year with the expansion of tax credits for the working poor. And it would be beefed up still more, he said, with the passage of health care legislation that allows those leaving welfare to keep medical benefits.
It is possible that welfare-to-work will prove cheaper than expected, but no one is saying it is probable. The big worry, then, is that once again the fragile coalition backing welfare reform will crack under the pressure of tight budgets and unrealistic expectations.

HEADLINE: Industrial Output Up a Bit; Operating Rate Off

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15

 BODY:
Evidence of slower economic growth is piling up. Production at American factories, mines and utilities barely rose in May, and a barometer of inflationary pressure was lower for the second straight month.
There was also reasonably good news about the productivity of American businesses. And, as expected, inventories rose slightly in April while sales slipped. 
 The Federal Reserve said today that industrial production posted its 12th straight increase in May, with output of business equipment and construction supplies barely offsetting the third consecutive decline in car and truck production.
Production rose a modest two-tenths of 1 percent last month on top of an April gain of one-tenth of 1 percent, which was revised downward from an earlier estimate of three-tenths of 1 percent. The size of the recent increases is down sharply from the last three months of 1993, when the economy expanded more rapidly than it had in a decade.
"I don't think we're on the verge of economic collapse," said Sandra Shaber, an economist with the WEFA Group, a Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., forecasting service. "Put all of it together, we'll have some noninflationary growth. It's wonderful."
The Fed said the industrial operating rate -- a barometer of inflationary pressure -- fell in May for the second straight month.
The central bank said production facilities operated at 83.5 percent of capacity in May, down a tenth of a percentage point from April and two-tenths from March.
The operating rate peaked at 83.9 percent in June 1989. If it rises too high, it could mean production limits are being reached -- leading to shortages that spur price and wage increases.
Many analysts now predict the Federal Reserve, which raised interest rates four times from February to May, will impose no further tightening of credit before August at the earliest.
Gene Sherman with M. A. Schapiro & Company in New York said the decline in both production and operating capacity for auto manufacturers was concealing stronger growth in other sectors.
"So far, so good," he said. "But, in my view. we're at the threshold of rising prices."
In another report today, the Labor Department said nonfarm productivity rose 1.3 percent at an annual rate in the first three months of this year. The figure, defined as output per number of hours worked, is nearly three times the half-percent rate reported earlier. But it still trailed the fourth quarter of last year, when productivity shot up at a 6.1 percent rate.
Also, the Commerce Department said still-lean business inventories rose two-tenths of 1 percent in April after falling in March for the first time in three months. The department also said business sales fell eight-tenths of 1 percent in April, the largest drop since they plunged 1.5 percent in December 1991.
The Fed said a 5.8 percent drop in production of cars and trucks was more than offset by gains in production of business equipment, up nine-tenths of 1 percent in May on top of a half-percent climb in April, and construction supplies, which rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in May following a 1.7 percent surge as spring arrived. Production of computers and office equipment surged 3.1 percent. All manufacturing production rose two-tenths of 1 percent in May, matching the April advance.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Maclean to Pick Bid for Cable Units

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15

 BODY:
The ranks of the biggest cable television companies in America are about to get shaken up for the second time in a month, as Maclean Hunter Ltd. of Canada prepares to pick a winning bid for its collection of United States cable franchises.
The aspiring buyers include several of the biggest cable companies in the country: the Comcast Corporation of Philadelphia; Continental Cablevision of Boston, and a joint venture between Tele-Communications Inc. of Denver and Knight-Ridder Inc., based in Miami. 
 With 553,000 customers in a number of fast-growing suburban markets and combined cash flow of $120 million, McLean Hunter's lucrative American cable franchises are almost certain to be sold for more than $1 billion.
 
An Active Market
 Maclean Hunter, based in Toronto, is selling the franchises as it prepares to be acquired by Rogers Communications Inc., a telecommunications company also based in Toronto. Rogers has said it wants to sell the systems, in part to reduce debt associated with its takeover of Maclean Hunter, which is expected to be completed later this year.
The auction, which should be concluded in the next day or two, comes as the market for cable television properties has become more active than it has been in months.
But the pattern of today's acquisitions is sharply different from that of earlier activity. Instead of telephone companies competing to purchase cable systems outside their territories, cable companies are buying up each other as they brace for competition from phone companies.
In the wake of new Federal price regulations for the cable industry, the regional Bell companies appear to have shifted their strategies from buying systems to upgrading their networks for video services and direct competition with cable operators.
"The phone companies have decided to sit it out," said John Waller 3d, president of Waller Capital, a cable television broker in New York. "It's going to be cable company buying cable company, not telephone companies buying cable companies."
Less than two weeks ago, the Times Mirror Corporation agreed to sell its extensive cable television holdings to Cox Enterprises in a stock deal valued at $2.3 billion -- about 12 times cash flow. If the Maclean Hunter properties are sold for only 10 times cash flow, they would bring about $1.2 billion.
People familiar with the auction, which is being managed by Goldman, Sachs, said Rogers Communications had asked for all-cash bids, which could drive prices below the valuations received by Times Mirror. In addition, one investment banker noted that the Maclean Hunter properties do not have the same strategic value that the Times Mirror systems had for Cox.
In that case, Cox was able to combine its own cable properties in Southern California with those of Times Mirror, thereby stitching together a powerful collection of systems from San Diego to Los Angeles.
Maclean Hunter's most valuable systems are in suburban New Jersey and Florida. It also owns a cable system in Detroit, but that system's performance has been dragged down by the city's weak economy.
Still, companies like Comcast and Continental Cablevision are believed to have an intense interest. Comcast, with 2.6 million subscribers at present, would move from being the nation's fourth-largest cable operator to the third-largest. If it acquired the MacLean Hunter properties, Continental Cablevision, with 2.9 million subscribers, would strengthen its position as the third-largest operator.
The largest cable companies are Tele-Communications, with 10.2 million subscribers, and Time Warner Cable, with 7.1. million customers.

HEADLINE: S.E.C. Asked to Study Derivatives in Funds

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Reacting to recent sharp price drops for several supposedly low-risk mutual funds, the chairman of the House subcommittee with securities oversight asked the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday for a comprehensive study of such funds' use of the complex financial instruments known as derivatives.
Representative Edward J. Markey, a Massachusetts Democrat who heads the House subcommittee on telecommunications and finance, has recently held a series of hearings into the regulatory issues posed by the growth of derivatives. 
 Derivatives are a broad family of new financial products whose value is based on, or derived from, the movement in a financial market, such as stocks, bonds, currencies and commodities. Mutual funds often substitute derivatives for other investments, often in the form of structured notes, which are bonds whose value is linked to an index of the stock market, or some other asset.
 
Mortgage Derivatives Held
 Most mutual funds that have gotten into trouble recently have held mortgage derivatives, which are complex bonds backed by pools of home mortgages. Many of these securities were offered with unusually high interest rates, but their principal value has eroded substantially in recent months as interest rates have risen.
For example, the Paine Webber short-term government bond fund fell 4 percent in one day, mainly because of illiquid mortgage derivatives.
Mr. Markey asked Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman of the S.E.C., to review a series of issues posed by derivatives. In particular, Mr. Markey sought a reading on whether the disclosures made about fund practices could be understood by the average investor.
 
Leverage Involved
 He also asked whether funds were taking too much risk to raise their yield, and whether derivatives posed problems because they were hard to value and were sometimes hard to sell and more leveraged than was generally permitted for mutual funds.
Mr. Markey asked that the S.E.C. complete the study within 30 days, an unusually brief period for such a lengthy request.
In fact, the agency may well ask for more time, Barry Barbash, the agency's top mutual fund regulator, said. "There are a lot of complex issues but not many easy answers." he said.
Mr. Barbash said that the S.E.C. had already begun several initiatives in response to mutual funds' growing use of derivatives. In February, the agency sent a letter to fund managers asking them to increase disclosure of their derivative activities. And it is about to send a second letter asking fund managers to look at their risk management controls that track derivatives positions.

HEADLINE: Corporate Spending Booms, but Jobs Stagnate

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Rarely since World War II has corporate America spent as much as it is spending today on the new equipment that is the foundation of a thriving economy. Companies are becoming more efficient and profitable. But don't celebrate. Rarely has so much spending resulted in so little expansion by businesses -- and so little job growth.
Take the Whirlpool Corporation. Its decision to build a factory in Tulsa, Okla., to produce stoves sounds like an expansion that would create a lot of jobs and a lot of stoves. But that is not the case. 
 The stoves that come off Whirlpool's new assembly line will only replace the gas and electric ranges that the company either makes at another of its plants or buys from competitors and resells with the Whirlpool label. The new factory will not add to the nation's supply of stoves. Gone is the robust optimism that more stoves should be made because people will buy them. That would have been the rationale for adding a factory in decades past.
 
Jobs Added, Jobs Lost
 Instead, Whirlpool merely intends to lower the cost of its products by making the stoves itself, more efficiently. And while Whirlpool will add 700 jobs when the plant opens next year, that many jobs, or more, will probably be lost elsewhere within the company and at its suppliers -- unless those suppliers can find customers that do not now seem to exist.
Like much of corporate America, Whirlpool does not think the demand among Americans for its product will rise significantly soon, and so it is reluctant to expand its capacity.
"American companies, being very cost-sensitive, are really trying to substitute machinery for labor rather than purchase more machinery and more labor," said David Wyss, chief economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill, an economic consulting firm. "Why expand here if you know there is a company in Japan operating at only two-thirds of capacity and seeking business in America to fill up its shop. Or there are skilled workers in Mexico who can do the job."
Nothing tells the story more vividly than the Commerce Department's figures for capital spending -- business's investment in factories, buildings and equipment. Capital spending reached $592 billion last year, in inflation-adjusted dollars, or a near-record 12 percent of the gross domestic product. But most of the spending was to replace existing equipment or, as at Whirlpool, to shift production from one place to another.
Although the estimate is inexact, the Commerce Department says that only 2.3 percent of the G.D.P., or $120 billion last year, went for what it classifies as expansion -- the new factories and buildings that require more workers. That compares with 4 percent or more during periods of economic growth in the 1960's, 1970's and early 1980's.
The approach that Whirlpool and others are taking to re-equip and upgrade the nation's industrial base strengthens corporate profits and makes companies more efficient, but is not so immediately favorable for wage earners.
In the new Tulsa factory, for example, stoves are to be made at lower cost. Prices can fall, and Whirlpool will sell more stoves. Very possibly, the new equipment, being fast and efficient, will allow Whirlpool to increase production and sales without hiring more people. Or perhaps there will be some hiring. But in either case, American companies that compete with Whirlpool could lose market share, and shed workers.
That brings hardship that many economists temper by outlining a longer-term solution. The day will come, they argue, when American-made stoves will be price-competitive with those imported from Mexico or Canada, for example. Production in those countries will then shift to the United States. New factories will open without old ones closing. When that process is multiplied across many industries, jobs are likely to be created at a more vigorous pace.
 
An 'Ultimate Payoff'
 "The link with jobs that goes through productivity does take some years, but that is the ultimate payoff," said Alan Blinder, a member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers.
To be sure, the heavy spending to replace equipment and factories has contributed considerably to recent economic growth. Several hundred thousand jobs created since early 1993 represent people who are manufacturing, installing or programming the machinery and computers that companies are buying in record numbers, Mr. Wyss said.
But the job multiplier effect from capital spending is muted. In the past, the equipment went more frequently into new factories and offices that then had to be staffed. The vigorous rise in employment spread fresh income through the economy, and that new spending power, in turn, raised demand for stoves and many other products and services.
One reason that businesses have been reluctant to expand is that such an investment has been less profitable than it used to be. Investment in factories and equipment is guided mainly by the return that a company can earn. Until the early 1970's, the average return was 10 to 15 percent a year, which meant that a machine bought for $10,000 to stamp out hubcaps, for example, earned the company $1,000 to $1,500 annually.
Since then, the average after-tax return on invested capital has never exceeded 8 percent, and in the 1990's it has ranged from 5 percent in 1991 to 6.8 percent last year, the Commerce Department reports. It isn't enough; corporate America's goal is more than 10 percent.
 
Paper Industry Cautious
 That helps to explain why, for example, the nation's giant paper manufacturing companies, after a round of expansion starting in the 1980's, resist another round now -- although paper mills are operating flat out and paper prices are rising, promising a higher return.
"The annual return today in the paper industry is an abysmal 1 to 2 percent; our shareholders would kill us if we invested in major expansion," said Timothy McKenna, aUnion Camp Corporation executive.
Instead, paper companies are installing new machines at existing plants, or upgrading old ones to cut costs or squeeze out more production. Union Camp, for example, is putting a $170 million machine in a Virginia plant, to recycle 100,000 tons of paper a year. "That is an expansion of production, without an expansion of manpower," Mr. McKenna said.
Similarly, AT&T, with 40 manufacturing plants in the United States, is upgrading many of them to meet the strong demand for equipment to modernize some of the Baby Bell telephone networks, and to expand telephone service in China and the Middle East. Workers, for example, are being hired for a third shift at a Richmond plant that makes wiring boards, many of them for export.
 
Move Overseas Seen
 But once the plant hits capacity, a new plant will probably be built overseas and hiring at Richmond might ease off, said Laurence C. Seifert, vice president of manufacturing.
"There would have to be more growth in the American economy to put a new factory here," he said. "Revenue has to grow by 18 percent a year to offset the gains we can get in production simply by installing new equipment. The 18 percent is the average offset for new technology, and in even the best United States markets, the revenue growth is less than 10 percent a year."
Similarly, America's railroad companies acquired 827 new locomotives last year, but that raised the nation's locomotive fleet by only 157, to 18,161. The locomotives, however, are more powerful and can haul more freight.
But investing in more trains and hiring more people to operate them is a different matter. That requires an average return on the investment of at least 11.5 percent a year, said Harry Levine, a vice president of the Association of American Railroads. Now the return is only 8 percent, which is okay if the goal is to buy more powerful, more efficient engines to haul freight on existing lines, often at less cost.
The national economy surged over the winter, but rising interest rates have slowed growth, taking some of the appeal away from capital spending. A railroad company projecting an 8 percent return from the purchase of a $1 million locomotive might decide to buy Treasury bonds instead, because they offer almost as much payback, with less risk.
"Given the risk, the industry is waiting for a greater return than it can get elsewhere," Mr. Levine said.
 
Whirlpool Rejected Mexico
 Whirlpool's Tulsa plant, announced in April, seems to offer that greater return. The $104 million plant is to employ 700 people when it opens and 1,300 later on. And if all goes well, Whirlpool will emerge a market leader in the one home appliance, stoves, where it has never had a big role.
Whirlpool settled on Tulsa after rejecting a low-wage site in Mexico, where General Electric has a modern stove factory. While Mexico's labor costs were lower, Tulsa's were low enough for skilled workers -- under $10 an hour -- and transportation costs were less.
Then, too, voters of Tulsa County have agreed to pay 25 percent of the new plant's $104 million cost. They voted yes, in a referendum on Tuesday, to a temporary rise in the county sales tax to raise $26 million of the capital outlay. They decided, in effect, to buy some of their new jobs. A no vote probably would have meant no plant and no new jobs. "If the tax increase had not passed," Thomas L. Vining, a Whirlpool vice president, said, "we would have regrouped and thought about what to do next."

But more of that investment than ever before is being devoted to replacing older assets, while the share used to expand capicity has dwindled since the 1960's. HEADLINE: U.S. Imports of Oil Increase

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
United States dependence on imported oil continued to grow last month, with domestic production failing to keep pace with surging demand, an oil industry group said yesterday in its monthly report on petroleum supplies.
According to the American Petroleum Institute, domestic crude oil production in May was more than 3 percent below levels a year ago, at 6.3 million barrels a day. 
 The overall drop in output comes as demand for petroleum products, especially gasoline, is rising, bolstered by an expanding domestic economy. Domestic deliveries of petroleum products, a key measure of demand, Were 4 percent higher than a year ago, the institute said.
Faced with declining domestic production, the United States has turned increasingly to imports to fill the supply gap.

HEADLINE: Ciba Corp. Decides to Keep Its U.S. Headquarters in the County

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ELMSFORD, N.Y., June 15

 BODY:
One of Westchester County's largest employers, the Ciba Corporation, has decided to keep its American corporate headquarters in the county, rejecting financial incentives offered by Connecticut.
New York offered more than $13 million of its own to keep the pharmaceutical and chemical manufacturing company, formerly known as Ciba-Geigy, and its 1,000 jobs, in Westchester. Neither Connecticut officials nor Ciba executives would say how much Connecticut had offered to lure the company across the state line. 
 Ciba said it had signed a letter of intent to move its headquarters from Ardsley to the Tarrytown Corporate Center.
 
Seeing a Turnaround
 Company officials said they had considered several sites in Fairfield County during an 18-month search for new office space for its headquarters and additives divisions, which have been in Ardsley since the mid-1950's.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who attended the news conference here announcing Ciba's decision, said, "Ciba's plan to keep the majority of its Westchester operations here in Westchester is a tribute to this community's high-skilled work force."
While noting that the state has lost hundreds of thousands of jobs in the recession, Mr. Cuomo said he was starting to see a turnaround. But he said the state would have to compete internationally as well as with New Jersey and Connecticut to attract and retain businesses like Ciba.
The state's financial package for Ciba includes low-interest loans, skills-training grants, research and development credits and tax abatements.
Joseph Cohen, a spokesman for the Connecticut Economic Development Department, acknowledged that a financial offer was made to Ciba.
 
Acknowledging 'Slim Chance'
 "Connecticut recognized from the outset that there was only a slim chance that Ciba would uproot and relocate," he said, "but we sought to accommodate them and put together what we believed was a competitive proposal." He added that "New York put together a very competitive package to keep what is a very good company."
The letter of intent announced today is between Ciba and Halpern Enterprises, which will lease Ciba 425,000 square feet of space at the Tarrytown corporate center complex, including a new 150,000 square-foot laboratory.
Various state and local approvals are necessary before the relocation of Ciba to Tarrytown can take place, the Greenburgh Town Supervisor, Paul Feiner, said.
While Richard Barth, chairman, president and chief executive officer of Ciba, praised state and local officials for working hard to make the deal possible, a Ciba spokesman said yesterday that until all approvals are obtained, "it is not a done deal."

HEADLINE: Questions for the N.A.A.C.P.

 BODY:
Where is the N.A.A.C.P. headed under its president, the Rev. Benjamin Chavis? That is a pressing question, given the fruits of the so-called "National African-American Leadership Summit" staged by Mr. Chavis this week in Baltimore.
Black elected officials, including all but one member of the 39-seat Congressional Black Caucus, avoided the meeting in droves. Also absent were some prominent non-government civil rights figures, including Joseph Lowery of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference. 
 Many who stayed away did so for fear of being associated with the Nation of Islam leader, Louis Farrakhan, well known for his anti-Semitic railings and especially his description of Judaism as "a gutter religion." Also present was the anti-Semitic black supremacist Leonard Jeffries.
For all the noise and hurt feelings it caused, the meeting came forth with nothing. On education reform, economic development, crime control -- all matters of pressing importance to the African-American poor, trapped in the inner cities -- no new proposals were announced.
The N.A.A.C.P. has been central to the quest for racial equality. Its efforts in such landmark events as Brown v. Board of Education have contributed immeasurably to the common good. Why sully that history by seeming to legitimize prejudice? And why risk political capital for what turned out to be a photo opportunity?
The answers lie with Mr. Chavis himself. Speaking of Mr. Farrakhan's presence, he said, "Never again will we allow an external force to dictate who we can meet with." In other words, Mr. Chavis wanted to prove his independence and demonstrate to his critics that he will do what he wants, and let the rest of the world take a hike.
Rhetoric like that plays well with crowds. But it falls far short of a statement of mission or a program for "improving the quality of life for the African-American community," which Mr. Chavis says was the convention's aim. Economic development, to choose just one subject, cannot be addressed through shrill rhetoric. It requires sober thought and conversation with the minority community, Government officials, bankers and corporate leaders, among others.
Mr. Chavis wants to "broaden" the N.A.A.C.P.'s appeal to inner-city blacks. It would be a tragedy for the country, the N.A.A.C.P. and Mr. Chavis himself if "broadening" came to mean empty rhetoric and public acceptance of bigotry.

HEADLINE: Journal;
The Tony Scandals

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
On Monday Edward Albee, the author of "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?" became the first American playwright to be invited to a state dinner at the Clinton White House. But only the night before, Mr. Albee had been persona non grata at the theatrical gala of the year: the Tony Awards.
No wonder the Clintons invited Mr. Albee. His new hit play, "Three Tall Women," won the Pulitzer Prize this spring. But that's not enough to win Mr. Albee a place at the Tonys. Because "Three Tall Women" is not playing at a theater owned by the club that controls the awards, it is designated an Off Broadway show and is barred from the potentially lucrative Tony competition. Mr. Albee's name went unmentioned at Sunday's Tony broadcast on CBS. 
 A scandal? Only the first of several. Thanks to easily manipulated rules, even some acclaimed artists who did turn up on Broadway this season, from the choreographer Lar Lubovitch ("The Red Shoes") to the actor Richard Chamberlain ("My Fair Lady"), were ineligible for Tonys while shows no one remembers ("Cyrano") received multiple nominations. As Variety has reported, many Tony voters flagrantly violate the balloting regulations. Then there was the Tony broadcast itself -- a flop with critics and Nielsen households alike.
Why does it matter? The Tony show is the New York theater's last, not-to-be-squandered toehold in network television. As recently as 1980 the broadcast commanded almost a third of the Nielsen audience -- a rating that fell by more than 50 percent in a decade, even before last Sunday's disastrous competition from a Knicks finals game. A dishonest, unwatched and unwatchable Tony show not only diminishes the theater but its artists -- not to mention a city whose economy and culture demand a healthy Broadway.
Nathan Lane, the young comic star of "Laughter on the 23rd Floor," felt this year's Tony broadcast confirmed the public impression that "on the entertainment food chain, the theater is somewhere between clog dancing and accordion playing." Mr. Lane was struck by the B-list Hollywood presenters ("Melanie Griffith saw a play once, but she didn't stay for the whole thing") and the show's reliance on taped pieces instead of live performance. "I began expecting a high-school film on personal hygiene," he said, "and by the end I was hoping for one."
Others felt, as the past Tony winner Jackie Mason put it, that the broadcast was "coming at them from a museum." The show opened with a salute to revivals -- "plays from yesterday," as a lyric rubbed it in -- and a tribute to the fuzzily identified George Abbott, age 106.
Only next to Mr. Abbott could a show that included a dowager's cryptic flashback to the Stage Door Canteen look youthful. Though the broadcast's theme was "The Past, the Present and the Future," the present barely registered as disoriented hosts rushed through the awards. The future mainly consisted of a five-minute plug for a coming revival of the 1927 "Show Boat." This production represents the future in only one way: Most of its tickets will cost $75, with even rear balcony matinee seats going for $55.
The Tony show was so dreary that it even failed to reap the traditional large economic rewards for its winners. Only the most conspicuous loser, Disney's "Beauty and the Beast," sold a ton of tickets the next day, aided by a terrific commercial that captured more of the theater's joy than any of the Tony broadcast proper. Four other Tony nominees announced their closings the next morning, and few in the theater were willing to bet that either the Tony-winning best play ("Angels in America: Perestroika") or musical ("Passion") would run past Labor Day.
In July, the few remaining Broadway attractions may be upstaged by the hearings that Attorney General Oliver Koppell will soon announce, as he steps up his criminal investigation into the path of prime tickets from box-office computers to scalpers. Against this backdrop of rock-bottom p.r., isn't it time for Broadway's creative minds to liberate the Tonys from the elderly businessmen who monopolize them and their acquiescent patrons at the out-to-lunch CBS?
An awards show that embraced the entire theatrical community and was written and cast by a Wendy Wasserstein, Stephen Sondheim, Tony Kushner and George Wolfe might be so much fun that it could even find a place on the schedule at Fox.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Why Can't We Have a True Waterfront Park on the Hudson?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Down by the Riverside" (editorial, June 5) praises the new path along Manhattan's Hudson River waterfront. As you write: "who needs fancy when a great waterway is dancing practically at one's feet?" 
 The Urban Development Corporation, that's who. This state authority has been seeking control of the waterfront and has repackaged and renamed itself the Hudson River Park Conservancy. But development is still its middle name. It is promoting a grandiose and ill-conceived scheme for the Hudson River waterfront, which would let the river dance at the feet of shopping malls, high rises and commercial development while blocking the river for the rest of us.
Like you, I believe that "grand and glitzy" schemes, costing billions and taking more than 20 years, have no place on the Hudson River. I support a plan conceived by the Federation to Preserve The Greenwich Village Waterfront & Great Port, on whose executive committee I serve. This is a plan for a true waterfront park, green, glorious, open and simple, with no development attached, one that can be built in years, not decades, and one that we can afford right now.
The $1.4 million that built the waterfront path is a small portion of the Federal money available for a true waterfront park. The rebuilding of Route 9A along the river entitles the state to money from the Federal Highway Trust Fund for "scenic enhancement purposes." An all-green park fits that definition. A development park doesn't.
Indeed, part of that Federal money, $80 million originally earmarked for Westway, is in the state's treasury at this moment, waiting to be used. Yet the Hudson River Park Conservancy has been fighting to return this $80 million to the Federal Government. Why? Because accepting it would automatically preclude development along the waterfront. And development -- not parks or dancing waters or conserving anything except perhaps their jobs -- is what the Hudson River Park Conservancy is all about.
The Hudson River waterfront is our last open space. To use it for development, especially when the city has so many other areas available for and in need of development, is environmentally and economically absurd.
 
STUART WALDMAN
New York, June 6, 1994

HEADLINE: FUTURE MARKETS;
Oil Price Is Highest In a Year

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DALLAS, June 15

 BODY:
Oil prices bounded today to their highest levels in a year as OPEC oil ministers congratulated each other in Vienna and a report showed that supplies had fallen in the United States.
Crude oil for July delivery rose 91 cents, to $19.86 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange today, continuing an advance from the $14 range in March. 
 Analysts also pointed to fears of a North Korean confrontation with the West over nuclear weapons, and fresh signs that no oil would soon be flowing from Iraq.
 
Interest Rates Rise
 The surge in oil prices pushed the Commodity Research Bureau's index to its highest close in three and a half years, gaining 3.31 points, to 238.61. The sharp jump in commodity prices revived concerns about inflation, causing the bond market to sell off and interest rates to rise. [Page D8.]
Relatively low oil prices, brought about by steady and at times excessive production in the second half of last year, was a major reason why inflation in the United States remained in check.
By late in the day, all the provocations and fears seemed to feed each other. "A lot of times, the market interprets everything in a certain way," said John H. Lichtblau, chairman of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation.
Refined energy products also climbed today, although not as much as crude oil. Spot prices of gasoline rose 1.67 cents, to 52.15 cents a gallon; heating oil rose 2.65 cents, to 50.58 cents a gallon.
 
Gasoline Up at Pump
 At the pump, gasoline prices have also been rising steadily, although they tend to be less volatile than crude oil. Regular self-serve unleaded bottomed out at $1.02 in the March 11 Lundberg Survey, reaching $1.09 in the June 10 survey, the most recent.
Trilby Lundberg, whose North Hollywood, Calif., firm conducts these surveys, said that the reviving economy as well as higher crude oil prices were pushing up the cost of gasoline. "It's not just vacations," she added. "It's commerce, too."
Refineries are running at a high 92 percent of capacity, she said. But gasoline prices may still slip during the summer because producers have already stocked up on the grades necessary to meet pollution requirements.
OPEC leaders themselves wondered whether the advance in oil prices could be sustained. But over the longer run, some analysts said, stronger worldwide demand and increased discipline by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries should keep prices from slipping back to the levels of earlier this year.
OPEC members agreed today to maintain their production limit of 24.52 million barrels a day through the end of the year. While that action was expected, the oil ministers' decision to forgo a planned September meeting underscored the group's renewed discipline.
Abdullah bin Hamad al-Attiah, the energy minister of Qatar presiding over the OPEC conference, boasted in a speech that the organization's strength since its March meeting had surprised all who followed the industry. He said the group could agree on higher prices, but questioned whether demand would support them.
Mr. Lichtblau, in an interview from Vienna, said that the Iraqi oil minister had also stoked the market by denouncing United Nations resolutions concerning the region. Turkey and Iraq have discussed flushing 25 million or more barrels of oil through a pipeline that has been idle since the Persian Gulf war, but United Nations approval would be required.
On the supply side, the American Petroleum Institute reported that the nation's crude oil inventories fell 2.2 million barrels, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, last week.
Traders reported a shortage of West Texas intermediate oil supplies to satisfy futures contracts for July delivery that expire on Tuesday. Those who sold these contracts must either buy them back, at the current higher prices, or fulfill them by delivering oil. As a result of the supply squeeze in the United States, the West Texas intermediate price has run far ahead of North Sea Brent contracts for July delivery.
 
North Korean Issue Cited
 The confrontation over North Korea's nuclear program caused some traders to start calculating the odds of a battle there, which could disrupt some oil supplies or increase demand.
Speaking of the day's jitters, Kevin Lindemer sounded less like a petroleum markets specialist at Cambridge Energy Research Associates than a psychiatrist talking a patient through some reversals. "There's anxiety in the market," he said. "There are some psychological pressures there."
In the shorter term, he said he counted on buyers to regain their composure, making it unlikely that oil prices would stay this high in the near future. Oil prices last topped $20 a barrel on June 9, 1993.
But by the last quarter of the year, he said, diminished surpluses and reviving demand as the world's major economies recover could provide continuing support for oil prices. The International Energy Agency predicts that by the end of the year the world will demand a million more barrels of oil from OPEC each day than it plans on pumping.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Farm Prices Up Sharply
 By Bloomberg Business News
Soybean and corn prices soared yesterday, reacting to the National Weather Service's forecast of continued hot weather and less than normal rain in the Midwest.
Traders are concerned that dry weather will damage crops at a time when nationwide supplies are low in the aftermath of last summer's devastating flooding.
July soybeans settled 14.75 cents higher at $7.0525 a bushel at the Chicago Board of Trade. July corn gained 4.75 cents, to $2.80 a bushel.
After the extraordinary floods in the Mississippi and Missouri River basins and tributary areas in 1993, Midwest farmers now face the prospect of near-drought.
"There are places in the eastern Corn Belt -- parts of Indiana -- where the land is so dry it has cracks in it," said Dave Miller, a spokesman for the American Farm Bureau Federation in Park Ridge, Ill. "Basically, we need rain."
Elsewhere, gold and silver prices surged as rising oil and grain prices raised traders' concerns about possible inflation. August gold rose $2.60, to $389 an ounce, at the Commodity Exchange in New York, while July silver gained 13 cents, to $5.522 an ounce.
"This market was ready to go," said Daniel Weissman, head trader with MTB Bank in New York. "It just needed an excuse."
