HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Markets
 Oil prices surged to their highest levels in a year on signs of a new pricing discipline within OPEC as well as a decline in American stockpiles. Crude oil rose to $19.86 a barrel. [Page D1.]
Treasury prices retreated after rising slightly on reports that suggested a slowdown in the economy. [D8.] 
 Stocks slipped in restrained trading. Falling bond prices, a declining dollar and rising commodity prices all contributed to weakness in the market. The Dow fell 24.42 points. [D10.]
The dollar fell sharply against the mark. Investors believe that a growing recovery in Western and Central Europe will forestall any plans by European central banks to cut interest rates. [D17.]
 
Companies
Kmart will propose a spinoff of its specialty chains and offer the public 20 to 30 percent stakes in them. The plan is seen as an attempt to appease shareholders who two weeks ago rejected another proposal to sell shares in the units. [D1.]
General Electric injected $200 million into its Kidder, Peabody unit last month to offset capital losses caused by the discovery of fictitious trades at the firm. [D1.]
Viacom is seeking to assure agents and authors unnerved by the sudden dismissal of Simon & Schuster's longtime chief executive that it is business as usual at the publishing company. [D1.]
British Telecom received the Justice Department's approval to buy 20 percent of MCI Communications for $4.3 billion. [D5.]
Shares of Cott fell sharply in Canada and the United States. The Canadian bottler of private-label soft drinks has been dogged by questions about its accounting. [D5.]
Class A baseball has come to New Jersey, but the company that is building the team's stadium has filed for bankruptcy. [D5.]
New Valley accepted a $650 million offer from Forstmann Little for its Western Union Financial Services unit. [D5.]
LSI Logic was selected to supply a microprocessor for Sony's Playstation 32-bit video game. [D6.]
The former chairman of First Jersey Securities, Robert E. Brennan, is on trial, accused by the S.E.C. of helping to defraud investors of $27 million. [D6.]
American tobacco executives followed a two-track approach to the health dangers of cigarettes for more than 40 years. In public, they said there was no proven risk, while in private, according to one company's documents, they debated how to deal with the very risk they were denying. [A1.]
 
International
Russia lifted restrictions on some foreign banks, but excluded Chase Manhattan and Citibank. Although the country desperately needs foreign cash to rejuvenate its economy, Russian bankers fear that foreign institutions will grab the best customers. [D2.]

The Economy
Companies are becoming more efficient, but rarely has so much spending brought so few new jobs. [D1.]
The Securities and Exchange Commission was asked by a powerful lawmaker to study mutual funds' use of derivatives. [D8.]

Today's Columns
Proposals to put welfare recipients into jobs won't be cheap. A study shows modest extra investments in training and job brokering could dent the welfare rolls. But the study also implies most people on welfare would need costly, government-supported jobs to join the 9-to-5 culture. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
Higher interest rates were expected to hurt mortgage bankers, but analysts were still surprised by the steep selloff this week in Countrywide Credit Industries. Market Place. [D8. ]
Lintas New York lost its third top executive in eight months. The departures have come after the agency was rocked by the loss of three big accounts. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D21.]

SECTION: Section D; Page 17; Column 1; Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 563 words

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls Against Mark; Europe Rate Outlook Cited

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar tumbled against the German mark yesterday, ending the day at its lowest point since late October amid growing speculation that Europe's economic recovery will halt a recent decline in interest rates across the Continent.
Although the Bundesbank and other European central banks cut interest rates several times this year, most remain higher than comparable American rates, making dollar-denominated assets less attractive to international investors. 
 "The Deutsche mark is coming back into favor for economic reasons," said John McCarthy, foreign-exchange manager at ING Capital Markets. "People are less bearish about Germany."
 
Mark and Swiss Franc Gain
 In New York, the dollar ended at 1.6364 marks, down more than a pfennig from 1.6470 marks on Tuesday.
The dollar also fell to a 20-month low of 1.3705 Swiss francs from 1.3870 francs. The Swiss currency has surged on reports that the president of the Swiss central bank said Swiss rates could rise sooner than expected.
Still, the dollar showed little change against the Japanese yen, slipping to 102.75 yen from 102.78 yen.
Germany's economy grew five-tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter. With the economy reviving, the German central bank is under less pressure to lower interest rates to spur business activity.
The Bundesbank shaved its securities repurchase rate just 5 basis points yesterday, to 5.05 percent from 5.10 percent, indicating to many traders that the pace of German rate cuts was slowing. The repurchase rate is what German banks pay for most of the money they borrow from the Bundesbank.
 
Slower U.S. Growth
 At the same time, many currency traders are convinced that the American economy is not growing fast enough to prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates again soon. The Fed has raised short-term rates four times this year to control inflation.
The latest sign that growth is slowing came yesterday when the Fed reported that American factory capacity in use slipped to 83.5 percent in May from 83.6 percent in April, indicating that inflationary pressures were not building as rapidly as some expected.
"I don't see inflation getting away from us," a Fed governor, John P. LaWare, said yesterday. "The current numbers don't show it."
Many traders expect the dollar to continue its slide unless the Treasury begins another effort to rescue it. The Treasury called on the Fed and 18 other central banks to buy dollars on May 4.
"Dollar selling will continue until the Treasury does something to stop it," said David Gilmore, a partner at Foreign-Exchange Analytics, a market consulting firm. "The market is looking for the bottom in the dollar."
 
Canadian Dollar Tumbles
 Elsewhere, the Canadian dollar fell for the fourth straight day after big Canadian banks raised their prime lending rates by half a percentage point.
In New York, the Canadian dollar tumbled to 71.97 United States cents from 72.20 cents. The Canadian dollar has fallen more than 5.5 percent since late January.
"I don't think we've seen the end of the decline" in the Canadian dollar, said Peter Sacks, president of Toron Capital Markets.
Yesterday, the Royal Bank of Canada, the country's largest financial institution, increased its prime lending rate to 7.25 percent, from 6.75 percent. The increase was matched by the country's five other major banks.

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 5; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 170 words

HEADLINE: Diluted Medicine

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "The Nurse Paradigm," Anna Quindlen's June 1 column: 
 While the idea that nurses should examine patients, perform simple procedures and even prescribe medication is gaining momentum, it does not mean this trend will be advantageous for all patients or, for that matter, even for the future of medicine in the United States.
We are seeing a dilution in the quality of medicine practiced as standards are relaxed under the premise that basic medical care will become more widely available and affordable. The trend is to find ways to duplicate the functions of doctors without doctors. It would be more honest to admit that these changes are dictated by the economics of medicine. Insurance companies will take the opportunity to provide medical care at a lower cost to them, while insisting that quality remains the same, though physicians may not provide basic care. There is a hierarchy, and the physician is better trained.
 
ARTHUR MIDDLETON, M.D.
Hackensack, N.J., June 6, 1994

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 5; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 402 words

HEADLINE: Technology Exports Mean U.S. Growth

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It is not correct to state that the Senate bill on exports "authorizes the Secretary of Commerce, acting alone, to grant relief from export controls" ("Too Relaxed on High-Tech Exports," editorial, May 29). The Secretary of Commerce leads the interagency government process to determine if relief is warranted, but is not the only actor. The process ends with the President in the absence of agency consensus. 
 Nor is it correct to say the legislation requires "that the U.S. Government relax its own controls within 18 months if they are not adopted by other supplier states." Both the Sen-
ate and House bills explicitly state that the President may decline to provide any relief from export controls, even if foreign availability is clearly established.
In discussing the General Accounting Office report on export licensing of nuclear-related items, you fail to note that 86 percent of the licenses granted to "questionable" countries were for computers.
The nuclear suppliers group -- the multilateral regime that regulates this trade -- has concluded that computers are not critical to the development of nuclear weapons and does not maintain them on its list of controlled items.
Accordingly, the United States has removed controls on lower-level computers to most destinations (excluding such countries as Iran, Iraq, Libya and North Korea), but maintains stricter controls than our allies on higher level computers to countries of nuclear concern.
Finally, there is no dispute that United States exports mean significant numbers of jobs, and the $18 billion of exports subject to licensing could account for hundreds of thousands of such jobs.
The real question is where does growth lie. In our economy it lies without question in exports generally and high-technology exports in particular. It is misleading to suggest that high-tech exports don't matter in economic terms because they are a small part of the total. They are the foundation of our ability to compete in the global marketplace.
When they contribute to developing weapons of mass destruction, we must control them, and the pending bills would let us do so better. When they do not, we should let United States exporters seek a fair market share, not limit them in creating sales and jobs.
 
WILLIAM A. REINSCH
Under Secy., Export Administration
Department of Commerce
Washington, June 8, 1994
